description: The Microsoft PowerShell is a secondary command line interface found in most Microsoft operating systems. The purpose of the PowerShell is to provide a much more feature rich scripting and automation environment than was previously possible in the base command shell. This series introduces the viewer to the PowerShell and its basic functions. It then moves in to specific areas like managing DNS, DHCP and Active Directory along with their typical commands.
name: PowerShell
subtitle: for Administrators

The purpose of the PowerShell is to provide a much more feature rich scripting and automation environment than was previously possible in the base command shell. This series introduces the viewer to the PowerShell and its basic functions. It then moves in to specific areas like managing DNS, DHCP and Active Directory along with their typical commands.
episodes.title: Windows PowerShell Overview
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,376
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,376 --> 00:00:12,270
Welcome to ITProTV's PowerShell for
Sys Admins program.

3
00:00:12,270 --> 00:00:16,130
What we're doing is we're recording
a series of videos that are covering

4
00:00:16,130 --> 00:00:17,990
how to use the Windows PowerShell.

5
00:00:17,990 --> 00:00:21,400
We're seeing a bigger and bigger push
from Microsoft use PowerShell for

6
00:00:21,400 --> 00:00:25,150
all sorts of things, and the product's
really advanced over the years.

7
00:00:25,150 --> 00:00:27,890
It's wonderful for
doing things like automation and

8
00:00:27,890 --> 00:00:30,980
scripting activities to occur in sequence
that you don't have to go through and

9
00:00:30,980 --> 00:00:33,130
do them over and over again yourself.

10
00:00:33,130 --> 00:00:35,440
Sometimes you have multiple servers
that you want to configure and

11
00:00:35,440 --> 00:00:38,010
you don't want to go and
do each one individually.

12
00:00:38,010 --> 00:00:41,770
We can write a PowerShell Script and
it'll knock them all out for us in one go.

13
00:00:41,770 --> 00:00:43,340
It's really pretty cool.

14
00:00:43,340 --> 00:00:47,200
But it is a lot different than
the command prompt that we're used to.

15
00:00:47,200 --> 00:00:48,870
Or maybe you're not used to
the command prompt at all.

16
00:00:48,870 --> 00:00:52,120
Maybe you're an all GUI person,
plenty of people are these days.

17
00:00:52,120 --> 00:00:53,700
So the Powershell can
be a little daunting,

18
00:00:53,700 --> 00:00:56,530
and that's what this program aims to fix.

19
00:00:56,530 --> 00:00:59,510
We're gonna take a look at,
well, some of the basics first.

20
00:00:59,510 --> 00:01:03,300
We'll start out with just what the
PowerShell is and how the interface works.

21
00:01:03,300 --> 00:01:07,300
The interface is pretty neat, and there's
some really cool tools and shortcuts that

22
00:01:07,300 --> 00:01:11,260
we can use just right in the basic
interface that can help us out a lot.

23
00:01:11,260 --> 00:01:13,580
From there, we're going to start
advancing into other topics.

24
00:01:13,580 --> 00:01:16,530
Let me show you the outline that
we've kind of worked up for this.

25
00:01:16,530 --> 00:01:20,000
Unlike a lot of shows on ITProTV,
this show is not built around a particular

26
00:01:20,000 --> 00:01:22,620
certification, so
we're going freestyle here.

27
00:01:22,620 --> 00:01:25,340
We're basically adding whatever
we feel is appropriate, and

28
00:01:25,340 --> 00:01:30,440
by we, I mean most of this is myself and
our other host Mike Roderick.

29
00:01:30,440 --> 00:01:34,190
We've taken a look at the various
PowerShell commands that we think most

30
00:01:34,190 --> 00:01:37,980
people need to know it to be prepared for
the exams and prepared for the real world.

31
00:01:37,980 --> 00:01:38,790
So, like I said,

32
00:01:38,790 --> 00:01:41,950
we're gonna start out right here with
the introduction to the PowerShell.

33
00:01:41,950 --> 00:01:45,480
We'll just go over some of those
basic commands, general syntax,

34
00:01:45,480 --> 00:01:47,770
how we can use the interface.

35
00:01:47,770 --> 00:01:50,900
From there, we'll start to focus
on the more practical skills.

36
00:01:50,900 --> 00:01:53,720
We'll have a series of videos that
are focusing on server management.

37
00:01:53,720 --> 00:01:56,833
These are generic tasks that
are performed on every Windows server.

38
00:01:56,833 --> 00:02:00,457
I might be adding roles,
removing features, managing services,

39
00:02:00,457 --> 00:02:04,660
whatever it is that we need to do as part
of the day to day operations of a server.

40
00:02:04,660 --> 00:02:09,034
Then we're gonna focus in on DNS, how to
get DNS, domain naming system, configured

41
00:02:09,034 --> 00:02:14,020
on a server, and how to work with zones
and other records all from the PowerShell.

42
00:02:14,020 --> 00:02:17,610
We'll proceed to DHCP,
dynamic host configuration protocol, and

43
00:02:17,610 --> 00:02:19,080
how to manage it.

44
00:02:19,080 --> 00:02:21,150
And then the big one, active directory.

45
00:02:21,150 --> 00:02:22,890
I know it doesn't look that
big here in the outline, but

46
00:02:22,890 --> 00:02:24,620
there's actually quite a bit to it.

47
00:02:24,620 --> 00:02:27,520
Creating the active directory,
working with user accounts,

48
00:02:27,520 --> 00:02:30,000
groups, organizational units,
group policy objects,

49
00:02:30,000 --> 00:02:33,805
all of that stuff that's buried inside
the active directory, you can completely

50
00:02:33,805 --> 00:02:37,785
interface with it via the PowerShell,
and then we're going to tackle Hyper-V.

51
00:02:37,785 --> 00:02:40,265
How do you get Hyper-V installed?

52
00:02:40,265 --> 00:02:43,595
How to manage virtual machines,
creating them, starting, stopping, taking

53
00:02:43,595 --> 00:02:48,635
snapshots, all those other things that are
part of the routine operation of Hyper-V.

54
00:02:48,635 --> 00:02:51,745
Now, depending on when
you watch this show,

55
00:02:51,745 --> 00:02:54,740
there may just be these videos available.

56
00:02:54,740 --> 00:02:57,340
But if it's been a year or

57
00:02:57,340 --> 00:03:00,110
however long, you may see that we have
quite a bit more content than that.

58
00:03:00,110 --> 00:03:03,070
And that's because this isn't based
around an exam set of objectives.

59
00:03:03,070 --> 00:03:05,660
We're not waiting on Microsoft
to tell us what to cover.

60
00:03:05,660 --> 00:03:08,090
Instead, we're just figuring it out.

61
00:03:08,090 --> 00:03:10,460
Whatever we feel like needs to be in
there we're throwing it in there.

62
00:03:10,460 --> 00:03:13,590
And that means that if you have any ideas,
if there was something you

63
00:03:13,590 --> 00:03:16,980
didn't see on that outline that
you want covered, let us know.

64
00:03:16,980 --> 00:03:18,370
Post in the Q & A forums,

65
00:03:18,370 --> 00:03:21,510
you can just go right in there into the
Microsoft forum and post and say hey, Don,

66
00:03:21,510 --> 00:03:25,770
I'd really like it if you did a section
on Microsoft SQL or Microsoft Exchange,

67
00:03:25,770 --> 00:03:28,500
you covered some of the PowerShell
stuff that's available from those.

68
00:03:28,500 --> 00:03:31,230
If that's something that interests you,
great, throw it on there.

69
00:03:31,230 --> 00:03:33,870
It's not on any of the exams
that our site prepares you for,

70
00:03:33,870 --> 00:03:37,610
at least not yet, but it's something
that's useful to know and we'll do it,

71
00:03:37,610 --> 00:03:39,050
we'll film it and get thrown on there.

72
00:03:39,050 --> 00:03:43,140
So if it's not on the outline, just let
us know, we'll work to get it added.

73
00:03:43,140 --> 00:03:44,333
But these are kind of the major ones.

74
00:03:44,333 --> 00:03:48,519
These are definitely ones that you need
to know if you're getting ready for

75
00:03:48,519 --> 00:03:51,917
the 70-410, 70-411 and 70-412 exams.

76
00:03:51,917 --> 00:03:55,029
And so we try to basically
wrap all those together, but

77
00:03:55,029 --> 00:03:58,083
we're definitely willing
to extend that as needed.

78
00:03:58,083 --> 00:04:02,034
All right, so that's what we're about to
jump into, and without further delay,

79
00:04:02,034 --> 00:04:03,625
we'll go ahead and get started.

80
00:04:03,625 --> 00:04:09,724
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Introduction To Powershell
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,998
[SOUND]
In this segment,

2
00:00:08,998 --> 00:00:12,667
we're just gonna take a quick moment
to do an Introduction to PowerShell.

3
00:00:12,667 --> 00:00:15,289
The odds are,
if you've come here to watch these videos,

4
00:00:15,289 --> 00:00:18,231
you already know what the PowerShell is,
but I find it's a good,

5
00:00:18,231 --> 00:00:21,734
healthy idea [LAUGH] to make sure we have
a basic understanding of the concept.

6
00:00:21,734 --> 00:00:24,150
And so,
that's just what we'll tackle right here.

7
00:00:24,150 --> 00:00:27,060
The Windows Powershell is a new

8
00:00:27,060 --> 00:00:29,440
command line interface that's
available for Windows.

9
00:00:29,440 --> 00:00:32,090
Now, I say new, but
it actually came out in 2006, and

10
00:00:32,090 --> 00:00:34,530
so it's about eight years old now.

11
00:00:34,530 --> 00:00:38,350
It's pretty mature,
it's in use by a lot of organizations.

12
00:00:38,350 --> 00:00:41,690
But it's new compared to
our old command line.

13
00:00:41,690 --> 00:00:46,040
In Windows NT, we had just the CMD,
the command interpreter.

14
00:00:46,040 --> 00:00:49,000
And prior to that,
we had the DOS command interpreter.

15
00:00:49,000 --> 00:00:53,130
So, it was a different environment back
then, a different set of commands.

16
00:00:53,130 --> 00:00:57,630
PowerShell looks to replace those
old command line interfaces.

17
00:00:57,630 --> 00:01:01,790
And basically, upgrade them into a new
world where we have a lot more power, and

18
00:01:01,790 --> 00:01:02,950
flexibility.

19
00:01:02,950 --> 00:01:06,990
Over the years, Microsoft has seen
the Linux environment grow, and

20
00:01:06,990 --> 00:01:08,050
grow, and grow.

21
00:01:08,050 --> 00:01:10,830
And one of the powerful features
in the Linux environment,

22
00:01:10,830 --> 00:01:13,630
is that the command line that you choose,
the Shell.

23
00:01:13,630 --> 00:01:17,480
If you choose the BASH Shell,
or TCSH, or one of those guys,

24
00:01:17,480 --> 00:01:21,810
you can do darn near programming language
right from the command prompt, and

25
00:01:21,810 --> 00:01:25,200
that makes it very powerful for
scripting, and automation.

26
00:01:25,200 --> 00:01:29,030
And so, Microsoft sought to
bring feature parity there.

27
00:01:29,030 --> 00:01:31,695
To be able to bring that functionality
into the Windows environment, so

28
00:01:31,695 --> 00:01:33,057
we weren't relying on Linux tools.

29
00:01:33,057 --> 00:01:34,903
And the PowerShell is what came of that.

30
00:01:34,903 --> 00:01:41,114
Now, the PowerShell was released in 2006
for Windows XP, and Windows Server 2003.

31
00:01:41,114 --> 00:01:44,857
And at the time, it was just called
PowerShell version 1.0, and you could go,

32
00:01:44,857 --> 00:01:47,320
and download it from Microsoft's website.

33
00:01:47,320 --> 00:01:50,020
So if you were running Windows XP,
or Windows Server 2003,

34
00:01:50,020 --> 00:01:52,600
you didn't have the PowerShell by default.

35
00:01:52,600 --> 00:01:53,960
You had to go, and download it.

36
00:01:53,960 --> 00:01:57,320
So on those machines,
you still had the regular command prompt.

37
00:01:57,320 --> 00:02:01,290
And from there you'd go in, and execute
your regular command line utilities, and

38
00:02:01,290 --> 00:02:02,670
that's what you had.

39
00:02:02,670 --> 00:02:05,461
But if you went, and
downloaded the PowerShell,

40
00:02:05,461 --> 00:02:08,390
now the PowerShell with
a new command prompt.

41
00:02:08,390 --> 00:02:09,560
You still had all your old commands.

42
00:02:09,560 --> 00:02:11,520
All your old commands still worked.

43
00:02:11,520 --> 00:02:13,271
But now, you have a lot of new stuff.

44
00:02:13,271 --> 00:02:16,609
And because Microsoft created
this from the ground up,

45
00:02:16,609 --> 00:02:18,322
they were able to modify it.

46
00:02:18,322 --> 00:02:21,116
However, they needed to
an ideal environment, and

47
00:02:21,116 --> 00:02:24,130
the first thing they did
is they brought in logic.

48
00:02:24,130 --> 00:02:26,360
So, we can do darn near programming.

49
00:02:26,360 --> 00:02:29,270
You can do what's effectively
like Visual Basic script almost

50
00:02:29,270 --> 00:02:32,130
from the command prompt, and
it'll execute that on the fly.

51
00:02:32,130 --> 00:02:34,990
It does just in time compiling,
and it's really cool.

52
00:02:34,990 --> 00:02:39,940
But it also is packed-full of
just whole new sets of commands.

53
00:02:39,940 --> 00:02:41,700
They're called commandlets, and

54
00:02:41,700 --> 00:02:46,580
those commands can do all sorts of things
from creating users, to stopping services,

55
00:02:46,580 --> 00:02:49,650
to shutting down the computer,
querying values.

56
00:02:49,650 --> 00:02:52,110
You can do a ton of stuff.

57
00:02:52,110 --> 00:02:54,800
And even better, it's fully extendable.

58
00:02:54,800 --> 00:02:57,410
Other companies can write
their own commandlets.

59
00:02:57,410 --> 00:03:00,350
They can extend that functionality,
and then you can import those to make

60
00:03:00,350 --> 00:03:04,070
use of them yourself, and
Microsoft extends it also.

61
00:03:04,070 --> 00:03:08,040
In fact, PowerShell version
1.0 is what came out in 2006.

62
00:03:08,040 --> 00:03:11,810
We're now on PowerShell 4.0,
with 5.0 on the horizon.

63
00:03:11,810 --> 00:03:15,380
And with each one,
they're introducing new commandlets.

64
00:03:15,380 --> 00:03:19,720
New commands we can use to execute,
and perform all sorts of activities.

65
00:03:19,720 --> 00:03:22,210
So, let's just run down some of
the additions real quick, so

66
00:03:22,210 --> 00:03:24,665
we understand the differences
that are out there.

67
00:03:24,665 --> 00:03:28,125
The most common PowerShell that
you'll encounter out there,

68
00:03:28,125 --> 00:03:29,930
is PowerShell version 2.0.

69
00:03:29,930 --> 00:03:34,005
Version 1.0 was the first one, and
you had to go, and download it to have it.

70
00:03:34,005 --> 00:03:37,375
So not many people did,
unless you had a specific need for it.

71
00:03:37,375 --> 00:03:40,990
But PowerShell version 2.0 was
the first one to be included

72
00:03:40,990 --> 00:03:43,435
with a Microsoft operating system.

73
00:03:43,435 --> 00:03:47,123
PowerShell version 2.0 was included
by default in Windows 7, and

74
00:03:47,123 --> 00:03:48,990
Windows Server 2008.

75
00:03:48,990 --> 00:03:50,850
Which are the most common
Microsoft platforms.

76
00:03:50,850 --> 00:03:52,810
That's why PowerShell version 2.0 is so
common.

77
00:03:53,870 --> 00:03:58,270
So, if you're out and about, and
you sit down at a machine at work, and

78
00:03:58,270 --> 00:04:01,440
you fire up PowerShell,
the odds are you're firing up 2.0.

79
00:04:01,440 --> 00:04:05,721
Now, 2.0 is very similar to 1.0,
it just has some stability enhancements,

80
00:04:05,721 --> 00:04:07,627
a few new features people asked for.

81
00:04:07,627 --> 00:04:10,971
It's available for
download for Windows XP, for

82
00:04:10,971 --> 00:04:14,163
Windows Vista, for Windows Server 2003.

83
00:04:14,163 --> 00:04:17,470
So, if you have those older OSs you could
go, and download it, and have it, or

84
00:04:17,470 --> 00:04:20,890
you could stay on PowerShell
1.0 if you really wanted to.

85
00:04:20,890 --> 00:04:23,280
But the main things that were added, well,

86
00:04:23,280 --> 00:04:26,710
there's one feature that was added that
I use all the time, and that's remoting.

87
00:04:26,710 --> 00:04:29,670
The ability to execute PowerShell
commands not on the computer

88
00:04:29,670 --> 00:04:32,120
that you're sitting at,
but on a remote computer.

89
00:04:32,120 --> 00:04:34,760
And that's really cool because you
might be on your Windows 7 laptop,

90
00:04:34,760 --> 00:04:39,090
and you're trying to work with
a Windows Server 2012 machine.

91
00:04:39,090 --> 00:04:41,400
And you wanna execute a PowerShell
commands on that remote machine.

92
00:04:41,400 --> 00:04:44,250
And that remoting functionality
is what gives you that ability.

93
00:04:44,250 --> 00:04:48,690
We've also got the PowerShell ISE, which
is an integrated scripting environment.

94
00:04:48,690 --> 00:04:51,640
I almost wanna call it
a graphical user interface.

95
00:04:51,640 --> 00:04:52,208
It really isn't thought.

96
00:04:52,208 --> 00:04:53,101
It's a neat utility,

97
00:04:53,101 --> 00:04:55,876
we'll see it in an episode that we're
gonna film here in a little bit.

98
00:04:55,876 --> 00:05:00,746
But it's a intelligent graphical system
that you can use to type in all your

99
00:05:00,746 --> 00:05:05,153
commands, and it'll do syntax checking,
and colorization, and

100
00:05:05,153 --> 00:05:09,300
all that other stuff to help
you with writing good scripts.

101
00:05:09,300 --> 00:05:12,250
So, those were both added
in PowerShell version 2.0,

102
00:05:12,250 --> 00:05:15,070
and that's where it really
started to see general adoption.

103
00:05:15,070 --> 00:05:18,688
This is where we saw people
abandoning the old command prompt,

104
00:05:18,688 --> 00:05:23,613
abandoning their old batch files, and CMD
scripts, and moving over to PowerShell.

105
00:05:23,613 --> 00:05:28,025
Well, in 2012 PowerShell 3.0 came out.

106
00:05:28,025 --> 00:05:32,320
I don't know, if I mentioned a date
on 2.0, 2.0 that was in 2009.

107
00:05:32,320 --> 00:05:36,760
So three years later, in 2012 we
had PowerShell 3.0, it came out.

108
00:05:36,760 --> 00:05:39,820
It's pre-installed in Windows 8,
and Windows Server 2012.

109
00:05:39,820 --> 00:05:43,760
So you kind of see, whenever a new
version of Windows comes out typically,

110
00:05:43,760 --> 00:05:45,538
a new version of PowerShell comes out too.

111
00:05:45,538 --> 00:05:49,500
It was pre-installed on Windows 8, and
Server 2012, but it was available for

112
00:05:49,500 --> 00:05:50,670
download.

113
00:05:50,670 --> 00:05:54,094
But this was the first time that
Microsoft cut off some operating systems.

114
00:05:54,094 --> 00:05:58,296
It's available for download for
Windows 7, and Windows Server 2008.

115
00:05:58,296 --> 00:06:02,330
It's not available for
Windows XP, or Windows Vista.

116
00:06:02,330 --> 00:06:06,680
And so, on those systems, Powershell
2.0 is the highest that you can go.

117
00:06:06,680 --> 00:06:09,380
And again, that's why Powershell
2.0 is still the most common.

118
00:06:10,420 --> 00:06:13,680
But it added some good stuff, one of
my favorite features that it added was

119
00:06:13,680 --> 00:06:16,500
the ability to do updates for
the help files.

120
00:06:16,500 --> 00:06:19,700
Sometimes the help files that come
with it aren't very detailed, or

121
00:06:19,700 --> 00:06:22,000
they change over time due to hot fixes.

122
00:06:22,000 --> 00:06:24,000
Well, now, you can dynamically
update the help files, and

123
00:06:24,000 --> 00:06:27,000
you can stay up to date, and
get some really good help there.

124
00:06:27,000 --> 00:06:31,010
The other thing is it brought in
something called Intellisense to the ISE.

125
00:06:31,010 --> 00:06:34,790
In the ISE, if you start to type
a command, it'll show you suggestions for

126
00:06:34,790 --> 00:06:36,940
what the remainder of
that command could be.

127
00:06:36,940 --> 00:06:40,160
It's a feature that's been found
in Visual Studio for a long time.

128
00:06:40,160 --> 00:06:44,020
They just brought that over
into PowerShell in version 3.0.

129
00:06:44,020 --> 00:06:48,848
The current, stable version of PowerShell
though, is PowerShell 4.0, and

130
00:06:48,848 --> 00:06:50,630
it just came out in 2013.

131
00:06:50,630 --> 00:06:52,150
So, it's pretty new.

132
00:06:52,150 --> 00:06:56,340
It's pre-installed on Windows 8.1,
and Windows Server 2012 R2.

133
00:06:56,340 --> 00:07:00,915
It's available for download for
Windows 8, Windows Server 2008,

134
00:07:00,915 --> 00:07:03,654
Windows Server 2012, and Windows 7.

135
00:07:03,654 --> 00:07:05,493
So, you can download it for
those guys, but

136
00:07:05,493 --> 00:07:07,960
anybody prior to Windows 7 can't have it.

137
00:07:07,960 --> 00:07:11,360
So that is the latest, and greatest,
and that's what I'm gonna be using for

138
00:07:11,360 --> 00:07:12,720
all the shows that we go through.

139
00:07:12,720 --> 00:07:14,610
We'll be sticking with PowerShell 4.0.

140
00:07:14,610 --> 00:07:19,870
Now, it added a few things that are not
necessarily noticeable to a lot of people.

141
00:07:19,870 --> 00:07:23,680
There's enhanced script security,
Microsoft wanted to ensure that

142
00:07:23,680 --> 00:07:26,870
malicious scripts couldn't run on
your system using the PowerShell.

143
00:07:26,870 --> 00:07:30,200
So, we'll see some changes there,
and some enhanced debugging.

144
00:07:30,200 --> 00:07:33,381
When problems happen, Powershell 4.0
can give you more detailed logs,

145
00:07:33,381 --> 00:07:34,529
and information about it.

146
00:07:34,529 --> 00:07:40,016
Now, Powershell 5.0 is on the horizon,
Microsoft has announced Windows 10,

147
00:07:40,016 --> 00:07:43,433
and Windows 10 will come
with Powershell 5.0.

148
00:07:43,433 --> 00:07:47,850
There's no release date yet, although
they're saying it'll be in the first, or

149
00:07:47,850 --> 00:07:52,030
second quarter of 2015 is kind
of what they're looking at now.

150
00:07:52,030 --> 00:07:55,480
And when it comes out,
there'll be new features there too.

151
00:07:55,480 --> 00:07:59,240
The only one I'm really aware of so far,
is something called package control.

152
00:07:59,240 --> 00:08:02,386
Remember, I mentioned that
PowerShell is extendable,

153
00:08:02,386 --> 00:08:04,685
that we can add more functionality to it.

154
00:08:04,685 --> 00:08:08,121
Well, it gets a little challenging when
you've got add ons from five different

155
00:08:08,121 --> 00:08:10,803
vendors, and how do you know
if there's updates, and so on.

156
00:08:10,803 --> 00:08:14,901
Well, in Powershell 5.0,
you'll have what are called repositories.

157
00:08:14,901 --> 00:08:17,525
The PowerShell can reach out
to these repositories, and

158
00:08:17,525 --> 00:08:19,778
make sure it has the latest
addition of an add on.

159
00:08:19,778 --> 00:08:22,970
And then if an update comes out,
It can dynamically do the update.

160
00:08:22,970 --> 00:08:24,630
It's a really cool feature.

161
00:08:24,630 --> 00:08:26,660
It's another thing found in
Linux platforms pretty commonly.

162
00:08:26,660 --> 00:08:29,633
Microsoft is now integrating
that into their PowerShell too.

163
00:08:29,633 --> 00:08:32,370
So, PowerShell 5.0,
that's the one I'm excited about.

164
00:08:32,370 --> 00:08:34,320
I'm looking forward to getting into that.

165
00:08:34,320 --> 00:08:38,730
But for now,
PowerShell 4.0 is what's stable.

166
00:08:38,730 --> 00:08:41,480
That's a little bit of
history about the PowerShell.

167
00:08:41,480 --> 00:08:43,170
I talked a little bit about what it is,

168
00:08:43,170 --> 00:08:47,510
a command line interface where we can
do all sorts of really cool stuff.

169
00:08:47,510 --> 00:08:50,540
And that's what's gonna lead into all
the rest of the remaining segments of

170
00:08:50,540 --> 00:08:51,146
this series is.

171
00:08:52,680 --> 00:08:54,160
Don, what's the cool stuff?

172
00:08:54,160 --> 00:08:55,450
Well, we're gonna see that.

173
00:08:55,450 --> 00:08:57,850
We'll get a chance to take a look at
how that command line interface works,

174
00:08:57,850 --> 00:09:00,860
we'll get a chance to see it,
and continue to work with it.

175
00:09:00,860 --> 00:09:04,600
But for right now, I think that's a pretty
good Introduction to the PowerShell, and

176
00:09:04,600 --> 00:09:05,650
its history.

177
00:09:05,650 --> 00:09:07,692
And now, we're ready to get
started with the learning.

178
00:09:07,692 --> 00:09:15,056
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Basic Command Syntax
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,351 --> 00:00:08,220
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,220 --> 00:00:11,501
In this segment we're going to take a look
at the basic ways that we can input

3
00:00:11,501 --> 00:00:12,945
commands into the PowerShell.

4
00:00:12,945 --> 00:00:15,655
You might be thinking to yourself
come on Don it's a command.

5
00:00:15,655 --> 00:00:17,185
You just type it and press enter.

6
00:00:17,185 --> 00:00:18,255
What's more to it?

7
00:00:18,255 --> 00:00:22,035
Well there's actually probably a good
five or six different ways we can

8
00:00:22,035 --> 00:00:26,075
feed commands into the PowerShell and
it's pretty interesting how that works.

9
00:00:26,075 --> 00:00:27,935
So I want to show you each of those and

10
00:00:27,935 --> 00:00:30,645
get you kind of familiar
with the basic syntax.

11
00:00:30,645 --> 00:00:34,445
First off, the commands that we run,
they're not technically commands.

12
00:00:34,445 --> 00:00:36,810
Microsoft calls them commandlets.

13
00:00:36,810 --> 00:00:40,868
And commandlets, that's just their little
name that says that it's really a program,

14
00:00:40,868 --> 00:00:44,500
and that command might
do more than one thing.

15
00:00:44,500 --> 00:00:47,900
If you think about the old style command
line, commands, you'd type something

16
00:00:47,900 --> 00:00:50,930
like DIR and press enter,
well that was the directory command.

17
00:00:50,930 --> 00:00:53,620
It would pull up the directory and
what files were in the directory.

18
00:00:53,620 --> 00:00:55,160
Did one thing.

19
00:00:55,160 --> 00:00:56,850
That's how most commands work.

20
00:00:56,850 --> 00:01:00,860
But commandlets might actually
cause a chain of events to happen.

21
00:01:00,860 --> 00:01:04,190
So that's why Microsoft just uses
a slightly different term for it.

22
00:01:04,190 --> 00:01:07,260
Commandlets are really easy to spot
because their names are always made up of

23
00:01:07,260 --> 00:01:08,480
two pieces.

24
00:01:08,480 --> 00:01:12,420
There's a verb and
a hyphen, followed by noun.

25
00:01:12,420 --> 00:01:18,760
That verb is normally something like,
get, set, modify, remove, right?

26
00:01:18,760 --> 00:01:21,280
It's an action,
it's something that you're doing.

27
00:01:21,280 --> 00:01:22,920
And then there's a hyphen
followed by a noun and

28
00:01:22,920 --> 00:01:25,760
the noun is normally what
it is you're modifying.

29
00:01:25,760 --> 00:01:28,840
So, for example, let me show you what's
probably the most important command that

30
00:01:28,840 --> 00:01:30,840
we're going to learn
in this entire series,

31
00:01:30,840 --> 00:01:35,820
which is the Get-Help command, all right.

32
00:01:35,820 --> 00:01:36,630
Get, that's the verb.

33
00:01:36,630 --> 00:01:38,170
I'm telling it I want to get something.

34
00:01:38,170 --> 00:01:39,088
Get it and show it to me.

35
00:01:39,088 --> 00:01:45,020
And then -Help, I want to pull up
the help for PowerShell, all right?

36
00:01:45,020 --> 00:01:47,150
If you ever wanna learn
more about a command and

37
00:01:47,150 --> 00:01:50,130
find information out about it,
Get-Help is your go to guy.

38
00:01:50,130 --> 00:01:52,440
This is probably
the command I run the most.

39
00:01:52,440 --> 00:01:56,470
So, Get-Help, we just type it right
into the PowerShell and we press enter.

40
00:01:56,470 --> 00:02:01,160
Now, with a commandlet,
it's designed to run in the PowerShell.

41
00:02:01,160 --> 00:02:03,110
How do I know if I'm in the PowerShell?

42
00:02:03,110 --> 00:02:04,630
You might not be, right?

43
00:02:04,630 --> 00:02:07,560
Windows still has the original
shell present, right?

44
00:02:07,560 --> 00:02:09,400
So, it's not like it went away.

45
00:02:09,400 --> 00:02:11,590
I've got it right here and
I can pull it up.

46
00:02:11,590 --> 00:02:14,840
And we can make use of it or
whatever it is that we want to do.

47
00:02:14,840 --> 00:02:18,510
Let me just kind of change this font so
I can actually read what's on the screen.

48
00:02:18,510 --> 00:02:19,490
There we go.

49
00:02:19,490 --> 00:02:22,440
So here I am but
the difference is in this command prompt

50
00:02:22,440 --> 00:02:25,530
if I do DIR all the commands
we're used to, they work.

51
00:02:25,530 --> 00:02:29,890
But if I type Get-Help I get that
it's not a program that's recognized.

52
00:02:29,890 --> 00:02:30,970
It doesn't work, right?

53
00:02:30,970 --> 00:02:33,040
So it's not a command prompt command.

54
00:02:34,060 --> 00:02:37,930
But if I get back here to my PowerShell
and I type Get-help, there it is.

55
00:02:37,930 --> 00:02:39,810
It just did a bunch of stuff, right?

56
00:02:39,810 --> 00:02:41,060
It scrolled by really fast.

57
00:02:41,060 --> 00:02:43,630
But that's basically it running, right?

58
00:02:43,630 --> 00:02:46,250
The Windows PowerShell
has that functionality.

59
00:02:46,250 --> 00:02:48,980
Microsoft wants to remind you of
when you're in the PowerShell, and

60
00:02:48,980 --> 00:02:51,060
that's why it looks so different.

61
00:02:51,060 --> 00:02:54,730
You'll notice when I pulled up that
regular command prompt it was black

62
00:02:54,730 --> 00:02:59,300
with gray text, and the prompt was just,
C:\Users\Don Pazet, and

63
00:02:59,300 --> 00:03:04,830
that was it, but here in PowerShell
it's blue with a white text,

64
00:03:04,830 --> 00:03:07,040
and it's got PS written
at the very beginning.

65
00:03:07,040 --> 00:03:10,970
That's the reminder to me saying,
oh I'm in the PowerShell.

66
00:03:10,970 --> 00:03:14,940
Now I'm on a Windows Server 2012 machine,
and you'll see in Windows Server 2012,

67
00:03:14,940 --> 00:03:18,380
PowerShell is added to
your task bar by default.

68
00:03:18,380 --> 00:03:20,380
So it's right there and you can launch it.

69
00:03:20,380 --> 00:03:25,280
In Windows 7 and
8 it's installed by default, but

70
00:03:25,280 --> 00:03:27,210
it's not under your Start menu.

71
00:03:27,210 --> 00:03:29,010
I mean, under your task bar.

72
00:03:29,010 --> 00:03:30,672
In Windows 7 it is under your Start menu.

73
00:03:30,672 --> 00:03:33,040
If you pull up your Start menu and
go into All Programs,

74
00:03:33,040 --> 00:03:34,730
you'll find it sitting right in there.

75
00:03:34,730 --> 00:03:38,755
In In Windows 8 you can just use the
search functionality on your start screen.

76
00:03:38,755 --> 00:03:43,125
If you bring up your start screen you
can type powershell or just power and

77
00:03:43,125 --> 00:03:45,405
it'll be one of the first
things that comes up.

78
00:03:45,405 --> 00:03:47,692
So, quick and easy to get into it.

79
00:03:47,692 --> 00:03:50,982
And then you're in your PowerShell.

80
00:03:50,982 --> 00:03:54,052
And once you're there, you're able to
start using the PowerShell commands.

81
00:03:54,052 --> 00:03:57,532
You can type Get-Help and
it's going to return that information.

82
00:03:58,574 --> 00:04:02,482
Now, PowerShell is,
like the name implies, pretty powerful.

83
00:04:02,482 --> 00:04:06,172
So, there are a ton of commands
that are available in there.

84
00:04:06,172 --> 00:04:11,860
If you ever want to see the full list,
there's a command that is Get-Command.

85
00:04:11,860 --> 00:04:13,820
This is another great one that we can run.

86
00:04:13,820 --> 00:04:17,730
Get-Command will show us all
the commands that are available.

87
00:04:17,730 --> 00:04:21,510
So here it is, it's going through and
listing all the commandlets and

88
00:04:21,510 --> 00:04:22,670
functions that are available.

89
00:04:22,670 --> 00:04:24,910
And we'll get a chance to
see more of these later.

90
00:04:24,910 --> 00:04:28,310
There's a ton, I actually don't
know how many are on here.

91
00:04:28,310 --> 00:04:30,380
You can even extend it and add your own,

92
00:04:30,380 --> 00:04:32,780
so who knows how many
your system will have.

93
00:04:32,780 --> 00:04:35,410
But there are well over a thousand

94
00:04:35,410 --> 00:04:38,240
different command modes that
are available for you to be able to run.

95
00:04:38,240 --> 00:04:40,960
Each one performing some
different functionality.

96
00:04:40,960 --> 00:04:44,080
But they all follow that verb,
noun format, right.

97
00:04:44,080 --> 00:04:48,180
So, I've got unlock, unprotect,
update, wait, write,

98
00:04:48,180 --> 00:04:50,350
those are all verbs, followed by nouns.

99
00:04:50,350 --> 00:04:54,080
Process, job, event,
what is it that I'm working with?

100
00:04:54,080 --> 00:04:55,300
It's a simple syntax.

101
00:04:55,300 --> 00:04:58,180
It's designed to be fairly plain
english so that if you look at one and

102
00:04:58,180 --> 00:05:00,088
you see something like this, Wait-Event.

103
00:05:00,088 --> 00:05:02,410
You should be able to guess what that is.

104
00:05:02,410 --> 00:05:05,660
We're waiting for
some kind of event to happen, right?

105
00:05:05,660 --> 00:05:09,040
So I have a pretty good idea
of what that command does.

106
00:05:09,040 --> 00:05:14,365
But if I want to find out more,
I can use Get-Help to find out more.

107
00:05:14,365 --> 00:05:20,375
Get-Help followed by the command I want
to learn about and I'll type Wait-Event.

108
00:05:23,010 --> 00:05:25,440
And now it's going to tell
me about that command.

109
00:05:25,440 --> 00:05:28,650
So it's giving me a little bit information
here and telling me what it's doing,

110
00:05:28,650 --> 00:05:31,870
in my case it's telling me it cannot
find the help file for this commandlet.

111
00:05:31,870 --> 00:05:32,900
That's useful.

112
00:05:32,900 --> 00:05:35,670
It's just giving me really generic syntax.

113
00:05:35,670 --> 00:05:37,730
That's not great.

114
00:05:37,730 --> 00:05:40,440
I'll show you how to fix
that in another segment.

115
00:05:40,440 --> 00:05:43,730
What happens is when you install
the PowerShell it installs help files for

116
00:05:43,730 --> 00:05:46,020
some very common commands, and

117
00:05:46,020 --> 00:05:49,140
the less common commands it doesn't
install the help files for.

118
00:05:49,140 --> 00:05:51,900
And so we actually have to tell it to
go online and get those help files.

119
00:05:51,900 --> 00:05:58,329
Let me pick something that's a little
more commonly used, like Get-Childobject.

120
00:05:58,329 --> 00:06:04,390
Actually, well searching help for
it, and not finding it.

121
00:06:04,390 --> 00:06:09,190
How about Childitem,
if I can type here that'll help me out.

122
00:06:09,190 --> 00:06:11,220
There we go, so here's Get-Childitem, and

123
00:06:11,220 --> 00:06:13,420
actually that one's help
files not pulling up either.

124
00:06:13,420 --> 00:06:15,570
So yeah, we'll definitely have
to do an update on this one.

125
00:06:15,570 --> 00:06:18,710
But you can use that to pull extended
information about most commands and

126
00:06:18,710 --> 00:06:21,970
you see a description of what they are and
how they work.

127
00:06:21,970 --> 00:06:22,820
When you're running that.

128
00:06:22,820 --> 00:06:24,295
What you're actually running two things.

129
00:06:24,295 --> 00:06:28,710
Get-Help is the commandlet
followed by modifiers.

130
00:06:28,710 --> 00:06:31,490
And the modifiers can
specify all sorts of things.

131
00:06:31,490 --> 00:06:33,312
What action you want to perform.

132
00:06:33,312 --> 00:06:35,200
What it is that you're
trying to do on the system.

133
00:06:35,200 --> 00:06:38,400
So I might want to do a Stop-Service.

134
00:06:38,400 --> 00:06:42,600
So I'm going to stop a service
that is running on my system and

135
00:06:42,600 --> 00:06:46,520
then I would follow that up with a name.

136
00:06:46,520 --> 00:06:50,390
And I might say -Name dnsclient.

137
00:06:50,390 --> 00:06:50,900
Right?

138
00:06:50,900 --> 00:06:54,120
Apparently my name is wrong though,
it didn't seem to like that.

139
00:06:54,120 --> 00:06:56,170
And so I might have my syntax wrong.

140
00:06:56,170 --> 00:06:59,970
It might just be Stop-Service dnsclient
but it is not finding that one either so

141
00:06:59,970 --> 00:07:02,280
I might not have
the dnsclient enabled at all.

142
00:07:02,280 --> 00:07:06,940
So we run the command, and it goes and
gives us a nice little error here.

143
00:07:06,940 --> 00:07:11,050
The error is kind of nice because
it tells you where your problem is.

144
00:07:11,050 --> 00:07:12,190
So when I look at this here it's tell me,

145
00:07:12,190 --> 00:07:14,810
it cannot find any service
with the name dnsclient.

146
00:07:14,810 --> 00:07:17,490
So apparently I'm using the wrong name for
it,

147
00:07:17,490 --> 00:07:20,010
or it just has a different
name than what I'm used to.

148
00:07:20,010 --> 00:07:23,618
So we would need to go and update to
find out what that proper name was.

149
00:07:23,618 --> 00:07:28,100
And specify that,
I could do a Get-Service, and

150
00:07:28,100 --> 00:07:31,180
then that's going to run and
show me all the services.

151
00:07:31,180 --> 00:07:33,530
And I can go and
find the dnsclient in there and

152
00:07:33,530 --> 00:07:37,460
see what it's actually called
since apparently I don't know.

153
00:07:37,460 --> 00:07:40,730
And the dnsclient is
actually called Dnscache.

154
00:07:41,840 --> 00:07:44,430
So if I use the right name this
will work a little better for me.

155
00:07:44,430 --> 00:07:48,140
So I wanna do Stop-Service dnscache.

156
00:07:50,640 --> 00:07:55,152
Now, notice up here,
when I've found it in my list, Dnscache.

157
00:07:55,152 --> 00:07:59,134
You see how the D is capitalized right
there and the rest of it is lowercase?

158
00:07:59,134 --> 00:08:00,719
I can write it that way.

159
00:08:00,719 --> 00:08:03,420
So if we go back here and
I'll just come in and

160
00:08:03,420 --> 00:08:07,216
punch it in like that and
it's going to reach out and stop it and

161
00:08:07,216 --> 00:08:11,020
[LAUGH] now i've bumped into
another issue that I know of.

162
00:08:11,020 --> 00:08:15,160
In this case I didn't run the PowerShell
as an administrator and so

163
00:08:15,160 --> 00:08:17,450
I'm not allowed to stop the service.

164
00:08:17,450 --> 00:08:21,680
So here it's just saying it cannot
open the Dnscache in this system and

165
00:08:21,680 --> 00:08:23,920
it's because I didn't run
it as an administrator.

166
00:08:23,920 --> 00:08:28,330
When you just click the PowerShell icon,
you're running it as a regular user.

167
00:08:28,330 --> 00:08:29,930
You have user account control or

168
00:08:29,930 --> 00:08:33,420
UAC that's in there that's preventing
you from doing certain things.

169
00:08:33,420 --> 00:08:36,780
But if you right click on that button,
you'll see run as administrator.

170
00:08:36,780 --> 00:08:38,920
And there we can fire
the command prompt up.

171
00:08:38,920 --> 00:08:42,380
As an administrator, and
now we'll be able to do more.

172
00:08:42,380 --> 00:08:45,600
We'll be able to say Stop-Service,
oops, if we can spell it.

173
00:08:47,240 --> 00:08:48,230
There we go.

174
00:08:48,230 --> 00:08:49,790
And then we can specify Dnscache.

175
00:08:49,790 --> 00:08:53,090
And it's gonna jump in there and stop it.

176
00:08:53,090 --> 00:08:53,640
Okay.

177
00:08:53,640 --> 00:08:56,130
And if I do Get-Service, and I go in, and

178
00:08:56,130 --> 00:09:00,930
I find my Dnscache again,
I'll just go find it here.

179
00:09:00,930 --> 00:09:03,810
I can see that it is now stopped, right?

180
00:09:03,810 --> 00:09:05,900
So, then we can start it back up again.

181
00:09:05,900 --> 00:09:07,750
If Stop-Service stopped it,

182
00:09:07,750 --> 00:09:11,410
it's pretty good guess that
Start-Service is gonna start it again.

183
00:09:11,410 --> 00:09:14,300
Most of your commands are gonna be
like that, fairly intuitive, right?

184
00:09:14,300 --> 00:09:19,640
We can figure out what we need to do
Fabian just asked in the chatroom there.

185
00:09:19,640 --> 00:09:22,710
I was leading in to that point and
got sidetracked.

186
00:09:22,710 --> 00:09:25,000
I mentioned how there was capitalization.

187
00:09:25,000 --> 00:09:28,530
See how I've got that capital D there and
