these aren't case sensitive.

415
00:21:33,380 --> 00:21:38,040
If I change this, see how I get the same
result there even with lower case, so

416
00:21:38,040 --> 00:21:39,470
you don't have to be precise.

417
00:21:39,470 --> 00:21:41,000
I normally start out with
something general, like,

418
00:21:41,000 --> 00:21:42,830
hey I wanna work with user accounts.

419
00:21:42,830 --> 00:21:49,470
So I do get-command *user*, right, show me
everything that has the word user in it.

420
00:21:49,470 --> 00:21:50,470
All right.
So I get this list.

421
00:21:50,470 --> 00:21:54,040
And then I can start to narrow it down
a little bit based on what I wanted.

422
00:21:54,040 --> 00:21:57,100
Like here active directory user,
that's what I wanted.

423
00:21:57,100 --> 00:22:03,920
And so now I can say get-command *-ADUser,
and now I'm just seeing those.

424
00:22:03,920 --> 00:22:08,650
Get, remove, set and new, let's run
over those four verbs right there,

425
00:22:08,650 --> 00:22:10,520
because those are the four
most common verbs.

426
00:22:10,520 --> 00:22:13,120
Get, that just means retrieve information.

427
00:22:13,120 --> 00:22:17,320
You're not actually changing anything,
you're just getting some information.

428
00:22:17,320 --> 00:22:20,410
New, that means we're creating a new user.

429
00:22:20,410 --> 00:22:22,220
We're adding something new to the system,

430
00:22:22,220 --> 00:22:25,000
we are making a change by
introducing something new.

431
00:22:25,000 --> 00:22:27,450
Sometimes you'll see the word add instead.

432
00:22:27,450 --> 00:22:30,199
So you might see new or add,
but new is the most common.

433
00:22:31,490 --> 00:22:32,400
Remove.

434
00:22:32,400 --> 00:22:33,320
Like the name implies,

435
00:22:33,320 --> 00:22:36,760
that's gonna get rid of it,
delete something out of the system.

436
00:22:36,760 --> 00:22:38,490
And then set.

437
00:22:38,490 --> 00:22:41,040
That's the one that modifies a record.

438
00:22:41,040 --> 00:22:44,300
When you say set-aduser,
you're setting some property,

439
00:22:44,300 --> 00:22:48,450
you're changing some value for
that user, and modifying what they do.

440
00:22:48,450 --> 00:22:50,530
Those are the four most common verbs,

441
00:22:50,530 --> 00:22:53,850
right there, that you'll encounter
working with power shell.

442
00:22:53,850 --> 00:22:57,630
And so when we start to look at these
commands, you'll see tons of them.

443
00:22:58,740 --> 00:23:04,080
If I want to do like get-command and
we'll do new-*.

444
00:23:04,080 --> 00:23:07,080
I want to see all the stuff
that I can create new ones of.

445
00:23:07,080 --> 00:23:10,680
You'll see there's a lot, I can create
new services, new Windows events.

446
00:23:10,680 --> 00:23:14,930
I can create new objects, new PS drives,
now all sorts of stuff in here.

447
00:23:14,930 --> 00:23:18,080
AD user, these are all different
things that we can create.

448
00:23:18,080 --> 00:23:20,650
And there's even some special
functions that do things,

449
00:23:20,650 --> 00:23:23,070
like new volumes for creating disks.

450
00:23:23,070 --> 00:23:26,340
Really powerful stuff in here,
if you just know to find the command.

451
00:23:27,390 --> 00:23:30,360
Now Microsoft has great documentation
on the TechNet website.

452
00:23:30,360 --> 00:23:33,380
You can go there and find lists of all
the commands that are available there.

453
00:23:33,380 --> 00:23:35,860
Very searchable, very easy to work with.

454
00:23:35,860 --> 00:23:38,640
But if you're under the gun, you're on
a computer and you don't have internet

455
00:23:38,640 --> 00:23:41,580
access, it's nice to know that you
can at least search through and

456
00:23:41,580 --> 00:23:42,430
find your commands here.

457
00:23:43,890 --> 00:23:46,550
All right, well that's a pretty
good spot to wrap this segment up.

458
00:23:46,550 --> 00:23:47,930
Let's take a look at what we've covered,
right.

459
00:23:47,930 --> 00:23:49,685
So we started with basic commandlets.

460
00:23:49,685 --> 00:23:53,526
And how they function, we had a change to
see some aliases that are already built in

461
00:23:53,526 --> 00:23:55,365
place, alternate commands.

462
00:23:55,365 --> 00:23:57,290
We even got a chance to
look at expressions,

463
00:23:57,290 --> 00:24:00,210
mathematical operations we can
perform from the command prompt.

464
00:24:00,210 --> 00:24:04,270
And then we just wrapped up talking about
a few other things, like using get help

465
00:24:04,270 --> 00:24:07,846
and get command to be able to find
the commands that are available, and

466
00:24:07,846 --> 00:24:10,168
locate what it is we need
to use in the system.

467
00:24:10,168 --> 00:24:11,760
All right,
hopefully you guys enjoyed that segment.

468
00:24:11,760 --> 00:24:14,960
Stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up.

469
00:24:14,960 --> 00:24:21,370
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Command History
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,900 --> 00:00:07,889
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,889 --> 00:00:12,450
In this segment we're gonna take a look
at the command history in Powershell.

3
00:00:12,450 --> 00:00:17,225
One of the faster ways to enter commands
that we used previously is to, well,

4
00:00:17,225 --> 00:00:18,625
use our command history.

5
00:00:18,625 --> 00:00:21,960
Powershell is actually keeping track
of all of the commands that you've run

6
00:00:21,960 --> 00:00:24,710
since you logged in and
started running it.

7
00:00:24,710 --> 00:00:26,340
Actually, even prior to log in.

8
00:00:26,340 --> 00:00:28,610
It actually keeps them
session by session so

9
00:00:28,610 --> 00:00:31,490
it can go go back to previous times
that you've logged into your system.

10
00:00:31,490 --> 00:00:33,580
I guess I shouldn't say every command,

11
00:00:33,580 --> 00:00:35,490
it's really just keeping
track of the last 64.

12
00:00:35,490 --> 00:00:40,230
So the last 64 commands that you've typed
are being held in Powershell's cache.

13
00:00:40,230 --> 00:00:42,750
And that means you can recall
them whenever you want.

14
00:00:42,750 --> 00:00:44,540
It's kind of a neat feature to have.

15
00:00:44,540 --> 00:00:45,850
Let's take a look at that.

16
00:00:45,850 --> 00:00:49,600
I've got a Powershell fired up right here,
and I've cleared my screen, so

17
00:00:49,600 --> 00:00:51,480
there's not really anything on it.

18
00:00:51,480 --> 00:00:55,400
But, I've previously used this,
right, I used it another segment.

19
00:00:55,400 --> 00:00:59,880
So, if I want to view my command history,
there's a few ways we can do it.

20
00:00:59,880 --> 00:01:02,790
The easiest way to bring a command
up that you've run previously,

21
00:01:02,790 --> 00:01:06,370
if it was run recently, is to use your
up and down arrows on your keyboard.

22
00:01:06,370 --> 00:01:08,450
If I press the up arrow on my keyboard,
it goes up,

23
00:01:08,450 --> 00:01:10,320
and there you can see
where I cleared my screen.

24
00:01:11,352 --> 00:01:14,410
Or where I'd use the Linux or
Unix LS command.

25
00:01:14,410 --> 00:01:16,450
Here's the get dash command new.

26
00:01:16,450 --> 00:01:19,830
These are the commands I ran
in a previous segment, right?

27
00:01:19,830 --> 00:01:22,620
And I can press my up arrow
to go back in time and

28
00:01:22,620 --> 00:01:25,020
I can press my down arrow
to go forward in time.

29
00:01:25,020 --> 00:01:27,980
I can scroll through and
find the command that I want.

30
00:01:27,980 --> 00:01:30,050
And then I can go in and I can modify it.

31
00:01:30,050 --> 00:01:34,820
So instead of get-command*-aduser,

32
00:01:34,820 --> 00:01:39,650
maybe I want to pull up one
that is *-eventlog, right?

33
00:01:39,650 --> 00:01:42,290
So I can modify the command as
appropriate, and there we go.

34
00:01:42,290 --> 00:01:44,580
So pretty easy way to pull that back up.

35
00:01:44,580 --> 00:01:45,920
Now, if the command you're looking for

36
00:01:45,920 --> 00:01:49,620
was just in the last few commands,
that works really well.

37
00:01:49,620 --> 00:01:51,500
But if you ran it 20 or 30 commands ago,

38
00:01:51,500 --> 00:01:54,110
you don't want to have to
scroll all the way back.

39
00:01:54,110 --> 00:01:55,810
So there's a few other
ways that we can do that.

40
00:01:57,050 --> 00:01:59,770
One way, is that we can actually
view our whole history.

41
00:01:59,770 --> 00:02:03,220
We can type get-history.

42
00:02:03,220 --> 00:02:06,030
And that will pull up
the Powershell history.

43
00:02:06,030 --> 00:02:09,030
And here I can go back and
see the previous commands.

44
00:02:09,030 --> 00:02:13,550
And so, I can see it starts up here at
one with stop-service DNS Cache, that was

45
00:02:13,550 --> 00:02:19,423
something I ran back early on, and then
all the commands that I ran after that.

46
00:02:19,423 --> 00:02:22,705
Moving forward including changing
directories, running commands,

47
00:02:22,705 --> 00:02:24,075
there was a bad command there.

48
00:02:24,075 --> 00:02:26,525
It doesn't tell you if the command
was successful, or not right?

49
00:02:26,525 --> 00:02:28,475
This was actually a bad command here.

50
00:02:28,475 --> 00:02:33,985
But, it's got the commands, and you could
easy copy and paste these if you want.

51
00:02:33,985 --> 00:02:36,260
Right, you could just highlight
them with your mouse.

52
00:02:36,260 --> 00:02:38,400
And press enter and that copies it.

53
00:02:38,400 --> 00:02:40,770
And you can right click with the mouse and
that paste it again.

54
00:02:40,770 --> 00:02:43,035
So that's one way that we
can quickly do things there.

55
00:02:43,035 --> 00:02:47,278
Get-history is nice cause it just
keeps track of all this stuff.

56
00:02:47,278 --> 00:02:53,140
You get a chance to see everything you've
run and it's constantly being updated.

57
00:02:53,140 --> 00:02:55,380
So as I take a look at my history.

58
00:02:55,380 --> 00:02:58,370
I can see my history just grew from
the 33 it was a minute ago to 36 now.

59
00:02:58,370 --> 00:03:00,790
And there's those commands.

60
00:03:00,790 --> 00:03:02,522
That I just typed that made it grow.

61
00:03:02,522 --> 00:03:03,590
All right.

62
00:03:03,590 --> 00:03:05,690
So, that's one way to do it.

63
00:03:05,690 --> 00:03:09,590
One thing I guess I should mention
is I'm in Windows Server 2012 and

64
00:03:09,590 --> 00:03:12,770
the quick edit mode is enabled by default.

65
00:03:12,770 --> 00:03:15,280
So when I wanted to copy
something I just highlighted

66
00:03:15,280 --> 00:03:16,830
it by using the left mouse button.

67
00:03:16,830 --> 00:03:19,720
I just clicked and
highlighted and pressed enter.

68
00:03:19,720 --> 00:03:23,660
But if you're in Windows Server 2008 or
2003, in one

69
00:03:23,660 --> 00:03:26,550
of the earlier versions of Powershell,
that's not turned on by default.

70
00:03:26,550 --> 00:03:29,150
So, you might need to turn quick edit on.

71
00:03:29,150 --> 00:03:33,250
Or, if you don't want to turn quick edit
on, you can go up here to your menu, and

72
00:03:33,250 --> 00:03:36,040
you can choose edit and mark, and

73
00:03:36,040 --> 00:03:37,690
that's what will turn on
the ability to highlight.

74
00:03:37,690 --> 00:03:39,020
And then you can press enter.

75
00:03:39,020 --> 00:03:42,008
So that may be a difference that
you see on your own system.

76
00:03:42,008 --> 00:03:45,620
All right, [COUGH] so
here we can see the history.

77
00:03:45,620 --> 00:03:49,120
That's great, it's the same thing I see
with my up and down arrows as we go

78
00:03:49,120 --> 00:03:52,540
through and start to look at the commands
there, so not much difference.

79
00:03:52,540 --> 00:03:53,630
Just we get to see them all.

80
00:03:54,930 --> 00:03:55,570
All right.

81
00:03:55,570 --> 00:03:58,720
Another thing that we can do, is there's
a couple of neat little keyboard shortcuts

82
00:03:58,720 --> 00:04:00,660
that deal with your function keys.

83
00:04:00,660 --> 00:04:05,970
If you hit F7 on your keyboard, so
that's F as in Frank and seven, right?

84
00:04:05,970 --> 00:04:10,070
Your function key number seven, when
you hit that, you get a little pop up.

85
00:04:10,070 --> 00:04:12,300
Then the pop up will
show the commands too.

86
00:04:12,300 --> 00:04:14,093
All right.
And you'll see where I can go and

87
00:04:14,093 --> 00:04:17,420
scroll back and there's each of
the commands that are in my history.

88
00:04:17,420 --> 00:04:21,500
The nice thing here is I can go through
and find the command I wanna run, and

89
00:04:21,500 --> 00:04:23,140
I can press enter and it runs it.

90
00:04:23,140 --> 00:04:26,000
So you can just scroll through and
find the command you want.

91
00:04:26,000 --> 00:04:30,020
Another thing you'll notice is that
most of those commands had a number

92
00:04:30,020 --> 00:04:31,580
attached to them, right?

93
00:04:31,580 --> 00:04:35,120
So when I hit F7, see how there's
that number beside each one.

94
00:04:35,120 --> 00:04:39,630
Or if I do get-history, right.

95
00:04:39,630 --> 00:04:41,930
Here we can see that number beside them.

96
00:04:41,930 --> 00:04:44,910
If you know the number of
the command that you want to run,

97
00:04:44,910 --> 00:04:50,780
you can just hit F9 on the keyboard,
and you can pick the command.

98
00:04:50,780 --> 00:04:53,260
So if I want to run get history,
or let's do a different one.

99
00:04:53,260 --> 00:04:55,390
Let's do get command and
that log, that's command 33.

100
00:04:55,390 --> 00:04:59,890
I can just type in 33, and,
it picks the wrong one.

101
00:04:59,890 --> 00:05:04,010
So you know, my history has changed,
apparently, so let's try that again.

102
00:05:04,010 --> 00:05:06,030
We get history.

103
00:05:06,030 --> 00:05:12,480
And I want to run, wait,
I confused myself.

104
00:05:12,480 --> 00:05:14,770
So I'll do get child item, which is 36.

105
00:05:14,770 --> 00:05:22,030
So if I want to do 36, i just F9 and
type in 36, and, I typed the wrong one.

106
00:05:22,030 --> 00:05:23,650
That's pretty spectacular.

107
00:05:23,650 --> 00:05:28,230
So, the problem here is when I run get
history, that's a command that I ran.

108
00:05:28,230 --> 00:05:29,310
And so it's modifying the numbers.

109
00:05:29,310 --> 00:05:33,750
So I actually need to increase it by one
or actually, here was can change this up.

110
00:05:33,750 --> 00:05:36,670
I'll just use F7 so
I'm not actually changing mine.

111
00:05:36,670 --> 00:05:37,250
And I'll look here.

112
00:05:37,250 --> 00:05:39,360
So I haven't actually run a command yet.

113
00:05:39,360 --> 00:05:41,520
And now if I want to run
get child item is 38.

114
00:05:42,970 --> 00:05:46,383
So, but it's gonna make me, there we go.

115
00:05:46,383 --> 00:05:49,710
Sooner or later I will get this to run.

116
00:05:49,710 --> 00:05:50,307
There we go.

117
00:05:50,307 --> 00:05:51,800
Get child item and we can run it, right.

118
00:05:52,830 --> 00:05:55,770
The numbers are pretty challenging
because they are constantly changing, so

119
00:05:55,770 --> 00:05:59,590
that's kind of a rough one for
us but it's there.

120
00:05:59,590 --> 00:06:01,920
You're able to see that history,
and it's able to function.

121
00:06:01,920 --> 00:06:04,110
The default is 64 commands.

122
00:06:04,110 --> 00:06:07,690
If you want it to record more,
well that's something you need to modify.

123
00:06:07,690 --> 00:06:10,810
We'll do a segment on
customizing the Powershell, but

124
00:06:10,810 --> 00:06:12,410
I want to stick with the defaults for
right now.

125
00:06:12,410 --> 00:06:13,350
So the default is 64,

126
00:06:13,350 --> 00:06:18,450
when we get to the 65th one, it'll
overwrite the oldest one, the first one.

127
00:06:18,450 --> 00:06:21,170
That one will go away and get replaced,
and so that's why those numbers

128
00:06:21,170 --> 00:06:24,490
are constantly changing as it shifts
through adding these new commands.

129
00:06:25,910 --> 00:06:28,320
All right, so those are some of
the different shortcuts we've got.

130
00:06:28,320 --> 00:06:29,918
I feel like I'm missing one.

131
00:06:29,918 --> 00:06:32,377
Oh, searching.

132
00:06:32,377 --> 00:06:35,180
So you might know that you've
typed a command before.

133
00:06:35,180 --> 00:06:37,110
And you wanna pull it back up again, and

134
00:06:37,110 --> 00:06:39,690
you just don't wanna
type the whole thing in.

135
00:06:39,690 --> 00:06:43,040
Well, what you can do is you can type
the first few characters, right.

136
00:06:43,040 --> 00:06:48,450
So I can just come in here and
start to type whatever that command was.

137
00:06:48,450 --> 00:06:53,100
And then if you hit F8 on your keyboard,
if I hit the F8 key.

138
00:06:53,100 --> 00:06:57,220
It does a search through my history and
it looks for commands that had that.

139
00:06:57,220 --> 00:07:00,000
Now that is not too
terribly spectacular right?

140
00:07:00,000 --> 00:07:03,980
We have tab autocomplete that will run.

141
00:07:03,980 --> 00:07:08,190
By hitting the tab key, but it's actually
looking at the command that we ran.

142
00:07:08,190 --> 00:07:10,700
So if we look for a command that I ran.

143
00:07:10,700 --> 00:07:12,933
This may be longer,
like this guy right here, right.

144
00:07:12,933 --> 00:07:14,530
This is a really long one.

145
00:07:14,530 --> 00:07:20,300
That's where it really saves us time and
that one wasn't really, truly functional.

146
00:07:20,300 --> 00:07:22,020
If we take something
like stop service here.

147
00:07:22,020 --> 00:07:25,390
This one, where it's more
than just a command, right.

148
00:07:25,390 --> 00:07:28,070
So stop service, I typed stop.

149
00:07:28,070 --> 00:07:30,240
I could actually probably
just stop right there and

150
00:07:30,240 --> 00:07:34,000
hit F8 and
see how it does stop.service DNS cache.

151
00:07:34,000 --> 00:07:35,600
It's the command that I typed.

152
00:07:35,600 --> 00:07:39,620
So, F7 shows you your history.

153
00:07:39,620 --> 00:07:42,680
F8 lets you search your history and

154
00:07:42,680 --> 00:07:46,820
F9 lets you run a command from
your history based on it's number.

155
00:07:46,820 --> 00:07:48,683
So, F7, F8, and F9.

156
00:07:48,683 --> 00:07:50,817
Some neat little keyboard shortcuts
that are available there.

157
00:07:51,830 --> 00:07:54,125
The other thing we talked about just
back at the beginning of the segment was

158
00:07:54,125 --> 00:07:56,720
get-history, which I
used several times there.

159
00:07:56,720 --> 00:08:00,320
Between those commands,
that's pretty much the command history.

160
00:08:00,320 --> 00:08:02,750
You'll see there's a few programming
shortcuts that are available too.

161
00:08:02,750 --> 00:08:04,590
We might see those in some
of the other segments but

162
00:08:04,590 --> 00:08:06,370
they are not as commonly used.

163
00:08:06,370 --> 00:08:08,120
Things like dollar sign dollar sign and

164
00:08:08,120 --> 00:08:11,120
a few other little shortcuts there
that can reference previous commands.

165
00:08:11,120 --> 00:08:14,550
But as far as the history goes,
these are the primary commands right here.

166
00:08:14,550 --> 00:08:17,360
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed that segment.

167
00:08:17,360 --> 00:08:21,265
Stay tuned we've got more
Powershell coming up.

168
00:08:21,265 --> 00:08:27,149
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Aliases
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,226 --> 00:00:05,660
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,982 --> 00:00:11,360
In this segment, we're going to take
a look at aliases in PowerShell.

3
00:00:11,360 --> 00:00:14,575
Now, when Microsoft created
the PowerShell, it was a new command line

4
00:00:14,575 --> 00:00:17,908
interface and so there's a bit of
a learning curve to get used to using it.

5
00:00:17,908 --> 00:00:18,651
You guys know.

6
00:00:18,651 --> 00:00:20,817
You're watching this show for
that very reason.

7
00:00:20,817 --> 00:00:22,843
But they wanted to make
it as easy as possible.

8
00:00:22,843 --> 00:00:26,647
And so they took a lot of commands that
we were used to back in the regular

9
00:00:26,647 --> 00:00:29,356
command prompt, be it Windows or
even Linux, and

10
00:00:29,356 --> 00:00:32,550
they added them as aliases
inside of PowerShell.

11
00:00:32,550 --> 00:00:36,120
There are many aliases that
are already created for us and

12
00:00:36,120 --> 00:00:38,540
we probably used without even
thinking about it, right?

13
00:00:38,540 --> 00:00:39,960
Let's take a look at some of those and

14
00:00:39,960 --> 00:00:43,362
then we'll get a chance to see how to
create our own aliases after that.

15
00:00:43,362 --> 00:00:46,240
All right, so how do I know what
aliases are already in the system?

16
00:00:46,240 --> 00:00:48,321
Well you can run Get-Alias and

17
00:00:48,321 --> 00:00:52,330
that will give you a list of
the ones that have been created.

18
00:00:52,330 --> 00:00:55,420
Now there's default ones that
come with Windows PowerShell and

19
00:00:55,420 --> 00:00:59,377
if you've installed any add-ons they
might have brought their own aliases too.

20
00:00:59,377 --> 00:01:00,705
So you may see more than I do, or

21
00:01:00,705 --> 00:01:04,060
you may see less than I do based
on the add-ons that you've got.

22
00:01:04,060 --> 00:01:08,270
But you'll see a ton of commands in here,
many of which come from the Windows world,

23
00:01:08,270 --> 00:01:11,530
some of which come from the Linux world or
UNIX world.

24
00:01:11,530 --> 00:01:14,530
So there's some commands we run
on a regular basis like dir,

25
00:01:14,530 --> 00:01:16,150
the old directory command.

26
00:01:16,150 --> 00:01:17,940
That's from the DOS days.

27
00:01:17,940 --> 00:01:22,715
Well you can still run it, but
it just maps to Get-ChildItem, right?

28
00:01:22,715 --> 00:01:27,416
Or copy, the old copy command,
well, that goes to Copy-Item.

29
00:01:27,416 --> 00:01:32,406
It's pairing up a name with the verb
noun commandlet that we're used to in

30
00:01:32,406 --> 00:01:33,380
PowerShell.

31
00:01:33,380 --> 00:01:33,961
All right.

32
00:01:33,961 --> 00:01:35,883
So just to make life easy.

33
00:01:35,883 --> 00:01:38,785
The other reason they do it is for
backwards compatibility.

34
00:01:38,785 --> 00:01:42,910
You might have batch files that have
been written to run at a regular command

35
00:01:42,910 --> 00:01:43,441
prompt.

36
00:01:43,441 --> 00:01:46,575
And Microsoft wanted to make sure
that those batch files would run even

37
00:01:46,575 --> 00:01:47,487
under PowerShell.

38
00:01:47,487 --> 00:01:51,203
By putting these aliases in there,
that fixes it right?

39
00:01:51,203 --> 00:01:54,765
But you may encounter some aliases that
are missing that you would expect to have,

40
00:01:54,765 --> 00:01:57,878
and I know that there's one in particular
that I bump into all the time.

41
00:01:57,878 --> 00:01:59,411
I'll show you here in a moment.

42
00:01:59,411 --> 00:02:00,960
And it gets frustrating.

43
00:02:00,960 --> 00:02:05,180
So Microsoft makes it where you
can create your own aliases and

44
00:02:05,180 --> 00:02:07,220
that's really nice cuz you
can start to make up for

45
00:02:07,220 --> 00:02:09,480
some of these commands that
you don't have anymore.

46
00:02:09,480 --> 00:02:13,964
Or you can just make things easier on
yourself by having a proper alias in

47
00:02:13,964 --> 00:02:14,495
place.

48
00:02:14,495 --> 00:02:16,414
So we'll get a chance to
see that as we go through.

49
00:02:16,414 --> 00:02:19,220
But these are the default
ones that are in place.

50
00:02:19,220 --> 00:02:23,070
If you're using a command and you just
wanna know about the alias it's doing, so

51
00:02:23,070 --> 00:02:24,670
for example, copy.

52
00:02:24,670 --> 00:02:26,230
If I use the copy command and

53
00:02:26,230 --> 00:02:30,410
I know it's an alias,
what's the actual commandlet for it?

54
00:02:30,410 --> 00:02:34,610
You can always run Get-Alias
followed by the specific command, so

55
00:02:34,610 --> 00:02:36,750
I'll say like Get-Alias copy.

56
00:02:36,750 --> 00:02:39,360
And when I run that,
it'll just show me that one, so

57
00:02:39,360 --> 00:02:43,260
easy to kinda narrow it down and find
the alias that I wanna see, all right?

58
00:02:43,260 --> 00:02:46,925
And there are aliases for
a lot of other systems, like with Linux.

59
00:02:46,925 --> 00:02:51,439
I know Fabian in the chat room was
mentioning it, how we have ls and pwd and

60
00:02:51,439 --> 00:02:55,070
commands like that,
that we're used to from other OSes.

61
00:02:55,070 --> 00:02:58,593
And it's just designed to make it
a smaller learning curve when we move

62
00:02:58,593 --> 00:02:59,760
into the PowerShell.

63
00:02:59,760 --> 00:03:02,580
All right, now, the aliases that
are there, those are exciting.

64
00:03:02,580 --> 00:03:05,521
Not terribly exciting, but they're there.

65
00:03:05,521 --> 00:03:07,019
We might want to make our own.

66
00:03:07,019 --> 00:03:08,910
Now why would I want to make my own?

67
00:03:08,910 --> 00:03:11,870
Well, maybe there's some command
not listed here that I want.

68
00:03:11,870 --> 00:03:14,940
The one that I always do is edit, right?

69
00:03:14,940 --> 00:03:19,230
When I got started in computers,
I was using DOS 3.3 and the edit command,

70
00:03:19,230 --> 00:03:20,489
it was built right in.

71
00:03:20,489 --> 00:03:26,565
You had this text-based light ANSI
graphics text editor that I used for

72
00:03:26,565 --> 00:03:29,830
years and years and years.

73
00:03:29,830 --> 00:03:32,080
And then one day,
Microsoft said you know what?

74
00:03:32,080 --> 00:03:33,350
We're not gonna support that anymore.

75
00:03:33,350 --> 00:03:35,310
We're gonna get rid of edit and
so it's gone.

76
00:03:35,310 --> 00:03:38,122
Well, to this day,
when I go to edit a file,

77
00:03:38,122 --> 00:03:41,097
I will often type edit
followed by a file name.

78
00:03:41,097 --> 00:03:46,190
So if I go into a directory
like my user account and

79
00:03:46,190 --> 00:03:52,789
I want to edit a file here called
test.txt, I might type edit.

80
00:03:52,789 --> 00:03:53,930
It doesn't have that command.

81
00:03:53,930 --> 00:03:56,560
Even if I went to the command
prompt it's not there either.

82
00:03:56,560 --> 00:03:58,830
So I might want to create an alias for
that.

83
00:03:58,830 --> 00:04:00,825
And aliases are really easy to create.

84
00:04:00,825 --> 00:04:05,922
You basically just say Set-Alias, and then
the word you want to use is the alias.

85
00:04:05,922 --> 00:04:07,310
I'm gonna create one called edit.

86
00:04:08,770 --> 00:04:14,040
Now an alias is mapping
a name to a command.

87
00:04:14,040 --> 00:04:16,910
And what would normally
follow here is a commandlet.

88
00:04:18,110 --> 00:04:21,610
But there is no commandlet that
provides me an editor either.

89
00:04:21,610 --> 00:04:24,830
So the other we can do with
an alias is point it to a binary.

90
00:04:24,830 --> 00:04:25,740
And that's what I'm gonna do.

91
00:04:25,740 --> 00:04:30,149
I'm gonna create an alias that's
gonna tie this to Notepad.

92
00:04:30,149 --> 00:04:34,750
So I'm gonna go in here and
specify that my alias for

93
00:04:34,750 --> 00:04:40,321
edit points to
C:\Windows\System32\notepad.exe.

94
00:04:40,321 --> 00:04:43,651
Now when I type that old edit command
that I'm just used to typing,

95
00:04:43,651 --> 00:04:47,694
it'll launch Notepad, and fire that up so
that I can edit that file, all right,

96
00:04:47,694 --> 00:04:49,540
pretty simple there.

97
00:04:49,540 --> 00:04:55,420
The way the alias works is any time
I type the word edit, anything after

98
00:04:55,420 --> 00:05:01,568
the word edit will be passed as a
parameter to this command, to notepad.exe.

99
00:05:01,568 --> 00:05:02,440
All right.

100
00:05:02,440 --> 00:05:07,049
One limitation of an alias is
you can't do other parameters.

101
00:05:07,049 --> 00:05:11,240
I can't add parameters
here to the alias itself.

102
00:05:11,240 --> 00:05:15,130
So if I wanted to run notepad.exe/q or
something like that, you can't do it,

103
00:05:15,130 --> 00:05:17,030
all right?

104
00:05:17,030 --> 00:05:21,881
For that, we'll have to use functions and
we'll see that in the next segment, but

105
00:05:21,881 --> 00:05:25,276
as far as this is concerned,
this is gonna work perfect for

106
00:05:25,276 --> 00:05:27,937
me because now when I type edit, test.txt.

107
00:05:27,937 --> 00:05:33,256
It'll take that test.txt and
feed that as a parameter to notepad.exe,

108
00:05:33,256 --> 00:05:36,189
and so when I run it, there's Notepad.

109
00:05:36,189 --> 00:05:39,430
It's telling me text.txt doesn't exist,
do I want to create a new one?

110
00:05:39,430 --> 00:05:40,560
Sure.

111
00:05:40,560 --> 00:05:45,253
I'll say this is my file, and
I'll go ahead and save that.

112
00:05:45,253 --> 00:05:50,319
So now I've got that file, and the next
time I do edit test.txt, there it is.

113
00:05:50,319 --> 00:05:54,595
So now I've got that command available and
I'm able to use it.

114
00:05:54,595 --> 00:05:58,877
One little word of caution here,
the aliases are actually tied to your

115
00:05:58,877 --> 00:06:03,684
current session so when you close out and
go back in, your aliases may be gone.

116
00:06:03,684 --> 00:06:07,716
Jump ahead, we'll have a video on
modifying your profile in PowerShell and

117
00:06:07,716 --> 00:06:11,822
you can set these aliases to be recreated
every time you launch a PowerShell.

118
00:06:11,822 --> 00:06:13,680
That way they're always there for you.

119
00:06:13,680 --> 00:06:15,870
If it's a temporary thing,
then it's great.

120
00:06:15,870 --> 00:06:18,720
It's like this, you close out of
PowerShell and they'll go away.

121
00:06:18,720 --> 00:06:21,784
But if you want it to be around long term,
you'll wanna go ahead and

122
00:06:21,784 --> 00:06:23,000
add that to your profile.

123
00:06:23,000 --> 00:06:23,824
All right.

124
00:06:23,824 --> 00:06:26,196
If we wanna get rid of an alias,

125
00:06:26,196 --> 00:06:31,760
you can use the Remove-Alias command,
and I can remove edit.

126
00:06:31,760 --> 00:06:33,030
Oh shoot, sorry.

127
00:06:33,030 --> 00:06:35,180
This one's a little bit weird.

128
00:06:35,180 --> 00:06:37,397
We actually have to do Remove-Item.

129
00:06:37,397 --> 00:06:40,705
And then alias:edit.

130
00:06:40,705 --> 00:06:43,070
Remove-Item is like a generic
removal command and so

131
00:06:43,070 --> 00:06:46,060
they don't actually have a remove just for
aliases.

132
00:06:46,060 --> 00:06:48,150
Because they know if you close
PowerShell they go away.

133
00:06:48,150 --> 00:06:49,880
So why do you need a remove?

134
00:06:49,880 --> 00:06:51,846
So if we want to force it we
have to use Remove-Item but

135
00:06:51,846 --> 00:06:53,347
it doesn't know what kind of item it is.

136
00:06:53,347 --> 00:06:58,390
So we have to say alias: and the name
of the alias and that will remove it.

137
00:06:58,390 --> 00:07:02,100
Now depending on your system it
might not actually get removed.

138
00:07:02,100 --> 00:07:04,740
That does happen where it stays resident.

139
00:07:04,740 --> 00:07:07,210
And I'll bet mine has done
that because I'm on a server.

140
00:07:07,210 --> 00:07:09,030
And so if I run edit.

141
00:07:09,030 --> 00:07:10,620
It did actually remove it.

142
00:07:10,620 --> 00:07:15,280
I have seen sometimes where the alias will
stay even after you've done a Remove-Item

143
00:07:15,280 --> 00:07:17,650
and that's because of the way
the PowerShell does the caching.

144
00:07:17,650 --> 00:07:20,890
In that case you can just close
PowerShell and reopen it again and

145
00:07:20,890 --> 00:07:22,322
that will take care of it.

146
00:07:22,322 --> 00:07:24,590
But that's how we can
create that alias and

147
00:07:24,590 --> 00:07:26,260
remove it if we need it gone, right now.

148
00:07:27,810 --> 00:07:33,100
All right, now with our aliases they're
pretty easy, pretty simple to create.

149
00:07:33,100 --> 00:07:36,183
Remember we did Set-Dash alias,
followed by a name and

150
00:07:36,183 --> 00:07:39,835
then whatever command it was
that we wanted, all right.

151
00:07:39,835 --> 00:07:44,115
That command could be a commandlet or it
can be an actual binary, an executable, or

152
00:07:44,115 --> 00:07:45,245
even a script for that matter.

153
00:07:45,245 --> 00:07:46,745
You can do an alias for
all sorts of things.

154
00:07:48,145 --> 00:07:52,890
If we wanna remove it, we have to use
Remove-Item followed by the alias: and

155
00:07:52,890 --> 00:07:54,840
whatever the actual alias name is,

156
00:07:54,840 --> 00:07:57,360
so pretty straightforward
process right there.

157
00:07:57,360 --> 00:07:59,220
And when you create your own aliases,

158
00:07:59,220 --> 00:08:02,010
like if I go back here and
create that alias again.

159
00:08:02,010 --> 00:08:05,430
When you run Get-Alias, you'll see
it in there, it'll be in the list.

160
00:08:05,430 --> 00:08:09,130
You know, these are just alphabetized,
so I can just go in, find my alias and

161
00:08:09,130 --> 00:08:10,630
it will be listed right there.

162
00:08:11,780 --> 00:08:14,730
So that's a basic overview of aliases.

163
00:08:14,730 --> 00:08:17,580
For a more powerful option,
take a look at functions.

164
00:08:17,580 --> 00:08:20,293
And that's what we're going to be covering
in the next segment, so stay tuned.

165
00:08:20,293 --> 00:08:22,313
There is more PowerShell after this.

166
00:08:22,313 --> 00:08:27,653
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Function
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,208
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,208 --> 00:00:12,450
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at functions in Windows PowerShell.

3
00:00:12,450 --> 00:00:14,686
If you watched our segment on aliases,

4
00:00:14,686 --> 00:00:18,625
we covered how to create a name that
represented some other command.

5
00:00:18,625 --> 00:00:23,205
And I mentioned in there that one of
the limitations of an alias is that you

6
00:00:23,205 --> 00:00:27,875
can't preload as part of the alias
command line modifiers for a command.

7
00:00:27,875 --> 00:00:29,330
Let me show you what I mean.

8
00:00:29,330 --> 00:00:32,130
The alias that I created in
that shell was the edit alias.

9
00:00:32,130 --> 00:00:36,560
I tied the name edit to notepad.exe.

10
00:00:36,560 --> 00:00:42,030
Well, what if I wanted to have an alias
that automatically edited a specific

11
00:00:42,030 --> 00:00:43,280
file, all right?

12
00:00:43,280 --> 00:00:47,750
A great example, and this is one that I
use myself, is the hosts file in Windows.

13
00:00:47,750 --> 00:00:52,160
The host file is what overrides our DNS
lookups so you can map IPs to names, and

14
00:00:52,160 --> 00:00:54,500
I find I end up editing
that more than I should.

15
00:00:54,500 --> 00:00:57,890
But if I wanted to create a single command
that I could run that would allow me

16
00:00:57,890 --> 00:00:59,330
to edit the host file,

17
00:00:59,330 --> 00:01:04,440
well I would need to be passing
the file name along with notepad.exe.

18
00:01:04,440 --> 00:01:07,390
All right so
I'd need to change the way this works.

19
00:01:07,390 --> 00:01:11,494
When we did the alias
it was set-alias edit.

20
00:01:11,494 --> 00:01:15,270
And then I specified
the path to notepad right.

21
00:01:15,270 --> 00:01:21,090
So this is the command that I
ran there to create the alias.

22
00:01:21,090 --> 00:01:23,790
Just mapping the name to a command.

23
00:01:23,790 --> 00:01:29,260
And when I use that alias, you would type
edit, and then whatever you wanted, right.

24
00:01:29,260 --> 00:01:31,940
You might have modifiers.

25
00:01:31,940 --> 00:01:34,850
You might have a filename, whatever it is.

26
00:01:36,050 --> 00:01:37,880
You punch in that information.

27
00:01:37,880 --> 00:01:41,605
Anything you type after edit
will get passed to Notepad so

28
00:01:41,605 --> 00:01:46,690
this would actually run as Notepad
/q /a hosts.txt, all right.

29
00:01:46,690 --> 00:01:49,680
But what if I wanted to
automatically have this stuff in it?

30
00:01:50,720 --> 00:01:52,570
Well, it won't let you do that.

31
00:01:52,570 --> 00:01:57,280
So if I do, like,
set-alias edit-hosts, right.

32
00:01:57,280 --> 00:02:01,375
I wanna create an alias called edit-hosts,
that'll edit that host file, all right.

33
00:02:01,375 --> 00:02:06,042
And I try and map that to C:\windows.

34
00:02:06,042 --> 00:02:08,834
Whoops, if I type it
right it'll work better.

35
00:02:08,834 --> 00:02:10,792
[LAUGH] It is not my day for typing.

36
00:02:10,792 --> 00:02:15,232
System32\notepad.exe and

37
00:02:15,232 --> 00:02:20,167
then the file that I wanted to edit.

38
00:02:20,167 --> 00:02:25,166
Which this one is buried away in here so
it is right there.

39
00:02:25,166 --> 00:02:29,820
Okay, so
I'm mapping the name edit-hosts, and

40
00:02:29,820 --> 00:02:34,930
I'm trying to map it to this program,
with this command line modifier,

41
00:02:34,930 --> 00:02:38,440
after it telling it which file
I want to edit, all right.

42
00:02:38,440 --> 00:02:40,240
Well, aliases don't like that.

43
00:02:40,240 --> 00:02:43,490
When I run that it's gonna get upset,
okay.

44
00:02:43,490 --> 00:02:47,320
And it's not just the space that
causes the problem, if I go in and

45
00:02:47,320 --> 00:02:49,130
put quotes around it to
take care of the space,

46
00:02:49,130 --> 00:02:52,420
it's not gonna be too much
happier in that scenario either.

47
00:02:53,800 --> 00:02:57,780
It ran, and
if I do a get-alias and I go and

48
00:02:57,780 --> 00:03:03,320
find that edit-hosts,
look at what my alias is.

49
00:03:03,320 --> 00:03:04,740
It's nothing, all right.

50
00:03:04,740 --> 00:03:07,960
It didn't give me an error, but
it didn't work either, right.

51
00:03:07,960 --> 00:03:10,910
So that's not gonna help me very much.

52
00:03:10,910 --> 00:03:13,440
So, if I wanna do an advanced alias,

53
00:03:13,440 --> 00:03:17,380
something that does more than just
provides a command to map to.

54
00:03:17,380 --> 00:03:19,070
We need to use a function.

55
00:03:19,070 --> 00:03:23,570
Functions allow you to attach all
sorts of stuff to a name, and

56
00:03:23,570 --> 00:03:26,420
the function really becomes
its own unique command.

57
00:03:26,420 --> 00:03:27,930
It's very cool stuff.

58
00:03:27,930 --> 00:03:29,790
So that's what I'm gonna do.

59
00:03:29,790 --> 00:03:32,470
I just need to get rid of
that one that we just made.

60
00:03:32,470 --> 00:03:34,130
We'll remove that.

61
00:03:34,130 --> 00:03:37,050
In fact, there's already a lot
of functions that are present

62
00:03:37,050 --> 00:03:38,430
inside of the system.

63
00:03:38,430 --> 00:03:42,960
When you do get-command, and you pull
up that list of all the commands in

64
00:03:42,960 --> 00:03:48,440
Powershell, notice how I just had a bunch
of screens go by that were functions,

65
00:03:48,440 --> 00:03:49,700
and now I've got a bunch
that are commandlets.

66
00:03:49,700 --> 00:03:53,140
So here I'm looking at the commandlets and
if I scroll back up,

67
00:03:53,140 --> 00:03:57,800
there's a lot of commands up here that
aren't commandlets at all, here but

68
00:03:57,800 --> 00:03:59,010
they're functions, all right.

69
00:03:59,010 --> 00:04:00,930
So what is a function?

70
00:04:00,930 --> 00:04:03,980
Well it's something that
does more than one thing.

71
00:04:03,980 --> 00:04:06,230
And that's what I wanna do,
I wanna run Notepad.

72
00:04:06,230 --> 00:04:08,870
But I don't just wanna run it by itself,
I wanna pass some values to it,

73
00:04:08,870 --> 00:04:10,160
some other things.

74
00:04:10,160 --> 00:04:11,630
I might have conditions.

75
00:04:11,630 --> 00:04:15,920
When you run this command, check and
see if I have a network connection.

76
00:04:15,920 --> 00:04:16,910
And if I do, do this.

77
00:04:16,910 --> 00:04:20,400
If I don't have a network connection,
then do this other thing.

78
00:04:20,400 --> 00:04:21,940
You can't do that with an alias.

79
00:04:21,940 --> 00:04:23,260
But you can with a function.

80
00:04:23,260 --> 00:04:25,430
They're very, very powerful, all right.

81
00:04:25,430 --> 00:04:28,000
Let me show you the basic way for
creating a function.

82
00:04:29,090 --> 00:04:30,550
We start with just the function command.

83
00:04:30,550 --> 00:04:33,470
I know that's a little bit
weird because in PowerShell

84
00:04:33,470 --> 00:04:37,330
most things are the verb noun format,
but this one we just say function.

85
00:04:37,330 --> 00:04:40,140
That lets it know that we're
about to create a function.

86
00:04:40,140 --> 00:04:43,310
And then we can say the name
we want the function to have.

87
00:04:43,310 --> 00:04:47,300
And I'm gonna call mine edit-hosts,
all right.

88
00:04:47,300 --> 00:04:53,120
Then you do the curly bracket, and then
you can put whatever you want in there.

89
00:04:53,120 --> 00:04:57,720
You can put one command, a series of
commands, you can put all sorts of logic,

90
00:04:57,720 --> 00:05:00,600
you can do a ton of stuff
inside of a function.

91
00:05:00,600 --> 00:05:01,670
Well mine's fairly simple.

92
00:05:01,670 --> 00:05:03,090
I don't need a ton of logic.

93
00:05:03,090 --> 00:05:07,690
I just want it to run Notepad,
and edit my file.

94
00:05:07,690 --> 00:05:11,560
Now, I could type out the full command,
but I'm actually gonna recycle my alias.

95
00:05:11,560 --> 00:05:13,720
Remember that alias I made was edit.

96
00:05:13,720 --> 00:05:15,320
So I can actually reuse that.

97
00:05:15,320 --> 00:05:18,014
Here I'm gonna say edit

98
00:05:18,014 --> 00:05:25,292
C:\Windows\System32\Drivers\Etc\Hosts,
right.

99
00:05:25,292 --> 00:05:28,510
Oh my head is on top of that,
let me scroll up a bit.

100
00:05:28,510 --> 00:05:29,208
There we go.

101
00:05:29,208 --> 00:05:32,610
So you can see the file that I'm editing,
and I'll just go with curly bracket.

102
00:05:32,610 --> 00:05:40,310
So I could have, right here, I could have
typed C:\Windows\System32\Notepad.exe.

103
00:05:40,310 --> 00:05:41,750
But since I already had an alias for

104
00:05:41,750 --> 00:05:45,070
it I'm just gonna reuse that alias right
here, save me a little bit of typing.

105
00:05:45,070 --> 00:05:49,508
And then I'm passing to that
alias this modifier, all right.

106
00:05:49,508 --> 00:05:52,318
Now edit-hosts is a lot more powerful.

107
00:05:52,318 --> 00:05:57,370
So alias Is just a name to a command,
and that's it.

108
00:05:57,370 --> 00:06:02,371
A function though, is a name to a series
of events of limitless power, right.

109
00:06:02,371 --> 00:06:04,720
That's a cool way to look at it.

110
00:06:04,720 --> 00:06:07,390
You can do all sorts of
crazy stuff in a function.

111
00:06:07,390 --> 00:06:08,940
And when I run that, it's gonna log it, so

112
00:06:08,940 --> 00:06:11,710
now I've got this function
created called edit-hosts.

113
00:06:11,710 --> 00:06:16,350
And when I run it, I can be anywhere on
my computer, any prompt that I'm at and

114
00:06:16,350 --> 00:06:18,230
I can just type edit hosts, and

115
00:06:18,230 --> 00:06:22,360
when I run that, it fires up Notepad,
and here I am in the Windows host file.

116
00:06:22,360 --> 00:06:25,580
And I can come in and I can start to
add entries that I need to modify.

117
00:06:25,580 --> 00:06:28,532
Now I need to make sure that I ran
my prompt as an administrator,

118
00:06:28,532 --> 00:06:30,333
otherwise I won't be able to save it.

119
00:06:30,333 --> 00:06:35,639
But I can come in here and say like,
my local machine has itprotv.net,

120
00:06:35,639 --> 00:06:41,667
www, that's one of our test domains that
we use, so I might throw that in there.

121
00:06:41,667 --> 00:06:45,231
And now whenever I try and
go to www.itprotv.net,

122
00:06:45,231 --> 00:06:47,500
it will just go to my own machine.

123
00:06:47,500 --> 00:06:48,480
I close that out.

124
00:06:50,000 --> 00:06:53,930
And we can always pull that right back up.

125
00:06:53,930 --> 00:06:54,890
And there it is.

126
00:06:54,890 --> 00:06:56,210
My values are saved, right.

127
00:06:56,210 --> 00:06:59,310
Nice little shortcut that we've made,
very easy to do.

128
00:06:59,310 --> 00:07:04,120
Because it's a function, what I could have
done is put that edit-host in there, and

129
00:07:04,120 --> 00:07:07,262
then right after it,
executed another command,

130
00:07:07,262 --> 00:07:11,570
like: ipconfig/flushdns,
and flush my DNS cache.

131
00:07:11,570 --> 00:07:14,270
You don't have to do that cuz
a host file would override it, but

132
00:07:14,270 --> 00:07:17,030
that's the idea that we can
have a series of events.

133
00:07:17,030 --> 00:07:18,360
You can even call a script.

134
00:07:18,360 --> 00:07:21,000
There's all sorts of neat stuff
that you can do in a function.

135
00:07:21,000 --> 00:07:24,290
Basically these curly brackets say,
all right sky's the limit.

136
00:07:24,290 --> 00:07:26,780
Whatever you can think of to
put in here is gonna run, and

137
00:07:26,780 --> 00:07:29,170
just close the curly
brackets when your done.

138
00:07:29,170 --> 00:07:31,170
Now you've got the function in place,
all right.

139
00:07:31,170 --> 00:07:35,150
So very powerful it's like
an advanced version of a alias,

140
00:07:35,150 --> 00:07:39,130
there we go a little brain freeze there.

141
00:07:39,130 --> 00:07:40,650
So, pretty neat stuff.

142
00:07:40,650 --> 00:07:43,190
Definitely something to take advantage of.

143
00:07:43,190 --> 00:07:45,480
Otherwise as far as functions
are concerned that's basically it.

144
00:07:45,480 --> 00:07:48,380
I don't wanna go into
the programming side.

145
00:07:48,380 --> 00:07:51,469
But all the other things we learned in the
other segments can go between those curly

146
00:07:51,469 --> 00:07:53,590
brackets, so you can really
fit a lot of stuff in there.

147
00:07:54,630 --> 00:07:56,300
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed that segment.

148
00:07:56,300 --> 00:08:00,000
Stayed tuned, we've got more
PowerShell coming up after this.

149
00:08:00,000 --> 00:08:04,700

episodes.title: Executing Binaries
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:06,379
[SOUND] In this segment,
we're gonna take a look at

2
00:00:06,379 --> 00:00:11,991
executing binaries inside of PowerShell.

3
00:00:11,991 --> 00:00:16,310
Now I know what you're thinking,
Don this is the dumbest segment ever.

4
00:00:16,310 --> 00:00:18,570
to execute a binary,
you just type his name and press enter.

5
00:00:18,570 --> 00:00:20,130
What's so crazy about that?

6
00:00:20,130 --> 00:00:21,780
Well, for the most part you're right.

7
00:00:21,780 --> 00:00:22,670
You're exactly right.

8
00:00:22,670 --> 00:00:25,110
You type a name and press enter and
that's how it works.

9
00:00:25,110 --> 00:00:27,090
But there's a few exceptions to that,

10
00:00:27,090 --> 00:00:30,700
times where we might have problems
with executing a binary, and

11
00:00:30,700 --> 00:00:33,260
I just want to highlight some of those so
that you guys are aware of them.

12
00:00:33,260 --> 00:00:33,850
All right?

13
00:00:33,850 --> 00:00:36,410
First off let's start
with that simple example.

14
00:00:36,410 --> 00:00:38,230
When it comes to executing a binary,

15
00:00:38,230 --> 00:00:41,870
if you know the name of it you
just run it, right, so Notepad.

16
00:00:41,870 --> 00:00:44,560
Well, notepad is notepad.exe.

17
00:00:44,560 --> 00:00:49,506
And I could type in
the full path if I wanted.

18
00:00:49,506 --> 00:00:52,470
So C:\\Windows\System32\notepad.exe.

19
00:00:52,470 --> 00:00:53,381
That works.

20
00:00:53,381 --> 00:00:54,530
That works.

21
00:00:54,530 --> 00:00:56,980
Or if it's in the path, right?

22
00:00:56,980 --> 00:00:58,710
You have this path variable.

23
00:00:58,710 --> 00:01:01,990
If you type in $path,
you'll see what it is.

24
00:01:01,990 --> 00:01:05,430
And mine is not showing up,
that's awesome.

25
00:01:05,430 --> 00:01:09,000
So [LAUGH] I guess I could
do write console but

26
00:01:09,000 --> 00:01:14,110
we can pull it up in our
system configuration also.

27
00:01:14,110 --> 00:01:17,120
Whoops not that one.

28
00:01:17,120 --> 00:01:20,120
Here let's pull it up this way.

29
00:01:20,120 --> 00:01:22,210
We can take a look at our path.

30
00:01:22,210 --> 00:01:27,340
And the path is what your system is
searching for whenever it runs programs

31
00:01:27,340 --> 00:01:32,440
you have these environment variables, and
one of them is your path right here, and

32
00:01:32,440 --> 00:01:35,190
it's basically just a giant
list of directories.

33
00:01:35,190 --> 00:01:38,770
And this will be kind of hard to see,
so let me pull this back up.

34
00:01:38,770 --> 00:01:39,560
Here we go.

35
00:01:39,560 --> 00:01:42,830
So it's this giant list of directories
that shows all the different

36
00:01:42,830 --> 00:01:44,680
places it'll look for a program.

37
00:01:44,680 --> 00:01:51,550
And so you'll see mine has System Roots,
System/32, so all these different folders.

38
00:01:51,550 --> 00:01:54,070
And your programs may or
may not be in that folder.

39
00:01:54,070 --> 00:01:56,160
If they are, great,
they'll run without a path.

40
00:01:56,160 --> 00:01:59,400
Otherwise, you'll need to specify a path.

41
00:01:59,400 --> 00:02:04,185
So I can run it with a path, or I can
run it without a path like notepad.exe.

42
00:02:04,185 --> 00:02:09,305
Because it's an executable I can
leave off the extension if I want.

43
00:02:09,305 --> 00:02:11,835
I don't have to put .exe or .com.

44
00:02:11,835 --> 00:02:15,445
I don't have to put .bat or
.cmd if I'm running those.

45
00:02:15,445 --> 00:02:18,290
So you can leave little
pieces off if you want.

46
00:02:18,290 --> 00:02:20,280
Running a binary is pretty simple.

47
00:02:20,280 --> 00:02:24,580
When it gets tricky is when we
involve special characters.

48
00:02:24,580 --> 00:02:26,470
What do I mean by a special character?

49
00:02:26,470 --> 00:02:27,730
Well things like a space.

50
00:02:27,730 --> 00:02:32,320
Something as simple as a space can cause
a real problem with running a program.

51
00:02:32,320 --> 00:02:35,070
If the program is in the path, you can run
just the program name and you're done.

52
00:02:35,070 --> 00:02:38,180
But if there's a space
in the program name,

53
00:02:38,180 --> 00:02:40,570
you've gotta make sure
the PowerShell understands that.

54
00:02:40,570 --> 00:02:42,200
And if there's a space in the path,

55
00:02:42,200 --> 00:02:44,650
if you're having to provide a path,
it has to understand that to.

56
00:02:45,830 --> 00:02:47,580
So we gotta be ready to handle that.

57
00:02:47,580 --> 00:02:49,445
If I run something like iexplore.

58
00:02:50,640 --> 00:02:54,940
That is the Internet explorer,
or is it iexplorer.

59
00:02:54,940 --> 00:02:56,380
Oh, shoot.

60
00:02:56,380 --> 00:02:58,580
Oh well, it's probably not in the path.

61
00:02:58,580 --> 00:03:00,499
So, if I try and run something like that.

62
00:03:01,580 --> 00:03:03,200
Let's go through and
see if we can't find this guy.

63
00:03:03,200 --> 00:03:05,220
I'm going to use my tab auto-complete.

64
00:03:05,220 --> 00:03:07,800
Actually you can see it right there
what tab auto-complete has done.

65
00:03:07,800 --> 00:03:10,050
When I started to type that path,

66
00:03:10,050 --> 00:03:16,330
I typed in C:\pro and
I hit Tab to do auto-complete for me.

67
00:03:16,330 --> 00:03:17,570
And notice what it did.

68
00:03:17,570 --> 00:03:20,370
It didn't just put quotes around it.

69
00:03:20,370 --> 00:03:22,960
I mean it did, it put quotes around it so
I know that there's a space.

70
00:03:22,960 --> 00:03:26,390
But it stuck this
ampersand at the beginning.

71
00:03:26,390 --> 00:03:27,710
What's that all about?

72
00:03:27,710 --> 00:03:30,740
Well, the ampersand is what
lets PowerShell know, hey,

73
00:03:30,740 --> 00:03:31,820
we're about to run a program.

74
00:03:31,820 --> 00:03:34,290
And there's some spaces in the name.

75
00:03:34,290 --> 00:03:36,470
That's the warning that we get,

76
00:03:36,470 --> 00:03:39,320
that we give PowerShell to
let it know that's happening.

77
00:03:39,320 --> 00:03:41,910
That's the little quirk,
that's the thing we need to remember.

78
00:03:41,910 --> 00:03:45,850
If you're executing a binary with spaces
in the file name or in the path, you've

79
00:03:45,850 --> 00:03:49,300
got to do an ampersand at the beginning
and then quotes around the command.

80
00:03:49,300 --> 00:03:52,210
They can be single quotes like it did,
or they can be double quotes,

81
00:03:52,210 --> 00:03:56,820
it doesn't matter, and we can continue
to use tab auto complete to find

82
00:03:56,820 --> 00:04:01,840
what it is we're looking for, and
I'm looking for Internet Explorer.

83
00:04:01,840 --> 00:04:03,390
Here, let me shorten that up a little bit.

84
00:04:03,390 --> 00:04:05,440
I know it starts with IE something or
another.

85
00:04:07,250 --> 00:04:09,270
I'll just keep hitting tab.

86
00:04:09,270 --> 00:04:10,620
There we go, all right.

87
00:04:10,620 --> 00:04:12,520
So here,
I don't have a space in the file name.

88
00:04:12,520 --> 00:04:14,760
It's just IExplorer.exe.

89
00:04:14,760 --> 00:04:16,410
But, there are spaces in the rest.

90
00:04:16,410 --> 00:04:18,250
So, we put apostrophes or

91
00:04:18,250 --> 00:04:22,170
quotes around it and an ampersand at
the beginning to let it be aware.

92
00:04:22,170 --> 00:04:26,180
And when we run that,
there it goes it ran Internet Explorer.

93
00:04:26,180 --> 00:04:26,860
Right.

94
00:04:26,860 --> 00:04:32,200
If you run it without the ampersand,
sometimes it'll understand,

95
00:04:32,200 --> 00:04:33,800
a lot of times it doesn't.

96
00:04:33,800 --> 00:04:37,550
And you run that and it ends up just
echoing the output that you provided.

97
00:04:37,550 --> 00:04:39,800
So here it is, echoing the output.

98
00:04:39,800 --> 00:04:40,870
That's it right?

99
00:04:40,870 --> 00:04:42,480
Didn't actually run the program.

100
00:04:42,480 --> 00:04:43,880
The ampersand is really important.

101
00:04:45,340 --> 00:04:48,290
There is another scenario
you can bump into also.

102
00:04:48,290 --> 00:04:52,370
Sometimes it's not so
much about a space in a file name,

103
00:04:52,370 --> 00:04:56,070
as it is special characters in
the command that you're running.

104
00:04:56,070 --> 00:05:03,305
So, for example, if I have Had a file,
let's say C:\test.txt all right.

105
00:05:03,305 --> 00:05:09,945
So I'm gonna say this is a test,
whoops, that's not what I wanted.

106
00:05:09,945 --> 00:05:11,975
I just want to save and get out.

107
00:05:11,975 --> 00:05:16,245
Alright, so I've got a file now,
that is test.txt.

108
00:05:16,245 --> 00:05:21,070
There it is, and I might want
to modify the file permissions.

109
00:05:21,070 --> 00:05:23,900
Well I know the GY I can go pull
up the properties of the file, but

110
00:05:23,900 --> 00:05:28,030
I can modify file permissions right from
the command line using the icacls or

111
00:05:28,030 --> 00:05:32,620
I C A C L S command line
utility to change those.

112
00:05:32,620 --> 00:05:36,400
Well, one of the problems
with the icacls command line

113
00:05:36,400 --> 00:05:38,170
is it uses a lot of special characters.

114
00:05:38,170 --> 00:05:41,100
It uses parenthesis,
that's the main one that causes problems.

115
00:05:41,100 --> 00:05:46,190
And PowerShell can choke on those
parentheses, it'll interpret them wrong.

116
00:05:46,190 --> 00:05:48,840
And so it's another area
where we have to be careful

117
00:05:48,840 --> 00:05:50,820
about what we're providing it, all right?

118
00:05:50,820 --> 00:05:55,615
So for example, if I wanted to run icacls

119
00:05:55,615 --> 00:06:03,120
C:\test.txt, and
gonna give myself full control, right?

120
00:06:03,120 --> 00:06:05,960
So I need to specify who I am.

121
00:06:05,960 --> 00:06:06,470
All right.

122
00:06:08,940 --> 00:06:12,270
And I'm gonna give myself,
well you know what?

123
00:06:12,270 --> 00:06:16,450
I'm gonna set some inheritance I guess.

124
00:06:16,450 --> 00:06:18,370
And then I need to modify that.

125
00:06:18,370 --> 00:06:23,610
I want my component inheritance and
object, or it's container and object.

126
00:06:23,610 --> 00:06:27,510
I really just need object cuz it's not
a folder, but I'll set those and F.

127
00:06:27,510 --> 00:06:29,890
I'm going to give myself full control.

128
00:06:29,890 --> 00:06:33,860
So, I'm going to give myself
full control of that file, but

129
00:06:33,860 --> 00:06:38,590
I've got quote marks inside of my commend,
I've got a colon inside of my command,

130
00:06:38,590 --> 00:06:41,430
and I've got some parentheses
inside of my command, and

131
00:06:41,430 --> 00:06:44,250
all of those can cause
problems with PowerShell.

132
00:06:45,980 --> 00:06:48,570
If I run that, it may work,
it may not, but

133
00:06:48,570 --> 00:06:52,960
notice what it says here
The term CI is not recognized.

134
00:06:52,960 --> 00:06:57,050
It was actually happy all the way along,
until it got to here.

135
00:06:57,050 --> 00:06:59,010
The colon kinda threw it.

136
00:06:59,010 --> 00:07:02,110
And then the CI,
it tried to run that as a command.

137
00:07:02,110 --> 00:07:04,030
And that didn't work, and it broke.

138
00:07:04,030 --> 00:07:06,720
Right?
It wasn't able to execute my command.

139
00:07:06,720 --> 00:07:10,310
And in the syntax highlighting down here,
it shows my command.

140
00:07:10,310 --> 00:07:13,920
And notice right here these
little squigglies The tilds.

141
00:07:13,920 --> 00:07:16,160
That's it telling me where
the command broke down.

142
00:07:16,160 --> 00:07:19,490
So it broke down here because
of special characters.

143
00:07:19,490 --> 00:07:22,401
Now if I want to try to get around
that there's a neat little shortcut

144
00:07:22,401 --> 00:07:23,670
you can use.

145
00:07:23,670 --> 00:07:28,480
There's a value we can stick in here
that tells PowerShell hey the name of

146
00:07:28,480 --> 00:07:33,800
the program is over, the rest of this
stuff is for that program, not for you.

147
00:07:33,800 --> 00:07:38,640
We can tell PowerShell to stop
interpreting the rest of the line.

148
00:07:38,640 --> 00:07:41,860
It'll just take the rest of the line and
feed it to the program we're calling.

149
00:07:41,860 --> 00:07:48,126
So when I called icacls right here all
this other stuff C:/test.text/grant,

150
00:07:48,126 --> 00:07:52,580
all this other stuff,
icacls cares about that.

151
00:07:52,580 --> 00:07:53,660
Not PowerShell.

152
00:07:54,670 --> 00:07:57,560
So I can come in here and
I can add a little bit more to it.

153
00:07:57,560 --> 00:07:59,900
And you can kind of pick
where you want it to be.

154
00:07:59,900 --> 00:08:02,220
I usually stick it after the file name.

155
00:08:02,220 --> 00:08:05,210
Because you know PowerShell
is happy up to that point.

156
00:08:05,210 --> 00:08:09,340
The symbol is dash dash percent.

157
00:08:09,340 --> 00:08:10,340
Or hyphen hyphen percent.

158
00:08:11,420 --> 00:08:16,970
When you put that in,
that tells PowerShell from this point on

159
00:08:16,970 --> 00:08:21,110
everything after hyphen
hyphen percent ignore it.

160
00:08:21,110 --> 00:08:22,250
Don't process it.

161
00:08:22,250 --> 00:08:26,014
Just hand it to whatever program or
command that we're running.

162
00:08:26,014 --> 00:08:27,160
And let them deal with it.

163
00:08:27,160 --> 00:08:31,380
So now the fact that I have these special
characters over here is no big deal.

164
00:08:31,380 --> 00:08:34,370
Because PowerShell is gonna
ignore everything else and

165
00:08:34,370 --> 00:08:38,830
take all of that and
feed it unchanged into icacls.

166
00:08:38,830 --> 00:08:43,560
And if I run that I should have
a little bit better success and,

167
00:08:43,560 --> 00:08:44,910
oh it didn't find me.

168
00:08:44,910 --> 00:08:48,400
So, no mapping between account names and
security IDs was done.

169
00:08:48,400 --> 00:08:51,120
So apparently my name
didn't look up right.

170
00:08:51,120 --> 00:08:52,370
Let's pick a different user.

171
00:08:54,250 --> 00:08:55,250
All right, you know what?

172
00:08:55,250 --> 00:08:59,890
I need to use the local machine names,
this is Server 01, there we go.

173
00:08:59,890 --> 00:09:03,400
Process file, successfully
processed one file and it's done.

174
00:09:03,400 --> 00:09:07,670
Much happier by telling it not to process
anything beyond that point, right?

175
00:09:07,670 --> 00:09:09,370
So you may have to use that,

176
00:09:09,370 --> 00:09:11,680
we really do see that a lot
with command line modifiers.

177
00:09:11,680 --> 00:09:12,980
All right so
if you're trying to run a command and

178
00:09:12,980 --> 00:09:16,540
you get something weird like this up here,
just tell it where to stop processing.

179
00:09:16,540 --> 00:09:19,460
Where PowerShell is done, and
the other program takes over.

180
00:09:20,820 --> 00:09:21,540
All right.

181
00:09:21,540 --> 00:09:23,870
So, couple of little caveats there.

182
00:09:23,870 --> 00:09:26,490
For most people running a binary
is exactly what we said at

183
00:09:26,490 --> 00:09:27,690
the beginning of the segment.

184
00:09:27,690 --> 00:09:30,280
You type in the name,
you press enter, and you're done.

185
00:09:30,280 --> 00:09:31,240
All right?

186
00:09:31,240 --> 00:09:35,330
But if there's spaces in the path or
filename, put that ampersand at

187
00:09:35,330 --> 00:09:38,980
the beginning and then surround
the command with quotes or apostrophes.

188
00:09:39,980 --> 00:09:44,540
If you have special characters in there
though you might need to use the dash dash

189
00:09:44,540 --> 00:09:48,440
percent, which tells you stop
processing beyond this point and

190
00:09:48,440 --> 00:09:50,270
hand that off to the program.

191
00:09:50,270 --> 00:09:53,260
Couple little interesting scenarios there,
things that you might bump into and

192
00:09:53,260 --> 00:09:55,310
that's why we had to do
a segment on executing binaries.

193
00:09:55,310 --> 00:09:57,840
Alright well I hope you guys
learned something new there.

194
00:09:57,840 --> 00:10:00,786
If not, stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up and

195
00:10:00,786 --> 00:10:03,747
I'm sure there will be something there for
you, stay tuned.

196
00:10:03,747 --> 00:10:09,409
>> [MUSIC]

episodes.title: Help Commands
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.471
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.471 --> 00:00:11.319
In this segment we're gonna take
a look at how we can pull up help for

3
00:00:11.319 --> 00:00:15.080
the various commands that
we use in the PowerShell.

4
00:00:15.080 --> 00:00:18.260
It's very unlikely that you're going
to memorize all the various commands

5
00:00:18.260 --> 00:00:19.180
that you need.

6
00:00:19.180 --> 00:00:22.990
And so very often we've got
to turn to the documentation.

7
00:00:22.990 --> 00:00:25.381
Sometimes you can go to
Microsoft's TechNet website and

8
00:00:25.381 --> 00:00:28.883
there is a wealth of information on there
and it's very easy to navigate and get at.

9
00:00:28.883 --> 00:00:32.134
But if you're dealing with a server
that has no web browser or

10
00:00:32.134 --> 00:00:35.706
you're in a protected network
where you have no Internet access,

11
00:00:35.706 --> 00:00:38.724
then you might not be able to
get to the TechNet website.

12
00:00:38.724 --> 00:00:42.170
And in that scenario, you need to rely
on the help tools that are available

13
00:00:42.170 --> 00:00:45.020
inside of PowrShell and
fortunately there's a lot of them.

14
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:48.240
There's actually a lot of different things
we can do to get information out of it

15
00:00:48.240 --> 00:00:50.550
that are incredibly useful, all right?

16
00:00:50.550 --> 00:00:52.000
So let's take a look at that.

17
00:00:52.000 --> 00:00:54.680
I know in some of the other segments
that we've already seen one of

18
00:00:54.680 --> 00:00:59.750
the big commands that I like to run,
and that is the Get-Help command.

19
00:00:59.750 --> 00:01:03.410
That's kind of number one go to guy
when I need help for something and

20
00:01:03.410 --> 00:01:07.130
if you just run Get-Help by itself,
it'll give you some basic information.

21
00:01:07.130 --> 00:01:10.940
And when we run that, well it's kind of
a lot of information here that scrolls by.

22
00:01:10.940 --> 00:01:15.690
And you'll see it's just giving you advice
on how to use the Get-Help command.

23
00:01:15.690 --> 00:01:18.570
And that's exactly what I'm gonna
show you here in just a moment.

24
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:23.200
Now, by default when you run Get-Help,

25
00:01:23.200 --> 00:01:27.110
you can then follow it up by specifying
a command to get the help from.

26
00:01:27.110 --> 00:01:32.310
And it will pull that help documentation
right here from the server that you're on.

27
00:01:32.310 --> 00:01:38.410
So if I wanna get help on a command,
like I wanna Get-Help Restart-Service, I

28
00:01:38.410 --> 00:01:43.410
wanna learn more about that command, when
I run it, it's gonna pull the help for it.

29
00:01:43.410 --> 00:01:47.710
But notice on my server here, it's saying
Get-Help cannot find the Help files for

30
00:01:47.710 --> 00:01:48.870
this cmdlet on this computer.

31
00:01:48.870 --> 00:01:50.810
All right, what's that all about?

32
00:01:50.810 --> 00:01:54.970
Well, when someone sets up a server
they will typically set it up

33
00:01:54.970 --> 00:01:59.180
with the minimum functionality
necessary to perform its job, and

34
00:01:59.180 --> 00:02:01.970
they choose to leave off
things that aren't required.

35
00:02:01.970 --> 00:02:06.460
Well, the help files for PowerShell
aren't necessarily required, and so

36
00:02:06.460 --> 00:02:08.160
some admins will choose to leave them off.

37
00:02:09.300 --> 00:02:12.460
Now, if your system is
connected to the Internet,

38
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:14.730
you may just go to the TechNet site and
use that.

39
00:02:14.730 --> 00:02:19.060
There's also a little extension we
can use to this, we can say Get-Help,

40
00:02:19.060 --> 00:02:24.400
the command we want help on, and then you
can add the -Online command, all right.

41
00:02:24.400 --> 00:02:27.440
And that's gonna tell it to reach out to
Microsoft's site, and pull up the help for

42
00:02:27.440 --> 00:02:29.100
that, and see what it did?

43
00:02:29.100 --> 00:02:32.972
It went right to the webpage for
Restart-Service and

44
00:02:32.972 --> 00:02:34.320
there is the information.

45
00:02:34.320 --> 00:02:37.010
Here is the help file and
it's got the information that I need,

46
00:02:37.010 --> 00:02:40.590
the syntax of the command,
the detailed description and

47
00:02:40.590 --> 00:02:44.270
all of the other information
associated with it all right here.

48
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:50.410
So that's one option for us, but
it's still doesn't solve the problem of

49
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:52.540
what if I don't have Internet access,
right?

50
00:02:52.540 --> 00:02:55.340
If I don't have Internet access and
I want to get this help documentation for

51
00:02:55.340 --> 00:02:57.610
a command, that doesn't help me.

52
00:02:57.610 --> 00:03:01.420
Well, if it's already installed
then it's not a big deal.

53
00:03:01.420 --> 00:03:05.060
But if it isn't installed,
we just need to install it, all right.

54
00:03:05.060 --> 00:03:09.600
Now for me this next step is one that I
pretty much do on servers regardless,

55
00:03:09.600 --> 00:03:12.650
even if the help documentation
is already installed.

56
00:03:12.650 --> 00:03:14.550
Sometimes it can be out of date.

57
00:03:14.550 --> 00:03:18.944
And so we have an Update-Help command
that'll reach out to Microsoft servers and

58
00:03:18.944 --> 00:03:22.448
download the latest version of
the help documentation for all for

59
00:03:22.448 --> 00:03:25.570
all the commandlets you
have installed right now.

60
00:03:25.570 --> 00:03:29.510
That's important because you
might have added more commandlets

61
00:03:29.510 --> 00:03:31.560
since the last time you
updated your help files.

62
00:03:31.560 --> 00:03:33.100
So you may actually be missing some,

63
00:03:33.100 --> 00:03:35.260
and here's a chance for
it to correct that and update it.

64
00:03:35.260 --> 00:03:36.310
And as service packs and

65
00:03:36.310 --> 00:03:39.590
hotfixes come out, updates to
the help files may be necessary, too.

66
00:03:39.590 --> 00:03:42.300
So it's definitely a good idea to do it,
all right.

67
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:46.260
Now the update process can take a little
while, and so I've got a second

68
00:03:46.260 --> 00:03:49.660
PowerShell window in the background here
that I'm gonna use to do the update.

69
00:03:49.660 --> 00:03:51.900
And if we want to update it and
have it go out and get it,

70
00:03:51.900 --> 00:03:53.480
the command is really simple.

71
00:03:53.480 --> 00:03:56.560
It's just the Update-Help command.

72
00:03:56.560 --> 00:04:00.550
And when you run that it's
gonna give us a little prompt.

73
00:04:00.550 --> 00:04:02.458
Actually apparently mine's
not even going to prompt.

74
00:04:02.458 --> 00:04:05.870
[LAUGH] Sometimes it will prompt and say
are you sure you want to get updates for

75
00:04:05.870 --> 00:04:08.600
all of your commandlets,
and you say yes or no.

76
00:04:08.600 --> 00:04:11.240
I must not have any extra
modules added in here.

77
00:04:11.240 --> 00:04:12.810
If you have extra modules
it will prompt you,

78
00:04:12.810 --> 00:04:16.610
just to kinda give you a little warning
about that it might take a long time.

79
00:04:16.610 --> 00:04:20.730
But here you see it's going out, and it's
pulling all this help documentation, and

80
00:04:20.730 --> 00:04:23.530
it's flashing by really fast here, but

81
00:04:23.530 --> 00:04:26.890
it says locating,
then downloading, then installing.

82
00:04:26.890 --> 00:04:28.780
Those are the three
stages it goes through.

83
00:04:28.780 --> 00:04:30.390
It'll locate the help content for

84
00:04:30.390 --> 00:04:34.140
a particular commandlet, it'll download
it, and then it'll install it.

85
00:04:34.140 --> 00:04:38.630
This is going to ensure that I have
the latest help information on my system.

86
00:04:38.630 --> 00:04:42.570
And then I'm able to reference it even
without an Internet connection, all right?

87
00:04:42.570 --> 00:04:46.790
That's a pretty handy thing especially if
you've got a server that's a core install.

88
00:04:46.790 --> 00:04:51.390
Now Microsoft's stance on this is, you
don't necessarily need to install the help

89
00:04:51.390 --> 00:04:56.225
on the server because you should be
developing an PowerShell scripts or

90
00:04:56.225 --> 00:04:59.305
commands that you're gonna be using
on your own workstation first in

91
00:04:59.305 --> 00:05:00.365
a test environment.

92
00:05:00.365 --> 00:05:03.055
So by the time you come to the server
you don't need the help documentation.

93
00:05:03.055 --> 00:05:05.955
Where you just run the commands that
you've already thoroughly tested.

94
00:05:05.955 --> 00:05:07.160
That's why it's not installed here.

95
00:05:07.160 --> 00:05:09.640
That's why it's an optional component.

96
00:05:09.640 --> 00:05:13.460
Now I've installed this help
documentation and while it's really,

97
00:05:13.460 --> 00:05:17.220
really unlikely, it has technically
increased my attack surface.

98
00:05:17.220 --> 00:05:21.000
I put help files on the server that don't
actually contribute to the function

99
00:05:21.000 --> 00:05:21.850
of this server.

100
00:05:21.850 --> 00:05:24.640
So you'll have to take
that with a grain of salt.

101
00:05:24.640 --> 00:05:27.320
You know, when you go to deploy this
in your own environment, you may or

102
00:05:27.320 --> 00:05:29.600
may not actually want to deploy
the help files on your server.

103
00:05:29.600 --> 00:05:33.270
But I actually stalled long
enough there that it finished.

104
00:05:33.270 --> 00:05:40.430
So now that it's done, if I go back
here and I do Get-Help Restart-Service,

105
00:05:40.430 --> 00:05:44.440
when I run that instead of telling
me it couldn't find a help file,

106
00:05:44.440 --> 00:05:48.200
now I get the help documentation and
it's right here on this server.

107
00:05:48.200 --> 00:05:50.310
It didn't have to go out
to the Internet to get it.

108
00:05:50.310 --> 00:05:50.880
All right?

109
00:05:50.880 --> 00:05:53.540
So don't be worried if you see
your help files are missing.

110
00:05:53.540 --> 00:05:58.200
Just run Update-Help, It'll run that and
get everything up to date.

111
00:05:58.200 --> 00:06:01.090
It's a good idea to run that periodically
anyway just to make sure you've got

112
00:06:01.090 --> 00:06:02.139
the latest help documentation.

113
00:06:03.510 --> 00:06:07.950
Now, in my scenario,
I knew the command I was looking for.

114
00:06:07.950 --> 00:06:13.680
And so I did Get-Help, I punched in
the command that I wanted, and here it is.

115
00:06:13.680 --> 00:06:17.350
If you don't know the command that you're
looking for, though, you might need to use

116
00:06:17.350 --> 00:06:21.730
the Get-Command commandlet to be able
to find the command you're looking for.

117
00:06:21.730 --> 00:06:28.130
If I know I'm gonna be working with DNS,
then I might need to do get-command and do

118
00:06:28.130 --> 00:06:32.190
a search for any command having to do with
DNS, and we can use wildcards for that.

119
00:06:32.190 --> 00:06:33.810
I know I've done this
in another segment but

120
00:06:33.810 --> 00:06:38.170
in case you haven't watched
it get-command *dns*.

121
00:06:38.170 --> 00:06:41.590
Those asterisks mean any number
of characters before and

122
00:06:41.590 --> 00:06:45.730
any number of characters after, show me
all the commands having to do with DNS.

123
00:06:45.730 --> 00:06:48.890
And I'll see there's, there's actually
quite a few that are listed in here,

124
00:06:48.890 --> 00:06:53.645
and let's see, I must not be a DNS
server cuz these are all client ones.

125
00:06:53.645 --> 00:06:56.835
If you're running a DNS server you'll
have even more that have to do with

126
00:06:56.835 --> 00:06:58.505
the server itself.

127
00:06:58.505 --> 00:06:59.855
The majority of these are functions,

128
00:06:59.855 --> 00:07:03.585
you'll see there's only a few
commandlets like Resolve-DNSName.

129
00:07:03.585 --> 00:07:06.945
If I want to learn more about
one of these I can use Get-Help

130
00:07:06.945 --> 00:07:08.735
followed by the name of that command.

131
00:07:08.735 --> 00:07:11.630
For example if I wanted
to pull up the help for

132
00:07:11.630 --> 00:07:16.721
Get-DNSClient I could come in here and
say Get-Help followed

133
00:07:16.721 --> 00:07:22.502
by Get-DNSClient and
there's the help documentation for it.

134
00:07:22.502 --> 00:07:26.310
All right now when we get the help
documentation, what is it telling us?

135
00:07:26.310 --> 00:07:29.735
Well the format of the help documentation,

136
00:07:29.735 --> 00:07:33.260
it actually follows a standard,
a pattern that Microsoft created.

137
00:07:33.260 --> 00:07:36.800
So all the documentation
is written the same way.

138
00:07:36.800 --> 00:07:38.613
When you run Get-Help for a command,

139
00:07:38.613 --> 00:07:41.738
it's typically gonna return these
five areas for us right here.

140
00:07:41.738 --> 00:07:47.575
A synopsis which is just a quick short
description of what the command does.

141
00:07:47.575 --> 00:07:48.357
In this case,

142
00:07:48.357 --> 00:07:53.010
retrieves details of network interfaces
configured on a specific computer.

143
00:07:53.010 --> 00:07:57.240
So this ones gonna go out and get
information about my network interfaces.

144
00:07:57.240 --> 00:07:58.732
And then we see the syntax.

145
00:07:58.732 --> 00:08:02.954
This is what we actually type into
the PowerShell to use the command.

146
00:08:02.954 --> 00:08:07.514
And it'll start out with the command
itself And then it'll list all

147
00:08:07.514 --> 00:08:12.170
of the modifiers for that command,
and there can be a bunch of them.

148
00:08:12.170 --> 00:08:15.460
Look at all these that are listed here,
forget -DnsClient.

149
00:08:15.460 --> 00:08:17.855
Well, they're not all required.

150
00:08:17.855 --> 00:08:21.280
Some of them are required,
some of them are optional, and

151
00:08:21.280 --> 00:08:23.510
it can be a little tricky
to recognize that.

152
00:08:23.510 --> 00:08:27.550
When you start to look at them,
these square brackets are how

153
00:08:27.550 --> 00:08:32.540
we know whether we've got a required
setting, or an optional setting, okay?

154
00:08:32.540 --> 00:08:39.042
When you see one that's written like
this -InterFaceAlias String, okay?

155
00:08:39.042 --> 00:08:45.120
What that's telling me is, when I run
Get-DNSClient, I can specify the alias for

156
00:08:45.120 --> 00:08:48.810
an interface, the name of an interface
that I want to find out information for.

157
00:08:48.810 --> 00:08:53.380
And if I do that, I need to specify
the string, the name that I'm looking for.

158
00:08:53.380 --> 00:08:57.520
And it's surrounded by
these square brackets,

159
00:08:57.520 --> 00:09:00.910
telling me that this is
an optional parameter.

160
00:09:00.910 --> 00:09:05.840
I don't have to specify this if don't
want to, I can leave it off, right?

161
00:09:05.840 --> 00:09:10.080
When we have one that's required, let's
see if any of these are actually required.

162
00:09:10.080 --> 00:09:13.120
So this one's optional,
cuz they're grouped together,

163
00:09:13.120 --> 00:09:15.390
this one's optional cuz
they're grouped together.

164
00:09:15.390 --> 00:09:18.150
The next one's optional,
are they all optional in this one?

165
00:09:18.150 --> 00:09:19.340
It looks like they are.

166
00:09:19.340 --> 00:09:20.860
Yeah, they're all optional on this one.

167
00:09:20.860 --> 00:09:25.200
Okay so, sometimes you'll have
a command where they're all optional.

168
00:09:25.200 --> 00:09:29.510
In other words,
I can just run get-DnsClient, all right?

169
00:09:29.510 --> 00:09:32.900
And when I run that by itself,
it runs, right?

170
00:09:32.900 --> 00:09:37.360
I didn't have to provide any
modifiers if I didn't want to.

171
00:09:37.360 --> 00:09:39.560
But there's other commands
that you do have to.

172
00:09:39.560 --> 00:09:42.140
So, for example, Restart-Service.
