00:22:10.630 --> 00:22:15.580
We create an alias as a name and
the name just ties to a commandlet and

400
00:22:15.580 --> 00:22:16.940
that's basically it.

401
00:22:16.940 --> 00:22:19.660
Well, the alias in this case is help.

402
00:22:19.660 --> 00:22:22.230
Help is mapped to get -help.

403
00:22:22.230 --> 00:22:25.850
So, if I wanted help for this file I could
actually use the help command to do it.

404
00:22:25.850 --> 00:22:26.960
Let me show you.

405
00:22:26.960 --> 00:22:31.990
So, if I do get -help,
let me start at the start of the screen.

406
00:22:31.990 --> 00:22:37.280
So I'll do "get-help" for
"restart-service".

407
00:22:37.280 --> 00:22:40.730
When I run that, it was more information
than what fit on the screen so

408
00:22:40.730 --> 00:22:42.800
it scrolled of the top but I got my help.

409
00:22:42.800 --> 00:22:45.040
That was the full version of the command.

410
00:22:45.040 --> 00:22:49.530
Well, if I run help restart-service.

411
00:22:51.080 --> 00:22:56.460
Help is an alias of get -help, but
when I run it, notice what it did.

412
00:22:56.460 --> 00:22:59.660
It puts the more command in by default.

413
00:22:59.660 --> 00:23:04.170
When you use the help alias it
automatically applies a pipeline into

414
00:23:04.170 --> 00:23:06.880
the more command and now it's paginated.

415
00:23:06.880 --> 00:23:09.090
All right, so
it's not like a normal alias.

416
00:23:09.090 --> 00:23:11.870
A normal alias is just
a name to a commandlet, and

417
00:23:11.870 --> 00:23:14.130
it doesn't modify the functionality
of that commandlet at all.

418
00:23:14.130 --> 00:23:18.470
It's just a name being mapped but,
in this case, it's a name being mapped and

419
00:23:18.470 --> 00:23:20.170
it applies the more command.

420
00:23:20.170 --> 00:23:23.210
So, pretty handy if you can just
wanna quickly view a help file,

421
00:23:23.210 --> 00:23:26.750
you can use that but
there's some limitations to it,

422
00:23:26.750 --> 00:23:30.930
you know, as far as it just
defaults to that base example.

423
00:23:30.930 --> 00:23:35.460
If I did -examples after it,
it can jump in and

424
00:23:35.460 --> 00:23:38.480
now we've got that or we can do -full.

425
00:23:38.480 --> 00:23:41.240
Right, so it still accepts those
command line modifiers, and

426
00:23:41.240 --> 00:23:44.690
it applies the more pagination for
me, so that can be pretty handy.

427
00:23:44.690 --> 00:23:49.354
So take advantage of that alias,
it's a pretty cool one.

428
00:23:49.354 --> 00:23:51.838
All right, but other than that,
that is about it.

429
00:23:51.838 --> 00:23:56.129
The only other things worth mentioning
here is that when you get-help One of

430
00:23:56.129 --> 00:23:58.757
the really handy things
is Tab autocomplete.

431
00:23:58.757 --> 00:24:02.240
When you start to type a command inside
of the PowerShell, you can hit Tab and

432
00:24:02.240 --> 00:24:04.590
it'll try and
guess what command you were typing.

433
00:24:04.590 --> 00:24:07.195
And if it guesses wrong,
you just keep hitting Tab over and

434
00:24:07.195 --> 00:24:08.749
over again until it gets it right.

435
00:24:08.749 --> 00:24:13.187
So for example, earlier I tried
to do Restart-Service DnsClient,

436
00:24:13.187 --> 00:24:17.775
but the name of, it was actually DnsCache,
and if I didn't know that,

437
00:24:17.775 --> 00:24:21.770
I could try and guess, I could try and
stumble my way through.

438
00:24:21.770 --> 00:24:22.830
Let me show you what I mean.

439
00:24:22.830 --> 00:24:27.519
So, if I run Get-Help, and then, Get-Dns,

440
00:24:27.519 --> 00:24:31.050
and I can't remember is it client?

441
00:24:31.050 --> 00:24:31.990
Is it cash?

442
00:24:31.990 --> 00:24:37.309
I can hit Tab and my Tab autocomplete
is gonna try and guess the command.

443
00:24:37.309 --> 00:24:39.569
And so, I'll see there is, DnsClient.

444
00:24:39.569 --> 00:24:41.330
There's DnsClientCache.

445
00:24:41.330 --> 00:24:43.930
So, it's got a couple of different
ones that it'll scroll through and

446
00:24:43.930 --> 00:24:45.130
show me those different options.

447
00:24:45.130 --> 00:24:46.890
So, you can use Tab autocomplete.

448
00:24:46.890 --> 00:24:50.010
You can also do things like wildcards.

449
00:24:50.010 --> 00:24:55.370
If you do Get-Help, Get-Dns*, it doesn't
give you the full help for everyone.

450
00:24:55.370 --> 00:24:56.750
Well, not that you can see.

451
00:24:56.750 --> 00:25:00.487
What it's actually doing is it's
putting it in a table so that I can

452
00:25:00.487 --> 00:25:04.910
see each of the commands, and the help
is actually being displayed over here.

453
00:25:04.910 --> 00:25:06.980
It's just in a table, so I don't know it.

454
00:25:06.980 --> 00:25:12.080
If I did this same command and I pipe
that into the format-list commandlet,

455
00:25:12.080 --> 00:25:17.010
which you can abbreviate to fl if
you want but I'll do format-list.

456
00:25:17.010 --> 00:25:19.960
When I run that,
it's displaying the help file for

457
00:25:19.960 --> 00:25:23.320
every one of those commands in line.

458
00:25:23.320 --> 00:25:26.480
And that may or
may not be what I actually want.

459
00:25:26.480 --> 00:25:30.140
You can actually cause a little bit of
trouble with that if you're not careful.

460
00:25:30.140 --> 00:25:31.780
So, not terribly useful, but

461
00:25:31.780 --> 00:25:36.110
I'll use it sometimes to find the commands
just to figure out what I'm looking for.

462
00:25:36.110 --> 00:25:40.530
But I'll usually use Get-Command to do it,
because when you do Get-Help,

463
00:25:40.530 --> 00:25:42.460
it's actually loading those help files.

464
00:25:42.460 --> 00:25:44.529
Did you see the green bar
that flashed by on my screen?

465
00:25:44.529 --> 00:25:46.509
It was real fast, but it still did it.

466
00:25:46.509 --> 00:25:50.629
It had to query those help files,
and that can take a little

467
00:25:50.629 --> 00:25:55.546
while if you did an excessively
large query, versus Get-Command.

468
00:25:55.546 --> 00:25:59.480
And then here, I could do Get-Dns*, right?

469
00:25:59.480 --> 00:26:03.160
When I run that, I didn't get that green
bar flashing by, and that's cuz I wasn't

470
00:26:03.160 --> 00:26:06.750
loading the help files,
it was just pulling the command list.

471
00:26:06.750 --> 00:26:10.490
So, I usually use Get-Command instead
of Get-Help to search for commands.

472
00:26:10.490 --> 00:26:11.850
All right.

473
00:26:11.850 --> 00:26:16.089
Other than that, that's basically how
we can pull help from the PowerShell.

474
00:26:16.089 --> 00:26:16.849
It's really useful.

475
00:26:16.849 --> 00:26:19.778
It's nice to have that inline
command help available for

476
00:26:19.778 --> 00:26:21.190
us to be able to get to that.

477
00:26:21.190 --> 00:26:23.698
More often than not though, I like
to rely on the TechNet pages because

478
00:26:23.698 --> 00:26:25.370
they've got a lot of
good information there.

479
00:26:25.370 --> 00:26:27.360
It's fully searchable, really handy.

480
00:26:27.360 --> 00:26:30.300
There's some good web
pages in the TechNet site

481
00:26:30.300 --> 00:26:33.580
that will give you all sorts of
PowerShell examples and new scenarios.

482
00:26:33.580 --> 00:26:35.390
Definitely good stuff there.

483
00:26:35.390 --> 00:26:37.940
But, if you're in a hurry,
if you don't have internet access,

484
00:26:37.940 --> 00:26:40.690
the help that's imbedded in the module,
it's pretty handy.

485
00:26:40.690 --> 00:26:42.362
You should definitely use it.

486
00:26:42.362 --> 00:26:45.482
All right, well, that's about it for
the help documentation.

487
00:26:45.482 --> 00:26:46.523
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

488
00:26:46.523 --> 00:26:47.521
Stay tuned.

489
00:26:47.521 --> 00:26:50.301
We've got more PowerShell coming up.

490
00:26:50.301 --> 00:26:54.640
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Piping Command Output
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,135
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,135 --> 00:00:12,755
In this segment we're gonna take a look at
piping command output from one command to

3
00:00:12,755 --> 00:00:14,042
another.

4
00:00:14,042 --> 00:00:17,080
In PowerShell we have what's
called the command pipeline.

5
00:00:17,080 --> 00:00:21,470
And what that means is that when we run
a command we may want to do additional

6
00:00:21,470 --> 00:00:24,500
things with the output other
than just look at it, right?

7
00:00:24,500 --> 00:00:29,130
The traditional command pipeline that we
have is you run a command and something

8
00:00:29,130 --> 00:00:32,600
gets displayed on the screen and you look
at it with your eyeballs and that's it.

9
00:00:32,600 --> 00:00:35,420
Right.
That's our command pipeline normally.

10
00:00:35,420 --> 00:00:41,110
But sometimes we want to take
the results of one command and

11
00:00:41,110 --> 00:00:43,090
feed it into another command.

12
00:00:43,090 --> 00:00:47,690
So the output from one command
becomes the input for another command.

13
00:00:47,690 --> 00:00:48,900
All right.

14
00:00:48,900 --> 00:00:51,430
You can use this for
a number of different things.

15
00:00:51,430 --> 00:00:56,990
For example, you might want to
restart certain services but

16
00:00:56,990 --> 00:00:59,030
you don't necessarily know
what those services are.

17
00:00:59,030 --> 00:01:03,960
So you might use a Get-Service command,
or something like that, to query for

18
00:01:03,960 --> 00:01:08,950
certain services, and it makes a list,
and you take that output, and feed that

19
00:01:08,950 --> 00:01:12,440
right back into the Restart-Service
command, right, that commandlet.

20
00:01:12,440 --> 00:01:15,460
And it takes the output
from the first command,

21
00:01:15,460 --> 00:01:18,670
uses it as input on the second command,
and takes action on it.

22
00:01:18,670 --> 00:01:22,630
And you can even pipeline
several layers deep if you want.

23
00:01:22,630 --> 00:01:25,350
Now a lot of us do this even
without thinking about it, and

24
00:01:25,350 --> 00:01:27,120
let me give you an example.

25
00:01:27,120 --> 00:01:30,350
Actually, let me get into a PowerShell
here before I give you an example.

26
00:01:30,350 --> 00:01:35,330
All right, so
if I take something like Get-Service.

27
00:01:35,330 --> 00:01:35,830
Right?

28
00:01:35,830 --> 00:01:39,790
When I run Get-Service,
it gives me a list of all of the services.

29
00:01:39,790 --> 00:01:40,340
All right?

30
00:01:40,340 --> 00:01:43,230
Well, there was more than
what fit on my screen.

31
00:01:43,230 --> 00:01:45,050
And, that can be a little excessive.

32
00:01:45,050 --> 00:01:46,280
Right?
It's just way more.

33
00:01:46,280 --> 00:01:48,160
I can scroll back and find things.

34
00:01:48,160 --> 00:01:52,170
But, I might want to add
pagination to that, right?

35
00:01:52,170 --> 00:01:54,350
Pagination, that just
means every 24 lines,

36
00:01:54,350 --> 00:01:57,030
put in a stop that says
Press any key to continue.

37
00:01:58,150 --> 00:02:02,520
And the easiest way to do that is to
take the output from Get-Service,

38
00:02:02,520 --> 00:02:07,169
and feed that into another command,
the more commandlet.

39
00:02:07,169 --> 00:02:14,040
All right?
And more is a built in part of the system.

40
00:02:14,040 --> 00:02:15,940
See how it's not an alias for anything.

41
00:02:15,940 --> 00:02:20,450
More is a command that's been
a part of Windows and DOS forever.

42
00:02:20,450 --> 00:02:23,500
And it just adds that
pagination to a screen.

43
00:02:23,500 --> 00:02:28,360
So if I wanna use it,
I can say Get-Service, and

44
00:02:28,360 --> 00:02:30,375
then I can use the | symbol.

45
00:02:30,375 --> 00:02:35,010
Now the | symbol, it's a little weird
the way that it's rendered on the screen.

46
00:02:35,010 --> 00:02:40,140
It's actually two vertical lines,
one on top of the other.

47
00:02:40,140 --> 00:02:44,320
When you look on screen, it looks like one
vertical line, but it is actually two.

48
00:02:44,320 --> 00:02:46,700
And if you look on your keyboard,
it's typically two.

49
00:02:46,700 --> 00:02:50,200
And you know I say that as I look at my
keyboard where it's a solid, single one.

50
00:02:50,200 --> 00:02:52,575
On a normal, 110-key or

51
00:02:52,575 --> 00:02:57,650
104-key Windows keyboard it'll be two
vertical lines, one on top of the other.

52
00:02:57,650 --> 00:03:01,710
And it's typically located right
above your Enter key, or Return.

53
00:03:01,710 --> 00:03:03,870
It'll be right above that or
right beneath your Backspace key.

54
00:03:03,870 --> 00:03:04,920
It doesn't have to be.

55
00:03:04,920 --> 00:03:06,850
Your keyboard might
have it somewhere else.

56
00:03:06,850 --> 00:03:11,080
But it's usually there and
it's usually the backslash key too.

57
00:03:11,080 --> 00:03:14,320
So you have to hold Shift to
get it to get that pipe symbol.

58
00:03:14,320 --> 00:03:18,180
But all the pipe symbol says
is it's telling PowerShell,

59
00:03:18,180 --> 00:03:22,460
as of this symbol,
everything to the left is one command.

60
00:03:22,460 --> 00:03:24,200
Run it.

61
00:03:24,200 --> 00:03:27,610
Run it, and instead of displaying
the output on the screen,

62
00:03:28,910 --> 00:03:35,030
feed the output as input into whatever I
type on the other side of this pipe symbol

63
00:03:36,280 --> 00:03:40,340
and then from there, take that output and
display that on the screen.

64
00:03:41,450 --> 00:03:44,342
And the more command is one of
the most simple versions of that.

65
00:03:44,342 --> 00:03:47,070
I'm gonna take the output
of get dash service, and

66
00:03:47,070 --> 00:03:49,470
I will pipe that into the more command.

67
00:03:50,810 --> 00:03:54,820
When I run that, I get the same output
I had a minute ago, but there's my

68
00:03:54,820 --> 00:03:59,600
more prompt, and I can press a key and
I can advance at my leisure, all right?

69
00:03:59,600 --> 00:04:02,340
Now, that one's not too
terribly spectacular,

70
00:04:02,340 --> 00:04:04,350
there's other ones that
are a little more impressive.

71
00:04:05,510 --> 00:04:10,220
One of my problems here with Get-Service
is that it displays a lot of stuff, right?

72
00:04:10,220 --> 00:04:13,910
And I see these three columns,
status, name, display name.

73
00:04:13,910 --> 00:04:16,437
But there's actually more [COUGH],
excuse me,

74
00:04:16,437 --> 00:04:21,210
more to each of those services than
what's being displayed on the screen.

75
00:04:21,210 --> 00:04:24,170
So what if I wanna see that other stuff?

76
00:04:24,170 --> 00:04:28,750
Well, there's another command
called Format-List that will help

77
00:04:28,750 --> 00:04:30,300
me see that other stuff.

78
00:04:30,300 --> 00:04:36,638
And so, I can pipe the output
of Get-Service into Format-List.

79
00:04:36,638 --> 00:04:38,949
But the output for Format-List,

80
00:04:38,949 --> 00:04:43,020
[COUGH] it's gonna be even longer
than what I originally had.

81
00:04:44,370 --> 00:04:46,662
So, I might want to pipe that
into another command too.

82
00:04:46,662 --> 00:04:50,410
I might wanna pipe that more.

83
00:04:50,410 --> 00:04:53,020
Now, I'm doing three stages.

84
00:04:53,020 --> 00:04:56,990
Command one, the output becomes input for
command two.

85
00:04:56,990 --> 00:05:00,510
Command two runs, and the output for
command two becomes the input for

86
00:05:00,510 --> 00:05:01,420
command three.

87
00:05:01,420 --> 00:05:03,950
You can pipeline as
many times as you want.

88
00:05:03,950 --> 00:05:05,520
All right, these are nested commands.

89
00:05:05,520 --> 00:05:07,410
Their gonna run one after the other,

90
00:05:07,410 --> 00:05:10,810
each one building off of
the output of the previous one.

91
00:05:10,810 --> 00:05:15,310
So, pretty important process here cuz we
can really use this to create some power.

92
00:05:15,310 --> 00:05:18,480
And when I run this, well, actually,
let me run it without the more command.

93
00:05:18,480 --> 00:05:19,268
I'll just run it like this.

94
00:05:19,268 --> 00:05:21,400
Get-Service | Format-List.

95
00:05:21,400 --> 00:05:24,970
And when I run it,
that's a lot of information.

96
00:05:24,970 --> 00:05:28,370
I see the additional columns that I
couldn't see in the table a minute ago.

97
00:05:28,370 --> 00:05:32,170
Sure, I get Name, DisplayName, and
Status, but now I see DependentServices,

98
00:05:32,170 --> 00:05:36,450
ServiceDescription, CanPause,
CanShutdown, CanStop, and ServiceType.

99
00:05:36,450 --> 00:05:38,640
A lot of additional stuff.

100
00:05:38,640 --> 00:05:41,790
And if I pipe that into the more command.

101
00:05:43,620 --> 00:05:47,430
Now, it's the same output but
paginated, all right?

102
00:05:47,430 --> 00:05:50,020
So three commands involved in this.

103
00:05:50,020 --> 00:05:51,810
That's the glory of pipelining, right?

104
00:05:51,810 --> 00:05:53,370
You can pipeline over and over and

105
00:05:53,370 --> 00:05:58,440
over again to create all sorts of
interesting output that matches your needs

106
00:05:58,440 --> 00:06:03,140
that may be very different than the output
that Microsoft normally gives you.

107
00:06:03,140 --> 00:06:06,070
We're going to do another segment later on
where we'll talk about different ways to

108
00:06:06,070 --> 00:06:07,220
format output.

109
00:06:07,220 --> 00:06:10,390
But for right now I'm just using this to
kind of demonstrate the different ways

110
00:06:10,390 --> 00:06:13,930
that we can feed the output
of one command into another.

111
00:06:15,380 --> 00:06:16,160
All right.

112
00:06:16,160 --> 00:06:18,800
So that's a pretty basic
example of pipelining.

113
00:06:18,800 --> 00:06:22,180
But, I didn't really do anything
with the data that I got.

114
00:06:22,180 --> 00:06:26,080
I ran a query, Get-Service,
give me all the services.

115
00:06:26,080 --> 00:06:28,860
But then, all I really did was
change the format of the output.

116
00:06:28,860 --> 00:06:30,110
That's not too fun.

117
00:06:30,110 --> 00:06:33,800
But you can actually take
actions based on various things.

118
00:06:33,800 --> 00:06:39,930
So, for example, if I want to restart
every service that has to deal with dns.

119
00:06:39,930 --> 00:06:40,580
All right.

120
00:06:40,580 --> 00:06:42,480
Well let me show you how we can do that.

121
00:06:42,480 --> 00:06:49,500
If I take Get-Service and
I do *dns*, right?

122
00:06:49,500 --> 00:06:52,980
It's gonna show me every service
that has to do with dns.

123
00:06:52,980 --> 00:06:55,410
Well, guess I picked a lame example
where there's only one of those.

124
00:06:55,410 --> 00:06:58,880
[LAUGH] So
some of them will have multiple services.

125
00:06:58,880 --> 00:06:59,520
This one just has one.

126
00:06:59,520 --> 00:07:01,600
What would be a better one to pick?

127
00:07:01,600 --> 00:07:02,530
I don't want to do RPC.

128
00:07:02,530 --> 00:07:03,960
That would be bad.

129
00:07:03,960 --> 00:07:06,940
Let's just take a look at our screen here,
see if I can spot something.

130
00:07:09,110 --> 00:07:11,030
I could do my virtual machine stuff.

131
00:07:11,030 --> 00:07:14,620
I could do Windows Update stuff,
that could be fun.

132
00:07:14,620 --> 00:07:16,470
See how much trouble we can
cause with Windows Update?

133
00:07:17,560 --> 00:07:21,660
So let me do a Get-Service for wu*.

134
00:07:21,660 --> 00:07:23,220
There, all right?

135
00:07:23,220 --> 00:07:27,230
So I've got two services, and they're both
stopped, so that's not terribly exciting.

136
00:07:27,230 --> 00:07:29,170
But they're right there,
and I can see these.

137
00:07:29,170 --> 00:07:31,260
And I guess one of them's Windows Update.

138
00:07:31,260 --> 00:07:32,960
The other one is actually the user driver.

139
00:07:32,960 --> 00:07:33,520
Well, whatever.

140
00:07:33,520 --> 00:07:34,430
It'll work for my example.

141
00:07:35,650 --> 00:07:39,240
So if I wanna restart both of those,
well I could take this output and

142
00:07:39,240 --> 00:07:46,089
I could feed that into
the Restart-Service commandlet.

143
00:07:46,089 --> 00:07:46,974
Right?

144
00:07:46,974 --> 00:07:50,600
Now not every commandlet works with this.

145
00:07:50,600 --> 00:07:51,910
And there's a reason for that.

146
00:07:51,910 --> 00:07:54,140
The output, here is a table.

147
00:07:54,140 --> 00:07:58,550
It's a table listing all of
the services that matched my query.

148
00:07:58,550 --> 00:08:01,110
Well Restart-Service may or

149
00:08:01,110 --> 00:08:05,820
may not be set up to receive
a table as its input, all right?

150
00:08:05,820 --> 00:08:07,538
Doesn't hurt to try.
We can give it a shot, but

151
00:08:07,538 --> 00:08:11,570
if you get an error like I just did,
well that's what's telling me, hey,

152
00:08:11,570 --> 00:08:13,690
I'm not set up to receive it like that.

153
00:08:13,690 --> 00:08:17,950
I can't handle restarting more
than one service at the same time.

154
00:08:17,950 --> 00:08:19,350
All right.

155
00:08:19,350 --> 00:08:22,700
When that happens,
it doesn't mean that you can't pipeline,

156
00:08:22,700 --> 00:08:25,320
it just means you have to do it
a slightly different way, all right?

157
00:08:25,320 --> 00:08:28,440
Sometimes, this'll work just fine, right?

158
00:08:28,440 --> 00:08:32,620
The command, your second command will
support receiving a matrix or receiving

159
00:08:32,620 --> 00:08:37,470
a table in and it'll act on it and it will
restart you to the services or whatever.

160
00:08:37,470 --> 00:08:40,430
But other times, you get errors like this.

161
00:08:40,430 --> 00:08:45,660
And we just have to modify our pipeline
procedure a little bit, to say take

162
00:08:45,660 --> 00:08:50,160
each individual line of our
first command's output and

163
00:08:50,160 --> 00:08:53,430
feed it into the second
command one at a time.

164
00:08:53,430 --> 00:08:55,990
In other words,
run that second command once for

165
00:08:55,990 --> 00:08:58,760
every single line of that
first command's output.

166
00:08:58,760 --> 00:09:00,860
This is a little bit more advanced, but

167
00:09:00,860 --> 00:09:03,380
it's something that
you'll commonly run into.

168
00:09:03,380 --> 00:09:05,970
So if you get a bunch of error, like this.

169
00:09:05,970 --> 00:09:10,030
Actually, here looking at my errors, my
errors are actually tied more to the fact

170
00:09:10,030 --> 00:09:12,280
that I tried to stop services
that were already stopped.

171
00:09:12,280 --> 00:09:14,208
So let's try something valid here.

172
00:09:14,208 --> 00:09:18,610
I'm just gonna stay start service cuz
they're both started, or, both stopped.

173
00:09:18,610 --> 00:09:20,360
So if I do start, oh,
I got an error there.

174
00:09:20,360 --> 00:09:23,010
Cannot be started due
to the following error,

175
00:09:24,110 --> 00:09:25,880
service controller error, and, am I, oh.

176
00:09:25,880 --> 00:09:27,640
I'm not an administrator.

177
00:09:27,640 --> 00:09:28,870
That'll probably be my problem there.

178
00:09:28,870 --> 00:09:32,760
So let me jump over to a PowerShell
where I'm running it as an admin,

179
00:09:32,760 --> 00:09:37,230
and we'll see if that works for
us a little bit better here.

180
00:09:38,570 --> 00:09:43,990
And we'll find out here in a moment
whether or not that worked for us.

181
00:09:43,990 --> 00:09:48,810
So, there we go, Start-Service was
perfectly happy receiving that table and

182
00:09:48,810 --> 00:09:49,530
it dealt with it.

183
00:09:49,530 --> 00:09:50,180
Right?

184
00:09:50,180 --> 00:09:52,425
So, I'm gonna go ahead and stop those,

185
00:09:52,425 --> 00:09:54,775
cuz I just don't need them
running during the show.

186
00:09:54,775 --> 00:09:55,785
But there we go.

187
00:09:55,785 --> 00:10:00,395
It's handling that table,
even though it wouldn't normally do that.

188
00:10:00,395 --> 00:10:04,815
Now if I have a command that just
outright won't deal with the table.

189
00:10:04,815 --> 00:10:06,145
I know this one got happy again, but

190
00:10:06,145 --> 00:10:10,305
if it won't deal with the able, then I've
gotta do what I was saying a minute ago.

191
00:10:10,305 --> 00:10:13,935
Run that second command one at at time,
over and over again, and

192
00:10:13,935 --> 00:10:15,330
let it do its job.

193
00:10:15,330 --> 00:10:19,170
For that we have to use another command,
and then here is where we start to

194
00:10:19,170 --> 00:10:23,760
get into a little bit of stuff that
a developer would normally work with.

195
00:10:23,760 --> 00:10:28,890
We have to create what is called a foreach
loop and a foreach loop just says for

196
00:10:28,890 --> 00:10:34,020
each line in our original output do this
command and you're gonna loop through it

197
00:10:34,020 --> 00:10:37,180
over and over and over again until you run
out of lines to run and then you'll stop.

198
00:10:37,180 --> 00:10:38,270
All right.

199
00:10:38,270 --> 00:10:41,030
So, we just have to modify how that works.

200
00:10:41,030 --> 00:10:46,860
As an example, let's see,
what would be a good example for this?

201
00:10:46,860 --> 00:10:47,595
Let's see.

202
00:10:47,595 --> 00:10:48,916
Get-process.

203
00:10:48,916 --> 00:10:54,100
All right, Get-Process will return to me

204
00:10:54,100 --> 00:10:57,760
a list of all the processes running
on my computer right now, okay.

205
00:10:57,760 --> 00:10:59,530
So there's all the processes.

206
00:10:59,530 --> 00:11:01,679
But it returns kind of
a lot of information.

207
00:11:02,980 --> 00:11:05,620
So, I see not just the processes,
like a process name.

208
00:11:05,620 --> 00:11:10,290
I also see their IDs, I can see their
virtual memory, their CPU utilization.

209
00:11:10,290 --> 00:11:14,750
I see tons of information about them,
not just a name.

210
00:11:14,750 --> 00:11:17,460
Well maybe I do just want the name,
and that's all I want.

211
00:11:17,460 --> 00:11:20,450
Well, we'll learn some filter
commands that make that really easy.

212
00:11:20,450 --> 00:11:21,877
But there's another way
that I can pull it.

213
00:11:23,180 --> 00:11:28,430
When you run Get-Process, that command
runs, and this output comes out.

214
00:11:28,430 --> 00:11:32,830
We don't see it, but the output
is actually stored in a variable.

215
00:11:34,000 --> 00:11:39,320
So PowerShell creates a variable
automatically and it's called $_.

216
00:11:39,320 --> 00:11:43,650
It's a temporary variable that's
only around while this command runs.

217
00:11:43,650 --> 00:11:47,350
And when we take the output for
our command, and we feed it into

218
00:11:47,350 --> 00:11:50,270
the next command, the next command's
really just looking for that variable.

219
00:11:50,270 --> 00:11:52,890
It's saying hey,
is there anything in $_ underscore?

220
00:11:52,890 --> 00:11:56,030
And if there is, that's the data
that I'm using as my input.

221
00:11:56,030 --> 00:11:57,680
So that's kinda what
happens in the background.

222
00:11:57,680 --> 00:11:59,260
We don't normally see it.

223
00:11:59,260 --> 00:12:06,040
Well if I wanna pull just the names that
are out of this list, well I could try it.

224
00:12:06,040 --> 00:12:11,570
I could say Get-Process and
I could pipe that into Write-Host,

225
00:12:11,570 --> 00:12:16,070
which is a commandlet that displays
things on your screen, and

226
00:12:16,070 --> 00:12:20,320
I could say $_ .name.

227
00:12:20,320 --> 00:12:26,139
So I'm saying write on my screen
the name value from inside of $_,

228
00:12:26,139 --> 00:12:32,780
that variable that's storing all
the data from my first command.

229
00:12:32,780 --> 00:12:37,280
So whenever you see that $_ it's almost
always used in a pipeline because it's

230
00:12:37,280 --> 00:12:39,870
referencing the output
from the previous command.

231
00:12:39,870 --> 00:12:43,938
Now, this is syntactically correct, but

232
00:12:43,938 --> 00:12:50,275
the problem here is Get-Process
is gonna return a ton of entries.

233
00:12:50,275 --> 00:12:54,540
But Write-Host is expecting one thing.

234
00:12:54,540 --> 00:12:56,790
It's expecting a single string.

235
00:12:56,790 --> 00:12:58,060
I'm about to give it a table.

236
00:12:58,060 --> 00:13:00,110
It's gonna get really upset about that.

237
00:13:00,110 --> 00:13:04,250
And we do $_, that's referring
to the whole table and the name.

238
00:13:04,250 --> 00:13:06,280
Well, there's a name for
all these different processes so

239
00:13:06,280 --> 00:13:09,120
it's not gonna be too happy
about that when I run it.

240
00:13:09,120 --> 00:13:11,220
Here, let's actually run it.

241
00:13:11,220 --> 00:13:12,450
Whoops!

242
00:13:12,450 --> 00:13:13,890
Well, shoot, that wasn't fair.

243
00:13:13,890 --> 00:13:17,300
Let me [LAUGH] so I do it a second time.

244
00:13:17,300 --> 00:13:18,159
Let me do this again.

245
00:13:18,159 --> 00:13:21,190
I added an extra slash there by accident
so let me just get that out of there.

246
00:13:21,190 --> 00:13:22,050
There we go.

247
00:13:22,050 --> 00:13:26,180
So if I run that, I get a ton of errors.

248
00:13:26,180 --> 00:13:27,880
Why am I getting a bunch of errors?

249
00:13:27,880 --> 00:13:32,220
Well, the reason is it's trying
to run this table of data,

250
00:13:32,220 --> 00:13:34,260
which it's not set up to deal with.

251
00:13:34,260 --> 00:13:37,550
And so, that's where it just gets
really upset and it lists it here.

252
00:13:37,550 --> 00:13:41,562
And, if we read the actual error,
you can see right here,

253
00:13:41,562 --> 00:13:46,100
Write-Host : The input object cannot
be bound to any parameters for

254
00:13:46,100 --> 00:13:50,580
the command either because the command
does not take pipeline input or

255
00:13:50,580 --> 00:13:53,400
the input and its properties do not match
the parameters to take pipeline input.

256
00:13:54,430 --> 00:13:55,760
It failed with a pipeline input.

257
00:13:56,840 --> 00:14:00,100
So here's where we can implement one of
these loops that I was talking about.

258
00:14:00,100 --> 00:14:04,418
So to fix this one, what we would
do is modify it a little bit.

259
00:14:04,418 --> 00:14:09,680
Instead of Get-Process and

260
00:14:09,680 --> 00:14:12,880
then going right into Write-Host,
I'm gonna bring in another command.

261
00:14:12,880 --> 00:14:19,250
I'm gonna put in Foreach, whoops,
I'm gonna spell for right.

262
00:14:19,250 --> 00:14:21,580
That'll be the start of success here.

263
00:14:21,580 --> 00:14:27,469
So ForEach-Object and
then in parenthesis or

264
00:14:27,469 --> 00:14:33,811
squiggly parenthesis I'm
gonna say Write-Host

265
00:14:33,811 --> 00:14:38,800
$_ .name and then I'll close that.

266
00:14:39,850 --> 00:14:40,400
Okay.

267
00:14:40,400 --> 00:14:41,750
Oh, I lost my -Object.

268
00:14:41,750 --> 00:14:42,900
Let me go fix that.

269
00:14:42,900 --> 00:14:45,070
Apparently I hit something
on the keyboard there.

270
00:14:45,070 --> 00:14:46,170
There we go.

271
00:14:46,170 --> 00:14:49,760
So what this is gonna say
is the original command

272
00:14:49,760 --> 00:14:51,430
is gonna output more
than one line of data.

273
00:14:51,430 --> 00:14:53,320
I'm gonna have more than one entry.

274
00:14:53,320 --> 00:14:56,935
So, instead of running Write-Host
against the whole thing,

275
00:14:56,935 --> 00:15:02,950
ForEach-Object, for each line in
the original output, run Write-Host once.

276
00:15:02,950 --> 00:15:07,760
So, if I've got 50 processes running, it's
gonna run the Write-Host command 50 times,

277
00:15:08,850 --> 00:15:11,280
one for each line of the original output.

278
00:15:11,280 --> 00:15:15,800
But the cool thing here is that Write-Host
doesn't support multiline input,

279
00:15:15,800 --> 00:15:19,160
now it's getting it one at a time,
it'll be perfectly happy.

280
00:15:19,160 --> 00:15:22,790
And so when I run that,
I get the names of my processes.

281
00:15:22,790 --> 00:15:26,660
It ran successfully, no errors,
and there we go, right?

282
00:15:26,660 --> 00:15:32,690
So slight variation of what we ran before,
right?

283
00:15:32,690 --> 00:15:34,958
So if we take a look at the two commands,

284
00:15:34,958 --> 00:15:40,580
there was Get-Process which I
pipelined into Write-Host and

285
00:15:40,580 --> 00:15:44,690
I used that $_ variable to
specify that input that I wanted.

286
00:15:44,690 --> 00:15:47,465
And the only reason I had to do that
cuz I could have let that off, but

287
00:15:47,465 --> 00:15:50,460
Write-Host would have just written
exactly what Get-Process outputted,

288
00:15:50,460 --> 00:15:52,430
it would have been pointless, right?

289
00:15:52,430 --> 00:15:53,810
But I did the .name.

290
00:15:53,810 --> 00:15:56,640
I was telling it I wanted
that property specifically.

291
00:15:56,640 --> 00:15:58,150
I didn't want all the other properties.

292
00:15:58,150 --> 00:16:00,590
So that's why I had to do the $_.

293
00:16:00,590 --> 00:16:02,640
But that's the one that
generated an error.

294
00:16:02,640 --> 00:16:07,940
When I added the foreach loop in there,
or ForEach-Object, that's

295
00:16:07,940 --> 00:16:11,220
what gave me the ability to run it one at
a time, and the command was successful.

296
00:16:11,220 --> 00:16:15,390
So just slight variation
of the command to do it.

297
00:16:15,390 --> 00:16:17,940
So pretty useful thing when
it comes to pipelining.

298
00:16:17,940 --> 00:16:22,080
You'll find that most of the commands
that you have do support pipelining.

299
00:16:22,080 --> 00:16:24,220
And you'll see it in
the help documentation.

300
00:16:24,220 --> 00:16:30,930
If I pull up the get-help, for
let's say, Restart-Service,

301
00:16:30,930 --> 00:16:35,110
and I'm gonna pull up the full,
when we go in here and

302
00:16:35,110 --> 00:16:38,240
we start to read some of the different
information that it's providing us.

303
00:16:38,240 --> 00:16:42,000
As you scroll through and see all these
parameters, down here under inputs, right?

304
00:16:42,000 --> 00:16:43,710
How do you feed input to it?

305
00:16:43,710 --> 00:16:45,160
Most of the time you'll see system string.

306
00:16:45,160 --> 00:16:46,910
That's us feeding input to it.

307
00:16:46,910 --> 00:16:48,410
But you'll also see this.

308
00:16:48,410 --> 00:16:52,480
You can pipe a service object or
a string that contains objects into it.

309
00:16:52,480 --> 00:16:56,800
So it's letting us know that you can
pipeline things in for this command.

310
00:16:56,800 --> 00:17:00,360
Not every command has that, some of
them don't support pipelining input.

311
00:17:00,360 --> 00:17:01,730
But you'll find the majority of them do.

312
00:17:03,080 --> 00:17:03,730
All right, so

313
00:17:03,730 --> 00:17:07,690
as far as our command pipeline, those are
basically the things we need to remember.

314
00:17:07,690 --> 00:17:11,400
First off that you can pipeline as
many commands in chain as you want.

315
00:17:11,400 --> 00:17:13,770
Eventually it gets really confusing and
overwhelming.

316
00:17:13,770 --> 00:17:17,030
So I find that I don't normally
go beyond like four or five.

317
00:17:17,030 --> 00:17:18,480
But you can keep going.

318
00:17:18,480 --> 00:17:20,540
I'm not even sure if
there is an actual limit.

319
00:17:20,540 --> 00:17:22,530
I've seen some pretty crazy examples.

320
00:17:22,530 --> 00:17:25,607
But you just keep putting that
pipeline character, the pipe,

321
00:17:25,607 --> 00:17:28,743
that two vertical bar symbol in
between each of your commands and

322
00:17:28,743 --> 00:17:31,437
just the output for
one becomes the input for the next.

323
00:17:31,437 --> 00:17:34,907
And it creates a chain reaction
until it gets to the last one and

324
00:17:34,907 --> 00:17:37,660
that's when it displays
output on your screen.

325
00:17:38,890 --> 00:17:41,870
All right.
Now we're gonna see that pipeline through

326
00:17:41,870 --> 00:17:44,930
tons of other segments as we
go through PowerShell because

327
00:17:44,930 --> 00:17:47,840
you can really use it to manipulate
your data and create some cool stuff.

328
00:17:49,180 --> 00:17:52,140
But as far as this one,
that's about it right there.

329
00:17:52,140 --> 00:17:55,280
So in this episode we got a chance
to see how to use the pipeline.

330
00:17:55,280 --> 00:18:00,290
We got to see how to use the $_ variable
and we got to see a little quirk with

331
00:18:00,290 --> 00:18:03,250
some commands where they don't
support multiline input.

332
00:18:03,250 --> 00:18:06,835
And so we saw the ForEach-Object
commandlet that can correct that for

333
00:18:06,835 --> 00:18:10,964
us, allowing us to run that command over
and over and over again to compensate for

334
00:18:10,964 --> 00:18:11,954
multiline input.

335
00:18:11,954 --> 00:18:13,416
So good stuff.

336
00:18:13,416 --> 00:18:16,037
Definitely something you'll end
up using in the real world.

337
00:18:16,037 --> 00:18:20,690
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment, stay
tuned, we got more PowerShell coming up.

338
00:18:20,690 --> 00:18:27,239
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Formatting Command Output
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,006 --> 00:00:04,630
[SOUND] In this segment, we're gonna take

2
00:00:04,630 --> 00:00:09,251
a look at some of the ways
that we can modify

3
00:00:09,251 --> 00:00:14,683
the format of the command
output in PowerShell.

4
00:00:14,683 --> 00:00:18,244
A lot of times you'll find that the way
the output is given to you on the screen

5
00:00:18,244 --> 00:00:19,468
It is not the most useful,

6
00:00:19,468 --> 00:00:23,470
or just isn't in a format that's useful
in the way that you intend it to be.

7
00:00:23,470 --> 00:00:27,050
Microsoft can't anticipate everybody's
use-case scenario, so they try and

8
00:00:27,050 --> 00:00:30,080
create something that's
practical in most environments.

9
00:00:30,080 --> 00:00:31,940
But oftentimes you'll need to modify it.

10
00:00:31,940 --> 00:00:34,980
Fortunately they give us a collection
of tools that let us do that.

11
00:00:34,980 --> 00:00:37,810
And, I'm gonna show you those right now.

12
00:00:37,810 --> 00:00:43,420
So the, first one that I want to talk
about is one that I use quite a bit.

13
00:00:43,420 --> 00:00:48,330
When we run most commands they'll
give you output in a table format.

14
00:00:48,330 --> 00:00:53,680
The only problem is you can't really fit
all that much on a normal computer screen.

15
00:00:53,680 --> 00:00:56,860
So, when it displays that
table there's usually some

16
00:00:56,860 --> 00:00:58,820
pieces that are missing from it.

17
00:00:58,820 --> 00:01:01,350
So, you don't see all
the information that you want.

18
00:01:01,350 --> 00:01:02,950
Let me show you an example.

19
00:01:02,950 --> 00:01:06,882
So here on my PowerShell if I run
get-service It's gonna pull up a list of

20
00:01:06,882 --> 00:01:08,558
the services on my computer and

21
00:01:08,558 --> 00:01:13,270
I'm just gonna pipe that in to the more
command here so it won't go too crazy.

22
00:01:13,270 --> 00:01:18,170
But you'll see it's giving me the status,
the name and the display name.

23
00:01:18,170 --> 00:01:19,640
And that's it.

24
00:01:19,640 --> 00:01:23,519
So I'm just getting three columns
in this table as it's arranged.

25
00:01:24,530 --> 00:01:27,310
But there's other columns
that are available.

26
00:01:27,310 --> 00:01:31,620
There's more data that it just didn't
have room on the screen to put in, right?

27

episodes.title: Script Execution Policies
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,520
[SOUND] In this segment, we're gonna take

2
00:00:05,520 --> 00:00:12,594
a look at
PowerShell's Script Execution Policies.

3
00:00:12,594 --> 00:00:16,603
When you get started with PowerShell, one
of the features that Microsoft promotes

4
00:00:16,603 --> 00:00:18,640
is how easy it is to write scripts.

5
00:00:18,640 --> 00:00:21,650
But you might've noticed that on
most systems, when you try and

6
00:00:21,650 --> 00:00:25,290
run a script, you get an error
telling you access denied.

7
00:00:25,290 --> 00:00:30,370
By default, the majority of systems
out there have the scripting disabled.

8
00:00:30,370 --> 00:00:34,630
And that seems unfortunate, but
it's there to protect you from, well,

9
00:00:34,630 --> 00:00:37,130
not just from yourself,
but from other people too.

10
00:00:37,130 --> 00:00:39,820
So basically Microsoft says,
hey, scripting is great.

11
00:00:39,820 --> 00:00:44,580
It's very powerful, but you probably
don't want it on unless you need it.

12
00:00:44,580 --> 00:00:48,200
So they turn it off by default, and
then it's up to you to go and modify that.

13
00:00:48,200 --> 00:00:50,650
Now, it's really easy to change it.

14
00:00:50,650 --> 00:00:52,210
We just need to know to do it.

15
00:00:52,210 --> 00:00:54,800
We have what are called
script execution policies.

16
00:00:55,940 --> 00:00:59,120
And these are the policies that define
what scripts we're allowed to run.

17
00:00:59,120 --> 00:01:02,280
Microsoft classifies scripts
a few different ways, all right.

18
00:01:02,280 --> 00:01:06,190
There are trusted scripts,
and untrusted scripts.

19
00:01:06,190 --> 00:01:09,110
A trusted script is one
that's been digitally signed.

20
00:01:09,110 --> 00:01:13,510
In other words, whoever wrote the script,
got a digital signature,

21
00:01:13,510 --> 00:01:17,200
a certificate, a private key,
public key pair, that they could then

22
00:01:17,200 --> 00:01:21,120
attach a digital signature to the script,
to show that it hadn't been modified.

23
00:01:21,120 --> 00:01:25,480
That way when you run it, if you trust
whoever issued that certificate,

24
00:01:25,480 --> 00:01:29,870
you'll be able to verify that the script
hasn't been modified, and run it, and

25
00:01:29,870 --> 00:01:33,190
know that it's written to run the way
that it was originally intended, and

26
00:01:33,190 --> 00:01:36,160
somebody hasn't modified
it to add their own code.

27
00:01:36,160 --> 00:01:37,470
That's a great idea, and

28
00:01:37,470 --> 00:01:42,010
it's definitely something that
most people would want, but.

29
00:01:42,010 --> 00:01:44,010
If you're writing your own scripts,

30
00:01:44,010 --> 00:01:48,060
you probably don't necessarily have
a public key infrastructure, or

31
00:01:48,060 --> 00:01:51,070
want to go through the headache of
digitally signing your scripts.

32
00:01:51,070 --> 00:01:54,230
And so,
Microsoft has several different tiers

33
00:01:54,230 --> 00:01:58,750
of other types of scripts that we can run,
and it really comes down to location.

34
00:01:58,750 --> 00:02:02,160
Digitally signed scripts are trusted,
and they're allowed to run.

35
00:02:03,790 --> 00:02:07,952
Untrusted script, scripts that aren't
digitally signed, are not allowed to run,

36
00:02:07,952 --> 00:02:08,950
all right?

37
00:02:08,950 --> 00:02:12,310
And that's the default policy
that you've got in PowerShell.

38
00:02:12,310 --> 00:02:16,540
So when get a script from Microsoft,
for example, it will likely run, but

39
00:02:16,540 --> 00:02:18,740
if you write your own,
it's gonna be blocked.

40
00:02:20,000 --> 00:02:23,960
Now, when we go to adjust the policy,
we can loosen those restrictions a bit.

41
00:02:23,960 --> 00:02:24,850
And we can say, all right,

42
00:02:24,850 --> 00:02:29,370
well, we'll allow the system to run
scripts in certain scenarios, all right.

43
00:02:29,370 --> 00:02:32,850
And those scenarios all boil down
to where the script is stored.

44
00:02:32,850 --> 00:02:36,920
Local scripts are ones that are stored
right there on that machine.

45
00:02:36,920 --> 00:02:38,190
You're saying hey, I wrote a script.

46
00:02:38,190 --> 00:02:41,570
It's stored right here on the machine,
and I wanna run it, all right.

47
00:02:41,570 --> 00:02:44,160
So we might wanna loosen
the policy to say, that's okay.

48
00:02:44,160 --> 00:02:47,400
We'll run digitally signed scripts, and
the ones that we've got locally stored.

49
00:02:48,660 --> 00:02:51,890
But you might have scripts that
are stored on a network share, and

50
00:02:51,890 --> 00:02:53,070
those are not allowed.

51
00:02:53,070 --> 00:02:56,420
So we might have to loosen
the restrictions even more, and say yeah,

52
00:02:56,420 --> 00:03:00,100
we'll allow these untrusted scripts
to run from a network store.

53
00:03:00,100 --> 00:03:01,610
But that's a problem.

54
00:03:01,610 --> 00:03:04,380
Because now if an attacker is
trying to get into your system,

55
00:03:04,380 --> 00:03:06,320
where are their scripts gonna be?

56
00:03:06,320 --> 00:03:07,370
Not locally, right?

57
00:03:07,370 --> 00:03:08,400
They'll be remote.

58
00:03:08,400 --> 00:03:10,650
So that's the exact thing
you don't want to do.

59
00:03:10,650 --> 00:03:14,980
So by adjusting this policy, you're
weakening the security of your server.

60
00:03:14,980 --> 00:03:19,190
Microsoft's recommendation is,
if you're going to be writing scripts,

61
00:03:19,190 --> 00:03:23,110
deploy a public key infrastructure, and
digitally sign all of your scripts.

62
00:03:23,110 --> 00:03:25,730
But most people don't
have that PKI in place.

63
00:03:25,730 --> 00:03:29,210
So the next best thing is,

64
00:03:29,210 --> 00:03:34,520
only run scripts that are digitally
signed or stored locally on that server.

65
00:03:34,520 --> 00:03:37,590
Ones that have been copied to, or
written right on that server, so

66
00:03:37,590 --> 00:03:41,160
that you can verify their
authenticity before you run them.

67
00:03:41,160 --> 00:03:43,180
Let's take a look at those policies now,
and how we can work with them, and

68
00:03:43,180 --> 00:03:44,810
how we can change them, all lright.

69
00:03:44,810 --> 00:03:48,620
First off, you probably want to know what
your execution policy is to start with.

70
00:03:48,620 --> 00:03:54,190
And we've got the get
dash execution policy,

71
00:03:54,190 --> 00:03:59,060
there we go, commandlet and it'll
return what policy we're in right now.

72
00:03:59,060 --> 00:04:03,210
There's four different policies, and for
most people restricted is the default.

73
00:04:03,210 --> 00:04:06,220
I say most,
because depending on who installed server,

74
00:04:06,220 --> 00:04:08,620
they can override that as part
of the installation option.

75
00:04:08,620 --> 00:04:10,240
So it could have been changed or

76
00:04:10,240 --> 00:04:12,950
a group policy object could
change that setting too.

77
00:04:12,950 --> 00:04:16,050
But if you just do a default install
,it's typically going to be restricted,

78
00:04:16,050 --> 00:04:18,460
and that's what I'm in right here.

79
00:04:18,460 --> 00:04:23,170
That means that I will run digitally
signed certificates, I mean scripts and

80
00:04:23,170 --> 00:04:24,620
that's it all right.

81
00:04:24,620 --> 00:04:26,240
I won't run any others.

82
00:04:26,240 --> 00:04:29,230
So for example i've written
a script here on my desktop.

83
00:04:30,420 --> 00:04:31,135
And there it is.

84
00:04:31,135 --> 00:04:31,880
Customize.ps1.

85
00:04:31,880 --> 00:04:36,470
This is a script that I tote around
that customizes my user interface.

86
00:04:36,470 --> 00:04:39,220
I'm not a big fan of the whole
blue background, and

87
00:04:39,220 --> 00:04:40,260
white text and all that stuff.

88
00:04:40,260 --> 00:04:43,990
So I manipulate it, and I just have
a little script that does that for me.

89
00:04:43,990 --> 00:04:50,518
So if I try and run that script,
I get an error, all right.

90
00:04:50,518 --> 00:04:52,010
In the error a script cannot be loaded,

00:04:52,010 --> 00:04:54,600
because running scripts is
disabled on this system.

92
00:04:54,600 --> 00:04:59,250
For more information, see about
execution policy at blah,blah,blah.

93
00:04:59,250 --> 00:05:01,200
And so it's telling me to go enroute.

94
00:05:01,200 --> 00:05:06,620
Well I can change that execution policy
to allow for the scripts to run.

00:05:06,620 --> 00:05:10,520
The command that we use for that,
is the set execution policy.

96
00:05:10,520 --> 00:05:14,260
And if we pull up our help
documentation on it, it's just,

97
00:05:14,260 --> 00:05:17,180
set execution dash policy.

98
00:05:17,180 --> 00:05:21,370
It will give you the basic command syntax
for it, In the four different levels.

99
00:05:21,370 --> 00:05:24,740
Which actually it doesn't list
the four different levels, does it?

100
00:05:24,740 --> 00:05:27,030
Well anyhow,
let's do the full output here, and

101
00:05:27,030 --> 00:05:32,240
see if it's included in the notes.

102
00:05:32,240 --> 00:05:33,630
Well there's really just four levels.

103
00:05:33,630 --> 00:05:35,430
Right?
Restricted is the default.

104
00:05:35,430 --> 00:05:35,950
Okay.
There are.

105
00:05:35,950 --> 00:05:36,870
All four of them.

106
00:05:36,870 --> 00:05:38,820
So, restricted is that default.

107
00:05:38,820 --> 00:05:41,390
And, here they just call
it all all signed, but

108
00:05:41,390 --> 00:05:45,660
if I move up a little bit,
there we go, there's restricted.

109
00:05:45,660 --> 00:05:50,000
So restricted, and that means we're not
going to let any scripts run whatsoever.

110
00:05:50,000 --> 00:05:53,390
Restricted here we're actually
disabling all the scripts.

111
00:05:53,390 --> 00:05:58,440
All sign now we're saying, we'll let those
digitally signed ones run, but any non

112
00:05:58,440 --> 00:06:01,330
digitally signed ones or untrusted ones,
we're not going to let those run at all.

113
00:06:02,390 --> 00:06:05,230
After that we start to get
into some of the weaker ones.

114
00:06:05,230 --> 00:06:06,620
And the main ones that
we're going to deal with,

115
00:06:06,620 --> 00:06:10,326
are these next two,
remote signed and unrestricted.

116
00:06:10,326 --> 00:06:15,620
The remote signed says,
I will allow digitally signed scripts,

117
00:06:15,620 --> 00:06:18,450
whether they are local or
remote, i'll allow those to run.

118
00:06:19,860 --> 00:06:25,090
But, if it's remote and
it's not signed, I won't let it run.

119
00:06:25,090 --> 00:06:27,370
So if it's remote it's gotta be signed.

120
00:06:27,370 --> 00:06:30,980
If it's local,
it doesn't have to be signed.

121
00:06:30,980 --> 00:06:33,760
Remote signed's what most
people switch to, because they

122
00:06:33,760 --> 00:06:37,220
want to make sure remote scripts don't
run unless they're digitally signed, but

123
00:06:37,220 --> 00:06:39,540
locally they want to allow them,
all right?

124
00:06:39,540 --> 00:06:43,270
And they can do that and allow that, and
then you'll have that certificate, or

125
00:06:43,270 --> 00:06:47,660
you'll have that script that you can run,
without having to digitally sign it.

126
00:06:47,660 --> 00:06:49,660
The next one is unrestricted though,
and that's the worst one.

127
00:06:49,660 --> 00:06:51,420
And that's where we say we don't care.

128
00:06:51,420 --> 00:06:54,100
We'll run scripts from wherever,
who cares right.

129
00:06:54,100 --> 00:06:57,470
And that'll run, and
now you open yourself up to vulnerability,

130
00:06:57,470 --> 00:07:00,485
cuz somebody could have modified
that script, and you won't know.

131
00:07:00,485 --> 00:07:02,735
You've got no way to verify that
modifications haven't been made.

132
00:07:03,865 --> 00:07:05,705
So, those are the main ones that we go to.

133
00:07:05,705 --> 00:07:08,395
There's a few others like bypass,
all right.

134
00:07:08,395 --> 00:07:11,355
Bypass basically just shuts
off the polices all together.

135
00:07:11,355 --> 00:07:13,605
Which is very much like unrestricted.

136
00:07:13,605 --> 00:07:17,080
And then undefined means
we don't have a policy.

137
00:07:17,080 --> 00:07:18,360
You're not normally
going to have that one,

138
00:07:18,360 --> 00:07:21,270
that would be something like in a group
policy object ,when you say undefined,

139
00:07:21,270 --> 00:07:23,510
and it would leave it up to the client
to make their own decision.

140
00:07:23,510 --> 00:07:27,910
So those are some of the different
values that we'll see.

141
00:07:27,910 --> 00:07:31,902
But the four main ones are,
restricted, remote signed,

142
00:07:31,902 --> 00:07:35,330
unrestricted, and
that all signed right there.

143
00:07:36,620 --> 00:07:38,780
All right.
So how does this affect us?

144
00:07:38,780 --> 00:07:41,020
Well, I couldn't run
that script a moment ago,

145
00:07:41,020 --> 00:07:44,520
because I'm not allowing
my locally signed one.

146
00:07:44,520 --> 00:07:45,070
All right?

147
00:07:45,070 --> 00:07:46,730
Or my locally unsigned ones.

148
00:07:46,730 --> 00:07:49,910
So, I might wanna change to remote signed.

149
00:07:49,910 --> 00:07:51,920
I don't wanna run remote ones
unless they're digitally signed,

150
00:07:51,920 --> 00:07:52,850
but local is okay.

151
00:07:52,850 --> 00:07:53,600
I wanna allow it.
All right?

152
00:07:54,680 --> 00:07:57,510
Well, let me just switch over
to a PowerShell that was run

153
00:07:57,510 --> 00:07:59,290
as an administrator,
which is not this one.

154
00:08:00,560 --> 00:08:02,700
I guess, let me launch
a PowerShell as an administrator.

155
00:08:04,550 --> 00:08:05,980
All right.
And I'm gonna do

156
00:08:05,980 --> 00:08:11,750
the Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned,
right?

157
00:08:11,750 --> 00:08:13,190
I'm gonna flip it so

158
00:08:13,190 --> 00:08:18,460
that I'm going to allow local scripts
to run, even if they're not signed.

159
00:08:18,460 --> 00:08:19,420
All right.

160
00:08:19,420 --> 00:08:24,280
Now if I go back to my other PowerShell
When I tried to run that script just

161
00:08:24,280 --> 00:08:26,380
a moment ago I got the big error,

162
00:08:26,380 --> 00:08:28,800
this guy right here where it
told me I wasn't allowed.

163
00:08:28,800 --> 00:08:34,700
Well now I'm gonna rerun that command,
I'm gonna rerun it, and this time it ran.

164
00:08:35,966 --> 00:08:39,540
All right, it ran and now I've got my
green text with the black background,

165
00:08:39,540 --> 00:08:42,390
that I like so much, and
it's laid out right here, and

166
00:08:42,390 --> 00:08:44,330
it's got everything I need, all right.

167
00:08:44,330 --> 00:08:47,142
So, it let me run that script now,
because we're in that remote signed mode.

168
00:08:47,142 --> 00:08:50,530
All right now,
what if I didn't run it from here?

169
00:08:51,780 --> 00:08:54,260
What if I ran it from
a network location instead?

170
00:08:56,702 --> 00:09:00,370
All right, well I copied that
over to a map network drive, and

00:09:00,370 --> 00:09:06,190
if I go over here and run it,
I still get a failure.

172
00:09:06,190 --> 00:09:08,430
That's the same exact
script I ran a moment ago.

00:09:08,430 --> 00:09:11,880
The difference is the script I ran

00:09:11,880 --> 00:09:15,130
right on the local system,
this one is on a mapped drive.

175
00:09:15,130 --> 00:09:18,730
X colon, I mapped that here to
another server here in the office, and

00:09:18,730 --> 00:09:22,980
it's telling me that it can't run, and
that's because of my execution policy.

177
00:09:22,980 --> 00:09:26,245
It's not allowed to run because it's
remote, and it's not digitally signed.

178
00:09:29,010 --> 00:09:29,810
All right.

179
00:09:29,810 --> 00:09:32,930
If I go and
I switch my policy to unrestricted,

00:09:32,930 --> 00:09:35,310
which is a really bad idea,
but we'll do it.

00:09:37,280 --> 00:09:39,700
Right, so
I'll switch over to unrestricted,

00:09:39,700 --> 00:09:45,290
now I can run scripts from wherever, and
if I jump back over here, I can try and

00:09:45,290 --> 00:09:50,040
run the script from my network share,
and now it's just giving me a warning.

184
00:09:51,250 --> 00:09:54,230
And I can say, see in that warning
right there, that's actually the,

00:09:54,230 --> 00:09:55,960
actually I need to say r for run.

00:09:55,960 --> 00:10:01,210
That's the difference between

When you say unrestricted,

00:10:04,010 --> 00:10:06,920
Bypass you're disabling the check so

00:10:06,920 --> 00:10:08,060
The difference is this warning.

00:10:08,060 --> 00:10:10,620
If you have bypass you

00:10:10,620 --> 00:10:14,350
So when I do this, I'll just hit Run Once,

00:10:14,350 --> 00:10:16,690

00:10:16,690 --> 00:10:20,710
So nice little set of security policies,

00:10:20,710 --> 00:10:24,020
very easy to modify,
it's the default that trips people up.

195
00:10:24,020 --> 00:10:26,640
I've heard from people where they said,

00:10:26,640 --> 00:10:28,880
me, it won't run my scripts.

And I say well what

Sometimes it tells you what's going on,

00:10:58,410 --> 00:10:58,980
All right.

So those are the execution policies

But for our database scripting,

00:11:41,090 --> 00:11:41,830
All right.

00:11:41,830 --> 00:11:43,150
If you're not running

you don't need to leave the policies

00:11:46,420 --> 00:11:49,230
So, you've got options with
how you wanna manipulate that,

00:11:49,230 --> 00:11:50,420
just remember that you can.

00:11:50,420 --> 00:11:52,450
You have the different options
that are available to you,

226
00:11:52,450 --> 00:11:54,230
and pick the one that meets your needs.

227
00:11:55,430 --> 00:11:58,420
All right, so in this segment, we got
a chance to take a look at the execution

policies that are a part of PowerShell,
and

00:12:00,580 --> 00:12:04,545
how they influence us

230
00:12:04,545 --> 00:12:10,285
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

231
00:12:10,285 --> 00:12:14,285
Stay tuned, we've got more

a lot of fonts have variable widths for
letters.

00:26:33,150 --> 00:26:37,710
it dictates exactly what's going to be on
our prompt, and it's got some links to

512
00:26:37,710 --> 00:26:40,620
Microsoft's page to help you a bit,
but let me just show you how it works.

513
00:26:40,620 --> 00:26:44,400
In my script,
I'm actually overriding my prompt and

514
00:26:44,400 --> 00:26:48,620
changing it, and so what I'm doing is
I'm basically saying the prompt as it is

515
00:26:48,620 --> 00:26:51,640
doesn't necessarily have all the stuff
that I want, so I'm going to change it.

516
00:26:51,640 --> 00:26:57,130
So, I call function Prompt,
and then squiggly brackets.

517
00:26:57,130 --> 00:27:00,190
Once you get in the squiggly brackets,

518
00:27:00,190 --> 00:27:04,060
anything that you put between
will become your new prompt.

519
00:27:04,060 --> 00:27:06,980
And that will replace the existing prompt.

520
00:27:06,980 --> 00:27:08,490
And because it's a squiggly bracket or

521
00:27:08,490 --> 00:27:11,210
curly bracket,
you can put all sorts of things in there.

522
00:27:11,210 --> 00:27:14,680
You can call other commandlets to
generate whatever's gonna be represented.

523
00:27:16,200 --> 00:27:20,260
When they run it, they're just doing
a little text field that says PS and

524
00:27:20,260 --> 00:27:24,271
they're doing a, I believe it's
Get-Location that pulls the path.

525
00:27:24,271 --> 00:27:26,093
Let me just verify that.

526
00:27:26,093 --> 00:27:28,090
Yeah, get-location.

527
00:27:28,090 --> 00:27:30,776
So, when you run get-location,
that pulls the path you're on.

528
00:27:30,776 --> 00:27:31,752
So, that's all they're doing.

529
00:27:31,752 --> 00:27:36,627
They're saying display the text PS and
a space and then run Get-Location and

530
00:27:36,627 --> 00:27:37,692
put the path in.

531
00:27:37,692 --> 00:27:40,180
Then stick a greater than sign on the end.

532
00:27:40,180 --> 00:27:42,040
Right, that's the default prompt.

533
00:27:42,040 --> 00:27:50,120
But we could say function
prompt { This is my prompt,

534
00:27:53,040 --> 00:27:57,430
like that and well oh shoot,
I wasn't syntactically correct so

535
00:27:57,430 --> 00:28:00,410
it's just dropped it to have that
basic PS at the very beginning.

536
00:28:00,410 --> 00:28:05,670
I probably need to change this
to be more of a Write-Host.

537
00:28:05,670 --> 00:28:10,010
And then put that in parentheses,
or in quotation marks, there we go.

538
00:28:10,010 --> 00:28:10,570
There.

539
00:28:10,570 --> 00:28:14,010
So now, every time I press enter, see how
it's showing me, this is my prompt and

540
00:28:14,010 --> 00:28:17,640
then I get the PS so
I can put whatever I want in there.

541
00:28:17,640 --> 00:28:19,300
To be able to do that.

542
00:28:19,300 --> 00:28:23,180
Well, we have to be a little bit careful,
notice that my prompt,

543
00:28:23,180 --> 00:28:27,040
if I clear my screen my prompt
is now two lines, right.

544
00:28:27,040 --> 00:28:29,900
I get this is my prompt,
followed by the actual prompt, and

545
00:28:29,900 --> 00:28:31,830
then I can start typing my command.

546
00:28:31,830 --> 00:28:35,180
And there's no space after PS.

547
00:28:35,180 --> 00:28:38,070
So I get PS>, and
then I'm immediately typing my command.

548
00:28:38,070 --> 00:28:39,610
And that can be a little confusing.

549
00:28:39,610 --> 00:28:42,410
So we normally do want to
apply a little bit of finesse.

550
00:28:42,410 --> 00:28:44,610
When we start to modify that prompt.

551
00:28:44,610 --> 00:28:46,460
And let me just show
you the one that I use.

552
00:28:46,460 --> 00:28:48,830
So, let's pull it up here.

553
00:28:48,830 --> 00:28:49,800
There we go.

554
00:28:49,800 --> 00:28:54,270
So the one that I use, I go into
function prompt, and I say Write-Host.

555
00:28:54,270 --> 00:28:56,330
I go ahead and leave the PS there,

556
00:28:56,330 --> 00:28:59,350
because I do like to remember
that I'm in the PowerShell.

557
00:28:59,350 --> 00:29:02,170
And then, I display a square bracket.

558
00:29:02,170 --> 00:29:05,590
And in side of that, get-date, all right?

559
00:29:05,590 --> 00:29:10,650
The reason I do get-date is, a lot of
times I will copy the stuff that I've run

560
00:29:10,650 --> 00:29:14,300
and paste it places, and
I want to remember when I did that, right?

561
00:29:14,300 --> 00:29:15,740
So I use get-date.

562
00:29:15,740 --> 00:29:18,390
You could do other things,
like get-location and

563
00:29:18,390 --> 00:29:20,380
you'd have your path in there, right?

564
00:29:20,380 --> 00:29:23,048
And it would just be separated out
by these square brackets that I've

565
00:29:23,048 --> 00:29:24,180
stuck around it.

566
00:29:24,180 --> 00:29:24,810
Right?

567
00:29:24,810 --> 00:29:26,970
And then I have that
closing greater than sign.

568
00:29:26,970 --> 00:29:29,100
But I could leave that
off if I didn't want it.

569
00:29:29,100 --> 00:29:31,400
Or maybe I wanted a colon instead.

570
00:29:31,400 --> 00:29:34,200
Right?
Maybe you're coming from the Cisco

571
00:29:34,200 --> 00:29:34,820
world or whatever.

572
00:29:34,820 --> 00:29:38,560
And you wanna have a colon or
a pound symbol or whatever.

573
00:29:38,560 --> 00:29:41,350
You could specify whatever
variation you wanted right there.

574
00:29:41,350 --> 00:29:42,400
It'll be perfectly happy with it.

575
00:29:43,470 --> 00:29:45,680
But it's what comes next
that's kind of important.

576
00:29:45,680 --> 00:29:49,020
If you're using Write-Host
to display text on screen,

577
00:29:49,020 --> 00:29:53,160
you probably wanna add
-NoNewLine to the end.

578
00:29:53,160 --> 00:29:57,510
That way your prompt is just on one
line instead of two or three or four,

579
00:29:57,510 --> 00:29:58,580
depending on what all you've run.

580
00:30:00,700 --> 00:30:03,400
I'm also changing the foreground
color of my prompt.

581
00:30:03,400 --> 00:30:06,590
I didn't have to do that, but I'm doing it
here just to show you guys as an example.

582
00:30:06,590 --> 00:30:09,050
So I want my prompt to be in cyan.

583
00:30:09,050 --> 00:30:14,060
My regular text is gonna be green, this
will be in cyan, very easy to tell the two

584
00:30:14,060 --> 00:30:17,420
apart, so I'll know when I'm looking
at a prompt versus my actual command.

585
00:30:19,010 --> 00:30:24,526
And then I'm using the return function
to return a space at the end.

586
00:30:24,526 --> 00:30:27,520
It's a good idea to have a space
to separate your commands out

587
00:30:27,520 --> 00:30:28,410
from the prompt.

588
00:30:28,410 --> 00:30:30,610
And so I'm just saying return and

589
00:30:30,610 --> 00:30:34,550
a space surrounded by quote marks there,
just to let it know to fill that in.

590
00:30:34,550 --> 00:30:36,720
And then I close it out, all right.

591
00:30:36,720 --> 00:30:41,490
So this is what I use, and
I'm just going to copy that and

592
00:30:41,490 --> 00:30:43,790
we'll paste that right
here into our prompt.

593
00:30:46,120 --> 00:30:48,400
All right, and there's my new prompt.

594
00:30:48,400 --> 00:30:51,810
I've got PS still, so
I know I'm in Powershell.

595
00:30:51,810 --> 00:30:53,340
And I see the date written out.

596
00:30:53,340 --> 00:30:55,890
And I could modify get-date
to show just time or

597
00:30:55,890 --> 00:30:58,020
whatever if you really
wanted to manipulate that.

598
00:30:58,020 --> 00:31:01,460
I then see a colon, and
now I can start to type my commands.

599
00:31:01,460 --> 00:31:03,015
And so I can do Get-Help.

600
00:31:03,015 --> 00:31:06,093
Or Get-Member,all right.

601
00:31:06,093 --> 00:31:08,240
And I can start to pull up my help.

602
00:31:08,240 --> 00:31:09,750
My foreground is in green.

603
00:31:09,750 --> 00:31:14,970
My background is in black and my prompt
is customized the way I want it and

604
00:31:14,970 --> 00:31:16,580
I'm ready to rock.

605
00:31:16,580 --> 00:31:18,830
So pretty straight forward.

606
00:31:18,830 --> 00:31:20,350
Pretty easy to do.

607
00:31:20,350 --> 00:31:25,520
Now, in my little example here,
I have all those various settings.

608
00:31:25,520 --> 00:31:26,680
I changed the buffer size.

609
00:31:26,680 --> 00:31:27,690
I changed the scroll back.

610
00:31:27,690 --> 00:31:28,950
I changed the window size.

611
00:31:28,950 --> 00:31:30,490
I changed the coloring.

612
00:31:30,490 --> 00:31:31,970
All of that, all right?

613
00:31:31,970 --> 00:31:34,520
And we just saw,
going ahead and applying it but

614
00:31:34,520 --> 00:31:37,650
there's one problem with
what were doing here.

615
00:31:37,650 --> 00:31:40,760
Watch what happens if
I close my PowerShell.

616
00:31:40,760 --> 00:31:46,795
So if I close my PowerShell and I open it
again, well, some of the setting stayed.

617
00:31:46,795 --> 00:31:47,945
Some didn't.

618
00:31:47,945 --> 00:31:51,535
My coloring stayed, but
my window size is gone.

619
00:31:51,535 --> 00:31:53,555
My window size is gone.

620
00:31:53,555 --> 00:31:55,665
My scroll back buffer is gone.

621
00:31:55,665 --> 00:31:57,845
My prompt is gone.

622
00:31:57,845 --> 00:32:01,860
Not every setting survives closing
the window and opening it again.

623
00:32:01,860 --> 00:32:04,720
In fact, here, it's really just that
foreground and background that stayed.

624
00:32:04,720 --> 00:32:07,930
Everything else has
reverted back to default.

625
00:32:07,930 --> 00:32:08,750
All right?

626
00:32:08,750 --> 00:32:12,260
So, if we want these commands
to always be present,

627
00:32:12,260 --> 00:32:15,890
we probably want to stick them
in our PowerShell profile.

628
00:32:17,170 --> 00:32:20,487
Now we haven't talked about
PowerShell profiles yet, but

629
00:32:20,487 --> 00:32:22,609
when you launch a PowerShell window,

630
00:32:22,609 --> 00:32:27,273
those default settings have to come from
somewhere, and they come from a profile.

631
00:32:27,273 --> 00:32:31,737
And there's actually four different
profiles that are available depending on

632
00:32:31,737 --> 00:32:32,740
your need.

633
00:32:32,740 --> 00:32:35,440
And so it's definitely something
that we need to address, but

634
00:32:35,440 --> 00:32:39,420
I wanna separate that out
into another segment.

635
00:32:39,420 --> 00:32:43,450
So, what we really need to do is once
we figured out our customizations,

636
00:32:43,450 --> 00:32:47,510
we need to take them and
put them into our profile.

637
00:32:47,510 --> 00:32:50,690
And that's going to make it
survive session after session.

638
00:32:50,690 --> 00:32:52,900
You'll be able to close your window and
open it again and

639
00:32:52,900 --> 00:32:55,870
it will always be set
the way that you want.

640
00:32:55,870 --> 00:33:00,060
So if you're watching these PowerShell
episodes in order, stay tuned.

641
00:33:00,060 --> 00:33:03,280
The very next one we're going to show
those profiles and how they work.

642
00:33:03,280 --> 00:33:06,060
If you're watching them out
of order that's fine too,

643
00:33:06,060 --> 00:33:10,070
just jump over to the profile one and I'll
show you right in there how to save this

644
00:33:10,070 --> 00:33:14,360
into your profile so that your
customizations will always be there.

645
00:33:14,360 --> 00:33:17,870
So, in this segment, we got a chance
to see how to customize the appearance

646
00:33:17,870 --> 00:33:19,740
of our power shell using the GUI,

647
00:33:19,740 --> 00:33:23,290
which was really easy, and then we got
to see how to do it programatically.

648
00:33:23,290 --> 00:33:26,520
It was a little more complex, but you
had more power and additional features,

649
00:33:26,520 --> 00:33:29,430
like changing the prompt,
which are really nice.

650
00:33:29,430 --> 00:33:32,050
Simple customizations to make
the PowerShell a more friendly

651
00:33:32,050 --> 00:33:32,930
environment for us.

652
00:33:32,930 --> 00:33:35,610
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

653
00:33:35,610 --> 00:33:38,072
Stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up.

654

episodes.title: PowerShell Profiles
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,445 --> 00:00:08,361
[SOUND]
In

2
00:00:08,361 --> 00:00:12,030
this segment we're gonna take
a look at PowerShell user profiles.

3
00:00:12,030 --> 00:00:16,041
I know in some of our other segments I've
mentioned how we can put changes into

4
00:00:16,041 --> 00:00:19,067
effect in PowerShell and
then when we close PowerShell and

5
00:00:19,067 --> 00:00:21,750
open it again those changes are gone.

6
00:00:21,750 --> 00:00:26,500
And the way that we prevent that, the way
that we get settings to stay present from

7
00:00:26,500 --> 00:00:29,880
session to session,
is by putting them into a profile.

8
00:00:29,880 --> 00:00:33,220
A profile is simply a,
well it's a file, is really a script,

9
00:00:33,220 --> 00:00:37,740
it's a PowerShell script, that runs
every time you launch PowerShell.

10
00:00:37,740 --> 00:00:39,860
And these are happening in the background
and you don't even know it.

11
00:00:39,860 --> 00:00:45,400
When you launch PowerShell, there's
actually four different scripts that run

12
00:00:45,400 --> 00:00:47,870
to make the console prompt that you see,

13
00:00:47,870 --> 00:00:52,230
to set things the way that you
want them when you get in there.

14
00:00:52,230 --> 00:00:53,700
Why four scripts?

15
00:00:53,700 --> 00:00:55,865
Well there's different types.

16
00:00:55,865 --> 00:00:58,838
For example they're actually
divided into two categories.

17
00:00:58,838 --> 00:01:03,596
There are some profiles that run just for
you, the user, and

18
00:01:03,596 --> 00:01:09,580
there are other profiles that run for
everybody, it's global.

19
00:01:09,580 --> 00:01:12,890
And there's scripts that run just for
user accounts,

20
00:01:12,890 --> 00:01:18,290
like yourself, and there's scripts that
run for user accounts and programs.

21
00:01:18,290 --> 00:01:21,310
Right, remember that you're not the only
person that can use the PowerShell.

22
00:01:21,310 --> 00:01:23,520
A lot of other programs will too.

23
00:01:23,520 --> 00:01:25,827
Microsoft Exchange is
a great example of that.

24
00:01:25,827 --> 00:01:29,242
In Microsoft Exchange if you
launch the GUI and you go in and

25
00:01:29,242 --> 00:01:32,240
you right click on a mailbox and
you choose delete,

26
00:01:32,240 --> 00:01:36,512
well, it doesn't actually just go and
delete it through a direct call.

27
00:01:36,512 --> 00:01:40,532
It actually calls the PowerShell, and it
runs the, I think it's remove-mailbox, or

28
00:01:40,532 --> 00:01:43,540
something like that, to remove
the mailbox and get out of there.

29
00:01:43,540 --> 00:01:45,880
So it's using the PowerShell too.

30
00:01:45,880 --> 00:01:48,043
So when you set one of
these scripts to run,

31
00:01:48,043 --> 00:01:51,290
you may not want it to run when
Exchange is using the PowerShell,

32
00:01:51,290 --> 00:01:54,137
you just want it to run when
users to use the PowerShell.

33
00:01:54,137 --> 00:01:58,032
So Microsoft understands that and
they've given us the ability

34
00:01:58,032 --> 00:02:01,795
to define four different scripts
to impact how that happens.

35
00:02:01,795 --> 00:02:05,130
All right, let me show you
the scripts before we dive in.

36
00:02:05,130 --> 00:02:09,340
So, I just have a Notepad window here
where I threw the script files in.

37
00:02:09,340 --> 00:02:13,650
So, each of them are kinda just listed
here based on who they apply to.

38
00:02:13,650 --> 00:02:17,510
So you'll see that we have some
scripts that apply to All Users.

39
00:02:17,510 --> 00:02:21,680
And we have other scripts that
just apply to the Current User.

40
00:02:21,680 --> 00:02:24,600
And then we have scripts
that apply to users and

41
00:02:24,600 --> 00:02:27,750
shells versus ones that
just apply to users.

42
00:02:27,750 --> 00:02:31,052
Now users/shells, that shells part,
that means programs.

43
00:02:31,052 --> 00:02:37,506
So if any program calls up a shell to run
a command these will affect that too.

44
00:02:37,506 --> 00:02:41,877
So when I'm creating a script, maybe I
have a script that changes my foreground

45
00:02:41,877 --> 00:02:46,331
and background color, changes my window
size, personalization stuff for me.

46
00:02:46,331 --> 00:02:48,919
Well, for me that's great.

47
00:02:48,919 --> 00:02:52,520
I want that to go on my
current user profile.

48
00:02:52,520 --> 00:02:55,650
But Exchange doesn't need to do that.

49
00:02:55,650 --> 00:02:57,940
It doesn't care about the color
of the command prompt.

50
00:02:57,940 --> 00:03:01,110
It doesn't care about the window size,
it's running in the background,

51
00:03:01,110 --> 00:03:03,640
we don't even see the window so
who cares what color it is.

52
00:03:03,640 --> 00:03:07,330
So I wouldn't want to put
that in Current Users/Shells,

53
00:03:07,330 --> 00:03:10,270
I'd want it to just go in
my own individual user.

54
00:03:10,270 --> 00:03:14,638
If I wanted all of my users to
have this same color layout and

55
00:03:14,638 --> 00:03:18,036
screen size,
I could put it under All Users.

56
00:03:18,036 --> 00:03:22,550
Or, if I had a change that I wanted to put
in place in PowerShell that I wanted to

57
00:03:22,550 --> 00:03:26,510
affect every single thing that uses
the PowerShell no matter what,

58
00:03:26,510 --> 00:03:29,794
I would put it under the All Users/Shells,
all right.

59
00:03:29,794 --> 00:03:33,877
So that's why we have these four
different profiles, so we can pick and

60
00:03:33,877 --> 00:03:35,590
choose where the stuff goes.

61
00:03:36,710 --> 00:03:40,581
Now the profiles themselves are just
stored in PowerShell scripts.

62
00:03:40,581 --> 00:03:43,844
So you'll see down here
where I've got Profile.ps1.

63
00:03:43,844 --> 00:03:46,350
Or Power-Shell_profile.ps1.

64
00:03:46,350 --> 00:03:49,194
These are the files that are stored in it.

65
00:03:49,194 --> 00:03:55,398
And ps1 those are just, well those
are Microsoft PowerShell scripts.

66
00:03:55,398 --> 00:03:57,872
ps1 stands for PowerShell version 1.0.

67
00:03:57,872 --> 00:04:00,370
I'm running 4.0, they're still called ps1.

68
00:04:00,370 --> 00:04:01,890
That's just kinda how it is.

69
00:04:01,890 --> 00:04:05,934
So you'll see that kinda layout sometimes,
it's a little bit odd.

70
00:04:05,934 --> 00:04:09,050
I've got some stray hyphens in here,
I'm gonna get rid of those.

71
00:04:09,050 --> 00:04:10,494
That'll cause some problems.

72
00:04:10,494 --> 00:04:14,829
All right, so basically those
are what are going to help me to

73
00:04:14,829 --> 00:04:18,450
define what runs under what scenarios.

74
00:04:18,450 --> 00:04:23,012
If it's something like my own
personal user customizations, font,

75
00:04:23,012 --> 00:04:26,400
color, the prompt,

76
00:04:26,400 --> 00:04:30,360
the actual value of the window size, that
stuff I'm going to put under current user.

77
00:04:30,360 --> 00:04:33,510
And so
I'm going to browse into my user profile.

78
00:04:33,510 --> 00:04:35,590
And in my user profile
inside of Documents,

79
00:04:35,590 --> 00:04:37,570
I'll have a folder called
Windows PowerShell.

80
00:04:37,570 --> 00:04:41,548
And inside that Windows PowerShell folder,
I'll have a file called

81
00:04:41,548 --> 00:04:45,604
Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1, and
that's gonna be it.

82
00:04:45,604 --> 00:04:49,694
I'll see that file, and that's the script
that's gonna run when my system runs.

83
00:04:49,694 --> 00:04:54,010
Now, if I go and look for
that right now, I may not have it.

84
00:04:54,010 --> 00:04:56,114
A lot of these profiles don't exist, and

85
