00:17:10,993 --> 00:17:15,063
When it launches, it normally
launches to your user profile, so

311
00:17:15,063 --> 00:17:17,291
it would be C:\User\DonPezet.

312
00:17:17,291 --> 00:17:22,531
But now if I do a Get-Location,
I can see that I'm in C:\.

313
00:17:22,531 --> 00:17:23,112
Right?

314
00:17:23,112 --> 00:17:25,416
I didn't put that in my prompt,
so I don't see it there.

315
00:17:25,416 --> 00:17:30,548
But I am now in C:/, and
I can start working right from there.

316
00:17:30,548 --> 00:17:31,129
All right.

317
00:17:31,129 --> 00:17:33,135
So, neat little customizations like that.

318
00:17:33,135 --> 00:17:35,525
And they'll now stay as
part of your profile.

319
00:17:35,525 --> 00:17:37,075
So, very cool stuff.

320
00:17:37,075 --> 00:17:39,695
Yeah, that's really about it.

321
00:17:39,695 --> 00:17:41,955
Oh, a couple little caveats,
things to remember.

322
00:17:43,085 --> 00:17:47,032
First, the user profile, it is a script.

323
00:17:47,032 --> 00:17:47,589
All right?

324
00:17:47,589 --> 00:17:48,529
It's a ps1 file.

325
00:17:48,529 --> 00:17:49,752
It's a script.

326
00:17:49,752 --> 00:17:53,125
So, remember your script execution policy.

327
00:17:53,125 --> 00:17:56,248
If you haven't watched it, we filmed
a segment on script execution policies.

328
00:17:56,248 --> 00:17:59,729
And if yours is set to restricted,
which is the default,

329
00:17:59,729 --> 00:18:01,769
scripts aren't allowed to run.

330
00:18:01,769 --> 00:18:03,801
So when you go to launch your PowerShell,

331
00:18:03,801 --> 00:18:06,192
the PowerShell profiles
actually don't work.

332
00:18:06,192 --> 00:18:10,499
In restricted mode PowerShell
profiles won't run, all right.

333
00:18:10,499 --> 00:18:15,261
If you've put it in remote signed well,
the local scripts are allowed to run and

334
00:18:15,261 --> 00:18:17,630
now your profiles will work.

335
00:18:17,630 --> 00:18:24,430
So, if you have configured this and
you find that it's not working, right.

336
00:18:24,430 --> 00:18:27,390
So, if I come in here and

337
00:18:27,390 --> 00:18:32,581
I do Set-ExecutionPolicy Restricted.

338
00:18:32,581 --> 00:18:34,450
All right, so
I'm just going to change that.

339
00:18:34,450 --> 00:18:37,056
All right, so
now I'm gonna launch my PowerShell.

340
00:18:37,056 --> 00:18:40,880
And I immediately get an error and
none of my settings took effect.

341
00:18:40,880 --> 00:18:42,270
It's cuz the script wasn't allowed to run.

342
00:18:43,300 --> 00:18:47,030
So be aware of that, you do need to
allow scripts to run in order for

343
00:18:47,030 --> 00:18:48,690
the profiles to work.

344
00:18:48,690 --> 00:18:50,590
Otherwise, you will always
get the default profile.

345
00:18:51,980 --> 00:18:55,050
All right, so those are a few little
things that we just need to be aware of.

346
00:18:55,050 --> 00:18:58,344
That's how the profiles work,
they're incredibly useful and

347
00:18:58,344 --> 00:19:01,829
they really help you customize
the PowerShell and make it your own.

348
00:19:01,829 --> 00:19:03,489
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

349
00:19:03,489 --> 00:19:07,071
Stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up!

350
00:19:07,071 --> 00:19:13,419
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Extending the PowerShell
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,014 --> 00:00:07,355
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,355 --> 00:00:11,554
In this segment we're going to take
a look at extending the functionality of

3
00:00:11,554 --> 00:00:14,470
PowerShell through add-on modules.

4
00:00:14,470 --> 00:00:17,580
The PowerShell, it's pretty powerful,
well I guess that's the name.

5
00:00:17,580 --> 00:00:22,250
Because it's got a lot of functionality
that's built into it, but There

6
00:00:22,250 --> 00:00:25,610
are oftentimes where you'll bump into
things that you need that aren't there.

7
00:00:25,610 --> 00:00:27,720
And when Microsoft
designed the PowerShell,

8
00:00:27,720 --> 00:00:32,000
they intended it to be flexible, to grow
with the needs of the customers, and

9
00:00:32,000 --> 00:00:35,520
that's why they enabled
the ability to add on modules,

10
00:00:35,520 --> 00:00:38,910
that would basically put in
the functionality we were missing.

11
00:00:38,910 --> 00:00:42,460
And that might be functionality that
Microsoft adds later on themselves.

12
00:00:42,460 --> 00:00:45,600
Or it might be a functionality
that third parties add on.

13
00:00:45,600 --> 00:00:48,980
Anybody can write an add on module for
PowerShell and

14
00:00:48,980 --> 00:00:52,520
create new commandlets, and new
functionality that wasn't there before.

15
00:00:52,520 --> 00:00:53,670
It's pretty neat stuff.

16
00:00:53,670 --> 00:00:54,410
All right.

17
00:00:54,410 --> 00:00:58,190
Well let's start with the official
modules, the ones that are built in, and

18
00:00:58,190 --> 00:01:00,190
then we'll kind of go from there.

19
00:01:00,190 --> 00:01:03,180
Now, throughout this show we've
seen several different modules,

20
00:01:03,180 --> 00:01:06,150
that really we never addressed as modules.

21
00:01:06,150 --> 00:01:08,820
We just have commandlets that
are available and we use them.

22
00:01:08,820 --> 00:01:09,460
Al lright.

23
00:01:09,460 --> 00:01:13,830
Well the base modules of PowerShell are,
there included,

24
00:01:13,830 --> 00:01:15,030
there included with the OS.

25
00:01:15,030 --> 00:01:18,820
And it's not just one module,
there's actually a good 20 or 30 modules,

26
00:01:18,820 --> 00:01:21,950
that are part of the base
installation of PowerShell.

27
00:01:21,950 --> 00:01:24,630
They're up and running and
doing various things that you need.

28
00:01:24,630 --> 00:01:28,030
And then as you add software,

29
00:01:28,030 --> 00:01:31,570
the software you install may
add additional modules too.

30
00:01:31,570 --> 00:01:34,150
So for example on my server here,
let's take a look at this one.

31
00:01:35,380 --> 00:01:40,970
If I fire open my command prompt, or
my PoweShell, and I do a Get-Command.

32
00:01:40,970 --> 00:01:44,320
I'll see all the different commands
that i've got available, right.

33
00:01:44,320 --> 00:01:48,540
And there is quite a few out
here it's quite the list, right.

34
00:01:48,540 --> 00:01:52,840
And as I look at each command it's
got commandlet name, and over here on

35
00:01:52,840 --> 00:01:57,060
the right, it has some information if I
scroll all the way to the top and look.

36
00:01:57,060 --> 00:01:59,150
That's the module name, all right.

37
00:01:59,150 --> 00:02:02,140
Each of these commands
are coming from a module.

38
00:02:02,140 --> 00:02:04,900
And some of these
are installed by default.

39
00:02:04,900 --> 00:02:06,710
Some of these have been added.

40
00:02:06,710 --> 00:02:10,650
Well, I'm in the function section here,
let me get down to just the commandlets.

41
00:02:10,650 --> 00:02:11,600
Here we go.

42
00:02:11,600 --> 00:02:16,799
So you'll see some of these are listed
as Microsft.PowerShell.core,

43
00:02:16,799 --> 00:02:21,390
or
Microsoft.PowerShell.utility.diagnostics.

44
00:02:21,390 --> 00:02:24,800
Those are the base commandlets
that are a part of PowerShell

45
00:02:24,800 --> 00:02:27,000
that everyone is going to have.

46
00:02:27,000 --> 00:02:30,080
But you start getting into some
of these other modules like

47
00:02:30,080 --> 00:02:32,070
the ActiveDirectory module".

48
00:02:32,070 --> 00:02:34,310
Not everyone's going to have that.

49
00:02:34,310 --> 00:02:37,690
My server that I'm on right now,
is an Active Directory domain controller.

50
00:02:37,690 --> 00:02:41,740
And because of that, when I installed
the active directory management tools,

51
00:02:41,740 --> 00:02:44,830
it automatically added
the active directory modules.

52
00:02:44,830 --> 00:02:48,290
I also installed Microsoft SQL on here.

53
00:02:48,290 --> 00:02:51,290
And, because I did that,
when it set that up,

54
00:02:51,290 --> 00:02:55,550
it also added some SQL tools,
and I'll see some right here.

55
00:02:55,550 --> 00:03:00,368
SQLPS, that's the SQL PowerShell,
and so here's Get-SqlIntstance,

56
00:03:00,368 --> 00:03:05,490
Get-SqlDatabase, right, these were added
because I'm running Microsoft SQL Server.

57
00:03:05,490 --> 00:03:09,940
So one of the easiest ways to add
additional functionality to PowerShell,

58
00:03:09,940 --> 00:03:11,380
Is just to install your software.

59
00:03:11,380 --> 00:03:15,060
All right, when you install your software,
these modules come along with it.

60
00:03:16,080 --> 00:03:18,240
Another example might be DNS.

61
00:03:18,240 --> 00:03:22,540
So if I take a look at any
command that involves DNS.

62
00:03:22,540 --> 00:03:28,320
Well I'm a DNS server, and so here's
all these different DNS commandlets,

63
00:03:28,320 --> 00:03:30,420
that were added as a part
of the DNS module.

64
00:03:30,420 --> 00:03:31,110
Right?

65
00:03:31,110 --> 00:03:33,790
Well, what about something
that I'm not running though?

66
00:03:33,790 --> 00:03:35,670
Something like DHCP.

67
00:03:35,670 --> 00:03:40,820
Well if I wanna manage a DHCP server,
I can do Get-Command*DHCP*.

68
00:03:40,820 --> 00:03:43,510
I don't have any DHCP commandlets.

69
00:03:43,510 --> 00:03:46,610
That doesn't mean they don't exist.

70
00:03:46,610 --> 00:03:48,500
I'm just not running that module,
all right?

71
00:03:48,500 --> 00:03:50,180
There is a module for that.

72
00:03:50,180 --> 00:03:52,240
I don't have it installed.

73
00:03:52,240 --> 00:03:55,830
So, I've got a couple of choices
about how I can add that support.

74
00:03:55,830 --> 00:03:57,540
One, I can install the DHCP server.

75
00:03:57,540 --> 00:03:58,820
That would do it.

76
00:03:58,820 --> 00:04:00,770
But what if I'm on my workstation?

77
00:04:00,770 --> 00:04:03,230
I'm on a Windows 7 or
Windows 8 machine, and

78
00:04:03,230 --> 00:04:05,530
I'm wanting to manage
a server that's running DHCP.

79
00:04:05,530 --> 00:04:08,250
So I don't want to be
a DHCP server myself.

80
00:04:08,250 --> 00:04:10,440
I just want to manage somebody else,
right.

81
00:04:10,440 --> 00:04:12,810
Well I need the module
without installing the roll.

82
00:04:14,390 --> 00:04:17,200
Well, for Microsoft services,

83
00:04:17,200 --> 00:04:21,640
they have what's called the remote
server administration tool, so the RSAT.

84
00:04:21,640 --> 00:04:24,430
And the RSAT is that collection
of utilities that you can use to

85
00:04:24,430 --> 00:04:25,490
manage the server.

86
00:04:25,490 --> 00:04:29,220
And that collection most people
think of it as the GUI's, right?

87
00:04:29,220 --> 00:04:31,580
It's got all the graphical
user interface utilities,

88
00:04:31,580 --> 00:04:33,950
from managing all the server roles.

89
00:04:33,950 --> 00:04:37,000
But it also has the PowerShell modules.

90
00:04:37,000 --> 00:04:40,090
So if we install the RSAT, then

91
00:04:40,090 --> 00:04:43,990
we'll be able to add in the PowerShell
modules from whatever pieces we want.

92
00:04:43,990 --> 00:04:46,510
And so that's another way
that we can get those added.

93
00:04:46,510 --> 00:04:50,260
Now when you install a module,
there's really not all that much to it.

94
00:04:50,260 --> 00:04:54,480
A module's simply a file that gets
copied to one of two locations.

95
00:04:54,480 --> 00:04:58,820
There is a global module folder, that's
available for every user of this computer,

96
00:04:58,820 --> 00:05:01,640
and then there's a module folder
that's available just for

97
00:05:01,640 --> 00:05:03,890
you, the individual user, all right.

98
00:05:03,890 --> 00:05:06,420
So you can have some that are just
available for your account and

99
00:05:06,420 --> 00:05:09,290
not other people, or
ones that are installed for everyone.

100
00:05:09,290 --> 00:05:12,130
So, when we do something
like installing the RSAT,

101
00:05:12,130 --> 00:05:15,330
what we're really doing is just copying
a few modules into those folders.

102
00:05:15,330 --> 00:05:16,700
Let me show you an example.

103
00:05:16,700 --> 00:05:21,890
So here I'm gonna take my user account,
and I'm just gonna browse into my profile,

104
00:05:21,890 --> 00:05:25,380
so if I go into my Don Pezet folder and
into Documents.

105
00:05:25,380 --> 00:05:29,050
I've got my Windows PowerShell folder, and
if you don't see that Windows PowerShell

106
00:05:29,050 --> 00:05:31,200
folder, that just means
you're running all defaults.

107
00:05:31,200 --> 00:05:32,800
You haven't added anything, right?

108
00:05:32,800 --> 00:05:35,200
And many people will see that.

109
00:05:35,200 --> 00:05:38,220
But if I go into it, I can see that
I've got my profile right there, and

110
00:05:38,220 --> 00:05:40,640
right above it I've got a Modules folder.

111
00:05:40,640 --> 00:05:46,020
And inside of there, I can see any modules
that I've added, just for my account.

112
00:05:46,020 --> 00:05:48,360
And right now, I don't have any.

113
00:05:48,360 --> 00:05:51,220
I haven't added any modules just for me.

114
00:05:51,220 --> 00:05:54,620
But I know there's a ton of modules,
there's the active directory one, and

115
00:05:54,620 --> 00:05:56,480
all those guys, where are they?

116
00:05:56,480 --> 00:05:58,100
Well, they're stored in
the Windows directory.

117
00:05:58,100 --> 00:06:03,580
If I browse to C:/windows Slash system 32

118
00:06:03,580 --> 00:06:08,470
Slash windows PoweShelll.

119
00:06:08,470 --> 00:06:11,561
And then in the diversion 1.0 folder.

120
00:06:11,561 --> 00:06:13,500
I'll see a bunch of stuff, right.

121
00:06:13,500 --> 00:06:15,590
Cuz this is really all
the PowerShell stuff.

122
00:06:15,590 --> 00:06:17,520
Well what i'm looking for
is this Modules folder.

123
00:06:17,520 --> 00:06:24,780
So that's c:/system 32
WindowsPowerShell/Version1.0/Modules.

124
00:06:24,780 --> 00:06:31,830
And in there, I'll see each module
in its own separate folder.

125
00:06:31,830 --> 00:06:32,480
So for example,

126
00:06:32,480 --> 00:06:35,960
the DNS Server modules, they're
right here in the DNS Server folder.

127
00:06:35,960 --> 00:06:38,650
The Active Directory modules,
they're right here in this folder.

128
00:06:38,650 --> 00:06:39,830
And you can go down the line, and

129
00:06:39,830 --> 00:06:42,860
kind of look at all the different
modules that have been installed.

130
00:06:42,860 --> 00:06:45,310
The PowerShell ones are all right here.

131
00:06:45,310 --> 00:06:47,430
The other ones like
network interface stuff.

132
00:06:47,430 --> 00:06:48,270
It's there.

133
00:06:48,270 --> 00:06:49,910
NFS and so on.

134
00:06:49,910 --> 00:06:54,370
Each of the modules that I currently have
available to me inside of PowerShell.

135
00:06:54,370 --> 00:06:58,430
So if I want to add additional modules,
I could copy them right

136
00:06:58,430 --> 00:07:01,440
here into the folder, but
we normally do it through the software.

137
00:07:01,440 --> 00:07:03,230
When we install a software package,

138
00:07:03,230 --> 00:07:06,740
it automatically adds
the modules,so I mentioned DHCP.

139
00:07:06,740 --> 00:07:09,120
If I look at my list
here I don't see DHCP.

140
00:07:09,120 --> 00:07:11,080
It doesn't have a folder so

141
00:07:11,080 --> 00:07:15,940
the module's not here so
if I want it I have to go and install it.

142
00:07:15,940 --> 00:07:21,400
I'm going to fire up my server manager,
and I'm going to go up to Manage.

143
00:07:22,430 --> 00:07:23,240
Actually I'll wait here.

144
00:07:23,240 --> 00:07:25,140
It's just doing it's
little server query thing.

145
00:07:25,140 --> 00:07:28,230
There we go.
I'll go to Manage and Add Roles and

146
00:07:28,230 --> 00:07:28,980
Features.

147
00:07:28,980 --> 00:07:31,110
Now I don't want to add
the DHCP server role.

148
00:07:31,110 --> 00:07:33,780
I don't want to actually be a DHCP server.

149
00:07:33,780 --> 00:07:37,970
So, I'm gonna skip over the roles,
and I'm gonna go right to features.

150
00:07:37,970 --> 00:07:41,957
So I'm gonna just move past this,
past the server selection, past the roles,

151
00:07:41,957 --> 00:07:46,064
I'm not changing anything there, and
on the feature screen, I'm gonna look for

152
00:07:46,064 --> 00:07:48,345
the Remote Server Administration Toolkit.

153
00:07:48,345 --> 00:07:51,665
And if I scroll down,
I'll find it right here,

154
00:07:51,665 --> 00:07:55,733
Remote Server Administration Tools,
and If I expand it,

155
00:07:55,733 --> 00:08:00,231
I can find my Feature and
Role Administration And DHCP is a role.

156
00:08:00,231 --> 00:08:05,020
So I'm gonna go under role administration
and in here somewhere, I'll find DHCP.

157
00:08:05,020 --> 00:08:06,250
Here's the DHCP server tools.

158
00:08:07,260 --> 00:08:12,050
Now, most of us think of that entry as
installing the graphical tools, or DHCP,

159
00:08:12,050 --> 00:08:13,720
which it does, right?

160
00:08:13,720 --> 00:08:17,390
But, if I look at the notes over here,
it installs the tools for

161
00:08:17,390 --> 00:08:21,960
the MMC snap-in,
it installs some netsh commands, and

162
00:08:21,960 --> 00:08:25,530
it installs a PowerShell module for
the DHCP server.

163
00:08:25,530 --> 00:08:27,546
So, that's exactly what I want.

164
00:08:27,546 --> 00:08:31,990
I'm gonna check that off and hit Next,
and then I'll let it install.

165
00:08:31,990 --> 00:08:36,070
That's gonna add the PowerShell
module that I need, and

166
00:08:36,070 --> 00:08:39,420
now I'll be able to use that module.

167
00:08:39,420 --> 00:08:40,000
All right?

168
00:08:40,000 --> 00:08:41,850
Now, I'm gonna give it
a moment while it does that.

169
00:08:41,850 --> 00:08:44,170
It actually takes longer
than it really should.

170
00:08:44,170 --> 00:08:46,890
The file that it's copying is,
I don't know,

171
00:08:46,890 --> 00:08:50,090
it's something like a massive 30 k or
something.

172
00:08:50,090 --> 00:08:53,290
A very tiny file, but
it always takes forever to get that added.

173
00:08:53,290 --> 00:08:56,580
I guess the GUI components probably
take it a little bit longer.

174
00:08:56,580 --> 00:08:58,410
But it's gonna copy over, and

175
00:08:58,410 --> 00:09:02,100
when it's done, I should be able
to go back to my Modules folder.

176
00:09:03,360 --> 00:09:05,640
And I'm just going to refresh this screen.

177
00:09:05,640 --> 00:09:09,500
And I should see, there it is,
a DHCP server folder.

178
00:09:09,500 --> 00:09:12,150
That's the module that was just added.

179
00:09:12,150 --> 00:09:16,720
And now that it's been added, I'll have
the DHCP commands available to me.

180
00:09:16,720 --> 00:09:23,330
Now if I go back to my PowerShell
window and do a Get-Command *dhcp* and

181
00:09:23,330 --> 00:09:28,550
run that, now I've got a bunch of
commands available, all from that module.

182
00:09:28,550 --> 00:09:30,410
I didn't even have to
reopen the PowerShell.

183
00:09:30,410 --> 00:09:33,910
It's just automatically there and
now it's available, all right?

184
00:09:33,910 --> 00:09:35,580
Pretty cool stuff.

185
00:09:35,580 --> 00:09:37,575
Now the module files themselves,

186
00:09:37,575 --> 00:09:39,756
I mentioned that anybody can create them,
right?

187
00:09:39,756 --> 00:09:43,848
If we go into that, you'll see
that there may be just one file or

188
00:09:43,848 --> 00:09:45,713
there may be several files.

189
00:09:45,713 --> 00:09:49,917
PowerShell modules are text files and

190
00:09:49,917 --> 00:09:53,594
their saved as a name dot PSM1 and

191
00:09:53,594 --> 00:09:58,340

The other one gave me the file
name on the same line as the file,

420
00:22:37,110 --> 00:22:40,130
versus here it's separated them out and
done a little highlighting.

421
00:22:40,130 --> 00:22:43,675
And then after so that here's
the line with Don Pezet on it, and

422
00:22:43,675 --> 00:22:45,395
it's highlighting the word that matched.

423
00:22:45,395 --> 00:22:47,245
Kind of a nice little add-on, right?

424
00:22:47,245 --> 00:22:49,715
Not anything spectacular,
you wouldn't pay thousands of dollars for

425
00:22:49,715 --> 00:22:53,445
that functionality, but for
a free module add-on, it's pretty useful,

426
00:22:53,445 --> 00:22:54,342
and it's nice to have.

427
00:22:56,352 --> 00:22:59,192
Right.
If you have a roaming user profile, and

428
00:22:59,192 --> 00:23:03,502
you've stored this commandlet in your
modules folder in your documents folder,

429
00:23:03,502 --> 00:23:05,962
as you move from machine to machine
to machine, it will follow you and

430
00:23:05,962 --> 00:23:07,850
you'll always have that
commandlet available.

431
00:23:07,850 --> 00:23:08,450
All right.

432
00:23:08,450 --> 00:23:11,290
But if you don't have a roaming user
profile when you go from machine to

433
00:23:11,290 --> 00:23:14,670
machine to machine you may or
may not have that command available.

434
00:23:14,670 --> 00:23:19,010
So a lot of people prefer not to use
add on modules like these just for

435
00:23:19,010 --> 00:23:20,530
consistency right.

436
00:23:20,530 --> 00:23:23,890
You don't want to rely on a module like
this and all of a sudden you get a new

437
00:23:23,890 --> 00:23:26,110
computer and you've got to figure
out all the modules that you missed.

438
00:23:26,110 --> 00:23:27,580
And and those back in.

439
00:23:27,580 --> 00:23:30,620
That's why Microsoft puts that
profile in your Documents folder,

440
00:23:30,620 --> 00:23:32,830
because most people back
up their Documents folder.

441
00:23:32,830 --> 00:23:36,020
When you move to a new computer you
copy your Documents folder over, and

442
00:23:36,020 --> 00:23:39,290
now you've got all your PowerShell stuff,
that's why they chose that location.

443
00:23:39,290 --> 00:23:44,390
So these are an example of an add-on
module that adds that functionality.

444
00:23:44,390 --> 00:23:47,438
If you go and do a Google search on the
Internet you will find thousands of add-on

445
00:23:47,438 --> 00:23:48,543
modules that are out there.

446
00:23:48,543 --> 00:23:51,692
Some from very big companies like Dell and
Quest.

447
00:23:51,692 --> 00:23:53,480
They have a bunch of
them that are out there.

448
00:23:53,480 --> 00:23:55,796
There's also ones that are just
from individual people.

449
00:23:55,796 --> 00:23:56,860
People like you and me.

450
00:23:56,860 --> 00:23:59,651
That had a need, and
went ahead and made it, right?

451
00:23:59,651 --> 00:24:03,050
Made the command that met their needs,
and maybe you have that same need, right?

452
00:24:03,050 --> 00:24:04,800
Maybe it was something
that you were looking for.

453
00:24:04,800 --> 00:24:06,190
That's how I came across this one.

454
00:24:06,190 --> 00:24:10,500
I was looking for a command that better
recreated what I had with grep but

455
00:24:10,500 --> 00:24:13,360
inside of PowerShell, and
select-string wasn't cutting it for me.

456
00:24:13,360 --> 00:24:15,700
And so I came across this one and
it works well.

457
00:24:16,880 --> 00:24:22,270
So those are some examples there of adding
on that functionality into PowerShell.

458
00:24:22,270 --> 00:24:25,310
Let me see if I'm missing anything.

459
00:24:25,310 --> 00:24:26,710
Oh, there is one other thing.

460
00:24:28,690 --> 00:24:33,370
When we add on modules like these,
If I'm adding SQL and

461
00:24:34,620 --> 00:24:38,012
Exchange, whatever all these
third party software modules.

462
00:24:38,012 --> 00:24:41,200
I may have to install a bunch of stuff
to my machine to get those modules.

463
00:24:41,200 --> 00:24:43,440
And if I'm just gonna need it one time,

464
00:24:43,440 --> 00:24:46,120
it's kind of a waste to add
modules that I'm not gonna need.

465
00:24:46,120 --> 00:24:51,770
The more modules that you have,
the slower PowerShell gets at launch time.

466
00:24:51,770 --> 00:24:54,370
Not when it's running, so
like once you're in and running,

467
00:24:54,370 --> 00:24:56,620
it runs the same regardless
of how many modules you have.

468
00:24:56,620 --> 00:25:00,580
But when you first launch PowerShell,
it has to index your modules and

469
00:25:00,580 --> 00:25:02,390
get those commands ready.

470
00:25:02,390 --> 00:25:04,660
And it will slow that time down.

471
00:25:04,660 --> 00:25:08,550
So for example if you launch your
PowerShell on a Microsoft Exchange server,

472
00:25:08,550 --> 00:25:13,610
it's not uncommon for it to sit and pause
for upwards of to a minute in some cases.

473
00:25:13,610 --> 00:25:16,360
And that is a long time in computers.

474
00:25:16,360 --> 00:25:22,970
So we try to minimize the amount of
PowerShell modules that we add on.

475
00:25:22,970 --> 00:25:26,610
But if you just need one right now, and

476
00:25:26,610 --> 00:25:30,660
there's another computer that already has
it, or maybe the server already has it,

477
00:25:30,660 --> 00:25:34,900
you can actually tell it to load
the modules from that other server.

478
00:25:34,900 --> 00:25:39,110
All right, there's a function inside
of PowerShell called remoting.

479
00:25:39,110 --> 00:25:43,180
Remoting is where you connect your
PowerShell to another system.

480
00:25:43,180 --> 00:25:47,180
And I'm gonna show that in another segment
where we talk about remote management.

481
00:25:47,180 --> 00:25:50,280
But one of neat aspects of
remoting is you can say,

482
00:25:50,280 --> 00:25:53,230
don't fully connect me to the other side.

483
00:25:53,230 --> 00:25:54,900
Just grab their modules.

484
00:25:54,900 --> 00:25:59,660
Give me the same modules that they already
have, just for this session, all right.

485
00:25:59,660 --> 00:26:02,560
I don't recommend it because it's not
the greatest thing cuz you can bump into

486
00:26:02,560 --> 00:26:06,690
conflicts where they might have a module
that's newer than the one you've already

487
00:26:06,690 --> 00:26:08,070
got or vice versa and so

488
00:26:08,070 --> 00:26:10,570
now they bump into each other
because they have the same module.

489
00:26:10,570 --> 00:26:14,340
You'll get a lot of errors when you
turn it on as it hits those duplicates.

490
00:26:14,340 --> 00:26:18,340
And then the ones that aren't
the same like the new ones,

491
00:26:18,340 --> 00:26:21,440
the additional ones, those that get
added in and then it will work great.

492
00:26:21,440 --> 00:26:25,470
This is something I really don't use very
often just because it's kind of a mess and

493
00:26:25,470 --> 00:26:27,120
there is a better option.

494
00:26:27,120 --> 00:26:32,100
So if you're looking to do this,
to load Powershell modules temporarily.

495
00:26:32,100 --> 00:26:34,220
Be sure to check out our
remote management episode.

496
00:26:34,220 --> 00:26:35,870
I'll show you guys a better way to do it.

497
00:26:35,870 --> 00:26:39,730
For completeness, let me show you right
here how to load modules from another

498
00:26:39,730 --> 00:26:42,160
server for temporary use.

499
00:26:42,160 --> 00:26:47,570
The way we do it is from inside of
our PowerShell, we just need to give

500
00:26:47,570 --> 00:26:51,060
it a heads up that we're gonna be loading
these commands from somewhere else.

501
00:26:52,080 --> 00:26:54,380
And it does take two lines to do this one.

502
00:26:54,380 --> 00:26:58,580
I'm going to create a variable called s.

503
00:26:58,580 --> 00:27:02,212
And I'm going to store the output of
a command which is going to be the New

504
00:27:02,212 --> 00:27:06,540
-PSSession command.

505
00:27:06,540 --> 00:27:08,080
And, I'm going to specify a computer.

506
00:27:08,080 --> 00:27:09,900
And this will be the remote computer.

507
00:27:09,900 --> 00:27:13,090
Who it is,
that has the module that you want.

508
00:27:13,090 --> 00:27:13,730
All right.

509
00:27:13,730 --> 00:27:15,160
So, my server is called Server01.

510
00:27:15,160 --> 00:27:16,800
I'm actually going to connect to myself.

511
00:27:16,800 --> 00:27:18,190
Just to show it.

512
00:27:18,190 --> 00:27:21,250
But you'd specify some other server or
workstation,

513
00:27:21,250 --> 00:27:22,458
that had the modules you needed.

514
00:27:22,458 --> 00:27:28,734
So, I'm saying,
set this session as a variable called $S.

515
00:27:29,750 --> 00:27:32,793
So, that's gonna store it and it's gonna
get angry at me what's its problem,

516
00:27:32,793 --> 00:27:34,290
access denied, oh, shoot!

517
00:27:34,290 --> 00:27:35,850
I need to be an administrator
to do this and

518
00:27:35,850 --> 00:27:38,960
I did not run my PowerShell
with administrative privileges.

519
00:27:38,960 --> 00:27:40,830
So, let me switch that around.

520
00:27:45,380 --> 00:27:47,040
There we go and we'll try this again.

521
00:27:47,040 --> 00:27:48,780
All right, there.

522
00:27:48,780 --> 00:27:53,150
So now I'm giving this variable
that allows me to call that session

523
00:27:53,150 --> 00:27:53,930
whenever I want.

524
00:27:53,930 --> 00:27:58,460
So now I can call a PowerShell connection
over to Server01 whenever I want.

525
00:27:58,460 --> 00:28:02,155
And from here, I just say,

526
00:28:02,155 --> 00:28:08,550
Import-PSSession-Session $S, right.

527
00:28:08,550 --> 00:28:10,800
Referencing the one I stored up here.

528
00:28:10,800 --> 00:28:14,930
So, I'm going to import
the PowerShell Session from that server.

529
00:28:14,930 --> 00:28:18,680
Import, just like when I imported modules,
that's what it's going to do here,

530
00:28:18,680 --> 00:28:23,100
it's going to take whatever modules are
available to a session on that server and

531
00:28:23,100 --> 00:28:25,990
connect them into this
session temporarily.

532
00:28:25,990 --> 00:28:26,630
Right?

533
00:28:26,630 --> 00:28:29,260
And when I run that it's
gonna reach out and

534
00:28:29,260 --> 00:28:30,790
it's gonna pull
the information from there.

535
00:28:30,790 --> 00:28:33,270
Now, expect to see some errors.

536
00:28:33,270 --> 00:28:35,550
Right?
You're gonna get errors anytime there's

537
00:28:35,550 --> 00:28:36,280
duplicates.

538
00:28:36,280 --> 00:28:38,690
Right?
Here I've got some unsafe command names.

539
00:28:38,690 --> 00:28:41,580
Which is usually just telling me that
there's a duplicate that's in there.

540
00:28:41,580 --> 00:28:45,050
And if I scroll back up,
looks like I didn't get all that many.

541
00:28:46,550 --> 00:28:47,930
Here I'm seeing, let's see.

542
00:28:47,930 --> 00:28:50,380
Which one did it die out on?

543
00:28:50,380 --> 00:28:53,500
Here it says, proxy creation has been
skipped for the question mark command

544
00:28:53,500 --> 00:28:57,490
because the Windows PowerShell cannot
verify the safety of the command name.

545
00:28:57,490 --> 00:29:01,310
So it's got some kind of grievance
there with that particular command.

546
00:29:01,310 --> 00:29:02,800
But I'm not too worried about that.

547
00:29:02,800 --> 00:29:07,140
Because right after it, I see all the
other commands that it tried to import.

548
00:29:07,140 --> 00:29:10,280
And notice how all these are warnings,
right.

549
00:29:10,280 --> 00:29:13,670
It says warning, and if I go all the way
to the bottom, it'll tell me here.

550
00:29:15,720 --> 00:29:20,510
It's giving us a warning, because it
would shadow an existing local command.

551
00:29:20,510 --> 00:29:21,440
So in this case,

552
00:29:21,440 --> 00:29:25,220
it's saying you've already got
the command locally, you don't need it.

553
00:29:25,220 --> 00:29:29,150
But anything that was different that
didn't throw an error, it would bring in,

554
00:29:29,150 --> 00:29:30,390
and we now have.

555
00:29:30,390 --> 00:29:32,940
And it's creating a temporary module.

556
00:29:32,940 --> 00:29:34,440
See this ModuleType script?

557
00:29:34,440 --> 00:29:39,160
It's creating a temporary module that
gives me all the various commands

558
00:29:39,160 --> 00:29:41,020
that are present on that other server.

559
00:29:41,020 --> 00:29:45,000
And now I can work as if those modules
were local, even though they're not.

560
00:29:45,000 --> 00:29:47,620
And when I close this
PowerShell window and

561
00:29:47,620 --> 00:29:50,780
open a new one, all those
commands are now gone, all right.

562
00:29:50,780 --> 00:29:54,305
So this is a good way to do
that temporarily, but for

563
00:29:54,305 --> 00:29:57,135
me, from my own personal experience,
you get so

564
00:29:57,135 --> 00:30:00,455
many conflicts with it that you can
get some really erratic behavior.

565
00:30:00,455 --> 00:30:02,685
And so I recommend you don't use it.

566
00:30:02,685 --> 00:30:05,685
While the functionality is there,
I typically don't.

567
00:30:05,685 --> 00:30:10,345
I use PSSession, but
I use it to create a full connection,

568
00:30:10,345 --> 00:30:12,745
where sure, I'm running
PowerShell on my own machine, but

569
00:30:12,745 --> 00:30:15,920
I'm actually seeing the PowerShell
on the remote machine.

570
00:30:15,920 --> 00:30:19,320
That means you're using all the commands
from the remote machine and

571
00:30:19,320 --> 00:30:20,770
that eliminates the conflicts.

572
00:30:20,770 --> 00:30:23,270
That ensures that you're running
a consistent environment.

573
00:30:23,270 --> 00:30:25,460
I prefer that much more than this method.

574
00:30:25,460 --> 00:30:26,010
All right?

575
00:30:26,010 --> 00:30:28,200
But, for completeness,
I did want to show that just so

576
00:30:28,200 --> 00:30:29,520
you're aware that you can do it.

577
00:30:30,760 --> 00:30:31,670
What is it that they say?

578
00:30:31,670 --> 00:30:33,940
Just because you can do something
doesn't mean you should.

579
00:30:33,940 --> 00:30:35,120
This is one of those cases.

580
00:30:36,180 --> 00:30:38,530
All right.
So that's about it for

581
00:30:38,530 --> 00:30:40,500
adding on functionality.

582
00:30:40,500 --> 00:30:44,490
Do be careful if you're going out there
and downloading third party modules.

583
00:30:44,490 --> 00:30:47,410
You need to download them from
people you trust because,

584
00:30:47,410 --> 00:30:50,540
if you go to run a module and it says oh,
you need to be an administrator and

585
00:30:50,540 --> 00:30:53,440
you've run the modules in administrator,
do you know what it's doing?

586
00:30:53,440 --> 00:30:56,630
There could be all sorts of
craziness written in the code for

587
00:30:56,630 --> 00:30:59,510
that module that you don't know,
so do a code review.

588
00:30:59,510 --> 00:31:00,280
Skim over it.

589
00:31:00,280 --> 00:31:02,260
Look at it.
See what it's doing.

590
00:31:02,260 --> 00:31:03,040
It might be phoning home.

591
00:31:03,040 --> 00:31:04,310
It might be sending emails or

592
00:31:04,310 --> 00:31:09,090
data back to an external server,
you won't know unless you look, all right?

593
00:31:09,090 --> 00:31:13,180
Or just use modules that
come from trusted providers.

594
00:31:13,180 --> 00:31:15,120
So if you're getting
software from Microsoft and

595
00:31:15,120 --> 00:31:17,295
it's got PowerShell modules,
you can trust that.

596
00:31:17,295 --> 00:31:19,470
All right,
then Microsoft made all this stuff.

597
00:31:19,470 --> 00:31:22,830
Or if you go into Oracle or
Dell or somewhere like that and

598
00:31:22,830 --> 00:31:25,310
they have PowerShell modules for
you, that's great.

599
00:31:25,310 --> 00:31:27,260
All right,
those are companies that you can trust.

600
00:31:27,260 --> 00:31:29,020
Well, I shouldn't have said Oracle.

601
00:31:29,020 --> 00:31:31,120
But companies that you
should be able to trust.

602
00:31:31,120 --> 00:31:35,950
But if you're downloading a module
that was written by John Doe and

603
00:31:35,950 --> 00:31:39,310
was posted to GitHub and
you're pulling it from there.

604
00:31:39,310 --> 00:31:40,300
You just don't know.

605
00:31:40,300 --> 00:31:45,170
So, you've got to skim over that and
make sure it's something you can trust.

606
00:31:45,170 --> 00:31:49,790
In this segment we got a chance to see how
to bring in modules into PowerShell to

607
00:31:49,790 --> 00:31:52,860
add additional commands and
functionality, and it's the sky's limit.

608
00:31:52,860 --> 00:31:55,250
There's a lot of stuff
you can do there and

609
00:31:55,250 --> 00:31:59,120
we wrapped up the segment taking a look
at importing a PowerShell session.

610
00:31:59,120 --> 00:32:02,350
All the commands from another
session on a remote system.

611
00:32:02,350 --> 00:32:03,570
And while it's not a great idea,

612
00:32:03,570 --> 00:32:07,120
it certainly is possible so
we got a chance to see that.

613
00:32:07,120 --> 00:32:11,060
All right, well if you're interesting
in seeing how to do it the right way

614
00:32:11,060 --> 00:32:14,750
be sure to check out our remote
management section, or that segment.

615
00:32:14,750 --> 00:32:17,350
We've got a section on there where we
show the other method that I mention.

616
00:32:17,350 --> 00:32:19,290
You'll definitely wanna check that out.

617
00:32:19,290 --> 00:32:21,380
Otherwise, that's about it for
this segment.

618
00:32:21,380 --> 00:32:27,452
So stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up.

619
00:32:27,452 --> 00:32:30,812
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Local vs Remote Management
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,865
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,865 --> 00:00:11,755
>> In this segment we're going to take
a look at local management versus remote

3
00:00:11,755 --> 00:00:14,270
management inside a PowerShell.

4
00:00:14,270 --> 00:00:16,990
The majority of the time we're working
in PowerShell we're doing what's called

5
00:00:16,990 --> 00:00:18,200
local management.

6
00:00:18,200 --> 00:00:21,140
In other words, all the commandlets
that we run they're running against

7
00:00:21,140 --> 00:00:24,760
the server that we're sitting on or
the workstation or whatever.

8
00:00:24,760 --> 00:00:28,060
So I'm on a Windows 7 machine and
I fire up the PowerShell,

9
00:00:28,060 --> 00:00:32,310
any commands I type, are running
against my Windows 7 machine, and

10
00:00:32,310 --> 00:00:36,685
if I wanna run against some other machine,
well that's just not the default.

11
00:00:36,685 --> 00:00:39,905
So, there's not really all that
much to say about local management.

12
00:00:39,905 --> 00:00:42,235
You launch the PowerShell and
you type stuff.

13
00:00:42,235 --> 00:00:43,705
Right?
It's what we've done in all of

14
00:00:43,705 --> 00:00:47,695
the various segments for this series so
far is just straight up local management.

15
00:00:47,695 --> 00:00:49,305
Nothing special there.

16
00:00:49,305 --> 00:00:51,675
But remote management,
there's something special.

17
00:00:51,675 --> 00:00:52,345
Right?

18
00:00:52,345 --> 00:00:56,260
Remote management is where I want to
run a PowerShell on my own machine but

19
00:00:56,260 --> 00:01:00,100
I wanted to actually perform
actions on other machines.

20
00:01:01,360 --> 00:01:05,410
Sometimes that can be easy,
sometimes it's not, all right?

21
00:01:05,410 --> 00:01:09,330
The best case scenario is that
the command you're running

22
00:01:09,330 --> 00:01:11,630
supports providing a target.

23
00:01:11,630 --> 00:01:15,000
Some of the command links you run
will actually have a target value.

24
00:01:15,000 --> 00:01:18,140
And if you leave the target off it just
defaults to your local machine, so

25
00:01:18,140 --> 00:01:20,395
it's defaulting to local management.

26
00:01:20,395 --> 00:01:22,600
But you might to run it
against a different machine,

27
00:01:22,600 --> 00:01:24,020
you'll be able to do that.

28
00:01:24,020 --> 00:01:26,214
Let me show you an example,
I'm gonna fire up my PowerShell.

29
00:01:27,770 --> 00:01:31,970
And let's take a look at get-aduser.

30
00:01:31,970 --> 00:01:36,620
Get-aduser is a command that will
query the active directory and

31

00:14:05,850 --> 00:14:10,150
Well if I go into a shell I
might forget that I did that.

259
00:14:10,150 --> 00:14:11,810
It's right here in the prompt.

260
00:14:11,810 --> 00:14:13,600
But you know how we get
when we're in a hurry.

261
00:14:13,600 --> 00:14:14,620
So I might forget, and

262
00:14:14,620 --> 00:14:16,600
now I'm running things on
a different system than I thought.

263
00:14:16,600 --> 00:14:18,180
And I start to cause some problems.

264
00:14:18,180 --> 00:14:22,190
So if it's just gonna be one command
that I'm gonna run remotely.

265
00:14:22,190 --> 00:14:25,970
Instead of doing a full shell like this

266
00:14:25,970 --> 00:14:29,340
I can use a different commandlet to be
able to push that along, all right?

267
00:14:29,340 --> 00:14:34,670
I need to get out of this session so
I'm going to type Exit PSsession and

268
00:14:34,670 --> 00:14:39,050
that'll put me back and now see how my
prompt, it dropped that server one.

269
00:14:39,050 --> 00:14:41,290
Now I'm right back to my own session.

270
00:14:41,290 --> 00:14:47,540
All right, now if I just wanted to
run one command on that remote side,

271
00:14:47,540 --> 00:14:52,150
the commandlet for
that is invoke dash command, right?

272
00:14:52,150 --> 00:14:54,270
We're gonna run a command but not on us,

273
00:14:54,270 --> 00:14:58,250
we're gonna invoke it
on some other system.

274
00:14:58,250 --> 00:15:02,070
And what this does is it lets
us take really any command, and

275
00:15:02,070 --> 00:15:06,860
we just copy the command, throw it to the
other system, let the other system run it,

276
00:15:06,860 --> 00:15:11,080
and then bring the output back and
show us the output, all right?

277
00:15:11,080 --> 00:15:13,010
So it's a temporary session.

278
00:15:13,010 --> 00:15:15,059
Just a temporary one used
to run this one command.

279
00:15:16,240 --> 00:15:20,210
And with it you basically
specify a computer name.

280
00:15:20,210 --> 00:15:21,940
And here's the really
cool part about this one.

281
00:15:21,940 --> 00:15:25,420
This one is actually a little
bit better than the shell.

282
00:15:25,420 --> 00:15:28,460
Because I can specify more
than one computer name.

283
00:15:28,460 --> 00:15:33,930
I could say server01, server02, server03.

284
00:15:33,930 --> 00:15:36,910
And i'm just separating them with commas.

285
00:15:36,910 --> 00:15:37,520
Right?

286
00:15:37,520 --> 00:15:39,300
So by doing this it's gonna reach out and

287
00:15:39,300 --> 00:15:43,280
run whatever I'm about to type
on all three of those servers.

288
00:15:43,280 --> 00:15:47,460
When I did the PS session, that shell,
that's just one server but

289
00:15:47,460 --> 00:15:48,130
here I can do multiple.

290
00:15:49,210 --> 00:15:52,130
So now I'm gonna invoke
a command on those servers.

291
00:15:52,130 --> 00:15:54,920
I'm gonna reach out to them and
tell them to do something and

292
00:15:54,920 --> 00:15:56,920
now I can tell them what I want.

293
00:15:56,920 --> 00:16:01,490
One of the problems I might bump into with
this, though, is the authentication piece.

294
00:16:01,490 --> 00:16:05,240
Well, it's gonna run under my credentials,
so I probably don't have to specify any.

295
00:16:05,240 --> 00:16:09,590
But I can specify the credentials here in
line if I need to, just to let it know.

296
00:16:09,590 --> 00:16:14,670
I could come in and say, -Credential, and

297
00:16:14,670 --> 00:16:20,040
specify my domain and whatever

298
00:16:20,040 --> 00:16:25,170
account it is that I'm using so that it
knows what credential I want to run as.

299
00:16:25,170 --> 00:16:27,250
If I don't have that password
it's going to prompt me for it so

300
00:16:27,250 --> 00:16:29,670
I'll have to provide the password, but I
don't have to put it here in the command.

301
00:16:30,820 --> 00:16:35,300
In my case though, I just need to
run it as me and that will be fine.

302
00:16:35,300 --> 00:16:37,590
And I'll go ahead and get rid of these
other servers because they don't exist.

303
00:16:37,590 --> 00:16:39,560
I'll just run this against server01.

304
00:16:39,560 --> 00:16:43,750
Now, after that I can
specify what I want to run.

305
00:16:43,750 --> 00:16:45,900
Now, if it's a single command I
can just throw it in here but

306
00:16:45,900 --> 00:16:49,500
what we normally do is we
throw it into a script block.

307
00:16:49,500 --> 00:16:53,130
A script block is like the curly
brackets I was talking about earlier.

308
00:16:53,130 --> 00:16:55,970
The curly brackets are nice cuz you can
actually put more than one command in

309
00:16:55,970 --> 00:16:59,090
there and they'll all run as part
of that instantaneous session.

310
00:16:59,090 --> 00:17:06,970
So, I could do something like {
get-process } and close that out.

311
00:17:06,970 --> 00:17:08,810
So now, it's gonna.

312
00:17:08,810 --> 00:17:11,642
Create a temporary session to server01.

313
00:17:11,642 --> 00:17:14,790
On server01,
it's going to run get-process and

314
00:17:14,790 --> 00:17:17,610
then the output will be displayed
right here on my screen.

315
00:17:17,610 --> 00:17:20,540
And if I was to do comma server two,
comma server three,

316
00:17:20,540 --> 00:17:23,040
it would reach out to all three of them.

317
00:17:23,040 --> 00:17:25,930
And then I would get the output for
each one on my screen and

318
00:17:25,930 --> 00:17:27,710
I could see those processes.

319
00:17:27,710 --> 00:17:30,550
So when I run that,
it's reaching out to it, and

320
00:17:30,550 --> 00:17:33,880
there's the processes all
coming from that system.

321
00:17:33,880 --> 00:17:37,980
And notice that it actually has
that extra column over here, it's

322
00:17:37,980 --> 00:17:42,320
adding a column called PS computer name,
so that I remember where that came from.

323
00:17:42,320 --> 00:17:45,360
Because if I'm running this
on more than one system

324
00:17:45,360 --> 00:17:46,820
I need to be aware of that, right.

325
00:17:46,820 --> 00:17:52,220
I need to know that it's from one host or
another.

326
00:17:54,050 --> 00:17:56,820
So, that's another cool little
way to go out there and do that.

327
00:17:56,820 --> 00:18:01,652
These are temporary versus PSSession
where once we go into a PSSession,

328
00:18:01,652 --> 00:18:05,210
you Enter -PSSession, you're now
in that shell until you exit it.

329
00:18:05,210 --> 00:18:07,790
And so you can stay in there for
hours on end.

330
00:18:07,790 --> 00:18:10,910
Invoke command, runs once, and it's done.

331
00:18:10,910 --> 00:18:15,040
Now I'm out of that system, and
I'm back to working on my regular machine.

332
00:18:15,040 --> 00:18:16,960
See my prompt never changed.

333
00:18:16,960 --> 00:18:18,270
I'm still on my own machine.

334
00:18:19,920 --> 00:18:22,520
All right.
So, that's pretty much it for

335
00:18:22,520 --> 00:18:23,340
remote managements.

336
00:18:23,340 --> 00:18:24,330
It's pretty straight forward.

337
00:18:24,330 --> 00:18:26,030
Microsoft made it easy.

338
00:18:26,030 --> 00:18:29,880
Just remember that the three or
four real options we have.

339
00:18:29,880 --> 00:18:31,020
Check your command.

340
00:18:31,020 --> 00:18:34,350
Your commandlet may already have
an option for specifying remote servers,

341
00:18:34,350 --> 00:18:38,280
in which case, that's the easiest,
stick with that, all right?

342
00:18:38,280 --> 00:18:42,810
Or you can try and proxy your commands
by using the import session but

343
00:18:42,810 --> 00:18:45,810
that's my least favorite so that's where
you start to get command conflicts.

344
00:18:45,810 --> 00:18:47,280
I don't like that one.

345
00:18:47,280 --> 00:18:51,800
Our third option is to do a PSsession and
create that shell to the other side.

346
00:18:51,800 --> 00:18:55,230
When we do that now we're logged into
the other system and running our commands.

347
00:18:55,230 --> 00:18:56,610
That works great.

348
00:18:56,610 --> 00:19:00,540
Our last option was, well,
if we use invoke command and

349
00:19:00,540 --> 00:19:02,020
we can run our commands
on that remote system.

350
00:19:02,020 --> 00:19:03,630
Get in and get out.

351
00:19:03,630 --> 00:19:04,420
And move on.

352
00:19:04,420 --> 00:19:08,440
So, all different methods of
remotely managing systems.

353
00:19:09,850 --> 00:19:12,070
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed that segment.

354
00:19:12,070 --> 00:19:15,846
That's about all I've got on that one,
so we'll wrap it up here, but

355
00:19:15,846 --> 00:19:18,930
stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up next.

356
00:19:18,930 --> 00:19:24,089
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: PowerShell ISE
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:09,197
[SOUND]
In this segment,

2
00:00:09,197 --> 00:00:11,810
we're gonna take a look
at the PowerShell ISE.

3
00:00:11,810 --> 00:00:16,510
The PowerShell ISE is a integrated
scripting environment.

4
00:00:16,510 --> 00:00:17,960
Now what the heck is that?

5
00:00:17,960 --> 00:00:22,190
Well, if you've ever worked with a
developer or if you've done any developing

6
00:00:22,190 --> 00:00:25,890
yourself you'll know that most
programmers work in what's called an IDE,

7
00:00:25,890 --> 00:00:27,840
an integrated development environment.

8
00:00:27,840 --> 00:00:31,170
And what an IDE allows them
to do is to write their code.

9
00:00:31,170 --> 00:00:35,780
They can write all their source code and
immediately compile and

10
00:00:35,780 --> 00:00:38,850
execute it right there from
inside of their development file.

11
00:00:38,850 --> 00:00:41,740
So they can make a change launch
their program and test it.

12
00:00:41,740 --> 00:00:43,620
Make another change launch
their program and test it.

13
00:00:43,620 --> 00:00:46,000
Doing it all right from one location.

14
00:00:46,000 --> 00:00:51,090
Now IDEs used to be really basic like
that back in well, in the 1980s.

15
00:00:51,090 --> 00:00:56,180
But in today's world, IDEs normally have
a lot of additional functionality, too.

16
00:00:56,180 --> 00:00:59,280
Like helping us check for
errors in our source code.

17
00:00:59,280 --> 00:01:02,430
So as we start to write our programming
language, if there's any mistakes in

18
00:01:02,430 --> 00:01:05,840
there, it'll help you spot them even
before you compile and run them.

19
00:01:05,840 --> 00:01:09,320
Well, power shell is not
a programming language.

20
00:01:09,320 --> 00:01:11,420
It's really a scripting language.

21
00:01:11,420 --> 00:01:15,980
And so, Microsoft wanted to create an IDE,
but for a scripting language.

22
00:01:15,980 --> 00:01:18,430
That's why they call it power shell ISE.

23
00:01:18,430 --> 00:01:20,470
And it works just like those IDE's do.

24
00:01:20,470 --> 00:01:25,330
We can write our PowerShell scripts and
it will check them If there's a mistake or

25
00:01:25,330 --> 00:01:27,330
error it will try and
highlight that for us.

26
00:01:27,330 --> 00:01:31,390
And it gives us the ability to run
them right from a single environment.

27
00:01:31,390 --> 00:01:34,230
Now the PowerShell ISC was
introduced in PowerShell 2.0.

28
00:01:34,230 --> 00:01:37,530
It wasn't in the original one,
they added it after the fact.

29
00:01:37,530 --> 00:01:40,680
And it's gotten more
advanced over the years.

30
00:01:40,680 --> 00:01:44,760
So in the newer versions we actually
have what's called IntelliSense, and

31
00:01:44,760 --> 00:01:47,800
that's where you start
to type a command and

32
00:01:47,800 --> 00:01:50,920
it'll actually give you suggestions
as to what should go after it.

33
00:01:50,920 --> 00:01:53,920
Now we have tab auto complete
that kind of does that, but

34
00:01:53,920 --> 00:01:57,810
what I'm talking about are when
we specify those property values.

35
00:01:57,810 --> 00:02:00,970
So, you might have seen in some of the
episodes where I'll do something like when

36
00:02:00,970 --> 00:02:05,710
I'm pipelining some of the commands, I'll
say dollar sign underscore dot name and

37
00:02:05,710 --> 00:02:09,470
that's saying dot name,
that's the property I want.

38
00:02:09,470 --> 00:02:13,300
From dollar sign underscore, that's
the result of a previous command, right?

39
00:02:13,300 --> 00:02:17,290
Well, with IntelliSense on, you can
type dollar sign underscore dot and

40
00:02:17,290 --> 00:02:20,570
all of a sudden it'll give you a list
of the properties to pick from.

41
00:02:20,570 --> 00:02:22,770
And so instead of having to
remember the property name myself,

42
00:02:22,770 --> 00:02:25,180
I can just pick it right there
from that list and off you go.

43
00:02:25,180 --> 00:02:27,000
That makes writing scripts a lot easier.

44
00:02:27,000 --> 00:02:29,980
It's definitely something that
makes things more convenient.

45
00:02:29,980 --> 00:02:33,190
And you can have one central place
to edit and work with your scripts.

46
00:02:33,190 --> 00:02:34,930
Load them, run them, and work with them.

47
00:02:35,930 --> 00:02:39,510
Alright, now PowerShell ISE is installed
automatically as a part of the PowerShell.

48
00:02:39,510 --> 00:02:43,710
So, if you've got PowerShell,
you've got PowerShell ISE.

49
00:02:43,710 --> 00:02:46,970
To launch it, Well,
you just run it, right?

50
00:02:46,970 --> 00:02:47,760
Let me show you what I mean.

51
00:02:48,910 --> 00:02:53,240
In Windows Server 2012, which is what I'm
running, the power shell icon is added to

52
00:02:53,240 --> 00:02:56,970
the task bar automatically and
if you right click on it,

53
00:02:56,970 --> 00:03:00,530
you'll see one of the options right
here is the Windows Powershell ISE.

54
00:03:00,530 --> 00:03:02,488
You can even run it as
an administrator if you want.

55
00:03:02,488 --> 00:03:06,070
On Windows seven, and Windows Server 2008,
it's under your start menu,

56
00:03:06,070 --> 00:03:10,250
you can go under there and
you'll find Windows PowerShell ISE.

57
00:03:10,250 --> 00:03:14,490
When you launch the ISE,
it's gonna look something like this.

58
00:03:14,490 --> 00:03:17,100
The window is made up of three panes.

59
00:03:17,100 --> 00:03:19,820
In the first pane, this is your code.

60
00:03:19,820 --> 00:03:21,220
This is what you're writing.

61
00:03:21,220 --> 00:03:24,229
The script or
commands that you're gonna be executing.

62
00:03:25,360 --> 00:03:27,970
At the bottom you have
a power shell window.

63
00:03:27,970 --> 00:03:29,760
This is an active power shell window.

64
00:03:29,760 --> 00:03:32,770
I can get in here,
run get-help or whatever and

65
00:03:32,770 --> 00:03:35,038
actually, did you guys see
IntelliSense kick in there?

66
00:03:35,038 --> 00:03:36,060
I type get-h.

67
00:03:36,060 --> 00:03:41,340
Oh now It's not gonna do it cuz I there,
let's try that again, there.

68
00:03:41,340 --> 00:03:45,920
I typed get-h and it's already showing me
all the commands that start with get-h.

69
00:03:45,920 --> 00:03:48,240
Help, history, host, hotfix, and

70
00:03:48,240 --> 00:03:51,740
it's even showing me their
syntax all right here in line.

71
00:03:51,740 --> 00:03:54,110
And I can just ignore that and
keep typing, and

72
00:03:54,110 --> 00:03:57,860
it's gonna keep updating
to show what I'm typing.

73
00:03:57,860 --> 00:03:59,240
Right?
So, really kind of

74
00:03:59,240 --> 00:04:00,390
a neat thing there that it does that.

75
00:04:00,390 --> 00:04:02,070
That's what intellisense adds.

76
00:04:02,070 --> 00:04:05,120
So even if I'm not worried
about writing scripts.

77
00:04:05,120 --> 00:04:08,710
I might still use this just to make it
easier to get the commands that I want.

78
00:04:08,710 --> 00:04:12,270
So I can type get-help and
run it and there went my help file.

79
00:04:12,270 --> 00:04:14,930
And I can scroll back up and
read that, there it is.

80
00:04:14,930 --> 00:04:16,620
The same as a regular PowerShell session.

81
00:04:16,620 --> 00:04:20,770
This is just a PowerShell window down
here with Intelliscents added on top.

82
00:04:21,920 --> 00:04:22,690
All right.

83
00:04:22,690 --> 00:04:26,850
On the right side of the screen,
I can see all of my commands.

84
00:04:26,850 --> 00:04:29,170
There's a giant list of all
the commands right here.

85
00:04:29,170 --> 00:04:33,160
That's rapidly searchable, and
I can filter it by module.

86
00:04:33,160 --> 00:04:35,970
So I can say, you know what,
I just wanna see the DNS commands.

87
00:04:35,970 --> 00:04:37,960
So let me get down here to DNS server.

88
00:04:37,960 --> 00:04:41,160
And now I'm just seeing
the DNS server commands.

89
00:04:41,160 --> 00:04:43,570
So cool part about that
is if I'm down here and

90
00:04:43,570 --> 00:04:46,790
I'm running commands,
up here I can choose a command and

91
00:04:46,790 --> 00:04:50,960
it's gonna give me information on it and
you know my head's sitting on top of it.

92
00:04:50,960 --> 00:04:52,470
Let me change my window size.

93
00:04:52,470 --> 00:04:53,610
There you go.

94
00:04:53,610 --> 00:04:56,870
So it's showing me the command right
there, giving me a basic description.

95
00:04:56,870 --> 00:04:59,670
And then I've got the insert and
copy options.

96
00:04:59,670 --> 00:05:03,110
If I hit insert, it's going to
insert it wherever my cursor was.

97
00:05:03,110 --> 00:05:07,650
So my cursor was down here, apparently
I hit some extra letter as there.

98
00:05:07,650 --> 00:05:11,750
My cursor was down here, and when I hit
insert, it added it in there for me.

99
00:05:11,750 --> 00:05:16,570
Or up here, if I come down and
edit this little script file.

100
00:05:16,570 --> 00:05:20,360
And I hit insert, it's gonna throw it in,
oh actually it threw it in down there but

101
00:05:20,360 --> 00:05:21,870
it should have thrown it in up here.

102
00:05:21,870 --> 00:05:23,400
But quick, easy way to do that,

103
00:05:23,400 --> 00:05:28,100
we can also do copy and
then just come in and paste it.

104
00:05:28,100 --> 00:05:29,120
And there it is too.

105
00:05:29,120 --> 00:05:30,150
So, oh!

106
00:05:30,150 --> 00:05:32,540
I know what to do with the a's,
it's an IPV6 record right?

107
00:05:32,540 --> 00:05:36,850
So we're adding a resource record or
AAAA, that would be an IPV6 record.

108
00:05:38,180 --> 00:05:40,510
All right, so kind of neat, right,

109
00:05:40,510 --> 00:05:43,820
it's all designed to make your
life a little bit easier.

110
00:05:43,820 --> 00:05:48,060
The other nice thing about it is you can
have more than one script open at a time

111
00:05:48,060 --> 00:05:51,460
so the one I'm looking at it
right now is profile dot .ps1.

112
00:05:51,460 --> 00:05:55,720
If you watch the segment on customizing
the user interface for PowerShell.

113
00:05:55,720 --> 00:05:58,790
This is the script that I wrote in
that episode that had all the various

114
00:05:58,790 --> 00:06:00,620
settings to configure my system.

115
00:06:00,620 --> 00:06:03,340
And it's laid that out.

116
00:06:03,340 --> 00:06:05,110
And it's colorized it.

117
00:06:05,110 --> 00:06:09,510
The coloring is designed to help me
recognize when i've made mistakes and

118
00:06:09,510 --> 00:06:10,400
other things.

119
00:06:10,400 --> 00:06:13,850
So notice like dollar sign console here,
that's a variable.

120
00:06:13,850 --> 00:06:17,990
And then the property after it foreground
color is listed and it's in black.

121
00:06:17,990 --> 00:06:21,920
It's letting me know that there
is a difference between those two

122
00:06:21,920 --> 00:06:24,230
as far as what their purpose is.

123
00:06:24,230 --> 00:06:27,190
And let me just kind of zoom in on this
a little bit so you can see it better.

124
00:06:27,190 --> 00:06:28,630
But you can see that coloring.

125
00:06:28,630 --> 00:06:32,900
So all my variable names are nice and
bright red so I can spot where I'm using

126
00:06:32,900 --> 00:06:35,950
those variables and
then I can see the various modifications.

127

here in the console, it's making me
type down here, in this separate bar.

355
00:18:29,990 --> 00:18:33,630
That's kind of nice, it does make it
a little easier to edit because up here,

356
00:18:33,630 --> 00:18:35,860
if you have a mistake
halfway through your command,

357
00:18:35,860 --> 00:18:38,110
you can't just click your cursor and
be halfway.

358
00:18:38,110 --> 00:18:43,040
You have to use your arrow keys, but down
here I can click my cursor wherever I want

359
00:18:43,040 --> 00:18:46,440
and it'll jump around and
get to it, and that's kind of nice.

360
00:18:46,440 --> 00:18:48,060
And your history still works.

361
00:18:48,060 --> 00:18:51,345
You can still use up and down arrows while
you're down here to pull up the commands

362
00:18:51,345 --> 00:18:54,080
that you've typed before,
so that's kind of nice.

363
00:18:54,080 --> 00:18:56,749
But now that's gonna run and
there's my output.

364
00:18:56,749 --> 00:19:01,829
I guess my foreground stayed black,
which is not showing up on.

365
00:19:01,829 --> 00:19:05,901
What you guys are seeing, you're just
seeing the blue plane there, but

366
00:19:05,901 --> 00:19:09,790
it's just black on blue,
which is practically impossible to read.

367
00:19:11,170 --> 00:19:14,156
Yeah, I guess my foreground
color is just not taking effect.

368
00:19:14,156 --> 00:19:17,680
Well, in Power GUI I know we have the
settings, if I go into the preferences or

369
00:19:17,680 --> 00:19:23,790
options, you can go in there and
customize the colors somewhere in here.

370
00:19:23,790 --> 00:19:26,330
Well, whatever,
I don't wanna fight with all that.

371
00:19:26,330 --> 00:19:32,550
But you can get that changed and
get everything kind of in place.

372
00:19:32,550 --> 00:19:33,105
And it's neat.

373
00:19:33,105 --> 00:19:35,625
You know, it's just another
simple way to work the thing.

374
00:19:35,625 --> 00:19:39,955
The PowerGUI itself is not necessarily
distinct from PowerShell ISE,

375
00:19:39,955 --> 00:19:41,515
until you get to the add-ons.

376
00:19:41,515 --> 00:19:46,155
With PowerGUI, what really makes it
special is what they call PowerPacks.

377
00:19:46,155 --> 00:19:49,135
And pretty much anybody can write
PowerPacks to stick on here and

378
00:19:49,135 --> 00:19:51,535
do all sorts of crazy other things.

379
00:19:51,535 --> 00:19:55,570
It's kinda like adding modules to
PowerShell, and they're available for

380
00:19:55,570 --> 00:19:58,320
download right from the PowerGUI
site which, if you ever wanna go to,

381
00:19:58,320 --> 00:20:04,400
is PowerGUI.org and it'll redirect to
Dell because Dell controls it now.

382
00:20:04,400 --> 00:20:08,315
So if you go to PowerGUI.org, you'll end
up right here on the Dell Tech Center.

383
00:20:08,315 --> 00:20:12,095
And this is the PowerGUI page, and
you can download it from here.

384
00:20:12,095 --> 00:20:15,355
They've got their documentation and
other information.

385
00:20:15,355 --> 00:20:20,200
And in here, they've got a link somewhere,
right here, that goes to the PowerPacks.

386
00:20:20,200 --> 00:20:21,270
And when you go into the PowerPacks,

387
00:20:21,270 --> 00:20:23,790
you'll see they've got ones for
all sorts of things.

388
00:20:23,790 --> 00:20:30,110
They've got Windows Media Player, Twitter,
Facebook, you'll find Amazon Web Services,

389
00:20:30,110 --> 00:20:34,580
all sorts of PowerPacks they've added
to create that additional functionality

390
00:20:34,580 --> 00:20:38,240
without having to go and install
the management tools for that software.

391
00:20:38,240 --> 00:20:39,460
That's kinda nice.

392
00:20:39,460 --> 00:20:42,980
With the PowerShell ISE, a lot of the
add-ons to it come with the software so

393
00:20:42,980 --> 00:20:46,150
you've gotta go and install that, and
that makes it a little more challenging.

394
00:20:46,150 --> 00:20:50,170
So, you'll see a lot of neat
stuff in there, it's pretty cool.

395
00:20:50,170 --> 00:20:54,540
So the PowerShell ISE or the PowerGUI,
they really do the same thing.

396
00:20:54,540 --> 00:20:58,300
They're giving you that graphical
development type interface

397
00:20:58,300 --> 00:21:01,790
that lets you write out a script,
do debugging, checking,

398
00:21:01,790 --> 00:21:04,880
and testing,
all from a controlled environment.

399
00:21:04,880 --> 00:21:09,700
And then when it's ready, you save your
script, you take it over to a server, and

400
00:21:09,700 --> 00:21:13,130
you execute it knowing that the script
will work right the first time,

401
00:21:13,130 --> 00:21:16,910
because you've already done thorough
testing and development, right?

402
00:21:16,910 --> 00:21:19,170
That's what PowerShell ISE is for.

403
00:21:19,170 --> 00:21:22,260
Now, a lot of people aren't even
aware of the PowerShell ISE, but

404
00:21:22,260 --> 00:21:24,020
it is installed by default.

405
00:21:24,020 --> 00:21:26,540
It's just most people click
on the icon down here, and

406
00:21:26,540 --> 00:21:30,210
never think about right-clicking
on it to see these other options.

407
00:21:30,210 --> 00:21:33,633
But even in your screen, if you go and
pull up your start screen and

408
00:21:33,633 --> 00:21:37,695
start typing in PowerShell, you'll see
where the ISE shows up right there.

409
00:21:37,695 --> 00:21:42,814
So, it is available, it's a part of
PowerShell from 2.0 on, it's there.

410
00:21:42,814 --> 00:21:47,000
All right, it seems like there's
something else that I wanted to mention.

411
00:21:49,890 --> 00:21:53,570
Oh, one other nice thing that I
like to use with PowerShell ISE

412
00:21:53,570 --> 00:21:58,270
is it has context-sensitive help, and
let me show you what I mean by that.

413
00:21:58,270 --> 00:22:00,774
If I go back into PowerShell,
into the PowerShell ISE,

414
00:22:00,774 --> 00:22:02,380
I'm gonna do an all new file.

415
00:22:02,380 --> 00:22:04,150
Right, so I'm just getting started.

416
00:22:04,150 --> 00:22:07,410
Well, if I hit F1 on my keyboard,

417
00:22:07,410 --> 00:22:09,660
it's gonna pull up the help
documentation just for PowerShell.

418
00:22:09,660 --> 00:22:13,220
So here it is, PowerShell ISE,
its help file.

419
00:22:13,220 --> 00:22:17,850
But if I start typing, so
if I'm doing Get-Help and

420
00:22:17,850 --> 00:22:21,290
then I press F1, it's gonna take
me to the help documentation.

421
00:22:21,290 --> 00:22:23,640
And [LAUGH] it totally failed to do it.

422
00:22:23,640 --> 00:22:27,210
It's supposed to take me to the health
documentation for Get-Help.

423
00:22:27,210 --> 00:22:29,220
Did I not have my cursor
in the right spot?

424
00:22:31,030 --> 00:22:31,760
Let's try that again.

425
00:22:33,490 --> 00:22:34,740
There we go.

426
00:22:34,740 --> 00:22:36,970
I put my cursor on Get-Help this time.

427
00:22:36,970 --> 00:22:38,930
And there it goes,
it popped up the right window.

428
00:22:38,930 --> 00:22:43,760
And I'm getting the help for that command,
so I didn't have to run Get-Help myself,

429
00:22:43,760 --> 00:22:48,390
it actually ran it for me and it did
that show window modifier to make it

430
00:22:48,390 --> 00:22:53,350
pop up in an extra window and now I've got
the syntax for that command right here.

431
00:22:53,350 --> 00:22:57,910
Just by using the F1 key, you click on the
command you want help on, you hit F1 and

432
00:22:57,910 --> 00:23:00,860
it comes up and
you could even pick other things.

433
00:23:00,860 --> 00:23:03,180
You know, I've got get-date right here.

434
00:23:03,180 --> 00:23:07,200
And if we go on pullet,
here's the help forget-date.

435
00:23:07,200 --> 00:23:08,730
So not even from my script up here,

436
00:23:08,730 --> 00:23:12,390
just from the actual console window and
it gave me the help that I needed.

437
00:23:12,390 --> 00:23:13,960
Pretty cool, pretty convenient, right.

438
00:23:13,960 --> 00:23:16,660
Those are some of the things
that we get with PowerShell ISE

439
00:23:16,660 --> 00:23:20,390
that are a lot easier to work with
than just being in the console itself.

440
00:23:21,922 --> 00:23:23,820
All right, well,
that's all I've got on those.

441
00:23:23,820 --> 00:23:25,780
Obviously there's a lot of
power to those utilities.

442
00:23:25,780 --> 00:23:27,330
Definitely experiment around with them,
but for

443
00:23:27,330 --> 00:23:31,952
most people that's the basic functionality
that you need to use them successfully.

444
00:23:31,952 --> 00:23:33,788
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

445
00:23:33,788 --> 00:23:37,141
Stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up.

446
00:23:37,141 --> 00:23:42,900
[SOUND]

episodes.title: PowerShell Drives
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.040
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.040 --> 00:00:11.890
In this segment we're gonna take
a look at PowerShell drives.

3
00:00:11.890 --> 00:00:14.970
Now, most of us have worked with hard
drives at one point or another and

4
00:00:14.970 --> 00:00:18.950
if you're using the PowerShell,
it's pretty likely that you have too.

5
00:00:18.950 --> 00:00:22.830
And so we're used to the way of thinking
that's been available inside of Windows

6
00:00:22.830 --> 00:00:28.280
and DOS way back 20, 30 years ago,
where we have a folder structure and

7
00:00:28.280 --> 00:00:31.460
we navigate around on our
hard drive to access files.

8
00:00:31.460 --> 00:00:34.875
Well, you can do all that
in the PowerShell, too, but

9
00:00:34.875 --> 00:00:38.720
in the PowerShell,
they're not actually files.

10
00:00:38.720 --> 00:00:39.720
They look like they are.

11
00:00:39.720 --> 00:00:41.880
It looks like we're browsing
around in that folder structure,

12
00:00:41.880 --> 00:00:43.395
but we really aren't.

13
00:00:43.395 --> 00:00:49.410
PowerShell, the whole interface, is really
just kind of emulating what we're used to.

14
00:00:49.410 --> 00:00:53.050
And that means in PowerShell, because
these aren't really the folder structures

15
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:58.240
that we're looking at, it can represent
all sorts of things as a drive letter.

16
00:00:58.240 --> 00:01:01.930
So, when I say PowerShell drives,
I'm not just talking about your C drive or

17
00:01:01.930 --> 00:01:03.360
a file system.

18
00:01:03.360 --> 00:01:07.220
A PowerShell drive could
point to a lot of things.

19
00:01:07.220 --> 00:01:11.290
Things like the registry or
your variable store,

20
00:01:11.290 --> 00:01:14.710
your alias store, it can point to
all sorts of of really cool things.

21
00:01:14.710 --> 00:01:16.250
And allows you to navigate around and

22
00:01:16.250 --> 00:01:18.820
work with it as if it were
part of the file system.

23
00:01:18.820 --> 00:01:23.820
So it takes this older mentality, this
methodology we've been using for years and

24
00:01:23.820 --> 00:01:27.360
years and years, and then places
it on top of other technologies,

25
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:28.580
which is really powerful.

26
00:01:29.620 --> 00:01:33.230
Let me show you some examples and we'll
kind of get an idea of how this works.

27
00:01:33.230 --> 00:01:36.440
And then we'll do and a few more segments
later on when we'll show how to work with

28
00:01:36.440 --> 00:01:38.270
specific entities inside of it.

29
00:01:38.270 --> 00:01:40.830
But let's just start by
taking a look at how

30
00:01:40.830 --> 00:01:43.990
regular file system functions
happen inside of PowerShell.

31
00:01:43.990 --> 00:01:45.545
So I'm going to fire up my PowerShell.

32
00:01:46.810 --> 00:01:50.980
And once we're in, it gives me
a representation that's a file system.

33
00:01:50.980 --> 00:01:55.080
Right, I see I'm in C:\Users\Don Pezet.

34
00:01:55.080 --> 00:01:57.700
And if I want to change directories and

35
00:01:57.700 --> 00:02:02.985
things like that,
I can do cd..to move up one directory.

36
00:02:02.985 --> 00:02:06.765
Or, if I'm in my own directory like that,

37
00:02:06.765 --> 00:02:09.745
I could do cd\,
to go all the way to the root.

38
00:02:09.745 --> 00:02:12.785
Those commands have been
present in Windows forever.

39
00:02:12.785 --> 00:02:14.635
Right, and present in DOS before that.

40
00:02:14.635 --> 00:02:16.095
These are not anything new.

41
00:02:17.145 --> 00:02:20.625
And if I've got a C drive and
a D drive, and an E drive,

42
00:02:20.625 --> 00:02:25.740
I could always switch between those
by typing e: or d:, and switching.

43
00:02:25.740 --> 00:02:26.370
Right.

44
00:02:26.370 --> 00:02:30.110
So those commands that we're used to,
they're are still there, right,

45
00:02:30.110 --> 00:02:31.170
they still work.

46
00:02:31.170 --> 00:02:33.210
But they're really aliases.

47
00:02:33.210 --> 00:02:37.170
Notice when I tried to change to e:, I
was trying to switch to that other drive.

48
00:02:37.170 --> 00:02:38.740
Look at the error that I got,

49
00:02:38.740 --> 00:02:41.090
well I don't have an E drive
right that's my first problem.

50
00:02:41.090 --> 00:02:42.660
But I got an error and

51
00:02:42.660 --> 00:02:47.060
it's telling me that set location
cannot find the drive, all right.

52
00:02:47.060 --> 00:02:52.895
So when I tried to switch by just typing
E: it was actually hitting an alias for

53
00:02:52.895 --> 00:02:56.290
set-location to try and
change that drive to access it.

54
00:02:56.290 --> 00:02:58.360
And then just letting me know
that a drive doesn't exist for

55
00:02:58.360 --> 00:03:02.910
that name and it's a PowerShell object
that it's referencing down here.

56
00:03:02.910 --> 00:03:08.440
Now, that object could actually
point to a lot of stuff, right.

57
00:03:08.440 --> 00:03:10.590
In fact, depending on
the software you've installed,

58
00:03:10.590 --> 00:03:12.420
you may have all sorts of crazy
things that even I don't.

59
00:03:12.420 --> 00:03:13.750
But let's take a look at the defaults.

60
00:03:13.750 --> 00:03:16.060
I just have the default stuff on mine.

61
00:03:16.060 --> 00:03:19.862
I'm going to run Get-PSDrives.

62
00:03:19.862 --> 00:03:22.880
Oops, sorry, it's not plural, Get-PSDrive.

63
00:03:22.880 --> 00:03:23.580
There we go.

64
00:03:24.580 --> 00:03:29.500
So when I do Get-PSDrive, it lists
the drives that I have on my system.

65
00:03:29.500 --> 00:03:31.200
And I can see that I've
got a handful of them.

66
00:03:31.200 --> 00:03:35.630
I did not make any of these, these were
all put here by default in Windows.

67
00:03:35.630 --> 00:03:37.870
And I can see the C drive.

68
00:03:37.870 --> 00:03:40.920
Right.
There is that hard drive that I'm in

69
00:03:40.920 --> 00:03:41.950
right now.

70
00:03:41.950 --> 00:03:46.280
It shows that I'm using 22 gigs of it,
it's actually a 40 gig drive, and

71
00:03:46.280 --> 00:03:50.370
it's a file system, and
I reference it as C:\.

72
00:03:50.370 --> 00:03:53.540
I've got a D:\ and an A:\.

73
00:03:53.540 --> 00:03:56.150
So I've got a few other pads
there that I can navigate.

74
00:03:56.150 --> 00:04:01.430
In terms of the file system,
those are the ones we're used to, right?

75
00:04:01.430 --> 00:04:03.200
But what are all these other things?

76
00:04:03.200 --> 00:04:08.230
Well, all the other ones that are listed
here are other types of drives, and

77
00:04:08.230 --> 00:04:11.420
some of them are really cool like
the registry ones right here.

78
00:04:11.420 --> 00:04:13.098
H K C U.

79
00:04:13.098 --> 00:04:15.560
What kind of drive letter is that?

80
00:04:15.560 --> 00:04:19.430
If I type HKCU:.

81
00:04:19.430 --> 00:04:21.510
Well, it gives me an error right.

82
00:04:21.510 --> 00:04:26.250
So it's telling me here that it's not
recognizing the name of a command-let.

83
00:04:26.250 --> 00:04:29.010
Well that's because it's not
like a single drive letter.

84
00:04:29.010 --> 00:04:35.030
But if I try and change directory into it,
HKCU:, my path changes.

85
00:04:35.030 --> 00:04:38.110
I just changed into a new drive.

86
00:04:38.110 --> 00:04:39.150
A drive called HKCU.

87
00:04:39.150 --> 00:04:39.890
What the heck is that?

88
00:04:39.890 --> 00:04:43.260
Well that stands for H key current user.

89
00:04:43.260 --> 00:04:44.780
That's a registry hive.

90
00:04:44.780 --> 00:04:48.210
If you want to edit values or
query values from the registry,

91
00:04:48.210 --> 00:04:53.560
you can browse right into your
registry as if it were a file system.

92
00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:55.100
And you can start to browse into here.

93
00:04:55.100 --> 00:05:00.030
So if I wanted to find things that
run when my computer starts, right?

94
00:05:00.030 --> 00:05:03.210
So I might go into HK current user,
or HP current user.

95
00:05:03.210 --> 00:05:05.500
Go into, what is it software?

96
00:05:05.500 --> 00:05:07.320
Let's see if I can remember this one.

97
00:05:07.320 --> 00:05:10.616
Software, Microsoft and Windows.

98
00:05:10.616 --> 00:05:15.785
And current version.

99
00:05:15.785 --> 00:05:17.990
And run I believe is the next folder.

100
00:05:17.990 --> 00:05:19.300
Yep, there it is.

101
00:05:19.300 --> 00:05:22.520
So I just browsed into my registry.

102
00:05:22.520 --> 00:05:26.220
And I can just run a dir and
see if there's anything in there.

103
00:05:26.220 --> 00:05:29.850
Now each of these providers
works a little bit differently.

104
00:05:29.850 --> 00:05:32.638
And we're going to do a segment on
the registry a little bit later.

105
00:05:32.638 --> 00:05:34.100
But that dir command,

106
00:05:34.100 --> 00:05:36.960
normally it says show me all
the files that are in this folder.

107
00:05:38.000 --> 00:05:41.370
Well, what files do I have
inside of my registry?

108
00:05:41.370 --> 00:05:42.330
None.

109
00:05:42.330 --> 00:05:47.780
The dir command is not really functional,
for the registry.

110
00:05:47.780 --> 00:05:51.180
Instead of looking for files,
I should be looking for parameters.

111
00:05:51.180 --> 00:05:52.510
Right?
In the registry,

112
00:05:52.510 --> 00:05:54.470
each folder is called a key.

113
00:05:54.470 --> 00:05:56.220
And that's what I've been
navigating right there, folder.

114
00:05:56.220 --> 00:05:59.640
So when I type dir, it's looking for
folders and it's not finding any.

115
00:05:59.640 --> 00:06:01.670
So now I need to look for parameters.

116
00:06:01.670 --> 00:06:04.380
I need to start diving into it, and
we'll do a segment on the registry and

117
00:06:04.380 --> 00:06:05.460
I'll show you guys how to do that.

118
00:06:05.460 --> 00:06:07.390
How to work with those
registry values in there.

119
00:06:07.390 --> 00:06:10.920
But what I wanted to show you though was
that I'm accessing the registry as if it

120
00:06:10.920 --> 00:06:11.700
was a file system.

121
00:06:12.760 --> 00:06:18.089
The same thing goes for things like
aliases and functions, when I did get-PS

122
00:06:18.089 --> 00:06:24.160
drive, I saw that I had Function,
Alias, Variable, Cert, right.

123
00:06:24.160 --> 00:06:27.880
Each one of these is pointing at
some kind of resource in my system.

124
00:06:27.880 --> 00:06:28.940
Cert, for example.

125
00:06:28.940 --> 00:06:30.270
I didn't run this as an administrator, so

126
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:32.530
it's probably gonna get
mad at me at one point.

127
00:06:32.530 --> 00:06:36.590
But if I change into that Cert directory,
and I start looking around,

128
00:06:36.590 --> 00:06:40.740
I can see I've got user certificates and
local machine certificates.

129
00:06:40.740 --> 00:06:44.850
I'll go into my user certificates,
since I should have access to that.

130
00:06:44.850 --> 00:06:45.710
And I can pull it up and

131
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:49.050
I can start to see some of
the different folders I have in there.

132
00:06:49.050 --> 00:06:53.850
So if I want to see who I trust, right,
my trust certificates, or my certificates,
