c:/windows/system32/powershell.

364
00:18:33.079 --> 00:18:34.920
The ones that are buried down in there.

365
00:18:34.920 --> 00:18:36.920
Those are the ones that
apply to all users, and

366
00:18:36.920 --> 00:18:38.470
you might want to consider that.

367
00:18:38.470 --> 00:18:40.200
The other option is not to use these.

368
00:18:40.200 --> 00:18:43.250
And in your scripts instead just to use
the ones that you know are going to

369
00:18:43.250 --> 00:18:44.030
be present.

370
00:18:44.030 --> 00:18:46.660
That's why Microsoft
creates these by default.

371
00:18:46.660 --> 00:18:49.140
Right.
Because everyone will have those.

372
00:18:49.140 --> 00:18:50.340
You can use them in your scripts and

373
00:18:50.340 --> 00:18:53.720
you'll be just fine,
even if somebody else runs them.

374
00:18:53.720 --> 00:18:55.640
So just be aware of that.

375
00:18:55.640 --> 00:18:59.860
The other thing is if you create
a PS drive so I'll do another one.

376
00:18:59.860 --> 00:19:02.150
Maybe I'll do one to
the registry this time right so

377
00:19:02.150 --> 00:19:06.650
I might say new PS drive dash name.

378
00:19:06.650 --> 00:19:11.390
And I'll call this the run.

379
00:19:11.390 --> 00:19:16.221
Right, so these would be things that run
when my system starts up or when logon or

380
00:19:16.221 --> 00:19:16.950
whatever.

381
00:19:16.950 --> 00:19:19.310
So I'm gonna map somewhere
into the registry.

382
00:19:19.310 --> 00:19:21.540
And I'll set my provider as registry.

383
00:19:22.790 --> 00:19:27.021
And then I need to specify the route and
for the route I just need tell

384
00:19:27.021 --> 00:19:30.588
it where I'm gonna to be mapping to and
so I might map to.

385
00:19:30.588 --> 00:19:41.545
HKCU:/SOFTWARE/Microsoft/Windows/Current

386
00:19:41.545 --> 00:19:44.954
Version/run.

387
00:19:48.775 --> 00:19:52.737
All right, so I'm creating that mapping,
what did I do here?

388
00:19:52.737 --> 00:19:55.183
A perimeter cannot be found
that matches provider.

389
00:19:55.183 --> 00:19:57.018
Shoot.
Is it PS provider?

390
00:19:57.018 --> 00:19:58.550
Oh, it is PS provider.

391
00:19:58.550 --> 00:19:59.810
There's a little typo on my part there.

392
00:19:59.810 --> 00:20:02.690
Let me change that from dash
provider to dash PS provider.

393
00:20:02.690 --> 00:20:03.780
There we go.

394
00:20:03.780 --> 00:20:06.850
All right so
now I've got this new PS drive.

395
00:20:09.660 --> 00:20:10.537
And so there it is.

396
00:20:10.537 --> 00:20:13.958
I can see I've created this
one that's called run.

397
00:20:13.958 --> 00:20:17.290
And if I were to change into it would take
me right into that eight key current user

398
00:20:17.290 --> 00:20:19.630
and into that key to be
able to browse to it.

399
00:20:19.630 --> 00:20:25.970
If I want to get rid of it, I can use
the remove dash PS drive command line.

400
00:20:25.970 --> 00:20:27.410
One little word of advice though.

401
00:20:27.410 --> 00:20:32.120
It doesn't work if you
are in the drive yourself.

402
00:20:32.120 --> 00:20:38.950
So if I'm in that PS drive and I'm working
around in here doing whatever direction.

403
00:20:38.950 --> 00:20:40.270
I'm already all the way in aren't I?

404
00:20:40.270 --> 00:20:40.940
Yup.

405
00:20:40.940 --> 00:20:45.790
So if I'm in there and I'm working and
I try and do a remove dash PS drive.

406
00:20:47.140 --> 00:20:52.030
And I specify that name in the name
of mine is just run, right.

407
00:20:52.030 --> 00:20:53.900
It's going to get an error because
it says it's in use, right, so

408
00:20:53.900 --> 00:20:56.480
you've got to get out of the drive first.

409
00:20:56.480 --> 00:20:58.820
And you can just move to another drive or
whatever and

410
00:20:58.820 --> 00:21:01.390
then you'll be able to remove it and
it's gone right.

411
00:21:01.390 --> 00:21:04.423
So if you're just using it temporarily,
like you have a script and

412
00:21:04.423 --> 00:21:06.818
at the beginning of the script
it creates a mapping.

413
00:21:06.818 --> 00:21:09.853
And then at the end of the script
you want to remove it again,

414
00:21:09.853 --> 00:21:11.629
you just use remove dash PS drive.

415
00:21:11.629 --> 00:21:12.960
It's pretty cool functionality.

416
00:21:12.960 --> 00:21:15.490
It's one that a lot of people
don't even know is there.

417
00:21:15.490 --> 00:21:18.940
Because when we look at this prompt,
we immediately think file system.

418
00:21:18.940 --> 00:21:21.490
And we expect things to
work like a file system.

419
00:21:21.490 --> 00:21:24.770
But over time you start to learn that hey,

420
00:21:24.770 --> 00:21:27.110
I'm not really looking
at the file system here.

421
00:21:27.110 --> 00:21:31.370
It's making it look like that,
it's making it look pretty but in reality.

422
00:21:31.370 --> 00:21:34.310
I'm looking at just output of
variables coming from PowerShell.

423
00:21:34.310 --> 00:21:35.810
And so these things, these drive letters,

424
00:21:35.810 --> 00:21:38.440
they can represent
whatever I want them to.

425
00:21:38.440 --> 00:21:39.660
And that's what PS Drives are all about.

426
00:21:41.380 --> 00:21:42.080
All right.
So,

427
00:21:42.080 --> 00:21:45.340
in this segment we got a chance to take
a look at what PowerShell drives were.

428
00:21:45.340 --> 00:21:47.530
We saw the default ones
that were already there.

429
00:21:47.530 --> 00:21:49.600
We got a chance to see how to create them.

430
00:21:49.600 --> 00:21:50.140
Work with them.

431
00:21:50.140 --> 00:21:51.930
And ultimately remove them.

432
00:21:51.930 --> 00:21:55.671
And just another thing to remember as I
mentioned we might want to add those to

433
00:21:55.671 --> 00:21:59.179
our profile so they'll be launched
in created every time that we launch

434
00:21:59.179 --> 00:22:01.417
a PowerShell and they're available for us.

435
00:22:01.417 --> 00:22:02.949
It's a really cool technology.

436
00:22:02.949 --> 00:22:06.195
Something you can take advantage of to
make your life a little bit easier.

437
00:22:06.195 --> 00:22:08.062
All right well I hope you
guys enjoyed the segment.

438
00:22:08.062 --> 00:22:15.215
Stay tuned we've got more
PowerShell coming up.

episodes.title: Add/Remove Roles and Features
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,125 --> 00:00:08,236
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,236 --> 00:00:12,268
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at how to add and remove Windows roles and

3
00:00:12,268 --> 00:00:14,640
features via the Powershell.

4
00:00:14,640 --> 00:00:16,720
Now this is a pretty easy function.

5
00:00:16,720 --> 00:00:19,530
I know a lot of you guys probably use the
server manager and go right in there and

6
00:00:19,530 --> 00:00:21,140
add whatever roles you want.

7
00:00:21,140 --> 00:00:25,740
But if you're trying to deploy large
quantities of servers one of the easiest

8
00:00:25,740 --> 00:00:29,260
things to automate is having the basic
roles and features installed.

9
00:00:29,260 --> 00:00:33,590
We can write a PowerShell Script
that not only deploys various roles

10
00:00:33,590 --> 00:00:34,190
but then goes on.

11
00:00:34,190 --> 00:00:37,060
On to configure them, and
get them set the way we want.

12
00:00:37,060 --> 00:00:40,440
So whenever we deploy a new server, we
can just throw a windows server image on

13
00:00:40,440 --> 00:00:44,060
there, and then run a powershell
script and now we've got a DNS server.

14
00:00:44,060 --> 00:00:46,440
Or run a powershell scrip and
now we've got an FTP server.

15
00:00:46,440 --> 00:00:49,500
Run a powershell script and
now we've got our web server, right.

16
00:00:49,500 --> 00:00:53,670
Really quick, really easy to set up and
spawn; but the first step of that

17
00:00:53,670 --> 00:00:56,680
is getting the right roles and
features in place, alright.

18
00:00:56,680 --> 00:00:59,410
Now, the process I managed to get with
the Powershell is actually pretty easy.

19
00:00:59,410 --> 00:01:01,910
There's only a handful of commands
that we need to remember.

20
00:01:01,910 --> 00:01:04,520
and the output of those
commands is pretty informative,

21
00:01:04,520 --> 00:01:07,650
so this is one of the simpler
tasks that we have to deal with.

22
00:01:07,650 --> 00:01:10,780
But, there's a lot of terminology in
it that can be difficult to remember,

23
00:01:10,780 --> 00:01:13,330
so I always rely on some of my
get commands to pull that up.

24
00:01:13,330 --> 00:01:14,520
And let me show you what I mean.

25
00:01:15,550 --> 00:01:20,030
The first command I want to show you is
the get dash Windows feature command.

26
00:01:20,030 --> 00:01:23,300
Now I know we're talking
about roles in features, but

27
00:01:23,300 --> 00:01:26,330
in the power shell it doesn't
discriminate between the two.

28
00:01:26,330 --> 00:01:28,650
It treats roles and features the same way.

29
00:01:28,650 --> 00:01:31,320
In fact, all throughout Windows
they're treated the same way,

30
00:01:31,320 --> 00:01:35,610
the only difference is in the GUI
that we see in the server manager.

31
00:01:35,610 --> 00:01:40,170
Microsoft does that as a favor to us to
say if it's a role, that's a big deal.

32
00:01:40,170 --> 00:01:42,920
That's something that needs
additional configuration.

33
00:01:42,920 --> 00:01:44,950
If it's a feature, that's a minor thing.

34
00:01:44,950 --> 00:01:46,720
Probably doesn't need
configuration at all.

35
00:01:46,720 --> 00:01:51,035
So that's simply a separation they
make in the GUI, not on the back end.

36
00:01:51,035 --> 00:01:54,245
So, on the back end we'll never
really see that word role.

37
00:01:54,245 --> 00:01:55,705
We're always gonna see feature.

38
00:01:55,705 --> 00:01:58,995
So, pretty much everything is
treated as a feature back here and

39
00:01:58,995 --> 00:02:02,155
if I do get dash Windows feature,

40
00:02:02,155 --> 00:02:06,870
it's going to give me a list of all of the
features that are available to Windows.

41
00:02:06,870 --> 00:02:10,190
And it lays them out in a nice
little hierarchical view and

42
00:02:10,190 --> 00:02:15,420
you'll see how some of these have
little xs to the left of them, right?

43
00:02:15,420 --> 00:02:18,720
And that x is letting me know
that that one is installed and

44
00:02:18,720 --> 00:02:21,820
then after that some of them
have empty boxes to the left and

45
00:02:21,820 --> 00:02:24,870
that's letting me know that
they are not installed, right?

46
00:02:24,870 --> 00:02:27,850
There's really three different
statuses that we'll see here.

47
00:02:27,850 --> 00:02:30,530
There's installed so we've already got it.

48
00:02:30,530 --> 00:02:34,900
There's available which means
it's on our hard drive but

49
00:02:34,900 --> 00:02:36,350
it's in the protected storage.

50
00:02:36,350 --> 00:02:38,270
We haven't actually moved it out for use.

51
00:02:38,270 --> 00:02:41,580
So you can't use it yet but
it is available if you want it.

52
00:02:41,580 --> 00:02:43,800
The third one is remove.

53
00:02:43,800 --> 00:02:46,470
You wont really see remove by default.

54
00:02:46,470 --> 00:02:50,980
When you deploy a server all of
the installation files from Windows Server

55
00:02:50,980 --> 00:02:53,050
2012 are copied along with it.

56
00:02:53,050 --> 00:02:55,780
And you may not want that,
you may not want to have these

57
00:02:55,780 --> 00:02:58,600
extra files sitting there because it
can increase your attack surface.

58
00:02:58,600 --> 00:03:03,170
So in high security environments,
they'll remove the installation files.

59
00:03:03,170 --> 00:03:07,620
And if that happens, you'll see
the feature or roll listed here and

60
00:03:07,620 --> 00:03:09,588
over here on it's status it will say,
removed.

61
00:03:09,588 --> 00:03:13,990
And that let;s you know that it's not
installed and if you ant to install it,

62
00:03:13,990 --> 00:03:17,670
you're gonna need to bring
along a Windows Media disc or

63
00:03:17,670 --> 00:03:20,915
have a network chair somewhere that has
the Windows installation files on it.

64
00:03:20,915 --> 00:03:23,840
'Cause otherwise, we're not gonna
be able to get to it, all right?

65
00:03:23,840 --> 00:03:26,380
So those are the three statuses
that we'll see as long.

66
00:03:26,380 --> 00:03:28,830
As it's listed as available,
we can install it and

67
00:03:28,830 --> 00:03:29,950
we won't have to provide any media.

68
00:03:31,190 --> 00:03:33,940
Now, this view does get
a little bit cluttered.

69
00:03:33,940 --> 00:03:37,140
So, one nice thing that we can do
is we can filter it a good bit.

70
00:03:37,140 --> 00:03:40,390
And the filtering,
Microsoft's actually anticipated this, so

71
00:03:40,390 --> 00:03:41,910
they created some shortcuts.

72
00:03:41,910 --> 00:03:45,890
The long way to filter this would
be to do like a crazy query.

73
00:03:45,890 --> 00:03:50,790
But if I just wanted to see what was
installed, for example, the long form of

74
00:03:50,790 --> 00:03:56,460
it would be to do Get-windowsFeature and

75
00:03:56,460 --> 00:04:00,820
then pipe that output into
a filter like where object.

76
00:04:00,820 --> 00:04:08,960
So I'll do where-object $_ and
I'm gonna query the install state.

77
00:04:10,190 --> 00:04:15,550
And I'm looking for where that install
state is listed as Installed, right?

78
00:04:15,550 --> 00:04:18,620
So there's my filter
just showing me those.

79
00:04:18,620 --> 00:04:22,240
Well now it's gonna give me a list and
I'll see all the installed ones, right?

80
00:04:22,240 --> 00:04:26,230
But Microsoft knows that this is
a pretty common query and so they

81
00:04:26,230 --> 00:04:30,700
actually made that kind of a default of
part of the syntax in get WindowsFeature.

82
00:04:30,700 --> 00:04:35,930
You can just run get-WindowsFeature,
well if you can spell it.

83
00:04:35,930 --> 00:04:42,260
There, get-windowsFeature, and then you
can pipe that and say where install.

84
00:04:42,260 --> 00:04:46,920
The install status, that one's actually
the primary value for this table.

85
00:04:46,920 --> 00:04:50,610
So when we just say where install,
it'll automatically do that and

86
00:04:50,610 --> 00:04:52,950
bring it right up, and we can do that for
the other statuses too.

87
00:04:52,950 --> 00:04:57,420
You can say like where available and
it'll bring those up and it'll show

88
00:04:57,420 --> 00:05:01,520
the ones that are available for install
which apparently it didn't pull for me.

89
00:05:01,520 --> 00:05:05,650
All right,
well [LAUGH] one I actually do a little

90
00:05:05,650 --> 00:05:10,470
more often is I'll do -ne,
so not equal to installed.

91
00:05:10,470 --> 00:05:12,600
In other words, show me all
the ones that aren't installed,

92
00:05:12,600 --> 00:05:15,340
which apparently it didn't like that
one either, what have I done here?

93
00:05:15,340 --> 00:05:17,820
Oh, with that one because
I'm doing a modifier,

94
00:05:17,820 --> 00:05:22,040
I actually have to specify install
state as what I'm querying.

95
00:05:22,040 --> 00:05:24,800
So, where the install state
is not equal to install then,

96
00:05:24,800 --> 00:05:29,820
I'll bet that's why my available
query didn't work a minute ago, too.

97
00:05:29,820 --> 00:05:32,440
So, when you run these,
the aliases are nice,

98
00:05:32,440 --> 00:05:37,090
they make life a little bit more simple
but you have to remember what they are.

99
00:05:37,090 --> 00:05:38,470
So, that's the challenge there.

100
00:05:39,500 --> 00:05:40,670
All right,
I went through those kind of quickly.

101
00:05:40,670 --> 00:05:42,590
Let me just recap the commands that I did.

102
00:05:42,590 --> 00:05:47,140
So to pull the list of installed ones,
I said get-windowsFeature, and

103
00:05:47,140 --> 00:05:49,430
I typed that into where, install.

104
00:05:49,430 --> 00:05:54,590
All right, and then to get the ones that
were not installed I had to add a little

105
00:05:54,590 --> 00:05:59,400
bit more to that and so I said where
InstallState is not equal to Installed.

106
00:05:59,400 --> 00:06:02,458
And that'll give me the ones that are
available and the ones that are removed.

107
00:06:02,458 --> 00:06:05,010
So it kinda breaks that out for
us and we can see it.

108
00:06:05,010 --> 00:06:10,250
So those are available, more commonly
though, I'm not looking for all of them.

109
00:06:10,250 --> 00:06:12,140
I'm looking for a particular feature.

110
00:06:12,140 --> 00:06:15,530
I might be just interested
in one particular thing.

111
00:06:15,530 --> 00:06:19,200
So I might do something
like get-windowsfeature and

112
00:06:19,200 --> 00:06:23,710
then specify a particular
feature like DHCP and

113
00:06:23,710 --> 00:06:26,290
now it's gonna bring back
that DHCP server, right.

114
00:06:26,290 --> 00:06:31,080
So there it is, that's the one and
you can actually do some wild-carding

115
00:06:31,080 --> 00:06:34,080
in here to pull up other ones,
cuz there might be more than one.

116
00:06:34,080 --> 00:06:38,210
For example there's the DHCP server,
and then there's the DHCP tools for

117
00:06:38,210 --> 00:06:40,575
managing it that are part of the RSAT,
right?

118
00:06:40,575 --> 00:06:43,915
So when I added those
asterisks around DHCP that

119
00:06:43,915 --> 00:06:46,615
helped me see all of the stuff
that's involved with DHCP.

120
00:06:46,615 --> 00:06:49,445
The only problem with that is it
doesn't really show the hierarchy.

121
00:06:49,445 --> 00:06:53,080
So like DHCP server tools
here is a part of the RSAT.

122
00:06:53,080 --> 00:06:57,460
So if I wanted to add it, I have to
kind of work through that process.

123
00:06:57,460 --> 00:07:01,000
But you can install it or remove it just
by using this shortcut name right here.

124
00:07:01,000 --> 00:07:02,650
So that's really all you need.

125
00:07:02,650 --> 00:07:05,410
So we don't necessarily
need to see the hierarchy

126
00:07:05,410 --> 00:07:06,740
in order to add that particular value.

127
00:07:06,740 --> 00:07:10,940
And that leads us to the next part is if
we want to install it, like if I want to

128
00:07:10,940 --> 00:07:15,760
be a DHCP server I can see it's available,
I haven't installed it, I can add it now.

129
00:07:15,760 --> 00:07:19,830
Let's start with something really
simple like the Telnet Client.

130
00:07:19,830 --> 00:07:24,410
The Telnet Client used to be installed
in Windows by default, so you used to be

131
00:07:24,410 --> 00:07:28,890
able to type Telnet and provide a host and
connect to it and you'll see it's not

132
00:07:28,890 --> 00:07:32,210
installed by default anymore because,
well because Telnet sucks.

133
00:07:32,210 --> 00:07:36,160
But we do still need it sometimes,
right, so if you want to install it,

134
00:07:36,160 --> 00:07:37,290
it is available.

135
00:07:37,290 --> 00:07:40,080
So if we do get-WindowsFeature and

136
00:07:40,080 --> 00:07:43,030
we search for
anything with the word Telnet in it.

137
00:07:43,030 --> 00:07:45,600
We'll see that we've got the telnet
client and the telnet server,

138
00:07:45,600 --> 00:07:46,910
they're both available.

139
00:07:46,910 --> 00:07:49,722
All I really care about on
this screen are the names.

140
00:07:49,722 --> 00:07:52,570
I wanna know the name so
I can install these.

141
00:07:52,570 --> 00:07:59,740
And when you go to install,
you just say add-windowsFeature and

142
00:07:59,740 --> 00:08:01,680
then you specify what you want to install.

143
00:08:01,680 --> 00:08:05,850
I wanna install the Telnet client, right?

144
00:08:05,850 --> 00:08:07,810
So I'll run that and
it's gonna go and install it.

145
00:08:07,810 --> 00:08:10,300
It's available so I've already
got the installation files and

146
00:08:10,300 --> 00:08:13,850
it's gonna bring it in and
I don't have permissions, all right?

147
00:08:13,850 --> 00:08:16,600
Well, I am an administrator
on this system.

148
00:08:16,600 --> 00:08:19,490
But I didn't run my power shell
with administrative privileges.

149
00:08:19,490 --> 00:08:20,640
So it's, flagging me on that.

150
00:08:20,640 --> 00:08:26,040
So I'm gonna copy that and
I'm gonna relaunch my power shell

151
00:08:26,040 --> 00:08:29,900
as an administrator this time.

152
00:08:29,900 --> 00:08:35,240
And once that's done, now I can rerun that
command and this time it'll be happy.

153
00:08:35,240 --> 00:08:38,400
So you do have to be an administrator to
add this stuff, in the GUI it would have

154
00:08:38,400 --> 00:08:42,840
just prompted me, but here in Poweshell I
actually have to relaunch the shell.

155
00:08:42,840 --> 00:08:45,750
And once that's done I'll
have the Telnet client.

156
00:08:45,750 --> 00:08:48,660
It will be installed and
be available to run.

157
00:08:48,660 --> 00:08:52,560
If I'm installing a role, something like
the active director domain services,

158
00:08:52,560 --> 00:08:55,930
then there's usually follow
configurations that I need to do.

159
00:08:55,930 --> 00:08:59,000
But in this case, it installed,
I can see it's successful.

160
00:08:59,000 --> 00:09:01,870
It's not pending a reboot, so

161
00:09:01,870 --> 00:09:03,960
that means I'm good,
I don't have to do anything else.

162
00:09:03,960 --> 00:09:07,610
If it says yes there, then that means I
need to reboot for it to take effect, and

163
00:09:07,610 --> 00:09:08,780
so I could reboot.

164
00:09:08,780 --> 00:09:12,980
If you want that to be automatic,
you can add it to the end like this,

165
00:09:12,980 --> 00:09:17,130
you can say, -restart and
then after it adds it, if this is a yes,

166
00:09:17,130 --> 00:09:19,520
it'll restart, if this is a no,
then it won't restart.

167
00:09:19,520 --> 00:09:22,240
So you can actually always
have restart there.

168
00:09:22,240 --> 00:09:24,720
But you might wanna schedule that
restart for a later time, so

169
00:09:24,720 --> 00:09:25,550
that's why it's not the default.

170
00:09:25,550 --> 00:09:29,170
All right, so I should have that client.

171
00:09:29,170 --> 00:09:33,140
If I go back to my command prompt here,
and I try and telnet again, now I can see

172
00:09:33,140 --> 00:09:36,660
that Telnet client is actually there and
working, it's been installed.

173
00:09:40,180 --> 00:09:44,280
Now when I automate something like this,
like if I'm rolling out a web server or

174
00:09:44,280 --> 00:09:47,600
whatever and I'm writing a script
that automates the deployment of it.

175
00:09:47,600 --> 00:09:51,120
I'll typically need to install
more than one roller feature.

176
00:09:51,120 --> 00:09:54,780
And if you need to do that, you don't
have to run the command more than once.

177
00:09:54,780 --> 00:09:57,720
You can actually install more than
one feature at the same time.

178
00:09:58,730 --> 00:10:04,590
So for example, if I want to install DNS
and WINS, I wanna install both, rIght?

179
00:10:04,590 --> 00:10:09,780
Well, I can find those features like DNS,

180
00:10:09,780 --> 00:10:12,820
which is actually just called DNS and
WINS which is called WINS.

181
00:10:12,820 --> 00:10:14,610
So, I already know their names.

182
00:10:14,610 --> 00:10:20,122
And if I want to add them, I can just
do add dash windows feature- DNA comma,

183
00:10:20,122 --> 00:10:25,170
WINS, Telnet-dash-server- however many I

184
00:10:25,170 --> 00:10:29,720
need- I can go through and specify those,
and it's gonna install them, all right?

185
00:10:29,720 --> 00:10:33,110
Now notice up here the DNS for
me is already installed.

186
00:10:33,110 --> 00:10:35,300
I'm already a DNS server, right?

187
00:10:35,300 --> 00:10:37,940
So, what's gonna happen
if I run this again?

188
00:10:37,940 --> 00:10:42,740
Nothing, so, it's just gonna say no change
needed, and move on to the next ones.

189
00:10:42,740 --> 00:10:45,570
So it will install the other
ones that I'm missing, and

190
00:10:45,570 --> 00:10:47,340
I'll skip over the ones
that are already there.

191
00:10:47,340 --> 00:10:49,370
So if you've got a PowerShell script, and

192
00:10:49,370 --> 00:10:51,700
one of the things that you wanna
do is check the prerequisites.

193
00:10:51,700 --> 00:10:53,390
Are these roles installed,
and if they're not,

194
00:10:53,390 --> 00:10:57,100
install them, you could skip the check and
say go ahead and add it.

195
00:10:57,100 --> 00:10:59,830
Cuz if it's already there,
it just leaves it be, all right?

196
00:10:59,830 --> 00:11:01,150
So when I run this,

197
00:11:01,150 --> 00:11:05,050
it's gonna install those three,
well they're not all roles, right?

198
00:11:05,050 --> 00:11:07,930
DNS is a role, but WINS is a feature,
and Telnet is a feature.

199
00:11:07,930 --> 00:11:12,000
So it's gonna add those in And the DNS
one, it's gonna skip right past that,

200
00:11:12,000 --> 00:11:14,180
and then it's gonna do WINS and Telnet.

201
00:11:14,180 --> 00:11:17,800
So here I can see I had success and
notice the feature result.

202
00:11:17,800 --> 00:11:19,310
Just Telnet server and WINS.

203
00:11:19,310 --> 00:11:22,610
It left out DNS because
it didnt have to do it.

204
00:11:22,610 --> 00:11:26,800
If I had run DNS just by itself
If I just take those guys out and

205
00:11:26,800 --> 00:11:30,340
just do DNS then here's where
it tells me no change needed.

206
00:11:30,340 --> 00:11:34,220
That's the exit code, I got exit code
of success here because it installed on

207
00:11:34,220 --> 00:11:36,650
the other one so
that's why I didn't see that.

208
00:11:36,650 --> 00:11:40,870
But that's what it did, it's installed
the roll, I've now got that functionality.

209
00:11:40,870 --> 00:11:43,480
I've got WINS and telnet server and

210
00:11:43,480 --> 00:11:47,240
all that other good stuff and I can go
in and I can start to manage those.

211
00:11:48,390 --> 00:11:51,790
Hopefully, none of you guys
have any WIN Servers anymore.

212
00:11:51,790 --> 00:11:54,600
But if you do, then here's our tool.

213
00:11:54,600 --> 00:11:55,100
Wonderful.

214
00:11:56,290 --> 00:12:00,360
So pretty easy to add those roles in and
get them in place.

215
00:12:00,360 --> 00:12:02,650
Not anything too spectacular there.

216
00:12:02,650 --> 00:12:07,060
I'm trying launch my wins panel, it's
been so long since I've gone in there.

217
00:12:07,060 --> 00:12:10,610
Oh, did I not install, oh,

218
00:12:10,610 --> 00:12:13,550
I had to have installed
the management tool for it, right?

219
00:12:13,550 --> 00:12:18,060
Well, anyhow,
we can always do get dash command,

220
00:12:18,060 --> 00:12:22,340
and look for any, actually wins is
not power shell enabled, is it?

221
00:12:23,480 --> 00:12:24,900
Nope, it sure isn't.

222
00:12:24,900 --> 00:12:27,160
So I see the WINS application is there but

223
00:12:27,160 --> 00:12:30,610
they never added any PowerShell commands
for it cuz it's so old and pointless.

224
00:12:30,610 --> 00:12:34,360
Same thing with Telnet,
but yeah, they are there.

225
00:12:34,360 --> 00:12:36,120
They're available, they're working.

226
00:12:36,120 --> 00:12:36,880
And now I can go and use them.

227
00:12:36,880 --> 00:12:41,370
All right if we wanna get rid of
a feature, if we wanna uninstall it.

228
00:12:41,370 --> 00:12:45,870
Well, to add it,
we use the add dash Windows feature and,

229
00:12:45,870 --> 00:12:47,700
to remove it, we just use remove.

230
00:12:47,700 --> 00:12:50,130
And it's the same thing,
we just specify the name, so,

231
00:12:50,130 --> 00:12:53,090
if I don't want wins
anymore I can do remove.

232
00:12:53,090 --> 00:12:58,040
And, actually you know, before I do that,
let's just verify, I'm gonna do get dash.

233
00:12:58,040 --> 00:13:04,740
WindowsFeature WINS, just to verify
that it does show up as installed.

234
00:13:04,740 --> 00:13:07,500
I can see its installed state right
there as showing as installed.

235
00:13:07,500 --> 00:13:08,730
I know it's good.

236
00:13:08,730 --> 00:13:15,080
And, now I can do Remove-WindowsFeature
WINS, and it's gonna remove it.

237
00:13:15,080 --> 00:13:17,670
And when it's done, it will let me know
that it's gone and then I can only

238
00:13:17,670 --> 00:13:21,920
query it again with Get-WindowsFeature to
verify that it is actually gone, right?

239
00:13:21,920 --> 00:13:24,210
It's a good idea to check that stuff.

240
00:13:24,210 --> 00:13:24,970
So, we'll let that run.

241
00:13:24,970 --> 00:13:25,970
Shouldn't take too terribly long.

242
00:13:25,970 --> 00:13:26,730
There we go.

243
00:13:26,730 --> 00:13:29,645
It is telling me that I need
to do a restart, right?

244
00:13:29,645 --> 00:13:32,455
So, it's not actually gone yet.

245
00:13:32,455 --> 00:13:38,065
It succeeded, but a restart is necessary
and so if I pull up that feature,

246
00:13:38,065 --> 00:13:42,370
the feature status Uninstall pending,
right?

247
00:13:42,370 --> 00:13:45,420
So I've done the uninstall,
but it's not complete.

248
00:13:45,420 --> 00:13:47,508
It may still be running,
I'll need to do a reboot.

249
00:13:47,508 --> 00:13:53,260
[COUGH] All right, so those are some of
the basic things that we need to do there.

250
00:13:53,260 --> 00:13:58,690
Now, I do want to mention one other thing
I've done all of this from a server and

251
00:13:58,690 --> 00:14:00,140
on a Windows Server machine.

252
00:14:00,140 --> 00:14:02,060
Windows Server 2012 or Server 2008,

253
00:14:02,060 --> 00:14:04,960
they've got all the various
commandlets that I just used.

254
00:14:06,300 --> 00:14:11,940
But if you're running the Powershell on
a Windows 7 or Windows 8 workstation.

255
00:14:11,940 --> 00:14:15,390
They don't have all the server
commandlets by default, all right?

256
00:14:15,390 --> 00:14:20,370
So if you've installed the RSAT,
the remote server administration tools on

257
00:14:20,370 --> 00:14:24,450
your system, then you'll likely have
all these and it'll work just fine.

258
00:14:24,450 --> 00:14:27,320
But if you haven't installed the RSAT,
then it might not work, so

259
00:14:27,320 --> 00:14:29,590
you might get that some of these
commandlets are not available.

260
00:14:29,590 --> 00:14:31,570
And installing the RSAT
takes care of that.

261
00:14:31,570 --> 00:14:35,460
Installing the server manager,
that's the real big piece in the RSAT.

262
00:14:35,460 --> 00:14:38,430
That's what's gonna take care of that and
give you that functionality, all right.

263
00:14:38,430 --> 00:14:39,600
But you can always double check it.

264
00:14:39,600 --> 00:14:41,800
You might need to import the module for
that.

265
00:14:41,800 --> 00:14:46,850
Do I have that written down?

266
00:14:46,850 --> 00:14:47,710
Here, I'll just test.

267
00:14:47,710 --> 00:14:49,720
I think I remember it offhand.

268
00:14:49,720 --> 00:14:52,490
If we do Import Module,
I think it's just called ServerManager.

269
00:14:53,560 --> 00:14:54,500
Yeah, that's it.

270
00:14:54,500 --> 00:14:57,590
So, if you're on a workstation,
on a client machine, and

271
00:14:57,590 --> 00:15:01,130
some of those applets weren't there,
the Windows Feature applets.

272
00:15:01,130 --> 00:15:04,350
If they weren't there, you can run
Import-Module ServerManager, and

273
00:15:04,350 --> 00:15:06,620
that's what's going to
activate those commands.

274
00:15:06,620 --> 00:15:08,360
But you've got to have
the Server Manager available, so

275
00:15:08,360 --> 00:15:12,030
that means you've got to have
the RSAT installed on your system.

276
00:15:12,030 --> 00:15:14,580
So I just wanted to throw that one out
there in case you bump into some of these

277
00:15:14,580 --> 00:15:16,640
commands not working for you.

278
00:15:16,640 --> 00:15:20,840
Normally when I do stuff like this, I'm
automating something on a server, and so

279
00:15:20,840 --> 00:15:23,430
I know those command words are already
there, I don't have to add them.

280
00:15:25,320 --> 00:15:29,610
All right, so that's basically it,
I don't have too much more to say on it.

281
00:15:29,610 --> 00:15:34,800
Just remember that get dash Windows
Feature is a really handy command because

282
00:15:34,800 --> 00:15:37,540
if you're anything like me, you can't
remember the names of half of these

283
00:15:37,540 --> 00:15:41,660
things, and Microsoft is very specific
about the name you want to use.

284
00:15:41,660 --> 00:15:45,590
So, in the output for
Get -WindowsFeature, you're looking for

285
00:15:45,590 --> 00:15:49,970
this column right here in the middle,
this column that's the name Because that's

286
00:15:49,970 --> 00:15:54,280
the one that's gonna help you find what
you should be typing into your command.

287
00:15:54,280 --> 00:15:56,230
And sometimes the names
are very different.

288
00:15:56,230 --> 00:15:58,050
That's where it gets really challenging.

289
00:15:58,050 --> 00:16:01,870
When you look at something like this guy
right here, Identity Federation Support.

290
00:16:01,870 --> 00:16:05,720
But then it's actually called
ADRMS-Identity, right?

291
00:16:05,720 --> 00:16:07,940
So how do we know what that name is?

292
00:16:07,940 --> 00:16:10,030
And normally they're at least close.

293
00:16:10,030 --> 00:16:14,560
But some of them aren't, some of them
are really a good bit different, so So you

294
00:16:14,560 --> 00:16:18,280
basically just have to go in here, find
that value and bring it in from there.

295
00:16:19,820 --> 00:16:22,760
All right, so that's about it for
roles and features.

296
00:16:22,760 --> 00:16:26,800
In this segment, we got a chance to see
how to add Windows roles and features.

297
00:16:26,800 --> 00:16:28,290
We saw how to query their status and

298
00:16:28,290 --> 00:16:32,160
then ultimately remove them if we were
done, pretty straightforward process.

299
00:16:32,160 --> 00:16:33,200
Nothing too challenging there.

300
00:16:33,200 --> 00:16:35,950
All right I hope you guys
enjoyed this segment.

301
00:16:35,950 --> 00:16:40,982
Stay tuned,
we've got more Powershell coming up.

302
00:16:40,982 --> 00:16:44,829

episodes.title: Working With Disks
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,008 --> 00:00:08,004
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,004 --> 00:00:11,532
In this segment we're gonna take
a look at managing our disks, and

3
00:00:11,532 --> 00:00:13,170
volumes with the PowerShell.

4
00:00:13,170 --> 00:00:17,404
Now, for most of us, when we go to manage
our hard drives inside of Windows Server,

5
00:00:17,404 --> 00:00:20,330
or Windows desktop, Windows 7, Windows 8.

6
00:00:20,330 --> 00:00:22,350
We typically use the computer
management tool,

7
00:00:22,350 --> 00:00:23,530
to go under the disc management tool.

8
00:00:23,530 --> 00:00:26,450
We've got a nice little
GUI to manage everything.

9
00:00:26,450 --> 00:00:28,250
If we want to automate, or script thing.

10
00:00:28,250 --> 00:00:31,220
We have a command line you
go to called disc part.

11
00:00:31,220 --> 00:00:34,790
And those are perfectly adequate tools
that do everything that we need.

12
00:00:34,790 --> 00:00:39,760
But Powershell has the full capabilities
of managing our disks and volumes also.

13
00:00:39,760 --> 00:00:43,450
So, there's a lot that we can do
right from inside of the Powershell.

14
00:00:43,450 --> 00:00:46,310
That doesn't require the use
of those external tools.

15
00:00:46,310 --> 00:00:47,300
And that's very handy.

16
00:00:47,300 --> 00:00:50,230
Because you might be automating
the deployment of a server.

17
00:00:50,230 --> 00:00:55,980
Where storage is provided on a SAN, and
the server is going to see that storage.

18
00:00:55,980 --> 00:00:57,650
And it just needs to provision it out.

19
00:00:57,650 --> 00:01:01,640
Create a partition, format it, give it
a drive letter, and make it available.

20
00:01:01,640 --> 00:01:04,110
So that's what we're going to
look at here in this segment.

21
00:01:04,110 --> 00:01:05,970
How we manage those disc volumes.

22
00:01:05,970 --> 00:01:07,860
From inside of the Powershell.

23
00:01:07,860 --> 00:01:10,360
So let's start by diving
into our Powershell.

24
00:01:10,360 --> 00:01:14,430
And covering just some few basic
commands that we need to be aware of.

25
00:01:14,430 --> 00:01:15,250
And you know what?

26
00:01:15,250 --> 00:01:17,490
I've made my prompt really tiny here.

27
00:01:17,490 --> 00:01:18,560
So let me.

28
00:01:18,560 --> 00:01:19,860
Let me bump that up really quick.

29
00:01:19,860 --> 00:01:22,020
So it's something we can actually read.

30
00:01:22,020 --> 00:01:25,940
As opposed to the microscopic
thing that I've got on the screen.

31
00:01:25,940 --> 00:01:28,900
And what we're gonna do is
we're gonna dive in here and

32
00:01:28,900 --> 00:01:30,550
just kinda mess around with some things.

33
00:01:30,550 --> 00:01:33,760
The first command that I wanna
do is simply querying what

34
00:01:33,760 --> 00:01:35,820
disks are on my system.

35
00:01:35,820 --> 00:01:40,300
So I can do a Get-Disk, and

36
00:01:40,300 --> 00:01:43,590
that will give me a list of
the disks that are in my system.

37
00:01:43,590 --> 00:01:46,790
Now if you get an error like I did.

38
00:01:46,790 --> 00:01:50,230
It usually means that you launched
the PowerShell not as an administrator.

39
00:01:50,230 --> 00:01:53,180
So I just launched it as a regular user,
and I'm getting permission denied.

40
00:01:53,180 --> 00:01:56,670
So I'm going to relaunch that PowerShell
as an administrator this time.

41
00:01:57,790 --> 00:02:03,880
And we'll do Get-Disk a second time,
and hopefully have some better results.

42
00:02:03,880 --> 00:02:06,965
Now that little query that
it runs in the background.

43
00:02:06,965 --> 00:02:09,135
It is querying the virtual disc service,

44
00:02:09,135 --> 00:02:12,965
and it can take it a moment to render
that and display it on screen.

45
00:02:12,965 --> 00:02:16,035
But mine jumped up here, and
it's showing me that I've got two discs.

46
00:02:16,035 --> 00:02:18,055
Now I'm running this on top of VMWare.

47
00:02:18,055 --> 00:02:20,030
So it's showing them as VMWare discs.

48
00:02:20,030 --> 00:02:23,750
In real life land, you'll usually see
that Seagate, or Western Digital, or

49
00:02:23,750 --> 00:02:25,860
whatever other name you've
associated with it.

50
00:02:25,860 --> 00:02:30,100
Unless it's on a SAN,
in which case you might see a one ID or

51
00:02:30,100 --> 00:02:31,000
something of that nature.

52
00:02:31,000 --> 00:02:33,620
So you could see any number of
things under friendly name.

53
00:02:33,620 --> 00:02:35,540
But the important parts
that we worry about,

54
00:02:35,540 --> 00:02:37,370
are things like the number over here.

55
00:02:37,370 --> 00:02:40,110
Which we'll need to know if
we're gonna modify these.

56
00:02:40,110 --> 00:02:42,910
The operational status,
whether it's online or offline,

57
00:02:42,910 --> 00:02:46,060
and then lastly the size and formatting.

58
00:02:46,060 --> 00:02:49,610
So this first disc that it found
is 60GB in size and it's MBR.

59
00:02:49,610 --> 00:02:54,310
It's using the master boot
recordm as opposed to like GPT.

60
00:02:56,610 --> 00:02:59,700
They're the new partitioning
table format in Windows.

61
00:02:59,700 --> 00:03:01,450
The bottom window says RAW.

62
00:03:01,450 --> 00:03:05,900
And RAW is what we'll see when we
have a disk that has no format.

63
00:03:05,900 --> 00:03:08,440
This is a brand new disk
it has no partitions on it.

64
00:03:08,440 --> 00:03:10,760
It's actually unusable the way that it is.

65
00:03:10,760 --> 00:03:15,290
In fact if I launch explorer,
what I expect to see is a C drive, there.

66
00:03:15,290 --> 00:03:17,050
And I don't see any other drives.

67
00:03:17,050 --> 00:03:20,943
And that's because this one has
no format on it, t's just RAW.

68
00:03:20,943 --> 00:03:26,880
Now, Get-Disk will list your physical
disks, and your virtual disks.

69
00:03:26,880 --> 00:03:30,870
Remember in Windows server 2012,
and Windows 7, Windows 8.

70
00:03:30,870 --> 00:03:33,440
You can create virtual hard disks.

71
00:03:33,440 --> 00:03:36,230
And you can mount those, and
they show up like regular disks.

72
00:03:36,230 --> 00:03:38,150

00:04:47,260 --> 00:04:50,580

00:07:45,250 --> 00:07:49,730

00:07:49,730 --> 00:07:53,899

00:07:53,899 --> 00:07:56,420

00:07:56,420 --> 00:08:00,620
But if we want to work with it,

00:08:04,579 --> 00:08:08,250

00:08:10,330 --> 00:08:13,070
Well, we've got a series of

00:08:13,070 --> 00:08:17,340
So the first thing that I wanna do

00:08:17,340 --> 00:08:21,925
When you hook a new blank disk up to

00:08:21,925 --> 00:08:26,146

00:08:26,146 --> 00:08:29,305
If it's been used on another computer
somewhere else, then if it's already

176
00:08:29,305 --> 00:08:32,820
partitioned or whatever, sometimes the
manufacturers will do that at the factory.

177
00:08:32,820 --> 00:08:34,130
They'll throw a partition on there.

178
00:08:34,130 --> 00:08:36,120
Then it might go online right away.

179
00:08:36,120 --> 00:08:38,940
And if that's the case,
you can skip this next step.

180
00:08:38,940 --> 00:08:42,646
But if you're offline, what you
need to do is initialize the disk.

181
00:08:42,646 --> 00:08:46,563
Initializing it brings it online and
gets it ready for our format.

182
00:08:46,563 --> 00:08:52,835
So that's what I'm gonna run next is

00:08:52,835 --> 00:08:54,875
And if you were using the disk manager,

00:08:54,875 --> 00:08:58,695

00:08:58,695 --> 00:08:59,965
When you see an offline disk,

00:09:03,685 --> 00:09:06,525

00:09:06,525 --> 00:09:10,885
So if I were to go into disk management,

00:09:10,885 --> 00:09:15,430

00:09:15,430 --> 00:09:18,540
And then I'll get a little prompt

191
00:09:18,540 --> 00:09:23,840
So that's the same process in the GUI that
I'm seeing down here in the PowerShell.

192
00:09:23,840 --> 00:09:25,180
All right.

193
00:09:25,180 --> 00:09:27,490
So I'm gonna say Initialize-Disk, and

00:09:27,490 --> 00:09:30,880

that I'm gonna be working with.

00:09:30,880 --> 00:09:32,770
And we do that by specifying the number.

00:09:32,770 --> 00:09:35,500
Remember I mentioned that number

00:09:35,500 --> 00:09:36,970
I don't want to initialize disk number 0,

00:09:36,970 --> 00:09:40,970
because that's where my operating system

00:09:40,970 --> 00:09:46,720
but I'm gonna go ahead and do number 1,

00:09:46,720 --> 00:09:49,590
Now, the disk is not offline anymore.

201
00:09:49,590 --> 00:09:50,870
Now it's online.

202
00:09:50,870 --> 00:09:55,175
If I do a Get-Disk again,
it shows as Online and

00:09:55,175 --> 00:09:58,400
it set it up for GPT instead of MBR.

00:09:58,400 --> 00:10:02,040
MBR are the old master boot record, that's
the old way of partitioning out a disk.

205
00:10:02,040 --> 00:10:03,670
GPT is the new way.

206
00:10:03,670 --> 00:10:06,360
It supports larger partitions,
more partitions, so

207
00:10:06,360 --> 00:10:07,970
it gives us a lot more flexibility.

208
00:10:07,970 --> 00:10:11,920
That's generally what you want unless
you're gonna be taking this disk

209
00:10:11,920 --> 00:10:15,810
off of your Windows machine and hooking
it up to a Linux or a Mac or whatever.

00:10:15,810 --> 00:10:18,020
In that scenario, you might wanna go MBR.

211
00:10:18,020 --> 00:10:19,340
I could have done that.

212
00:10:19,340 --> 00:10:24,220
If you do Get-Help Initialize-Disk,

00:10:25,720 --> 00:10:26,330
Oh, shoot.

00:10:26,330 --> 00:10:29,830
I don't have my help documentation

00:10:29,830 --> 00:10:31,090

00:10:31,090 --> 00:10:33,980
But you do have an option in here,

00:10:33,980 --> 00:10:37,563
For the partition style,
you can specify MBR.

218
00:10:37,563 --> 00:10:40,440
And when you do that, that's what's

219
00:10:42,970 --> 00:10:46,630
All right, so now that my disk is online,

00:10:46,630 --> 00:10:51,180
But if I look back here in my

00:10:51,180 --> 00:10:55,023

00:10:55,023 --> 00:10:57,600
that's the next step on

You initialize the disk and

So the next thing that I'm gonna do is I'm

00:11:10,350 --> 00:11:14,390

00:11:14,390 --> 00:11:16,800
So that's the number I'm working on and

I'll say AssignDriveLetter.

00:11:38,710 --> 00:11:41,370
And I could specify which

00:11:41,370 --> 00:11:44,180
If I leave it blank, it'll just

00:11:44,180 --> 00:11:44,910

00:11:44,910 --> 00:11:46,540

00:11:58,896 --> 00:12:00,610
There it is, there's MaximumSize.

UseMaximumSize.

And that's what a lot of us want,

[INAUDIBLE] there we go, and

00:12:39,620 --> 00:12:42,230

So as soon as I format it,

So you do get a lot of flexibility and
power right inside the power shell.

528
00:27:08,862 --> 00:27:12,340
All right, so in this segment, we got
a chance to see how to initialize a new

529
00:27:12,340 --> 00:27:17,220
disk, create a partition on it, format
it and get it lettered and ready to go,

530
00:27:17,220 --> 00:27:22,770
we saw how to resize the disk,
defragment it and check it for errors.

531
00:27:22,770 --> 00:27:24,420
So we saw a lot of good stuff.

532
00:27:24,420 --> 00:27:27,380
I guess the only thing I left out
is if you wanna get rid of a disk,

533
00:27:27,380 --> 00:27:30,770
it would be Remove-Partition,
kind of goes without saying.

534
00:27:30,770 --> 00:27:33,340
So you would say
Remove-Partition-DriveLetter and

535
00:27:33,340 --> 00:27:34,400
the letter.

536
00:27:34,400 --> 00:27:37,190
And that would take that partition
out if you were done with it.

537
00:27:37,190 --> 00:27:39,710
Be careful with that, though, because you

538
00:27:39,710 --> 00:27:42,580
do get warnings when you go to remove
it but it's not the same as in the GUI.

539
00:27:42,580 --> 00:27:44,410
You don't get a ton of warnings on it.

540
00:27:44,410 --> 00:27:48,270
So it is easier to accidentally remove
a volume if you're not careful.

541
00:27:49,300 --> 00:27:52,630
All right, well that's about it for
managing disks inside of the Powershell.

542
00:27:52,630 --> 00:27:53,880
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

543
00:27:53,880 --> 00:27:57,441
Stay tuned,
we got more Powershell coming up.

544
00:27:57,441 --> 00:28:02,660

episodes.title: Registry Operations
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,226 --> 00:00:08,063
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,063 --> 00:00:08,963
In this segment,

3
00:00:08,963 --> 00:00:12,750
we're gonna take a look at registry
operations inside of the PowerShell.

4
00:00:13,780 --> 00:00:17,880
As you start to automate processes you'll
find that there's commonly a need for

5
00:00:17,880 --> 00:00:21,000
you to either query
the Windows registry to

6
00:00:21,000 --> 00:00:23,420
find out information about
the systems configuration.

7
00:00:23,420 --> 00:00:27,680
Or maybe even to change the registry,
to modify the configuration of a system.

8
00:00:27,680 --> 00:00:30,310
And you can do all that
from within the PowerShell.

9
00:00:30,310 --> 00:00:33,460
Inside of the PowerShell there's actually
some really neat functionality that allows

10
00:00:33,460 --> 00:00:37,850
it to access all sorts of different
things beyond our normal services and

11
00:00:37,850 --> 00:00:40,450
file type operations that we expect.

12
00:00:40,450 --> 00:00:44,270
And the registry is one of those things
that's included that is a little bit

13
00:00:44,270 --> 00:00:47,380
beyond what the average user thinks of
when they start working with PowerShell.

14
00:00:48,380 --> 00:00:51,190
One of the ways that we're able to
do this is through what's called

15
00:00:51,190 --> 00:00:52,780
a PowerShell drive.

16
00:00:52,780 --> 00:00:56,550
If you haven't watched our segment on
PowerShell drives yet, I encourage you to

17
00:00:56,550 --> 00:01:00,640
watch that before this video because I
show you how those PowerShell drives work.

18
00:01:00,640 --> 00:01:02,520
And how they can interact
with the registry.

19
00:01:02,520 --> 00:01:05,090
But I'm gonna make use of
one of those right here.

20
00:01:05,090 --> 00:01:09,420
Inside of the PowerShell it actually
already has some mappings to

21
00:01:09,420 --> 00:01:12,418
two particular hives
inside of the registry.

22
00:01:12,418 --> 00:01:16,960
H key current user and
H key local machine.

23
00:01:16,960 --> 00:01:21,070
When we modify the registry,
we're almost always modifying keys and

24
00:01:21,070 --> 00:01:24,350
values that are inside of those two hives.

25
00:01:24,350 --> 00:01:27,200
And Microsoft knows that, so
they've given us visibility into it.

26
00:01:27,200 --> 00:01:29,400
Let me show you what I mean.

27
00:01:29,400 --> 00:01:33,460
When you go into the PowerShell, we're
used to seeing things like our C drive and

28
00:01:33,460 --> 00:01:38,120
navigating around this user
interface as a file system.

29
00:01:38,120 --> 00:01:40,090
That's what we're used to seeing.

30
00:01:40,090 --> 00:01:43,250
But there's actually some
drive letters that are mapped

31
00:01:43,250 --> 00:01:44,730
that aren't letters at all.

32
00:01:44,730 --> 00:01:46,260
They're actually words.

33
00:01:46,260 --> 00:01:52,270
If you do get-ps drive you can see
PowerShell drives that are defined and

34
00:01:52,270 --> 00:01:56,850
there's these two guys right here,
HKCU and HKLM.

35
00:01:56,850 --> 00:02:01,380
Those are registry mappings, and
they're mapped to H key current user and

36
00:02:01,380 --> 00:02:02,600
H key local machine.

37
00:02:02,600 --> 00:02:06,640
So we can actually access
those portions of the registry

38
00:02:06,640 --> 00:02:08,450
right here from the command line.

39
00:02:08,450 --> 00:02:14,540
I can type CD or
Change Directory, HKCM: so

40
00:02:14,540 --> 00:02:20,270
just like I might type CDC: to change
to the C drive, here I'm doing HKCM.

41
00:02:20,270 --> 00:02:26,001
And when I do that it's
gonna give me in here.

42
00:02:26,001 --> 00:02:26,962
Oh, it's HKLM.
I guess maybe if I used the right letters.

43
00:02:26,962 --> 00:02:28,830
There we go.
And now my prompt is going to change, and

44
00:02:28,830 --> 00:02:34,800
I'm in hp local machine, and
if I do DIR like a directory, it's

45
00:02:34,800 --> 00:02:38,430
gonna pull up a list and I'll start to see
some of the things that are in there..

46
00:02:38,430 --> 00:02:42,180
Now keep in mind that even as an
administrator you can see I'm running this

47
00:02:42,180 --> 00:02:46,350
as an administrator, there are some things
in the register we don't have access to,

48
00:02:46,350 --> 00:02:48,210
the SAM database is one of those.

49
00:02:48,210 --> 00:02:50,600
That's the security
database inside of Windows.

50
00:02:50,600 --> 00:02:53,460
So that's why I got an error
right there in the list.

51
00:02:53,460 --> 00:02:56,910
That's to be expected because I'm
not allowed to look in there.

52
00:02:56,910 --> 00:03:00,000
But if I change into one of these
other subfolders like if I change

53
00:03:00,000 --> 00:03:02,820
into the software folder.

54
00:03:02,820 --> 00:03:08,010
I can do a DIR and now I start to see
the various keys that are inside of there.

55
00:03:08,010 --> 00:03:11,040
Now be aware of the terminology here.

56
00:03:11,040 --> 00:03:15,760
Inside of the registry you have folders
and those folders are called keys.

57
00:03:15,760 --> 00:03:18,920
Inside of a key you might have other keys.

58
00:03:18,920 --> 00:03:22,340
Or you might have other properties,
all right?

59
00:03:22,340 --> 00:03:24,660
And then each property has a value.

60
00:03:24,660 --> 00:03:27,652
Let's look at the graphical user interface
to kind of get a better idea of that.

61
00:03:27,652 --> 00:03:30,547
I'm gonna go into the registry, and

62
00:03:30,547 --> 00:03:34,850
I'm gnna go into H key current or
H key local machine.

63
00:03:36,230 --> 00:03:38,390
And I'll go into software, all right.

64
00:03:38,390 --> 00:03:41,990
Now that's where I'm at inside
of the PowerShell right now.

65
00:03:41,990 --> 00:03:44,070
I'm in this software folder.

66
00:03:44,070 --> 00:03:46,390
And as I continue to navigate down,

67
00:03:46,390 --> 00:03:49,460
I'm just navigating from folder to folder,
right.

68
00:03:49,460 --> 00:03:52,120
I'm going from key to key.

69
00:03:52,120 --> 00:03:59,060
So, I'm in the software, and
then if I go into Microsoft and Windows.

70
00:03:59,060 --> 00:04:03,480
Here, I'll go into,
I want to go into Windows NT.

71
00:04:04,550 --> 00:04:07,540
I got to put quotes around it
cuz there's a space in it.

72
00:04:07,540 --> 00:04:11,250
And then I'm going to go
into current version.

73
00:04:11,250 --> 00:04:14,490
And then I'm gonna go into winlogon.

74
00:04:16,290 --> 00:04:21,490
So I just changed all the way down into
that particular area of the registry.

75
00:04:21,490 --> 00:04:23,890
If I go back to my GUI,
I can do the same thing.

76
00:04:23,890 --> 00:04:25,740
I can go to Microsoft and

77
00:04:25,740 --> 00:04:30,690
I can find Windows NT here on
the list somewhere eventually.

78
00:04:30,690 --> 00:04:32,300
There it is.

79
00:04:32,300 --> 00:04:36,090
And inside of Windows NT,
I can find Current Version, and

80
00:04:36,090 --> 00:04:39,810
inside of Current Version,
I can find WinLogon.

81
00:04:39,810 --> 00:04:40,960
Right?

82
00:04:40,960 --> 00:04:43,020
So there's WinLogon, all right?

83
00:04:43,020 --> 00:04:44,380
Now when I look at WinLogon,

84
00:04:44,380 --> 00:04:48,350
here in the GUI I see all these
values inside of it, right?

85
00:04:48,350 --> 00:04:52,420
But in my PowerShell,
I'm in that same WinLogon folder.

86
00:04:52,420 --> 00:04:57,330
And if I do DIR, I just see this,
alternate shells,

87
00:04:57,330 --> 00:05:01,520
GP extensions, and
auto logon check, and that's it.

88
00:05:01,520 --> 00:05:02,730
Where's everything else?

89
00:05:02,730 --> 00:05:05,530
Right here in the GUI,
I see a ton of stuff.

90
00:05:05,530 --> 00:05:08,170
But back there I'm only seeing a couple.

91
00:05:08,170 --> 00:05:12,310
Well the reason is what it's showing
me in the command line when I

92
00:05:12,310 --> 00:05:16,890
do those DIR commands,
that's just showing me the keys.

93
00:05:16,890 --> 00:05:20,760
If I expand out the win log
on folder over here and

94
00:05:20,760 --> 00:05:23,400
look I've got a key
called alternate shells.

95
00:05:23,400 --> 00:05:26,560
Auto log on check, GP extensions
that's where those are coming from.

96
00:05:26,560 --> 00:05:31,120
Those are keys,
it's not showing me the properties.

97
00:05:31,120 --> 00:05:35,180
So in PowerShell we navigate
based on the keys, but

98
00:05:35,180 --> 00:05:38,010
what we really want at the end
of the day are the properties.

99
00:05:38,010 --> 00:05:41,520
We wanna either see, A,
what's in a property,

100
00:05:41,520 --> 00:05:43,820
so what's a property's current value.

101
00:05:43,820 --> 00:05:47,220
Or B,
we need to change the value of a property.

102
00:05:47,220 --> 00:05:47,770
All right?

103
00:05:47,770 --> 00:05:50,970
So when we work with a registry,
getting to the folder,

104
00:05:50,970 --> 00:05:52,600
that's only part of our battle.

105
00:05:52,600 --> 00:05:55,250
The other part is dealing
with the property.

106
00:05:55,250 --> 00:06:00,670
Now, I used the DIR commands and
the CD, the change directory commands,

107
00:06:00,670 --> 00:06:03,360
and that's the real problem
with what I was doing here.

108
00:06:03,360 --> 00:06:06,230
Those map to something a little
bit different, all right?

109
00:06:06,230 --> 00:06:11,829
When you use CD, change directory,
that's actually mapped to Set-Location.

110
00:06:11,829 --> 00:06:14,290
All right.
And if you think of what that means.

111
00:06:14,290 --> 00:06:17,440
I'm just sending the location
of mt current context.

112
00:06:17,440 --> 00:06:20,470
So where I'm running
commands from right now.

113
00:06:20,470 --> 00:06:24,883
So I set my location to HTLM

114
00:06:24,883 --> 00:06:29,806
:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows
NT\CurrentVersion\winlogon.

115
00:06:29,806 --> 00:06:37,205
When I do DIR, DIR is actually alias for
Get-ChildItem.

116
00:06:37,205 --> 00:06:38,135
All right.

117
00:06:38,135 --> 00:06:41,035
And when you're running Get-ChildItem,

118
00:06:41,035 --> 00:06:45,740
it's saying what's a child of
the current key that I'm in.

119
00:06:45,740 --> 00:06:49,370
Well the properties,
those are properties of the current key,

120
00:06:49,370 --> 00:06:52,600
they're not children of the current key
and that's why they don't show up, and

121
00:06:52,600 --> 00:06:55,020
it's because of what DIR is mapped to.

122
00:06:55,020 --> 00:06:58,290
So instead, what I really need
to use is not get-ChildItem,

123
00:06:58,290 --> 00:07:01,066
I need to use get-ItemProperty.

124
00:07:01,066 --> 00:07:05,320
Get-ItemProperty of the path that I'm in

125
00:07:05,320 --> 00:07:09,210
will show me that list of properties and
that's what we really expect to see here.

126
00:07:09,210 --> 00:07:09,810
Right?

127
00:07:09,810 --> 00:07:15,340
So, if I do Get-ItemProperty and
then I need to tell it a path and

128
00:07:15,340 --> 00:07:20,400
so I can specify .\ that means the current
directory, the one that I'm in.

129
00:07:20,400 --> 00:07:22,290
If I was somewhere else,
I might have to write it out.

130
00:07:22,290 --> 00:07:23,750
So, I'll just do a .\.

131
00:07:23,750 --> 00:07:28,290
And now I get a list of all of
the properties that are inside of there.

132
00:07:28,290 --> 00:07:33,030
So that was Get-ItemProperty,
followed by the path, I'm already in it.

133
00:07:33,030 --> 00:07:36,520
So now I can look down this list and
I see all sorts of things,

134
00:07:36,520 --> 00:07:40,090
like DefaultDomainName, which is blank.

135
00:07:40,090 --> 00:07:44,880
And if I go back over to the GUI, I can
find default domain name right there.

136
00:07:44,880 --> 00:07:46,230
That's the property.

137
00:07:46,230 --> 00:07:49,180
And I can see that it's value is empty.

138
00:07:49,180 --> 00:07:52,199
So now I'm seeing what's on this screen.

139
00:07:52,199 --> 00:07:58,018
So on the left side that's set location,
get-childitem.

140
00:07:58,018 --> 00:08:01,182
On the right side That
is Get-ItemProperty,

141
00:08:01,182 --> 00:08:06,140
that's how we get those values and
look at what's in there.

142
00:08:06,140 --> 00:08:08,190
So a little bit different
than what we're used to.

143
00:08:09,280 --> 00:08:13,440
The other thing to keep in mind is
that I navigated into that directory.

144
00:08:13,440 --> 00:08:16,500
We're not always gonna be there,
we're not always gonna have that.

145
00:08:16,500 --> 00:08:20,570
So, for example, I might,
let me just put it back here.

146
00:08:20,570 --> 00:08:23,290
I'm gonna change back to my C: drive,
right?

147
00:08:23,290 --> 00:08:24,984
So when I launch the PowerShell,

148
00:08:24,984 --> 00:08:27,898
it's usually gonna default
to my user profile, right?

149
00:08:27,898 --> 00:08:36,185
So I might be somewhere like this,
Actually,

150
00:08:36,185 --> 00:08:39,023
it would normally start like right in my
profile, so something like that, right?

151
00:08:39,023 --> 00:08:42,700
So I fire up a new PowerShell,
and here I am, right?

152
00:08:42,700 --> 00:08:46,759
And if I want to query
those registry key values,

153
00:08:46,759 --> 00:08:53,106
I can still do Get-ItemProperty but
the path is gonna be a lot more complex.

154
00:08:53,106 --> 00:08:55,570
And you know it's an optional modifier,
-Path.

155
00:08:55,570 --> 00:08:56,420
You don't have to put that there,

156
00:08:56,420 --> 00:08:59,430
cuz it assumes you're gonna provide
the path next, but I'll do it.

157
00:08:59,430 --> 00:09:01,120
And then you can specify that path.

158
00:09:01,120 --> 00:09:06,358
And so I could say, HKLM,
H-key local machine,

159
00:09:06,358 --> 00:09:11,478
\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT, shoot,

160
00:09:11,478 --> 00:09:18,460
I've got a space, so I gotta go back
here and throw in a quote mark,

161
00:09:18,460 --> 00:09:23,730
\Currentversion\winlogon, like that.

162
00:09:23,730 --> 00:09:26,650
And now it's gonna give me
those properties for that path.

163
00:09:27,660 --> 00:09:29,970
So I can run that and there they are.

164
00:09:29,970 --> 00:09:33,910
So I don't have to navigate to that
other folder if I don't want to.

165
00:09:33,910 --> 00:09:38,197
But if I don't navigate to it then I am
going to have to lay out that full path

166
00:09:38,197 --> 00:09:39,315
that's in there.

167
00:09:39,315 --> 00:09:41,220
And the same thing goes for
the regular user.

168
00:09:41,220 --> 00:09:45,198
If I want to see programs
that run when I log in,

169
00:09:45,198 --> 00:09:51,940
things that auto run well I could do
Get-ItemProperty like we saw moment ago.

170
00:09:51,940 --> 00:09:53,773
Let me move that up on my screen.

171
00:09:53,773 --> 00:09:59,891
But I'm gonna change this a little bit,
because I want it to be HKCU,

172
00:09:59,891 --> 00:10:05,169
H Key Current User
\Software\Microsoft\Windows, and

173
00:10:05,169 --> 00:10:11,731
actually I need to get rid of the NT
on this one, \CurrentVersion\Run.

174
00:10:11,731 --> 00:10:16,773
Anything in that folder, when I log into
Windows, is going to run as I log in.

175
00:10:16,773 --> 00:10:20,730
And so here I'm pulling up the item
property for that, and there's nothing.

176
00:10:20,730 --> 00:10:24,106
Nothing on my system is set to run
when I log in, so that's cool.

177
00:10:24,106 --> 00:10:27,490
So I've got that, and
I can query it and pull it up.

178
00:10:27,490 --> 00:10:28,023
All right?

179
00:10:28,023 --> 00:10:33,079
This is the way that most of us are gonna
reference those registry entries and

180
00:10:33,079 --> 00:10:37,273
that's making use of that
PowerShell drive for the registry.

181
00:10:37,273 --> 00:10:40,691
All right, there is actually
another way to write this,

182
00:10:40,691 --> 00:10:45,300
like a long hand way of doing it,
without using the PowerShell drive.

183
00:10:45,300 --> 00:10:48,310
That little shortcut right there actually
explodes out into something very,

184
00:10:48,310 --> 00:10:49,260
very large.

185
00:10:49,260 --> 00:10:53,120
If I wanted to type the full syntax for
this it's actually a bit different.

186
00:10:53,120 --> 00:10:54,060
Let me just show you guys.

187
00:10:54,060 --> 00:10:57,480
You probably won't do this in real
life because it is kind of annoying.

188
00:10:57,480 --> 00:10:58,980
But let me just show you so

189
00:10:58,980 --> 00:11:03,995
that you can know what that full syntax
actually would be is it would be

190
00:11:03,995 --> 00:11:13,480
Microsoft.PowerShell.Core\Registry.

191
00:11:13,480 --> 00:11:16,970
So that's me calling the calling
the actual, oh I'm spelling Core wrong.

192
00:11:16,970 --> 00:11:21,400
That's me calling the actual module that's
allowing me to access the registry.

193
00:11:21,400 --> 00:11:25,901
So Microsoft.Powershell.Core\Registry::
and

194
00:11:25,901 --> 00:11:30,986
then I specify HKEY_Current,
actually it's all capital,

195
00:11:30,986 --> 00:11:37,356
it's not really case sensitive, but
they always write it in capitals here.

196
00:11:37,356 --> 00:11:44,440
HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Wind-
ows\CurrentVersion\Run, right?

197
00:11:44,440 --> 00:11:45,960
That's where I'm looking.

198
00:11:45,960 --> 00:11:51,460
So, Microsoft PowerShell core/registry
is the module that's loading it.

199
00:11:51,460 --> 00:11:56,160
And then the :: says this is the path
that I want to send to that module.

200
00:11:56,160 --> 00:11:57,350
And it gets this long path.

201
00:11:57,350 --> 00:12:01,190
So considerably longer command, I mean,
I had to wrap around the screen for

202
00:12:01,190 --> 00:12:04,580
that one,
versus using the PowerShell drive there.

203
00:12:04,580 --> 00:12:06,520
That saves you quite a bit.

204
00:12:06,520 --> 00:12:08,350
But the result is the same.

205
00:12:08,350 --> 00:12:09,310
It queries it.

206
00:12:09,310 --> 00:12:11,515
I get that it's empty.

207
00:12:11,515 --> 00:12:13,924
All right.
So looking at these values is pretty

208
00:12:13,924 --> 00:12:15,820
straightforward, right?

209
00:12:15,820 --> 00:12:19,606

00:24:43,180 --> 00:24:46,490
we'll just do workgroup Right?

439
00:24:46,490 --> 00:24:48,910
So I want that default
domain to be workgroup.

440
00:24:48,910 --> 00:24:54,130
I can take this same command and
just say Set-ItemProperty.

441
00:24:54,130 --> 00:24:55,220
The path is right here,

442
00:24:55,220 --> 00:24:59,320
the name is DefaultDomainName and
the value is going to be workgroup.

443
00:24:59,320 --> 00:25:02,330
And that's gonna set it
because it already exists.

444
00:25:02,330 --> 00:25:06,930
And so if I go into here and I refresh
that I can see that now it's changed.

445
00:25:06,930 --> 00:25:09,650
It's set to workgroup.

446
00:25:09,650 --> 00:25:17,100
So that's creating a property, deleting
a property, and changing a property.

447
00:25:17,100 --> 00:25:20,160
And those are the three things
that we do most of the time.

448
00:25:20,160 --> 00:25:24,920
So you're running a script, and
you might create a registry key, so

449
00:25:24,920 --> 00:25:26,490
it's doing something.

450
00:25:26,490 --> 00:25:30,160
You then change it to populate it with
values while your script is running and

451
00:25:30,160 --> 00:25:33,490
then when your script is all done,
you might remove those registry values.

452
00:25:33,490 --> 00:25:35,950
Those three operations,
those happen all the time.

453
00:25:37,410 --> 00:25:39,150
You may also need to go through and

454
00:25:39,150 --> 00:25:41,420
query the values to verify
that they're there, and

455
00:25:41,420 --> 00:25:43,950
that's where we use that get-ItemProperty
that I showed you earlier.

456
00:25:45,160 --> 00:25:49,660
And so if I want to modify that with
this syntax earlier when I did that.

457
00:25:49,660 --> 00:25:50,700
Let's see where is my example.

458
00:25:50,700 --> 00:25:51,630
Here.

459
00:25:51,630 --> 00:25:52,520
This example was much,

460
00:25:52,520 --> 00:25:56,990
much longer than I need it to be
because I'm already in that path.

461
00:25:56,990 --> 00:25:59,440
So I could shorten that a good bit.

462
00:25:59,440 --> 00:26:06,305
And I could say Get-ItemProperty -Path and
then point that to the local directory and

463
00:26:06,305 --> 00:26:10,264
then -Name,
I want to to be DefaultDomainName.

464
00:26:13,105 --> 00:26:17,323
And then I'm going to tell it that
I just want default domain name and

465
00:26:17,323 --> 00:26:19,920
not all that other stuff until I query it.

466
00:26:19,920 --> 00:26:20,540
And there we go.

467
00:26:20,540 --> 00:26:22,010
I got work group, right?

468
00:26:22,010 --> 00:26:26,560
So those four commands right there:
creating a key modifying a key, or

469
00:26:26,560 --> 00:26:31,280
sorry not keys, creating a property,
modifying a property, deleting a property,

470
00:26:31,280 --> 00:26:35,080
those are pretty important, and
then querying, or getting the property.

471
00:26:35,080 --> 00:26:38,535
Those four things are what we
normally do inside of our scripts.

472
00:26:38,535 --> 00:26:39,385
All right?

473
00:26:39,385 --> 00:26:41,635
Now you can do the keys also.

474
00:26:41,635 --> 00:26:45,185
With the keys you just use
your regular director command.

475
00:26:45,185 --> 00:26:48,545
So if I want to make my own sub-folder,
for

476
00:26:48,545 --> 00:26:53,335
example, if I've got let's see.

477
00:26:55,160 --> 00:27:00,610
If I want to create my own software
package, right, so I might have DonCo.

478
00:27:00,610 --> 00:27:01,390
RIght?

479
00:27:01,390 --> 00:27:05,730
And so, I just created a DonCo folder
by using MKDIR, make directory.

480
00:27:05,730 --> 00:27:09,120
RIght?
And make directory, if I do get-alias,

481
00:27:09,120 --> 00:27:13,990
you can see that that's really just mapped
to, apparently it mapped to nothing.

482
00:27:15,850 --> 00:27:16,810
Well that's interesting.

483
00:27:17,930 --> 00:27:20,680
Anyhow it's just should be
mapped to new-child item.

484
00:27:20,680 --> 00:27:21,990
That may just be something
that's built in.

485
00:27:21,990 --> 00:27:25,090
I always assumed that was an alias.

486
00:27:25,090 --> 00:27:31,170
Basically it's, hm MD is [INAUDIBLE]
I guess is its own little command.

487
00:27:31,170 --> 00:27:32,930
I learned something new everyday I guess.

488
00:27:32,930 --> 00:27:35,320
But I can make those keys really easy.

489
00:27:35,320 --> 00:27:37,780
I don't have to do any crazy long syntax

490
00:27:37,780 --> 00:27:40,550
because the PowerShell drive
lets me do it, all right.

491
00:27:40,550 --> 00:27:44,065
But I could if I wanted
to do it the long way.

492
00:27:44,065 --> 00:27:47,435
I could do the new-child item and

493
00:27:47,435 --> 00:27:51,725
then specify that path and layout that
new folder and kind of go that route too.

494
00:27:51,725 --> 00:27:52,755
They're both effective.

495
00:27:52,755 --> 00:27:54,635
This is just considerably simpler.

496
00:27:54,635 --> 00:27:58,090
And we get that created, so now I've
got a DonCo folder inside of Software.

497
00:27:58,090 --> 00:28:02,829
And now I can start to create all
the values that I needed by doing

498
00:28:02,829 --> 00:28:08,108
the new-ItemProperty, and
then specifying the path of right here,

499
00:28:08,108 --> 00:28:13,940
and then specifying the name of the
ItemProperty, and the value, and so on.

500
00:28:13,940 --> 00:28:17,762
So maybe I have a property
called Registered, so

501
00:28:17,762 --> 00:28:22,798
I'm checking whether people have
registered my software, and

502
00:28:22,798 --> 00:28:28,204
the value for it might be false by
default, so I can get that created,

503
00:28:28,204 --> 00:28:35,360
and now it's in there, and now I can query
that see if people registered my software.

504
00:28:35,360 --> 00:28:39,990
And then one day somebody can figure out
my cheesy registration scheme and go and

505
00:28:39,990 --> 00:28:41,880
change that to true and not pay me.

506
00:28:41,880 --> 00:28:46,470
So that's the basics right there of
messing with those records and values.

507
00:28:46,470 --> 00:28:47,710
Pretty straightforward.

508
00:28:47,710 --> 00:28:49,950
The only tricky part about this is
just that most people don't know

509
00:28:49,950 --> 00:28:50,510
about it, right?

510
00:28:50,510 --> 00:28:52,360
And it's really easy to get in there and

511
00:28:52,360 --> 00:28:55,180
work with the registry all from
inside of the power shell.

512
00:28:55,180 --> 00:28:59,110
Now, in real life land,
if I want to modify a registry value

513
00:28:59,110 --> 00:29:02,742
I will almost always just go right here
into regedit and do it via the GUI.

514
00:29:03,970 --> 00:29:07,660
So, the time that we make use of it
here in the PowerShell is when we want

515
00:29:07,660 --> 00:29:08,940
to automate things.

516
00:29:08,940 --> 00:29:11,760
When you want to run a script and
have it manipulate some values.

517
00:29:11,760 --> 00:29:16,230
When you want to set things,
like that default domain name.

518
00:29:16,230 --> 00:29:19,190
If you're in a multi-domain environment,

519
00:29:19,190 --> 00:29:22,190
when somebody logs in they can
choose from the different domains.

520
00:29:22,190 --> 00:29:24,330
Well, you might want to
set their default one, and

521
00:29:24,330 --> 00:29:27,090
you might need to set that
across a thousand computers.

522
00:29:27,090 --> 00:29:28,050
You don't want to go to each one.

523
00:29:28,050 --> 00:29:31,520
You could do a group policy object, but

524
00:29:31,520 --> 00:29:34,460
if it's an environment where
you don't have that control or

525
00:29:34,460 --> 00:29:37,660
that ability you could also just
do it through a PowerShell script.

526
00:29:37,660 --> 00:29:40,380
And you could do it just like this,
push it along, and

527
00:29:40,380 --> 00:29:42,830
now all those machines get
their default value set.

528
00:29:42,830 --> 00:29:45,930
So pretty cool stuff, pretty useful, and

529
00:29:45,930 --> 00:29:49,015
definitely something that you'll
make use of out in your life land.

530
00:29:50,322 --> 00:29:52,960
All right, I think I've pretty much
covered everything that I wanted to.

531
00:29:52,960 --> 00:29:55,150
Let me see if I missed
anything in my notes here.

532
00:29:55,150 --> 00:29:56,910
Looks like we got it all.

533
00:29:56,910 --> 00:30:02,220
So In this segment, we got a chance to see
how to navigate inside of the registry,

534
00:30:02,220 --> 00:30:05,450
based on using the PowerShell
drive functionality.

535
00:30:05,450 --> 00:30:10,200
We got a chance to see how to query
the keys inside of the registry as well

536
00:30:10,200 --> 00:30:14,070
as well as how to query the properties,
so how to return the values for

537
00:30:14,070 --> 00:30:15,040
the properties.

538
00:30:15,040 --> 00:30:18,720
And then lastly we saw how to create,
change, and

539
00:30:18,720 --> 00:30:23,830
remove those same properties so that we
can support our software and our scripts.

540
00:30:23,830 --> 00:30:26,050
All right,
hopefully you guys enjoyed that segment.

541
00:30:26,050 --> 00:30:29,035
Stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up.
