episodes.title: Configuring Networking
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,164
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,164 --> 00:00:11,781
In this segment, we're going to be taking
a look at configuring our network adaptors

3
00:00:11,781 --> 00:00:14,000
with using the Microsoft PowerShell.

4
00:00:14,000 --> 00:00:16,640
Now I know for me, when I use PowerShell,

5
00:00:16,640 --> 00:00:18,730
a lot of times I try to get in and
get out as fast as I can.

6
00:00:18,730 --> 00:00:22,270
And not mess with it too much because
I don't remember the commands.

7
00:00:22,270 --> 00:00:27,420
And so with a new server, one of the first
things that I need to do is assign an IP

8
00:00:27,420 --> 00:00:30,740
address to it and open up some firewall
ports so I can remote manage it.

9
00:00:30,740 --> 00:00:34,840
And then that's the end of me using
PowerShell on a core server installer or

10
00:00:34,840 --> 00:00:35,630
something like that.

11
00:00:35,630 --> 00:00:36,470
So.
those

12
00:00:36,470 --> 00:00:38,651
are some of the things that we
are going to take a look at here.

13
00:00:38,651 --> 00:00:39,770
>> Yeah, cause you really have to.

14
00:00:39,770 --> 00:00:41,430
When you first set up
that core installation,

15
00:00:41,430 --> 00:00:43,048
you know you are going to
end up managing it remotely.

16
00:00:43,048 --> 00:00:47,290
But, you can't manage it remotely
until you have set up your WinRM,

17
00:00:47,290 --> 00:00:48,240
your remote management.

18
00:00:48,240 --> 00:00:50,750
Set up your firewall rules and
given it a name, and

19
00:00:50,750 --> 00:00:53,740
given it an IP address, conjoin it to
the domain and all that good stuff.

20
00:00:53,740 --> 00:00:56,810
So we've got to know those commands at
least to get that guy on the network,

21
00:00:56,810 --> 00:00:58,110
get it manageable.

22
00:00:58,110 --> 00:01:02,350
And then from then on we can use
our remote management and our GUIs.

23
00:01:02,350 --> 00:01:06,190
Thank God. [LAUGH] >> Now the tricky
part here is inside of the PowerShell

24
00:01:06,190 --> 00:01:09,900
there is more than one way to
reference your network adapter.

25
00:01:09,900 --> 00:01:12,580
So we have a series of
commands that we can use,

26
00:01:12,580 --> 00:01:13,970
just like all of the other
PowerShell shows.

27
00:01:13,970 --> 00:01:17,740
Our get commands, our set commands,
our remove or whatever.

28
00:01:18,820 --> 00:01:21,490
But how do we reference which
adapter we're working with?

29
00:01:21,490 --> 00:01:23,840
Because on a server you'll typically
have more than one adapter.

30
00:01:23,840 --> 00:01:25,300
Even on a desktop or laptop though,

31
00:01:25,300 --> 00:01:28,190
you might have a wireless and
a wired adapter, Bluetooth.

32
00:01:28,190 --> 00:01:29,940
Right, they all show up as adapters.

33
00:01:29,940 --> 00:01:31,830
So let's start with the real basics.

34
00:01:31,830 --> 00:01:33,920
How do we get information
about our network adapter?

35
00:01:35,000 --> 00:01:38,720
Well, the first thing command we're gonna
see is the get-netadapter command and

36
00:01:38,720 --> 00:01:41,950
if we just run that, here,
I'll fire that up in my PowerShell.

37
00:01:41,950 --> 00:01:45,150
I'll just run get-netadapter.

38
00:01:45,150 --> 00:01:48,420
That'll give me my list of network
adapters that are in my system.

39
00:01:48,420 --> 00:01:52,480
And I can see that I've gone one, it's an
Intel 82574L gigabit network connection.

40
00:01:52,480 --> 00:01:56,130
>> Nice [LAUGH]
>> It's got a name,

41
00:01:56,130 --> 00:01:58,270
in this case it's called local network.

42
00:01:58,270 --> 00:02:01,530
It's got a description,
which is that big long run-on there.

43
00:02:01,530 --> 00:02:04,540
It's got an interface index, which is 12.

44
00:02:04,540 --> 00:02:05,838
And, what is that?

45
00:02:05,838 --> 00:02:09,190
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's Microsoft just assigning

46
00:02:09,190 --> 00:02:11,000
a numerical identifier to your interface.

47
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:13,750
And they do that because,
you have a lot of virtual interfaces too,

48
00:02:13,750 --> 00:02:15,593
like your IPv6 tunnel interfaces.

49
00:02:15,593 --> 00:02:16,410
>> Mm-hm, tunnel, yep.

50
00:02:16,410 --> 00:02:19,400
>> They come and go and so you may or
may not have those numbers and

51
00:02:19,400 --> 00:02:21,290
they just give a simple
way to reference them.

52
00:02:22,760 --> 00:02:25,490
>> Yeah, that's a real good command
to know cuz that one, like you said,

53
00:02:25,490 --> 00:02:27,250
gives you the list of
everything you've got.

54
00:02:27,250 --> 00:02:29,240
And then you got your choice of
how you wanna reference that.

55
00:02:29,240 --> 00:02:30,250
Do you wanna reference it by name or

56
00:02:30,250 --> 00:02:33,080
do you wanna reference
it by that index number?

57
00:02:33,080 --> 00:02:36,270
It's also a reason I usually change
the names on most of my adapters.

58
00:02:36,270 --> 00:02:40,030
To something a little shorter,
LAN1, LAN2 no spaces.

59
00:02:40,030 --> 00:02:43,170
Unfortunately I still gotta use my
quotes in PowerShell, in the prompt,

60
00:02:43,170 --> 00:02:45,110
in the old school command prompt.

61
00:02:45,110 --> 00:02:46,270
If you didn't have any spaces in there,

62
00:02:46,270 --> 00:02:49,220
then you could get away without
the quotations around it.

63
00:02:49,220 --> 00:02:50,050
>> Yeah, and you know that,

64
00:02:50,050 --> 00:02:52,740
that name, that was just
the automatically assigned one.

65
00:02:52,740 --> 00:02:54,940
I didn't assign it.

66
00:02:54,940 --> 00:02:56,600
Is my search anywhere not gonna work?

67
00:02:56,600 --> 00:02:59,370
There, network and sharing center.

68
00:02:59,370 --> 00:03:02,390
So, you know, if you go in your network
and sharing center into your adapter,

69
00:03:02,390 --> 00:03:04,240
see how it's just called
local network right there?

70
00:03:04,240 --> 00:03:09,846
And I could rename that, you know,
call it IT Pro TV studio.

71
00:03:09,846 --> 00:03:15,174
>> Now that's even longer than
what you started with [LAUGH]

72
00:03:15,174 --> 00:03:17,003
>> You know, it sort of is, isn't it.

73
00:03:17,003 --> 00:03:20,670
So heck maybe we just call it LAN.

74
00:03:20,670 --> 00:03:22,060
>> Call it LAN one and
LAN two, that's what I do.

75
00:03:22,060 --> 00:03:23,230
>> Easy as possible.

76
00:03:23,230 --> 00:03:25,730
So then, that's what's being
returned right back here.

77
00:03:25,730 --> 00:03:30,040
If I do get-netadapter,
now it's got that nice short name of LAN.

78
00:03:30,040 --> 00:03:33,910
That does make a lot of the other
commands we're gonna run easier.

79
00:03:33,910 --> 00:03:35,760
You really have a couple of choices here.

80
00:03:35,760 --> 00:03:37,780
And as we work with it you need to pick,

81
00:03:37,780 --> 00:03:40,530
do you want to go with
the interface index number?

82
00:03:40,530 --> 00:03:44,140
That's easy if you know the Interface
index number or you can query to get it.

83
00:03:44,140 --> 00:03:47,730
Or do you want to use the named identifier
adapter which can be easier because

84
00:03:47,730 --> 00:03:49,140
they're simple to remember.

85
00:03:49,140 --> 00:03:50,410
But it's up to you.

86
00:03:50,410 --> 00:03:52,750
So when you're watching this show,

87
00:03:52,750 --> 00:03:54,260
if you're watching this
live you won't see this.

88
00:03:54,260 --> 00:03:56,940
But if you're watching this recorded
you'll see the show notes beneath

89
00:03:56,940 --> 00:04:00,930
the episode and
a lot of the commands we list twice.

90
00:04:00,930 --> 00:04:04,400
Once using the interface index number and
once using the name.

91
00:04:04,400 --> 00:04:06,990
Two different ways to run the same command
based on the information you know.

92
00:04:06,990 --> 00:04:11,020
One of the things I like
to do with names is,

93
00:04:11,020 --> 00:04:16,680
the interface index number can vary
from server to server to server.

94
00:04:16,680 --> 00:04:18,950
But if you take your server and
you say all right,

95
00:04:18,950 --> 00:04:20,660
here's gonna be my management
interface adapter.

96
00:04:20,660 --> 00:04:22,690
And so I'm gonna rename it management.

97
00:04:22,690 --> 00:04:25,990
So now on all of your servers you
have an adapter called management.

98
00:04:25,990 --> 00:04:28,040
The index number might be
different on all of your servers,

99
00:04:28,040 --> 00:04:29,760
but the name is always management.

100
00:04:29,760 --> 00:04:32,910
Now you can easily create one
script that can run on everywhere

101
00:04:32,910 --> 00:04:34,530
because the name is always the same.

102
00:04:34,530 --> 00:04:38,070
The interface index number,
to my knowledge you can't change but

103
00:04:38,070 --> 00:04:39,160
you might be able to.

104
00:04:39,160 --> 00:04:41,120
>> No, I think it generates it and
you never really know.

105
00:04:41,120 --> 00:04:42,140
It does seem to start with 12.

106
00:04:42,140 --> 00:04:44,720
I don't know why it starts
with that number but

107
00:04:44,720 --> 00:04:47,250
I've seen where on just
about every machine I go to.

108
00:04:47,250 --> 00:04:50,340
Multiple network adapters they start
at 12, 13, 14 and work their way up.

109
00:04:50,340 --> 00:04:53,040
>> They must reserve the others for
something, who knows.

110
00:04:53,040 --> 00:04:58,169
Probably SharePoint or
MSN messenger [LAUGH].

111
00:04:58,169 --> 00:05:03,330
All right well, so now we've got some
basic information about our adapter.

112
00:05:03,330 --> 00:05:07,050
And if we want wanna work with it, well
we've more get commands that we can use.

113
00:05:07,050 --> 00:05:08,670
There is more than what shows
up here on this screen.

114
00:05:08,670 --> 00:05:10,780
See how my link speed is
being truncated and all.

115
00:05:10,780 --> 00:05:16,550
So if we pipe that into format list,
we can see all the additional information.

116
00:05:16,550 --> 00:05:19,950
I can see it's an 802.3 adapter, which
pretty much everything these days is.

117
00:05:19,950 --> 00:05:21,480
>> Right.
I can see that it's up.

118
00:05:21,480 --> 00:05:23,010
It's a 1-gig connector.

119
00:05:23,010 --> 00:05:26,970
I can see that speed, and the driver
information is attached there also.

120
00:05:28,500 --> 00:05:31,350
>> Yeah, this git net adapter is
really giving me properties about

121
00:05:31,350 --> 00:05:32,150
the adapter itself.

122
00:05:32,150 --> 00:05:36,330
That's we're not seeing our TCPI settings
and things like that, or IP address.

123
00:05:36,330 --> 00:05:38,580
That's not showing up in there
that's a different command.

124
00:05:38,580 --> 00:05:40,970
It was a git-net IP address, I think.

125
00:05:40,970 --> 00:05:41,710

00:17:21,630 --> 00:17:26,060

00:17:39,975 --> 00:17:42,500

remove dash netipaddress from interface

And so we'll remove that, and

00:18:34,781 --> 00:18:42,365
And I can do the get-netipaddress and

00:18:42,365 --> 00:18:43,860
And I don't see it in my list there.

00:18:45,620 --> 00:18:46,402
And actually,

00:18:56,448 --> 00:18:58,410

387
00:18:58,410 --> 00:19:03,190
So, I can see that .3 is now gone and

So, let me just pull up

00:19:08,160 --> 00:19:11,640
So looking at my get history you'll

that's how we added that

And then I follow that up with the remove
-net IP address to get rid of the address

>> [LAUGH]
>> So, yep, so

you just separated them with commas,

I always forget and then I just end up

00:22:07,698 --> 00:22:10,259
So now this machine is ready

00:22:10,259 --> 00:22:13,940
do the other things that we need to,

00:22:13,940 --> 00:22:19,340
And we can go our get-netip address or

00:22:19,340 --> 00:22:23,520
You can start to pull a lot

00:22:23,520 --> 00:22:26,490
see actually, let's see.

There we go.

00:22:28,760 --> 00:22:32,030
So we can start to pull it up and

Now be careful, remember with the IP

episodes.title: Managing Services
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,007 --> 00:00:08,099
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,099 --> 00:00:11,663
In this segment we're gonna take a look
at managing background services using

3
00:00:11,663 --> 00:00:13,650
the Microsoft PowerShell.

4
00:00:13,650 --> 00:00:16,610
On any server, and really on your
workstations too, there's a number

5
00:00:16,610 --> 00:00:19,290
of services that are running in the
background that we may need to manipulate,

6
00:00:19,290 --> 00:00:22,010
and they might be the ones that
are built into Windows that came

7
00:00:22,010 --> 00:00:23,290
with the operating system.

8
00:00:23,290 --> 00:00:26,300
When they might be third party
wants that we've added on.

9
00:00:26,300 --> 00:00:28,620
Either way,
we can manage them with the PowerShell and

10
00:00:28,620 --> 00:00:31,850
that's really useful if you're trying to
script and automate certain activities.

11
00:00:31,850 --> 00:00:34,550
>> Absolutely.
>> Now for the most part,

12
00:00:34,550 --> 00:00:38,750
typically you're just gonna be looking for
a broken services and starting them again.

13
00:00:38,750 --> 00:00:42,490
There's some typical really rudimentary
things that everybody does.

14
00:00:42,490 --> 00:00:43,930
I wanna start with those commands.

15
00:00:43,930 --> 00:00:45,630
And then we'll move into some
of the more advanced things.

16
00:00:45,630 --> 00:00:49,310
I will say this, just right off the bat,
Microsoft did not spend a lot of

17
00:00:49,310 --> 00:00:52,620
time adding a bunch of service
functionality into the PowerShell.

18
00:00:52,620 --> 00:00:55,530
So, some of things we see here will
require us to get a little bit

19
00:00:55,530 --> 00:00:57,910
create with how we use
the PowerShell to work with it.

20
00:00:59,180 --> 00:01:02,600
Let's start with a real simple one which
is simply getting a list of our services,

21
00:01:02,600 --> 00:01:05,871
and as you'd think the command
is just get-services.

22
00:01:05,871 --> 00:01:08,390
>> Pretty straight forward.

23
00:01:08,390 --> 00:01:10,600
>> Sorry.
It's get-service, it's not plural.

24
00:01:10,600 --> 00:01:11,410
There we go.

25
00:01:11,410 --> 00:01:15,500
So if we get that service, we get a list
of services that are available and

26
00:01:15,500 --> 00:01:16,340
there's a bunch of to them.

27
00:01:16,340 --> 00:01:21,260
And this is the equivalent of going
to that control panel item right, or

28
00:01:21,260 --> 00:01:26,300
administrative tool, if I were to go into,
apparently I'm spelling challenged today.

29
00:01:26,300 --> 00:01:30,010
But if I go into the services
administrative tool, I get this list of

30
00:01:30,010 --> 00:01:33,211
all the services that are on my system and
the ones that are running, and so on.

31
00:01:33,211 --> 00:01:35,560
If I went back,
here that's exactly what I'm seeing too.

32
00:01:37,330 --> 00:01:41,600
One of the nice things about this though
is that, it does display the service name

33
00:01:41,600 --> 00:01:43,530
but those names might not be
what you're familiar with.

34
00:01:43,530 --> 00:01:45,110
That's because every
service has two names.

35
00:01:45,110 --> 00:01:48,800
You have a service name and
a display name.

36
00:01:48,800 --> 00:01:50,680
I'm seeing the service name here.

37
00:01:50,680 --> 00:01:51,740
Followed by that display name.

38
00:01:51,740 --> 00:01:54,660
So there might be a service
that I'm really used to,

39
00:01:54,660 --> 00:01:57,490
like the DNS client, right?

40
00:01:57,490 --> 00:01:59,200
And so
that's what I'm used to seeing it as,

41
00:01:59,200 --> 00:02:02,750
and in the administrative
tool that's what it shows up.

42
00:02:02,750 --> 00:02:06,490
But you'll see here, there's a service
name attached to it, Dnscache.

43
00:02:06,490 --> 00:02:09,340
As we work with the services,
a lot of times we're expected to

44
00:02:09,340 --> 00:02:12,150
know the actual service name and
not the display name, and so

45
00:02:12,150 --> 00:02:14,630
that's something we'll have to kind of
compete against as we work with this.

46
00:02:14,630 --> 00:02:16,320
>> Okay,
well that makes it a little challenging.

47
00:02:17,742 --> 00:02:20,070
>> All right so,
getting a list of services, that's great.

48
00:02:20,070 --> 00:02:22,170
Now I know what's going on on my system.

49
00:02:22,170 --> 00:02:23,690
I might want to filter that a bit.

50
00:02:23,690 --> 00:02:26,860
I know Mike when I told you we were
gonna film this show, Mike said yeah,

51
00:02:26,860 --> 00:02:29,465
we really need to have one more that
just shows like running services.

52
00:02:29,465 --> 00:02:30,550
>> Mm-hm, right.

53
00:02:30,550 --> 00:02:32,255
>> Or maybe even ones that aren't running.

54
00:02:32,255 --> 00:02:33,090
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, exactly.

55
00:02:33,090 --> 00:02:35,030
It is nice to be able to
filter that list down and

56
00:02:35,030 --> 00:02:36,260
find exactly what you're looking for.

57
00:02:36,260 --> 00:02:38,870
I need to know, is this service running,

58
00:02:38,870 --> 00:02:41,890
or which services are actually
running on my machine?

59
00:02:41,890 --> 00:02:43,400
Cuz that list can get a little long.

60
00:02:43,400 --> 00:02:44,500
>> It can get really long.

61
00:02:44,500 --> 00:02:46,760
Especially on systems where you've
installed a lot of software.

62
00:02:46,760 --> 00:02:48,110
You see this on workstations more.

63
00:02:48,110 --> 00:02:49,990
Servers are normally pretty clean.

64
00:02:49,990 --> 00:02:53,190
But just like any PowerShell command,
we can use sort object.

65
00:02:53,190 --> 00:02:55,210
And Where-Object to change that,

66
00:02:55,210 --> 00:02:58,050
right, Sort-Object lets us just arrange
the way that things are being ordered on

67
00:02:58,050 --> 00:03:01,150
the screen, and
Where-Object will let us filter it.

68
00:03:01,150 --> 00:03:06,085
So, if I take Get-Service and I'm just
going to pipe that commands output into

69
00:03:06,085 --> 00:03:10,460
Sort-object, and
we can tell it what we want to sort by.

70
00:03:10,460 --> 00:03:12,500
You can sort by any of these
different columns over here.

71
00:03:12,500 --> 00:03:13,880
I'm going to sort it by status.

72
00:03:15,560 --> 00:03:17,670
When I run that, it's going to sort it.

73
00:03:17,670 --> 00:03:19,900
So now, I've got all of my running
services right here at the bottom.

74
00:03:19,900 --> 00:03:21,880
I've got my stopped ones
that are above that.

75
00:03:21,880 --> 00:03:23,450
So I can see each of those.

76
00:03:23,450 --> 00:03:24,970
And they're just in the list.

77
00:03:24,970 --> 00:03:26,130
There they are.

78
00:03:26,130 --> 00:03:28,990
It's very, very exciting.

79
00:03:28,990 --> 00:03:30,560
It's not terribly exciting.

80
00:03:30,560 --> 00:03:34,450
Now, I might want to use something like
Where-object to tell it only to show me

81
00:03:34,450 --> 00:03:37,470
the stopped services, or
just show me the running services.

82
00:03:37,470 --> 00:03:41,580
So we can filter beyond that if we want
to, so I can get rid of sort object.

83
00:03:41,580 --> 00:03:42,225
And I can change that.

84
00:03:42,225 --> 00:03:43,672
>> Mm-hm.

85
00:03:43,672 --> 00:03:46,560
>> Now, Where-object the syntax is
always a little weird on this one.

86
00:03:46,560 --> 00:03:47,955
>> It's a little goofy, isn't it?

87
00:03:47,955 --> 00:03:50,960
>> Cuz what you have to do, you have
to call that variable that represents

88
00:03:50,960 --> 00:03:53,080
the output of the first commands
part of our pipe lining.

89
00:03:53,080 --> 00:03:54,595
>> Yeah.
>> If you watched our pipe lining episode,

90
00:03:54,595 --> 00:03:55,610
you already know about this.

91
00:03:55,610 --> 00:03:57,645
But-
>> Because really treating that list,

92
00:03:57,645 --> 00:04:00,070
Get-Services, returning a list
of all the services, and

93
00:04:00,070 --> 00:04:01,610

episodes.title: Managing Proceses
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,240 --> 00:00:08,059
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,059 --> 00:00:11,655
In this segment we're going to take
a look at managing processes from within

3
00:00:11,655 --> 00:00:13,600
the Microsoft PowerShell.

4
00:00:13,600 --> 00:00:15,140
Most of us are familiar with the,

5
00:00:15,140 --> 00:00:19,350
the graphical interface that we have,
it's called the Task Manager in Windows.

6
00:00:19,350 --> 00:00:21,170
And it lets you see all of your processes,

7
00:00:21,170 --> 00:00:23,230
what's running,
their CPU loads and all that.

8
00:00:23,230 --> 00:00:28,060
And that's great if you're sitting at
the machine and you've got your GUI handy.

9
00:00:28,060 --> 00:00:29,780
But if you're trying to work
with things from the PowerShell

10
00:00:29,780 --> 00:00:30,990
it's not particularly useful.

11
00:00:30,990 --> 00:00:33,530
So fortunately we have a whole suite of

12
00:00:33,530 --> 00:00:37,240
utilities that we can use from the
PowerShell to really do the same thing.

13
00:00:37,240 --> 00:00:38,580
Let's take a look at it.

14
00:00:38,580 --> 00:00:41,000
So here on this machine I've got
the Task Manager pulled up and so

15
00:00:41,000 --> 00:00:42,450
I've got my processes that are running,

16
00:00:42,450 --> 00:00:45,705
you see like I'm running Internet Explorer
and some of the other the other

17
00:00:45,705 --> 00:00:50,835
things like the memory they're using and
so on, all presented right here.

18
00:00:50,835 --> 00:00:54,675
I can get that same data
from within the PowerShell.

19
00:00:54,675 --> 00:00:56,811
If I just do Get-Process.

20
00:00:56,811 --> 00:01:00,915
Get-Process is kind of like
task manager for PowerShell.

21
00:01:00,915 --> 00:01:04,075
It'll show me all the processes that
are running on this system, and

22
00:01:04,075 --> 00:01:05,975
I see there's CPU utilization.

23
00:01:05,975 --> 00:01:10,310
I see their memory, network bandwidth,
how many handles they've got open.

24
00:01:10,310 --> 00:01:11,940
All listed right here.

25
00:01:11,940 --> 00:01:15,350
Same data that we're looking at
inside of the GUI based task manager.

26
00:01:16,480 --> 00:01:18,540
Now the only negative about this view is,

27
00:01:18,540 --> 00:01:21,710
unlike the task manager,
this is not being dynamically updated.

28
00:01:21,710 --> 00:01:22,710
So the task manager,

29
00:01:22,710 --> 00:01:26,190
it's showing you real time data on
the utilization on your system.

30
00:01:26,190 --> 00:01:28,080
Here, it's a point in time.

31
00:01:28,080 --> 00:01:31,390
This is how things look
right then when I ran it.

32
00:01:31,390 --> 00:01:32,900
Not how it is necessarily right now.

33
00:01:34,180 --> 00:01:37,430
Now if I wanna get detailed information
about a process, I can do that.

34
00:01:37,430 --> 00:01:40,600
Every process is listed
along with a process ID.

35
00:01:40,600 --> 00:01:42,310
That's this column right here.

36
00:01:42,310 --> 00:01:44,130
And if I take the ID for one.

37
00:01:44,130 --> 00:01:46,120
Like, I'll take Internet Explorer here.

38
00:01:46,120 --> 00:01:47,000
It's 3288.

39
00:01:47,000 --> 00:01:51,260
Well, I can take that process ID and
I can add to Get-Process.

40
00:01:51,260 --> 00:01:52,659
And say Get-Process.

41
00:01:53,780 --> 00:02:00,030
- id 3288 and now it'll get me
information about that process itself.

42
00:02:00,030 --> 00:02:04,640
Well, you might ask yourself, well wait
a minute Don, it's the same thing right?

43
00:02:04,640 --> 00:02:06,220
It's really just showing the same data.

44
00:02:06,220 --> 00:02:08,960
Well the key thing to remember
here is there's always more

45
00:02:08,960 --> 00:02:10,970
than what shows up on the screen.

46
00:02:10,970 --> 00:02:17,010
If I were to take that and
pipe that through Format-List,

47
00:02:17,010 --> 00:02:20,910
now I can see, well, actually less,
right, I'm seeing less data now.

48
00:02:20,910 --> 00:02:24,920
ID handle CPU name,
what happened to all of that other stuff?

49
00:02:24,920 --> 00:02:28,370
Well, the problem here is that the data
that we're getting from get dash

50
00:02:28,370 --> 00:02:31,020
process is actually being pulled
from more than one location,

51
00:02:31,020 --> 00:02:34,700
and it's being rendered on the screen,
and it looks like it's all just one

52
00:02:34,700 --> 00:02:37,250
set of data but it's actually coming
from more than one background.

53
00:02:37,250 --> 00:02:39,010
You'll notice that there some
things that are even missing,

54
00:02:39,010 --> 00:02:42,200
like what user is responsible for
generating these processes.

55
00:02:42,200 --> 00:02:46,160
So when we start to manipulate that
data sometimes we lose some of it and

56
00:02:46,160 --> 00:02:48,160
we have to pull it from other locations.

57
00:02:49,200 --> 00:02:53,900
All right now we can also do things
like Get-Process instead of- id,

58
00:02:53,900 --> 00:02:56,040
we can just do like a name.

59
00:02:56,040 --> 00:03:02,743
So if I want to get the process for
iexplorer, Internet Explorer is iexplorer.

60
00:03:02,743 --> 00:03:04,000
Now it'll pull that up and

61
00:03:04,000 --> 00:03:08,070
the nice thing here is that I might have
more than one process with that name.

62
00:03:08,070 --> 00:03:09,140
And it'll list it.

63
00:03:09,140 --> 00:03:12,560
And if there's more than one process that
I'm looking or I can actually just set

64
00:03:12,560 --> 00:03:17,610
commas in here, and I can say show
me I explore as well as explorer.

65
00:03:17,610 --> 00:03:20,800
I want both, and
now I get that filtered view there, too.

66
00:03:20,800 --> 00:03:24,550
So couple of different ways that we can
manipulate this data to be able to get

67
00:03:24,550 --> 00:03:26,340
exactly what we want.

68
00:03:26,340 --> 00:03:31,098
Now, if we're going through the trouble
to look at processes we're probably

69
00:03:31,098 --> 00:03:33,269
concerned about CPU utilization.

70
00:03:33,269 --> 00:03:35,180
At least for me,
that's why I'm normally going.

71
00:03:35,180 --> 00:03:39,710
Sometimes it's memory or whatever but
a lot of times it's just CPU utilization.

72
00:03:39,710 --> 00:03:42,840
So when we go in here we might
wanna sort this information.

73
00:03:42,840 --> 00:03:46,750
And you'll notice when I just do
a straight up Get-Process the data's not

74
00:03:46,750 --> 00:03:47,930
really sorted.

75
00:03:47,930 --> 00:03:53,120
It's kinda spread out just in any order,
it's not truly random, it's actually

76
00:03:53,120 --> 00:03:57,110
alphabetized by the process name and so
it's just kinda just listed in that order.

77
00:03:57,110 --> 00:03:58,190
Well that might make sense for

78
00:03:58,190 --> 00:04:01,040
what we want, it might not make sense for
what we want.

79
00:04:01,040 --> 00:04:04,330
If I wanna see who's using
the most CPU from my system,

80
00:04:04,330 --> 00:04:09,380
well I can take Get-Process and
I can feed that into Sort-Object and

81
00:04:09,380 --> 00:04:13,450
I can sort that out to put it in
the order that I want, all right.

82
00:04:13,450 --> 00:04:15,610
So, let me show you an example of that.

83
00:04:15,610 --> 00:04:18,450
I'm going to pipe that into Sort-Object,

84
00:04:18,450 --> 00:04:22,750
and I'll need to pick what I want to
sort by, and I'm gonna sort by CPU.

85
00:04:22,750 --> 00:04:26,070
And so when I do that,
now it is sorted by CPU.

86
00:04:26,070 --> 00:04:28,570
And it goes from lowest to highest so

87
00:04:28,570 --> 00:04:32,760
you'll see my highest CPU utilizer
right there, down at the bottom.

88
00:04:32,760 --> 00:04:38,230
You can change that if you want if you
just add -descending to the end of it,

89
00:04:38,230 --> 00:04:42,360
that will flip the order so the highest
is at the beginning and the lowest is

90
00:04:42,360 --> 00:04:46,042
at the bottom, and now I can see that
same data just in a different order.

91
00:04:46,042 --> 00:04:48,120
So, Sort-Object is a great way to do that.

92
00:04:49,870 --> 00:04:51,890
All right, some of the other
things that we might want to do,

93
00:04:51,890 --> 00:04:53,460
we might want to kill a process.

94
00:04:53,460 --> 00:04:56,280
If I see somebody taking
up too much CPU or

95
00:04:56,280 --> 00:04:59,230
just annoying me in general,
maybe like Internet Explorer here,

96
00:04:59,230 --> 00:05:01,810
it's just sitting there in
the background but it's doing something.

97
00:05:01,810 --> 00:05:03,200
So I decide that I want to kill it.

98
00:05:03,200 --> 00:05:04,430
I just want to get it out of there.

99
00:05:04,430 --> 00:05:08,160
Well, we can use Stop-Process to do that.

100
00:05:08,160 --> 00:05:13,030
If we run Stop-Process and
then the process that we want to kill off,

101
00:05:13,030 --> 00:05:14,370
that will knock it off.

102
00:05:14,370 --> 00:05:17,065
Now if I just do Stop-Process iexplorer,
well,

103
00:05:17,065 --> 00:05:20,650
there's more than one process
called iexplorer right now.

104
00:05:20,650 --> 00:05:24,555
In Internet Explorer every time you open
up a tab, it runs in its own process.

105
00:05:24,555 --> 00:05:29,735
So if I do Stop-Process iexplorer,
it'll kill Internet Explorer outright.

106
00:05:29,735 --> 00:05:34,075
But if I just wanna kill a particular tab,
I'll need to do it by the id number so

107
00:05:34,075 --> 00:05:36,000
I can get that specific one.

108
00:05:36,000 --> 00:05:38,950
We don't normally do that because it's
really hard to tell which process ID

109
00:05:38,950 --> 00:05:40,500
a tab is tied to.

110
00:05:40,500 --> 00:05:44,380
But in other software you might have
a reason to kill off a particular process.

111
00:05:44,380 --> 00:05:46,250
And you'd use the ID for that.

112
00:05:46,250 --> 00:05:51,995
In fact, if you do a Get-Help,
for Stop-Process,

113
00:05:51,995 --> 00:05:58,710
you'll see that it accepts i
-d but- name is the default.

114
00:05:58,710 --> 00:05:59,860
So it's expecting a name.

115
00:05:59,860 --> 00:06:01,260
You can provide it the ID.

116
00:06:01,260 --> 00:06:03,010
It's up to you,
whichever one you want to provide.

117
00:06:04,350 --> 00:06:08,160
Now also keep in mind that you do need
to have permissions to stop the task.

118
00:06:08,160 --> 00:06:12,470
If you're just a regular user, you're not
going to be able to kill others' tasks.

119
00:06:12,470 --> 00:06:16,060
But if you're an administrator and you've
run your PowerShell with administrative

120
00:06:16,060 --> 00:06:18,690
privileges, you'll be able to
stop other people's tasks.

121
00:06:18,690 --> 00:06:22,840
And you can say Stop-Process iexplorer.

122
00:06:22,840 --> 00:06:26,230
And I've got my Internet Explorer windows
down here, so I've got like Google News,

123
00:06:26,230 --> 00:06:28,000
and slash dot pulled up, and

124
00:06:28,000 --> 00:06:32,520
I'm just gonna run this Stop-Process and
it's letting me know that, oh sorry,

125
00:06:32,520 --> 00:06:37,430
I need to throw in this dash name, so
it knows what to look for, there we go.

126
00:06:37,430 --> 00:06:40,820
And I can see that Internet Explorer
just dropped right out of the bottom.

127
00:06:40,820 --> 00:06:46,870
So that was Stop-Process -name iexplorer,
and it killed Internet Explorer outright.

128
00:06:46,870 --> 00:06:50,980
If I do a Get-Process,

129
00:06:50,980 --> 00:06:56,240
iexplorer, now it's gonna return back and
tell me there's nothing.

130
00:06:56,240 --> 00:06:58,990
There were no processes called iexplorer.

131
00:06:58,990 --> 00:07:01,880
And I know I didn't have a syntax
error cuz if I just change that to,

132
00:07:01,880 --> 00:07:04,240
like, explorer, that returns back.

133
00:07:04,240 --> 00:07:06,120
Right?
So there were just no processes

134
00:07:06,120 --> 00:07:06,755
called iexplorer.

135
00:07:08,800 --> 00:07:12,730
All right, there are some other neat
little tricks that we can do with this.

136
00:07:12,730 --> 00:07:17,190
For most people, that's all you need right
there, Get-Process and Stop-Process.

137
00:07:17,190 --> 00:07:20,860
Those are the two main ones that we use,
but there's another one that I like,

138
00:07:20,860 --> 00:07:25,440
if you want to hunt for processes that
are frozen, that are not responding.

139
00:07:25,440 --> 00:07:27,490
You know how sometimes
a program will lock up and

140
00:07:27,490 --> 00:07:29,390
in the task manager it will
just say not responding and

141
00:07:29,390 --> 00:07:34,150
you can try an end the task that way We
can actually use the PowerShell to query

142
00:07:34,150 --> 00:07:38,030
for which processes are not responding,
and then attempt to terminate them.

143
00:07:38,030 --> 00:07:41,390
Or maybe we just wanna query and
see which one's not responding, right.

144
00:07:41,390 --> 00:07:44,710
So that command,
it actually involves more than one thing.

145
00:07:44,710 --> 00:07:47,760
I'm gonna start with Get-Process,
all right, so

146
00:07:47,760 --> 00:07:53,720
that's gonna pull my process list, and
I'm gonna pipe that into where-object.

147
00:07:53,720 --> 00:07:57,570
Remember, we can use where-object to
filter the output that we're getting, so

148
00:07:57,570 --> 00:08:01,540
I'm gonna filter this out, and I'm gonna
filter it out with a little filter script.

149
00:08:03,850 --> 00:08:06,780
And my filter script is
gonna be a fairly simple one

150
00:08:06,780 --> 00:08:09,428
I'm going to start by
taking my original data.

151
00:08:09,428 --> 00:08:10,860
So that $_,

152
00:08:10,860 --> 00:08:14,420
that's a reference that says whatever
the output from the first command is.

153
00:08:14,420 --> 00:08:19,410
So Get-Process is output and
then dot responding.

154
00:08:20,560 --> 00:08:27,370
We didn't see it up here, up here in this
table there's no column called responding.

155
00:08:27,370 --> 00:08:31,410
And when I did that format list,
remember we saw even less.

156
00:08:31,410 --> 00:08:32,990
But it doesn't mean the data isn't there.

157
00:08:32,990 --> 00:08:35,300
It's just not being rendered on screen.

158
00:08:35,300 --> 00:08:40,510
And so I'm referencing a value that
doesn't necessarily show up by default.

159
00:08:40,510 --> 00:08:42,200
Responding, right?

160
00:08:42,200 --> 00:08:45,650
If the app is not responding,
then it's gonna fail that, right?

161
00:08:45,650 --> 00:08:52,819
So I'm gonna say,$_Responding -eq $False.

162
00:08:52,819 --> 00:08:56,500
If it reflects false,
that means it's not responding and

163
00:08:56,500 --> 00:09:00,180
that's an app that I need to kill off,
alright.

164
00:09:00,180 --> 00:09:03,480
Now, if I just run it like that well,

165
00:09:03,480 --> 00:09:08,410
that's gonna return a list of any apps
that are currently not responding.

166
00:09:08,410 --> 00:09:14,160
But I can take that and I can pipe
that one more time into stop-process.

167
00:09:14,160 --> 00:09:17,835
And now it will say,
give me a list of my processes.

168
00:09:17,835 --> 00:09:20,775
Filter it down to just the ones
that are not responding and

169
00:09:20,775 --> 00:09:23,325
whatever ones are not responding,
stop them.

170
00:09:23,325 --> 00:09:25,955
All right.
So we're kind of stepping through as we go

171
00:09:25,955 --> 00:09:29,970
through and thin our list out and
then stop those processes outright.

172
00:09:29,970 --> 00:09:31,560
And it kills them out.

173
00:09:31,560 --> 00:09:34,000
Now in my case there weren't any
processes that weren't responding so

174
00:09:34,000 --> 00:09:35,540
that's not gonna happen.

175
00:09:35,540 --> 00:09:39,450
But you can make really neat commands like
these, right, a series of commands that

176
00:09:39,450 --> 00:09:43,930
work together to achieve your goal and you
can automate sorts of things with this.

177
00:09:43,930 --> 00:09:44,990
So really cool.

178
00:09:44,990 --> 00:09:48,840
You can query like what the CPU load
is of a very particular process,

179
00:09:48,840 --> 00:09:51,140
maybe you're trying to develop
your own logging system.

180
00:09:51,140 --> 00:09:52,020
You can do that.

181
00:09:52,020 --> 00:09:55,470
There's really no limit to what
you can achieve with this.

182
00:09:55,470 --> 00:09:58,420
But, just keep in mind that basically
everything that you can do inside of

183
00:09:58,420 --> 00:10:02,520
the task manager, well, you can do
right here through the PowerShell.

184
00:10:02,520 --> 00:10:06,000
The only one that really gives you
a problem is which user is attached to

185
00:10:06,000 --> 00:10:06,600
the process.

186
00:10:06,600 --> 00:10:10,220
For whatever reason, Microsoft hasn't
added that support into Powershell yet.

187
00:10:10,220 --> 00:10:14,202
By the time you watch this video maybe
they will have, but at this time I'm

188
00:10:14,202 --> 00:10:18,400
not aware of anyway to see what
user's responsible for that process.

189
00:10:18,400 --> 00:10:22,740
Versus if I go into the task manager, well
in the task manager you can quickly and

190
00:10:22,740 --> 00:10:26,630
easily see which users
are tied to which processes.

191
00:10:26,630 --> 00:10:29,530
When I see something like
Windows Explorer right here,

192
00:10:29,530 --> 00:10:32,090
I can see that D Pezet is who launched it.

193
00:10:32,090 --> 00:10:32,630
Right?

194
00:10:32,630 --> 00:10:34,590
Well, the PowerShell doesn't show that.

195
00:10:34,590 --> 00:10:36,570
Microsoft will probably
add that in the future.

196
00:10:36,570 --> 00:10:40,330
If you guys out there in TV land know
a way to do that, definitely let me know.

197
00:10:40,330 --> 00:10:43,740
I haven't seen a way to do that, so
that's one thing that we can't do, but

198
00:10:43,740 --> 00:10:47,630
otherwise pulling our data back,
looking at how it's going,

199
00:10:47,630 --> 00:10:52,800
stopping processes those functions we
can easily do from in the power shop.

200
00:10:52,800 --> 00:10:55,350
So in this segment we got
a chance to see Get-Process,

201
00:10:55,350 --> 00:10:57,838
which is like our PowerShell
based task manager.

202
00:10:57,838 --> 00:11:02,680
We saw Stop-Process, how we could stop
any or kill off any processes running.

203
00:11:02,680 --> 00:11:06,470
And lastly, I showed you guys how to
detect not responding processes and

204
00:11:06,470 --> 00:11:07,630
how to stop them also.

205
00:11:07,630 --> 00:11:10,070
I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

206
00:11:10,070 --> 00:11:10,660
Stay tuned.

207
00:11:10,660 --> 00:11:16,119
We've got more PowerShell,coming up.

208
00:11:16,119 --> 00:11:18,450

Yay printers [LAUGH].

00:00:16,335 --> 00:00:18,510
Those of you that have seen me before,

00:00:21,680 --> 00:00:24,870
They are always seem to be

We're going to take a look at some of our
PowerShell commands that we can use to

our print servers, as well as adding

I think is what's called on the HOL page.

00:00:48,840 --> 00:00:51,830
And here I am on server
one that's running 2012R2.

16
00:00:53,100 --> 00:00:55,460
And I'm gonna pull up PowerShell.

17
00:00:55,460 --> 00:00:57,180
So the first thing I'm gonna do.

18
00:00:57,180 --> 00:00:59,640
There's a few steps that
are involved in adding a printer.

19
00:00:59,640 --> 00:01:03,160
You guys, we've added printers through

20
00:01:03,160 --> 00:01:05,590
When we go to add a printer,
we've gotta do a couple of things.

21
00:01:05,590 --> 00:01:08,610
We've gotta make sure we've got
the driver For the printer.

00:01:08,610 --> 00:01:11,240
We've gotta create a port for
that printer.

00:01:11,240 --> 00:01:12,950
And then we've gotta
create the printer itself.

24
00:01:12,950 --> 00:01:14,890
Right?
Remember in Microsoft land,

25
00:01:14,890 --> 00:01:17,060
the thing that sits on your desk, or

26
00:01:17,060 --> 00:01:20,360
is sitting over there in the corner of
the office, that's not the printer.

Right?
That's the print device.

28

What we've gotta do is create the printer,

printers window, in our control

30

So the first thing I'm gonna do,

31

So the command for that.

32

I've got a link that I'm

In fact I can pull that up real

00:01:42,490 --> 00:01:44,590
Microsoft has a great page
of course on tech net.

35
00:01:45,900 --> 00:01:50,020
And here on again, I'll put that note or
this link in our show notes.

36
00:01:50,020 --> 00:01:53,010
Here you can see all the different
commands I have available for

37
00:01:53,010 --> 00:01:54,950
working for working with my printers.

38
00:01:54,950 --> 00:01:57,710
Things like add printer,
add printer driver,

39
00:01:57,710 --> 00:02:01,850
add printer port,
obviously to begin to set this up.

40
00:02:01,850 --> 00:02:05,480
And then once you've got printers On
stall, then we've got our get command,

00:02:05,480 --> 00:02:09,360
where we can retrieve properties
about those printers, get printer,

00:02:09,360 --> 00:02:14,230
get printer driver, get printer port,
get printer properties.

43
00:02:14,230 --> 00:02:16,460
We can also work with
the jobs through PowerShell.

44
00:02:16,460 --> 00:02:19,660
We can pull back a list
of the running jobs.

45
00:02:19,660 --> 00:02:24,570
We can stop and start those jobs,
resume those jobs, cancel jobs,

46
00:02:24,570 --> 00:02:25,830
and things like that.

47
00:02:25,830 --> 00:02:26,550
So let's get started.

48
00:02:26,550 --> 00:02:30,130
First thing we're going to do again,
is switch back here to my server and

49
00:02:30,130 --> 00:02:31,860
I'm going to install the print drivers.

50
00:02:31,860 --> 00:02:37,150
That's going to be add-printerdriver,
If I could spell,

51
00:02:37,150 --> 00:02:43,620
it would make the auto-fill a little
bit easier, add-printerDriver.

52
00:02:43,620 --> 00:02:45,180
Now I'm gonna go ahead and

00:02:45,180 --> 00:02:48,680
use the switch computer name,
just to show you guys the switch.

00:02:49,690 --> 00:02:52,280
Because I'm running it on the machine
that I'm installing the printer,

00:02:52,280 --> 00:02:53,510
I could just leave that blank.

56
00:02:53,510 --> 00:02:57,170
It will default, if I don't use
the -ComputerName parameter,

57
00:02:57,170 --> 00:03:00,390
it's gonna default to the machine I'm
actually running this command on.

58
00:03:00,390 --> 00:03:03,890
If I was doing a remote session
with another server, again,

59
00:03:03,890 --> 00:03:06,730
I could leave out that -ComputerName,
because I'm on that server,

60
00:03:06,730 --> 00:03:13,654
remoting in to it, and it would assume,
or default, to the local machine.

61
00:03:13,654 --> 00:03:19,610
But I'll do it anyway, -Computer,

and then the name of the print
driver that I'm installing.

So, I'm going to do a dash name, and

already installed on this machine, or
it has available through the Windows.

00:03:32,550 --> 00:03:38,538
So, we're going to go to Dell, Color,

00:03:38,538 --> 00:03:44,702
which one did I use here, laser, pcl6,

00:03:44,702 --> 00:03:50,184
if I remember right, class driver.

Hit Enter.

00:22:12,756 --> 00:22:17,331
day to day objectives that we have when
working with firewall rules and Windows.

473
00:22:17,331 --> 00:22:19,340
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

474
00:22:19,340 --> 00:22:23,440
Stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up.

475
00:22:23,440 --> 00:22:29,200
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Installing DNS
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:02,979
[SOUND] In this segment,

2
00:00:02,979 --> 00:00:08,592
we're gonna take a look
at installing the DNS

3
00:00:08,592 --> 00:00:13,329
role on a server through PowerShell.

4
00:00:13,329 --> 00:00:16,607
Often times, we wanna set up a DNS server
but we might be doing this remotely,

5
00:00:16,607 --> 00:00:19,342
from our workstation setting DNS
up on a server somewhere else.

6
00:00:19,342 --> 00:00:23,485
Or it might be a core install of the
server, where we have access to PowerShell

7
00:00:23,485 --> 00:00:26,436
and we wanna install DNS,
but we don't have the GUIs.

8
00:00:26,436 --> 00:00:28,201
That's what we're going
to look at right here.

9
00:00:28,201 --> 00:00:30,026
>> And
it's a pretty straight forward command,

10
00:00:30,026 --> 00:00:31,960
I think we've done this
in a few other segments.

11
00:00:31,960 --> 00:00:36,700
We're just gonna use the install
dash Windows feature commandlet, So

12
00:00:36,700 --> 00:00:42,358
Install-WindowsFeature, And

13
00:00:42,358 --> 00:00:44,903
then the name of the role that I wanna
install in this case is gonna be dns.

14
00:00:44,903 --> 00:00:48,541
And then the only other thing I have
to choose or decide is, whether or

15
00:00:48,541 --> 00:00:50,814
not I wanna include the management tools.

16
00:00:50,814 --> 00:00:55,374
And typically we do, so I'm gonna just
type in IncludeManagementTools as one of

17
00:00:55,374 --> 00:00:56,320
my parameters.

18
00:00:56,320 --> 00:00:59,679
>> If this were a core server install,
you'd wanna install the DNS server,

19
00:00:59,679 --> 00:01:02,387
but there's no point in
installing the management tools,

20
00:01:02,387 --> 00:01:04,138
because you can't run them, right?

21
00:01:04,138 --> 00:01:07,950
These are the GUI tools and
some command line utilities you can't use.

22
00:01:07,950 --> 00:01:11,580
The management tools are what you
typically want on your workstation, but

23
00:01:11,580 --> 00:01:13,860
if you are gonna be managing
this from the server itself,

24
00:01:13,860 --> 00:01:16,620
if it is a full server install, you might
as well install the management tools.

25
00:01:16,620 --> 00:01:18,520
But you do have to provide that option,
if you leave it off,

26
00:01:18,520 --> 00:01:19,820
it doesn't install them by default.

27
00:01:19,820 --> 00:01:21,688
>> Exactly.

28
00:01:21,688 --> 00:01:26,475
So we hit that, that's pretty much it, we
can watch it run, and it will install DNS.

29
00:01:26,475 --> 00:01:29,873
>> Now once it gets installed,
it's there, it's actually running,

30
00:01:29,873 --> 00:01:31,220
it does start the service,

31
00:01:31,220 --> 00:01:34,695
which I guess we can verify when we
get that service after this is done.

32
00:01:34,695 --> 00:01:38,589
But it'll install it, it'll start running,
but it's not really doing much for

33
00:01:38,589 --> 00:01:41,648
us because there's no zone, so
we've got some more work to do.

34
00:01:41,648 --> 00:01:45,093
But the basic installation is right there,
and yeah, Mike just queried it,

35
00:01:45,093 --> 00:01:48,381
we can see the DNS server's up,
it's running, and we're in business.

36
00:01:48,381 --> 00:01:51,154
So, key thing to remember
here is simply whether or

37
00:01:51,154 --> 00:01:54,130
not you choose to include
the management tools or not.

38
00:01:54,130 --> 00:01:56,190
But otherwise, installing DNS?

39
00:01:56,190 --> 00:01:57,082
Super easy.

40
00:01:57,082 --> 00:01:59,605
All right, well in this segment
we saw installing DNS, I know,

41
00:01:59,605 --> 00:02:01,262
not the most exciting thing in the world.

42
00:02:01,262 --> 00:02:02,940
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] But stay tuned,

43
00:02:02,940 --> 00:02:06,121
because in our following segments we're
gonna show how we configure DNS to

44
00:02:06,121 --> 00:02:08,762
actually get it to be useful,
to get it to be doing something.

45
00:02:08,762 --> 00:02:13,329
As it stands right here we've basically
created a DNS caching server, but

46
00:02:13,329 --> 00:02:15,368
we likely want to do more with it.

47
00:02:15,368 --> 00:02:19,280
So be sure to check out our other
segments as we start to configure DNS.

48
00:02:19,280 --> 00:02:26,604
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Managing Zones
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,203
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,203 --> 00:00:11,396
In this segment, we're gonna take
a look at one of the first things we do

3
00:00:11,396 --> 00:00:12,840
when we set up a new DNS Server.

4
00:00:12,840 --> 00:00:16,610
Which is, configuring and
managing our zones.

5
00:00:16,610 --> 00:00:19,195
A DNS server is not terribly useful
without some zones in there.

6
00:00:19,195 --> 00:00:21,380
From being able to do forward and
reverse lookups.

7
00:00:21,380 --> 00:00:24,460
And so, that's what we're
going to look at right here.

8
00:00:24,460 --> 00:00:26,210
>> All right.
So we're going to start by setting up,

9
00:00:26,210 --> 00:00:28,920
as we know from DNS, there's different
types of zones we can create.

10
00:00:28,920 --> 00:00:31,750
We've got our primary, and
our secondaries, and our stubs.

11
00:00:31,750 --> 00:00:33,730
We can choose to do active
directory integrated.

12
00:00:33,730 --> 00:00:37,100
Or we can set it up as a separate
file if it's not a domain controller.

13
00:00:37,100 --> 00:00:39,550
Or if we choose just not to do
active directory integrator.

14
00:00:39,550 --> 00:00:42,620
So the first command I'm going to do is
I'm just going to add a primary zone.

15
00:00:42,620 --> 00:00:44,540
This server is a domain controller.

16
00:00:44,540 --> 00:00:46,850
And he’s already got a zone for
contoso.com.

17
00:00:46,850 --> 00:00:48,560
It’s Active Directory integrated.

18
00:00:48,560 --> 00:00:50,610
And I’m gonna add a second
zone to the server.

19
00:00:50,610 --> 00:00:57,143
So the command is gonna be
add-dnsserver primary zone.

20
00:00:57,143 --> 00:00:59,955
Oops, So not enough letters,
try that one more time.

21
00:00:59,955 --> 00:01:02,618
We're not going to tab
through all of that.

22
00:01:02,618 --> 00:01:05,063
So, add -dnsserver primary zone.

23
00:01:05,063 --> 00:01:08,995
And then -name, and the name of
the zone that you want to create.

24
00:01:08,995 --> 00:01:17,120
In this case I'm just going to
call it west01.contoso.com, oops.

25
00:01:17,120 --> 00:01:20,060
And after the name, we're going
to give it the replication scope.

26
00:01:20,060 --> 00:01:22,540
Because this is going to be
active directory integrated,

27
00:01:22,540 --> 00:01:24,940
if you think back to running
through this through your GUI.

28
00:01:24,940 --> 00:01:27,575
You've got to choose if I'm going
to replicate this to all domain

29
00:01:27,575 --> 00:01:29,846
controllers in the domain
that are running DNS.

30
00:01:29,846 --> 00:01:32,861
All domain controllers in
the force that are running DNS.

31
00:01:32,861 --> 00:01:35,850
And so the parameter for
that is just replication scope.

32
00:01:35,850 --> 00:01:38,060
And I'm going to do forest for that one.

33
00:01:38,060 --> 00:01:42,721
And then I can add a little -passthrough
if we want to see a little bit of

34
00:01:42,721 --> 00:01:45,095
output for that, I'll hit enter.

35
00:01:48,495 --> 00:01:52,380
And there I can see I have now
created a zone, west01.contoso.com.

36
00:01:52,380 --> 00:01:55,190
It is a primary for the zone type.

37
00:01:55,190 --> 00:01:59,650
IsDSIntegrated is listed as true,
all right.

38
00:01:59,650 --> 00:02:04,125
And if we take a look at my DNS console,
and I refresh my Forward Lookup Zones.

39
00:02:06,536 --> 00:02:09,370
I now have a zone for west01.contoso.com.

40
00:02:09,370 --> 00:02:11,460
And when I look at Forward Lookup Zones,

41
00:02:11,460 --> 00:02:14,260
I can see that it is
Active Directory Integrated.

42
00:02:14,260 --> 00:02:14,850
All right.

43
00:02:14,850 --> 00:02:17,350
So that's one type of
zone that we can create.

44
00:02:17,350 --> 00:02:19,610
>> And for most people, active
directory integrated is what you want.

45
00:02:19,610 --> 00:02:22,340
But one of the things Mike said at
the beginning of the segment was, hey,

46
00:02:22,340 --> 00:02:24,730
this guy is an active
directory domain controller.

47
00:02:24,730 --> 00:02:27,190
If you're going to be
running your DNS server

48
00:02:27,190 --> 00:02:29,480
not on an active directory
domain controller.

49
00:02:29,480 --> 00:02:31,750
Well, you don't really
have that option anymore.

50
00:02:31,750 --> 00:02:36,690
So you need to go old school, and create
what's called the standard primary zone.

51
00:02:36,690 --> 00:02:39,710
One that's not stored in the active
directory, but instead stored in a file.

52
00:02:40,750 --> 00:02:43,100
>> You know what,
I don't think this guy is running DNS.

53
00:02:43,100 --> 00:02:46,135
So let's install -windowsfeature.

54
00:02:46,135 --> 00:02:47,790
>> [LAUGH]
>> I forgot about that.

55
00:02:47,790 --> 00:02:50,655
>> It is hard to add a zone to
a server not actually running DNS.

56
00:02:50,655 --> 00:02:53,180
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

57
00:02:53,180 --> 00:02:54,390
we're get that running real quick.

58
00:02:55,580 --> 00:02:56,680
Success was true.

59
00:02:56,680 --> 00:02:57,660
Boy that was awfully fast.

60
00:02:57,660 --> 00:02:59,410
Maybe I
>> It must already be running.

61
00:02:59,410 --> 00:03:00,240
>> Good.

62
00:03:00,240 --> 00:03:02,700
All right so on this guy,
this is not a domain controller.

63
00:03:02,700 --> 00:03:06,280
It's a member server that
I've installed DNS on.

64
00:03:06,280 --> 00:03:08,130
So we're gonna create
another primary zone.

65
00:03:08,130 --> 00:03:09,880
This time I'm gonna do a file based zone.

66
00:03:09,880 --> 00:03:12,930
So this might be something you
might run out your DMZ, or

67
00:03:12,930 --> 00:03:14,820
somewhere you need a DNS server.

68
00:03:14,820 --> 00:03:18,310
But you don't wanna put it, or
don't have a domain controller.

69
00:03:18,310 --> 00:03:19,790
So the command is gonna be very similar.

70
00:03:19,790 --> 00:03:26,715
It's gonna be add -dnsserver primary zone.

71
00:03:26,715 --> 00:03:27,410
So DNS server primary zone.

72
00:03:27,410 --> 00:03:29,810
And I've gotta give it a name.

73
00:03:29,810 --> 00:03:32,824
So the name is going to be,

74
00:03:32,824 --> 00:03:37,758
let’s call this west2.contoso.com.

75
00:03:40,138 --> 00:03:42,530
All right, and what else do I need?

76
00:03:42,530 --> 00:03:46,830
And for this one, since it's not going
to be active directory integrated.

77
00:03:46,830 --> 00:03:49,720
I've got to give it a name for
the file that it's going to create.

78
00:03:49,720 --> 00:03:52,240
Where it's going to store
those resource records.

79
00:03:52,240 --> 00:03:52,980
And again,

80
00:03:52,980 --> 00:03:56,580
if you think back to the GUI interface
you've gone through that wizard before.

81
00:03:56,580 --> 00:04:01,865
Same options there, so
we'll say west2.contoso.com.

82
00:04:01,865 --> 00:04:03,605
>> You going to do a looks like -zonefile.

83
00:04:03,605 --> 00:04:07,425
>> Oops, I forgot my parameter there.

84
00:04:07,425 --> 00:04:11,014
So let's do that, zonefile.

85
00:04:11,014 --> 00:04:11,770
There we go.

86
00:04:13,290 --> 00:04:13,820
And we hit enter.

87
00:04:14,830 --> 00:04:17,015
And have it take a look at my DNS console.

88
00:04:24,506 --> 00:04:26,039
Let me expand down my
forward look up zones.

89
00:04:28,470 --> 00:04:31,310
>> There you go.
>> And there's my west2.contoso.com.

90
00:04:31,310 --> 00:04:34,930
So there we created an active directory
integrated zone on a domain controller.

91
00:04:34,930 --> 00:04:38,610
And then now we've created a-
>> Standard primary.

92
00:04:38,610 --> 00:04:40,630
>> Standard primary,
from back in the old days.

93
00:04:40,630 --> 00:04:43,260
>> The thing to remember is that
the command is really the same,

94
00:04:43,260 --> 00:04:47,440
both times we did add-
dnsserver primary zone.

95
00:04:47,440 --> 00:04:52,410
The difference was for active directory
integrated, you did -replication scope.

96
00:04:52,410 --> 00:04:54,820
Which said what domain controllers
are going to carry this.

97
00:04:54,820 --> 00:05:00,555
And then for a standard primary,
just ones outside, we did a -zone file.

98
00:05:00,555 --> 00:05:02,935
Instead of being stored as
a replication scope in the AD,

99
00:05:02,935 --> 00:05:04,865
this one is stored in a file.

100
00:05:04,865 --> 00:05:07,685
And that file,
I can never remember, It was what?

101
00:05:07,685 --> 00:05:11,750
C:/Windows/System32/DNS, but
it's just right in there.

102
00:05:11,750 --> 00:05:13,021
[CROSSTALK] Just a text files.

103
00:05:13,021 --> 00:05:14,770
Contains the whole zone.

104
00:05:14,770 --> 00:05:16,310
It's created and you're in business.

105
00:05:16,310 --> 00:05:20,300
So setting up a primary zone like that,
not a big deal at all.

106
00:05:20,300 --> 00:05:21,080
>> Not at all.

107
00:05:21,080 --> 00:05:21,664
All right.
So those

108
00:05:21,664 --> 00:05:25,890
are my active directory integrated,
and my standard primaries.

109
00:05:25,890 --> 00:05:27,840
Next thing we want to create is
going to be reverse lookup zone.

110
00:05:28,950 --> 00:05:31,790
So again, the command is similar.

111
00:05:31,790 --> 00:05:34,760
We're gonna change that up.

112
00:05:34,760 --> 00:05:38,500
It starts out the same,
add-dnsserverPrimaryZone.

113
00:05:38,500 --> 00:05:44,990
And then for this one, instead of a zone
name, we're gonna do a network ID.

114
00:05:46,460 --> 00:05:47,430
So network ID.

115
00:05:48,720 --> 00:05:53,937
And we're going to,
I forget what network we're using,

116
00:05:53,937 --> 00:05:57,141
192.168.1.0/24.

117
00:05:57,141 --> 00:05:58,590
That one.

118
00:05:58,590 --> 00:06:01,270
And then again,
because this is the domain controller.

119
00:06:01,270 --> 00:06:06,190
So let's do the -replicationScope.

120
00:06:06,190 --> 00:06:07,350
And we'll do forest again.

121
00:06:07,350 --> 00:06:11,880
So this is gonna create a reverse lookup
zone that is active directory integrated.

122
00:06:13,040 --> 00:06:14,650
So let's verify that, that worked.

123
00:06:14,650 --> 00:06:17,060
We'll flip back over to my DNS console.

124
00:06:17,060 --> 00:06:19,800
We'll refresh my good old
reverse lookup zones here.

125
00:06:21,390 --> 00:06:25,050
And there she is,
my 192.168.1.0 reverse lookup zone.

126
00:06:27,000 --> 00:06:29,250
So that's gonna be an active
directory integrated zone.

127
00:06:29,250 --> 00:06:32,200
If we look at the type,
that is active directory integrated.

128
00:06:32,200 --> 00:06:35,620
And then,
just like with the standard primaries,

129
00:06:35,620 --> 00:06:40,490
the command to do a file based
reverse lookup zone is the same thing.

130
00:06:40,490 --> 00:06:45,300
Instead of doing the replication scope.

131
00:06:45,300 --> 00:06:46,710
We're going to give it
that zone file name.

132
00:06:48,320 --> 00:06:49,580
I flip back over here.

133
00:06:51,390 --> 00:06:56,610
And do another add -dnsserverPrimaryZone.

134
00:06:56,610 --> 00:07:01,660
We'll do a dash name,
I'm sorry, dash network ID.

135
00:07:01,660 --> 00:07:03,340
And again, we'll do the same thing.

136
00:07:03,340 --> 00:07:11,044
192.168.1.0/24.

137
00:07:11,044 --> 00:07:14,030
And then, for the zone file.

138
00:07:14,030 --> 00:07:17,720
We'll do instead of the replication scope,
we're going to do the zone file.

139
00:07:17,720 --> 00:07:24,003
And the zone files, reverse look up
zones or the network ID backwards.

140
00:07:24,003 --> 00:07:30,880
So we'll do 0.168.192.

141
00:07:30,880 --> 00:07:34,525
And then that reserve dns suffix.

142
00:07:34,525 --> 00:07:41,670
in -addr.arpa.dns for that file.

143
00:07:43,220 --> 00:07:47,010
>> And that final name, you can actually
put whatever name you want in there.

144
00:07:47,010 --> 00:07:50,240
You could call it bob.txt if you wanted,
but it would still work.

145
00:07:50,240 --> 00:07:54,190
But if you want to kind of
observe the normal process.

146
00:07:54,190 --> 00:07:56,860
These are the default file
names that Microsoft would use.

147
00:07:56,860 --> 00:07:59,120
If you use the GUI to create that zone,

148
00:07:59,120 --> 00:08:02,490
it would create a file named
exactly like Mike just did there.

149
00:08:02,490 --> 00:08:05,020
So, while you can use whatever you want.

150
00:08:05,020 --> 00:08:06,800
You're usually better off
sticking with the standards.

151
00:08:06,800 --> 00:08:10,190
Because if somebody else has to come
behind you and troubleshoot the server.

152
00:08:10,190 --> 00:08:12,480
They're not gonna know what Bob.txt is.

153
00:08:12,480 --> 00:08:15,300
But they are gonna know what
that file name is right there.

154
00:08:15,300 --> 00:08:15,820
>> Exactly.

155
00:08:15,820 --> 00:08:18,060
>> But, just like Mike said,
instead of doing the replication scope,

156
00:08:18,060 --> 00:08:20,000
you just do zone file, and that's it.

157
00:08:20,000 --> 00:08:22,940
Really the only difference between
a forward look up zone, and

158
00:08:22,940 --> 00:08:24,420
a reverse look up zone.

159
00:08:24,420 --> 00:08:26,800
Is in a forward look up zone,
we gave it a name.

160
00:08:26,800 --> 00:08:29,530
In a reverse look up zone
we gave it a network ID.

161
00:08:29,530 --> 00:08:31,290
Right?
That's the difference between the two.

162
00:08:32,800 --> 00:08:34,840
>> All right.
So we've set up our primaries,

163
00:08:34,840 --> 00:08:35,450
our secondaries.

164
00:08:35,450 --> 00:08:37,300
The next thing I want to do,
actually I'm sorry.

165
00:08:37,300 --> 00:08:38,620
We set up all of our primaries, right?

166
00:08:38,620 --> 00:08:41,470
We did the active directory integrated,
and then the standard primary.

167
00:08:41,470 --> 00:08:44,650
Next thing we're gonna want to be able
to do, is provide some redundancy.

168
00:08:44,650 --> 00:08:47,060
We've got a DNS server
that's hosting a zone.

169
00:08:47,060 --> 00:08:49,930
I want more than one
DNS Server hosting that zone.

170
00:08:49,930 --> 00:08:52,050
In case one of them fails.

171
00:08:52,050 --> 00:08:57,480
So we on DC1 I've got a zone for
contoso.com.

172
00:08:57,480 --> 00:08:59,210
>> And that's active directory.

173
00:08:59,210 --> 00:09:00,090
Is that active directory?

174
00:09:00,090 --> 00:09:01,050
>> That is active directory integrated.

175
00:09:01,050 --> 00:09:02,420
>> If they're active directory integrated,

176
00:09:02,420 --> 00:09:06,340
remember that any DNS server that you
bring up that's in that replication scope.

177
00:09:06,340 --> 00:09:07,750
It’ll automatically get the zone.

178
00:09:07,750 --> 00:09:11,690
So you’ve already got replication there,
it’s no big deal, you’re done.

179
00:09:12,810 --> 00:09:18,160
But what if that zone is hosted on
a Linux server, or a UNIX Bind server.

180
00:09:18,160 --> 00:09:21,440
Or it’s just hosted in some other domain,
and you want a copy of it?

181
00:09:21,440 --> 00:09:24,310
Well, in that case,
you might not be a part of that domain.

182
00:09:24,310 --> 00:09:26,380
You don't get a copy of that DNS zone.

183
00:09:26,380 --> 00:09:30,420
And you may wanna set up what's
called a standard secondary.

184
00:09:30,420 --> 00:09:34,490
And a standard secondary being one
that is a backup copy of that zone,

185
00:09:34,490 --> 00:09:36,880
that's stored on your own DNS server.

186
00:09:36,880 --> 00:09:37,610
>> Exactly.

187
00:09:37,610 --> 00:09:40,360
So we'll go over here,
I'm gonna go over to serve one, and

188
00:09:40,360 --> 00:09:42,549
I'll use him as my secondary.

189
00:09:43,640 --> 00:09:48,329
And the command for that one is gonna

190
00:09:48,329 --> 00:09:53,190
be add -dnsserverSecondaryZone.

191
00:09:53,190 --> 00:09:56,270
And for this one, the zone already exists.

192
00:09:56,270 --> 00:09:59,260
Contoso or DC1 is hosting that zone.

193
00:09:59,260 --> 00:10:03,160
So I've gotta give it the name of the zone
that I wanna make this secondary for.

194
00:10:03,160 --> 00:10:05,550
>> Which we're gonna do that
,we'll do west01 I guess.

195
00:10:05,550 --> 00:10:11,223
Let's make sure we called it-
>> I think you called it west1.

196
00:10:11,223 --> 00:10:13,115
>> I think I did too.

197
00:10:13,115 --> 00:10:16,690
west2 and nope, west01 and west8.

198
00:10:16,690 --> 00:10:17,921
I'm not very consistent with my names.

199
00:10:17,921 --> 00:10:21,240
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

200
00:10:21,240 --> 00:10:26,570
we'll call this one West 01.contoso.com.

201
00:10:26,570 --> 00:10:30,170
And then because this guy
is not a domain controller.

202
00:10:30,170 --> 00:10:32,940
I'm going to have to create a file
to store that information in.

203
00:10:32,940 --> 00:10:34,743
So the zone file.

204
00:10:34,743 --> 00:10:39,751
And again, And we'll just use our
native standard convention here,

205
00:10:39,751 --> 00:10:43,724
west01.contoso.com.dns.

206
00:10:43,724 --> 00:10:45,905
Now, this is a secondary.

207
00:10:45,905 --> 00:10:48,085
So he's a read-only copy.

208
00:10:48,085 --> 00:10:50,180
He has to get that
information from somewhere.

209
00:10:50,180 --> 00:10:53,820
So in my PowerShell command, I've got
to specify who that master server is.

210
00:10:53,820 --> 00:10:55,680
Who's he getting his copy from?

211
00:10:55,680 --> 00:10:58,650
And the parameter for
that is just masterservers.

212
00:10:58,650 --> 00:11:05,328
So -masterservers, and
then the IP address of my master server.

213
00:11:05,328 --> 00:11:12,071
In this case 192.1 68.1.1, and enter.

214
00:11:12,071 --> 00:11:15,831
And now if I flip over
here to my DNS console.

215
00:11:15,831 --> 00:11:18,000
I should have a new forward lookup zone.

216
00:11:19,470 --> 00:11:20,180
For west01.

217
00:11:21,230 --> 00:11:22,690
But, I've got an error.

218
00:11:22,690 --> 00:11:24,860
I can see that that zone
hasn't been loaded up.

219
00:11:24,860 --> 00:11:25,490
Remember when you're.

220
00:11:25,490 --> 00:11:28,020
Setting up your secondaries by default.

221
00:11:28,020 --> 00:11:30,800
Starting with I think 2008,
they finally got it right.

222
00:11:30,800 --> 00:11:34,690
By default DNS servers don't
allow zone transfers at all.

223
00:11:34,690 --> 00:11:38,250
You have to go in to specify who is
allowed to request the copy of that zone.

224
00:11:38,250 --> 00:11:41,040
So even though I've added
the secondary zone here, and

225
00:11:41,040 --> 00:11:43,040
I've told it who to get the copy from.

226
00:11:43,040 --> 00:11:46,190
When he calls out dc1, and says,
hey can I get a copy of that zone?

227
00:11:46,190 --> 00:11:48,070
dc1 is saying no.

228
00:11:48,070 --> 00:11:49,980
You can't have a copy of that.

229
00:11:49,980 --> 00:11:53,540
So what we need to do is
go back over to our master.

230
00:11:53,540 --> 00:11:54,540
In this case dc.

231
00:11:55,720 --> 00:11:59,815
And let it know that it's okay to
give a copy of that zone to server1.

232
00:12:01,330 --> 00:12:03,120
And this is a cool command.

233
00:12:03,120 --> 00:12:05,530
We can do a few different
options with this.

234
00:12:05,530 --> 00:12:10,250
The command is going to be,
we're modifying an existing zone.

235
00:12:10,250 --> 00:12:12,140
We're not creating a new zone here.

236
00:12:12,140 --> 00:12:16,660
So it's gonna be set
-dnsserverPrimaryZone.

237
00:12:16,660 --> 00:12:20,230
Set dash DNS server primary zone.

238
00:12:20,230 --> 00:12:23,570
And then the name of the zone
that you want to modify.

239
00:12:23,570 --> 00:12:26,190
In this case west01.

240
00:12:26,190 --> 00:12:29,410
Oops, let's make sure we add
the name parameter there.

241
00:12:30,430 --> 00:12:35,030
The name is going to
be west01.contoso.com.

242
00:12:35,030 --> 00:12:38,860
And then there's a few different
options you can do, right?

243
00:12:38,860 --> 00:12:41,010
We've got the notify option in DNS.

244
00:12:41,010 --> 00:12:43,910
Normally, we would do standard
primaries and secondaries.

245
00:12:43,910 --> 00:12:46,810
There's an interval,
fifteen minutes by default.

246
00:12:46,810 --> 00:12:50,104
That refresh interval,
that's how often the secondary's going to

247
00:12:50,104 --> 00:12:52,441
query the master to see
if there's any changes.

248
00:12:52,441 --> 00:12:55,995
With the notify option, I can tell the
master, hey as soon as there's a change,

249
00:12:55,995 --> 00:12:57,580
notify all your secondaries.

250
00:12:57,580 --> 00:13:00,220
Let them know there's been a change, and
then they won't wait the 15 minutes.

251
00:13:00,220 --> 00:13:02,450
They'll go ahead and
request replication right then.

252
00:13:02,450 --> 00:13:06,950
Just speeds up the convergence
on those zones.

253
00:13:06,950 --> 00:13:08,685
So I'm going to do a -notify.

254
00:13:10,880 --> 00:13:12,720
And there's a few different
options you can do here.

255
00:13:12,720 --> 00:13:16,130
I'll give you guys the link to TechNet
that has the different parameters.

256
00:13:16,130 --> 00:13:18,800
You can decide whether you wanna notify

257
00:13:18,800 --> 00:13:21,690
all of the secondaries that
are getting a copy of that zone.

258
00:13:21,690 --> 00:13:25,430
Or you can say, I just wanna
notify particular secondaries.

259
00:13:25,430 --> 00:13:28,380
For me,
I'm just gonna do a notify which says that

260
00:13:28,380 --> 00:13:31,150
any secondary that's allowed
to get a copy of this zone.

261
00:13:31,150 --> 00:13:33,060
Go ahead and notify them anytime
there has been a change.

262
00:13:34,790 --> 00:13:37,270
And then I have to tell who
the secondary server is.

263
00:13:37,270 --> 00:13:40,700
Who's allowed to reach out and
get a copy of that zone file.

264
00:13:40,700 --> 00:13:43,589
And the parameter for
that is gonna be secondary service.

265
00:13:45,560 --> 00:13:47,130
And then we do it by IP address.

266
00:13:47,130 --> 00:13:49,282
In this case, 192.168.

267
00:13:49,282 --> 00:13:50,345
What are we?

268
00:13:50,345 --> 00:13:53,610
.1.103 for server1.

269
00:13:55,490 --> 00:13:58,780
And then what do we?

270
00:13:58,780 --> 00:13:59,850
And then we're gonna choose.

271
00:13:59,850 --> 00:14:03,159
So if you think back to the GUI,
we're telling it who the secondary is.

272
00:14:04,300 --> 00:14:07,090
We also have to decide whose allowed
to get the zone transferred.

273
00:14:07,090 --> 00:14:10,780
In the GUIs you've got the options,
no transfers at all.

274
00:14:10,780 --> 00:14:13,730
You've got the option to any
server that requests it.

275
00:14:13,730 --> 00:14:16,820
Which means I can open up a command
prompt and request a zone transfer.

276
00:14:16,820 --> 00:14:21,080
We could say only to named servers
listed on the named servers tab.

277
00:14:21,080 --> 00:14:23,780
Or we can say the specific name servers.

278
00:14:23,780 --> 00:14:27,780
And I can list the ones that
are allowed to request that transfer.

279
00:14:27,780 --> 00:14:34,210
And so in my case, I'm going to do the
anybody that's all secondaries basically.

280
00:14:34,210 --> 00:14:36,799
So the option is going to be
transfer to secure servers.

281
00:14:38,000 --> 00:14:43,250
So it's going to be a -secure secondaries.

282
00:14:43,250 --> 00:14:47,600
And then, we're going to use the option,
transfer to any server,

283
00:14:47,600 --> 00:14:49,725
would be the mistake, right.

284
00:14:49,725 --> 00:14:53,130
>> [LAUGH]
>> Transfer to secure servers is the one

285
00:14:53,130 --> 00:14:54,730
that I wanna do.

286
00:14:54,730 --> 00:14:56,990
TransferToZoneNameServer.

287
00:14:56,990 --> 00:15:01,090
That'd be one that I can specify which
particular servers I wanted that to go to.

288
00:15:02,960 --> 00:15:04,010
Alright.
So I hit enter on that.

289
00:15:04,010 --> 00:15:05,970
Now if we take a look at the zone now.

290
00:15:07,140 --> 00:15:08,790
So back here on the properties of west01.

291
00:15:08,790 --> 00:15:10,100
And lemme refresh that.

292
00:15:10,100 --> 00:15:11,659
Make sure we get all those changes.

293
00:15:13,070 --> 00:15:14,650
Take a look at
the properties of that zone.

294
00:15:14,650 --> 00:15:17,240
And I go over here to
the Zone Transfers tab.

295
00:15:17,240 --> 00:15:21,070
I can see zone transfers
are now being allowed.

296
00:15:21,070 --> 00:15:26,010
Only to the following server, and then
there's the IP address of the secondary.

297
00:15:26,010 --> 00:15:27,880
If I go down to my Notify options.

298
00:15:27,880 --> 00:15:31,650
You'll see that automatic
notify is turned on.

299
00:15:31,650 --> 00:15:34,340
Server is listed on the name
servers tab is selected.

300
00:15:36,100 --> 00:15:39,160
So we'll go ahead and,
I'm just having trouble resolving that.

301
00:15:40,430 --> 00:15:41,830
There we go.
It looks like he's got it though.

302
00:15:42,980 --> 00:15:48,040
So now if I switch over to server1,

303
00:15:48,040 --> 00:15:49,980
let's check and
see if we're allowed to get that zone now.

304
00:15:49,980 --> 00:15:53,110
And there we go.

305
00:15:53,110 --> 00:15:55,610
So now the secondary's
allowed to query that master.

306
00:15:55,610 --> 00:15:59,550
And retrieve a copy of that zone file
anytime there's a change being made

307
00:15:59,550 --> 00:16:00,330
to that zone file.

308
00:16:00,330 --> 00:16:03,330
The master's gonna notify the secondary,
and he'll request that copy again.

309
00:16:04,920 --> 00:16:06,580
>> All right, and that's pretty much that.

310
00:16:06,580 --> 00:16:09,580
So just remember the little
subtle differences between them.

311
00:16:09,580 --> 00:16:12,470
When it came to forward lookup zones,
well, for

312
00:16:12,470 --> 00:16:15,550
that one we really just to make the
decision whether it was active directory

313
00:16:15,550 --> 00:16:19,920
integrated or whether it was a standard,
primary, outside of the active directory.

314
00:16:19,920 --> 00:16:23,700
The difference there being whether
we gave it a replication scope, or

315
00:16:23,700 --> 00:16:27,750
whether we gave it
a zone file to store in.

316
00:16:27,750 --> 00:16:30,640
For the reverse lookup zones,
those are basically the same.

317
00:16:30,640 --> 00:16:31,360
We created those.

318
00:16:31,360 --> 00:16:33,310
And again, you specified
a replication scope if it was

319
00:16:33,310 --> 00:16:34,450
active directory integrated.

320
00:16:34,450 --> 00:16:36,650
Or a zone file if they were outside.

321
00:16:36,650 --> 00:16:39,310
For the secondary zones though,
it was a good bit different.

322
00:16:39,310 --> 00:16:41,180
Right, we had a little bit
of security we had to jump

323
00:16:41,180 --> 00:16:42,650
through there to get that opened up.

324
00:16:42,650 --> 00:16:48,060
And then we got that replica copy from
there, adding it as a standard secondary.

325
00:16:48,060 --> 00:16:50,430
Not a primary zone this time,
but a secondary zone.

326
00:16:50,430 --> 00:16:53,360
So those are some of the different
zones that we can create.

327
00:16:53,360 --> 00:16:56,990
And that's one of the first steps that
we take when we set up a new DNS server.

328
00:16:56,990 --> 00:17:02,790
You've got to have the zones there, before
you can start responding to DNS queries.

329
00:17:02,790 --> 00:17:06,120
Now the zones we created still
aren't particularly useful.

330
00:17:06,120 --> 00:17:08,520
>> No. [LAUGH] >> You need to get
some host records in there, so

331
00:17:08,520 --> 00:17:09,720
you can provide some information.

332
00:17:09,720 --> 00:17:11,240
And right now we don't have any.

333
00:17:11,240 --> 00:17:13,345
So make sure you stay tuned.

334
00:17:13,345 --> 00:17:15,960
Because we have more segments coming down
the line where we're going to cover all

335
00:17:15,960 --> 00:17:18,100
those host records, and
getting those put in there.

336
00:17:18,100 --> 00:17:20,780
But as far as our basic
operation of creating zones,

337
00:17:20,780 --> 00:17:22,720
we saw several different examples here.

338
00:17:22,720 --> 00:17:24,677
And it's really about that, right Mike?

339
00:17:24,677 --> 00:17:25,690
>> I think so, we got it all covered.

340
00:17:25,690 --> 00:17:27,720
>> All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

341
00:17:27,720 --> 00:17:32,619
Stay tuned,
we've got more PowerShell coming up.

342
