episodes.title: Managing DNS Records
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:07,878
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,878 --> 00:00:13,510
In this segment we're going to take a look
at creating records inside of a DNS zone.

3
00:00:13,510 --> 00:00:16,200
The zones are pretty useless until we
actually get some records in there to be

4
00:00:16,200 --> 00:00:16,930
able to query against.

5
00:00:16,930 --> 00:00:18,830
That's what we're gonna see here.

6
00:00:18,830 --> 00:00:21,890
Now there are a lot of different
record types inside of DNS.

7
00:00:21,890 --> 00:00:24,410
So we're just gonna run down the list and
maybe hit them in,

8
00:00:24,410 --> 00:00:27,695
I don't know whatever order,
popularity maybe, or something.

9
00:00:27,695 --> 00:00:29,090
>> [LAUGH] Alphabetical, we'll do that.

10
00:00:29,090 --> 00:00:31,610
>> That could be fun.

11
00:00:31,610 --> 00:00:34,530
Well no, I guess I should redefine fun.

12
00:00:34,530 --> 00:00:37,340
But anyhow, let's run through here and
we'll get some records created.

13
00:00:37,340 --> 00:00:40,650
We'll start with the most common one,
which is a simple A record.

14
00:00:40,650 --> 00:00:42,620
And just to refresh,

15
00:00:42,620 --> 00:00:48,220
an A record Is simply a mapping between
a hostname and an IPv4 address.

16
00:00:48,220 --> 00:00:50,420
It's a little variation between IPv4 and
IPv6.

17
00:00:50,420 --> 00:00:52,560
But we'll just start right here.

18
00:00:52,560 --> 00:00:53,820
>> Yeah.
It's a good one to start with.

19
00:00:53,820 --> 00:00:56,300
A lot of these are gonna be created,
depending on what we're talking about,

20
00:00:56,300 --> 00:01:00,080
a lot of these usually we're gonna have
dynamic updates enabled on our zones.

21
00:01:00,080 --> 00:01:03,430
So the client should be creating
a lot of their own records.

22
00:01:03,430 --> 00:01:05,240
But if we need to go in there and
manually create one,

23
00:01:05,240 --> 00:01:06,790
these are the commands we're gonna use.

24
00:01:08,102 --> 00:01:09,590
>> And now I keep calling them records,

25
00:01:09,590 --> 00:01:13,060
but technically the official
name is a resource record.

26
00:01:13,060 --> 00:01:16,685
And so the PowerShell commandlet that
we're gonna use for all of this is going

27
00:01:16,685 --> 00:01:20,795
to be the add-dnsserver
resource record command list.

28
00:01:20,795 --> 00:01:23,085
A nice short one, easy to remember.

29
00:01:23,085 --> 00:01:25,385
So let me just fire up
my PowerShell here and

30
00:01:25,385 --> 00:01:27,415
you'll see add-DnsServerResourceRecord.

31
00:01:27,415 --> 00:01:30,991
And the syntax that we use here is pretty
much the same for all of these, but

32
00:01:30,991 --> 00:01:34,586
it does vary just a little bit based
on the type of record we're creating.

33
00:01:34,586 --> 00:01:37,390
So, that's the main
command we're gonna use.

34
00:01:37,390 --> 00:01:40,020
I wanna create an A Record, so
I'm just gonna come in here and

35
00:01:40,020 --> 00:01:43,120
tell it what zone I'm working with.

36
00:01:43,120 --> 00:01:47,550
And maybe I want to create a record for
my laptop, so I've got my donlaptop.

37
00:01:47,550 --> 00:01:50,450
I want to create a record for
it in lab.itpro.tv.

38
00:01:50,450 --> 00:01:53,580
So the zone I'm going to work
with is going to be lab.itpro.tv,

39
00:01:53,580 --> 00:01:58,700
and then I'll specify that
I'm creating an A record, -A.

40
00:01:58,700 --> 00:02:03,480
And then I'll specify -Name and
what I want it to be.

41
00:02:03,480 --> 00:02:06,710
Now I want it to be donlaptop, right.

42
00:02:06,710 --> 00:02:10,903
I don't wanna specify
donlaptop.lab.itpro.tv, cuz it already

43
00:02:10,903 --> 00:02:15,599
knows the domain from the zone name up
here, so it's really just the A records

44
00:02:15,599 --> 00:02:18,545
name itself, and so when I run, uh-oh
>> Oops.

45
00:02:18,545 --> 00:02:19,428
[LAUGH]
>> I kinda left

46
00:02:19,428 --> 00:02:21,212
off an important part there, didn't I?

47
00:02:21,212 --> 00:02:23,339
[LAUGH]
>> So after I specify the name,

48
00:02:23,339 --> 00:02:24,920
the whole point of this is to
>> [LAUGH]

49
00:02:24,920 --> 00:02:25,864
>> Map a name to an IP so

50
00:02:25,864 --> 00:02:29,581
I probably need to add just a little bit
more to this command to get it working

51
00:02:29,581 --> 00:02:30,711
the way that I need it.

52
00:02:30,711 --> 00:02:32,806
So,
>> It is nice that it was gonna prompt

53
00:02:32,806 --> 00:02:35,380
you, letting you know that hey,
you're missing a couple things here

54
00:02:35,380 --> 00:02:37,290
>> Dear Don, quit being a moron.

55
00:02:37,290 --> 00:02:38,000
Add this in here.

56
00:02:38,000 --> 00:02:43,300
So I'll go ahead and say IPv4 address,
and what address I want it to be?

57
00:02:43,300 --> 00:02:47,310
And I guess I should know what my address
is, but I'll just put one in here.

58
00:02:47,310 --> 00:02:48,710
I think I'm 240.

59
00:02:48,710 --> 00:02:51,190
So we'll put that in, and
that's my IP address.

60
00:02:51,190 --> 00:02:53,030
Now if I run this,

61
00:02:53,030 --> 00:02:55,770
it's got all the information that
it needs to be happy, right?

62
00:02:55,770 --> 00:02:58,200
It's got my host name, which is donlaptop.

63
00:02:58,200 --> 00:03:00,040
It’s got my IP address that
it’s gonna map to, and

64
00:03:00,040 --> 00:03:01,940
it knows the zone that’s
gonna create it in.

65
00:03:01,940 --> 00:03:05,140
So I could stop right here,
but there’s a few

66
00:03:05,140 --> 00:03:08,390
more values that we might wanna specify
to get this record working right.

67
00:03:08,390 --> 00:03:09,530
Right, Mike?

68
00:03:09,530 --> 00:03:10,060
>> Yeah, exactly.

69
00:03:10,060 --> 00:03:11,990

00:14:26,640 --> 00:14:31,650
is an exchange record or
an exchanger record, or an MX record.

291
00:14:31,650 --> 00:14:33,270
And again, the syntax is very similar.

292
00:14:33,270 --> 00:14:37,290
You can see that it's still gonna
be the Add-DnsServerResourceRecord.

293
00:14:37,290 --> 00:14:40,480
Just gonna specify a different type
of record that we're gonna create.

294
00:14:40,480 --> 00:14:43,610
And this one's gonna require
a little bit different information.

295
00:14:43,610 --> 00:14:44,980
>> Yeah, these are weird.

296
00:14:44,980 --> 00:14:47,620
Mail exchange change records
are just outright weird.

297
00:14:47,620 --> 00:14:50,390
So when we go to add one,
we have to give it a name.

298
00:14:50,390 --> 00:14:53,820
But the name is pretty particular,
so I'm gonna give it a name.

299
00:14:53,820 --> 00:14:55,741
And the name is going to be .-MX.

300
00:14:55,741 --> 00:15:00,920
Oops, actually that's actually not right,
is it?

301
00:15:00,920 --> 00:15:03,450
It just needs to be the name is dot.

302
00:15:03,450 --> 00:15:07,560
So, the MX record doesn't
technically have a name.

303
00:15:07,560 --> 00:15:10,380
It is an MX record, and
then, in its return value,

304
00:15:10,380 --> 00:15:12,440
it contains a list of servers.

305
00:15:12,440 --> 00:15:16,640
So the name is kind of an odd one,
and let's see,

306
00:15:16,640 --> 00:15:18,340
that should be happy with the dot.

307
00:15:18,340 --> 00:15:19,805
There are some times
where you need to do a-

308
00:15:19,805 --> 00:15:21,435
>> Just leave it blank, or?

309
00:15:21,435 --> 00:15:24,510
>> You can leave it blank,
or you can do an @ symbol.

310
00:15:24,510 --> 00:15:26,790
Let's give it a shot here
with just leaving it blank,

311
00:15:26,790 --> 00:15:29,070
so that it knows that it
doesn't actually have a name.

312
00:15:29,070 --> 00:15:32,140
And then after that, we say -MX, so
that it knows that it's an MX record.

313
00:15:32,140 --> 00:15:35,027
And then we need to follow it up with
what zone that we're gonna to be

314
00:15:35,027 --> 00:15:36,200
creating this in.

315
00:15:36,200 --> 00:15:39,160
So I'm creating a record for
lab at itpro.tv.

316
00:15:39,160 --> 00:15:45,390
And then, inside of lab.itpro.tv,
I create this MX record.

317
00:15:45,390 --> 00:15:48,520
Now it needs to know what
servers are gonna be tied to it.

318
00:15:48,520 --> 00:15:50,409
So I've gotta provide a little
more information than what

319
00:15:50,409 --> 00:15:51,186
we've got right here.

320
00:15:51,186 --> 00:15:53,897
So I'm gonna say -MailExchange.

321
00:15:53,897 --> 00:15:58,877
And then the server or servers,
you may have more than one.

322
00:15:58,877 --> 00:15:59,400
Server.

323
00:15:59,400 --> 00:16:01,745
Mx record is really like a text field, and

324
00:16:01,745 --> 00:16:04,990
you can have several servers
that are inside of it.

325
00:16:04,990 --> 00:16:06,210
I'm gonna add just one.

326
00:16:06,210 --> 00:16:07,980
I'll do mail.lab.itpro.tv,

327
00:16:07,980 --> 00:16:13,600
which is not a real server, but
I'll punch that one in there.

328
00:16:13,600 --> 00:16:16,560
And, you can have preference,
or a weight, to them.

329
00:16:16,560 --> 00:16:20,170
So if you have multiple servers,
which one do you go to first.

330
00:16:20,170 --> 00:16:21,860
It's a numerical value.

331
00:16:21,860 --> 00:16:25,185
The lower the number,
the more preferred the server is.

332
00:16:25,185 --> 00:16:27,741
So, most people usually do like 10,
20, 30, 40.

333
00:16:27,741 --> 00:16:29,621
But you could do 1, 2, 3, 4 if you wanted.

334
00:16:29,621 --> 00:16:31,200
You've got some flexibility.

335
00:16:31,200 --> 00:16:35,859
I'm going to do let's see,
I'll do -Preference 10.

336
00:16:35,859 --> 00:16:38,950
So, that's pretty common right there.

337
00:16:38,950 --> 00:16:41,730
So, let's run that, and it actually got a
little upset about that name [CROSSTALK].

338
00:16:41,730 --> 00:16:44,198
>> Yeah, let me throw that back in.

339
00:16:44,198 --> 00:16:45,596
We'll make it happy.

340
00:16:45,596 --> 00:16:49,020
There's our dot.

341
00:16:49,020 --> 00:16:50,090
>> There we go, that looks better.

342
00:16:50,090 --> 00:16:52,220
So, it did complain and
needed that dot in there,

343
00:16:52,220 --> 00:16:56,260
just so it knew that it was kind of an
empty value, so now I've got an MX record,

344
00:16:56,260 --> 00:17:01,670
that points to mail.lab.itpro.tv, and it's
got a preference of 10, and it's in place.

345
00:17:01,670 --> 00:17:04,470
Now, I do want to verify that
just to make sure it's clear.

346
00:17:04,470 --> 00:17:07,720
I'll go back here to my
forward lookup zone and

347
00:17:07,720 --> 00:17:09,660
I'll just refresh that real quick.

348
00:17:09,660 --> 00:17:13,310
And now I can see that I've got
a mail exchanger record right here.

349
00:17:13,310 --> 00:17:16,490
And see how for
the name it says same as parent folder.

350
00:17:16,490 --> 00:17:17,760
That's what the dot means.

351
00:17:17,760 --> 00:17:21,070
That means this is a mail exchanger,
not for just an individual host,

352
00:17:21,070 --> 00:17:23,880
but for lab.itpro.tv.

353
00:17:23,880 --> 00:17:29,170
And then it's got mail.lab.itpro.tv
right there, with a preference of 10.

354
00:17:29,170 --> 00:17:31,375
>> And one of the things I like
to do when I'm working is,

355
00:17:31,375 --> 00:17:34,140
a lot of us have used the GUI for
a long time, the GUI.

356
00:17:34,140 --> 00:17:38,570
And now we're starting to use PowerShell
to get a little more Administrative,

357
00:17:38,570 --> 00:17:40,950
getting more powerful with our
administration, be able to script things,

358
00:17:40,950 --> 00:17:42,040
automate things.

359
00:17:42,040 --> 00:17:45,130
But I always like to think about,
okay when I was in the GUI,

360
00:17:45,130 --> 00:17:46,430
what did I have to fill in?

361
00:17:46,430 --> 00:17:49,439
Think about the wizard that you went
through cuz you're providing all

362
00:17:49,439 --> 00:17:52,815
of the same information in this PowerShell
command that you would in the GUIs.

363
00:17:52,815 --> 00:17:56,815
So if you right-click New MX Record,
always leave that first line blank.

364
00:17:56,815 --> 00:18:00,715
And it says it's gonna use the parent
domain name if you do that.

365
00:18:00,715 --> 00:18:02,365
Kinda helps remember what
switches I need to do and

366
00:18:02,365 --> 00:18:03,932
what values I need to put in there.

367
00:18:03,932 --> 00:18:05,052
>> Yep.

368
00:18:05,052 --> 00:18:08,592
The last record type we wanna talk
about is probably the weirdest.

369
00:18:08,592 --> 00:18:10,582
We saw with MX servers,
or mail exchangers,

370
00:18:10,582 --> 00:18:16,200
that's a pretty specific example of a
service that's directly supported by DNS.

371
00:18:16,200 --> 00:18:20,570
The people that designed this whole
naming service, they said you know what,

372
00:18:20,570 --> 00:18:24,260
we don't wanna keep adding specific
records for services out there.

373
00:18:24,260 --> 00:18:27,720
So instead they created a generic
service type resource record,

374
00:18:27,720 --> 00:18:33,180
which is called an SRV record, and SRVs
can point to any service that's out there.

375
00:18:33,180 --> 00:18:36,390
If they had to do it all over again today,
we wouldn't have MX records,

376
00:18:36,390 --> 00:18:38,990
instead they would use SRV records also.

377
00:18:38,990 --> 00:18:41,180
But we have SRV records for
everything else.

378
00:18:41,180 --> 00:18:45,140
The active directory uses the heck out of
these, but there are other programs and

379
00:18:45,140 --> 00:18:48,170
protocols that can make use of it too,
so we do see these quite a bit.

380
00:18:49,170 --> 00:18:52,325
SRV records,
DNS doesn't really know what they are.

381
00:18:52,325 --> 00:18:55,845
So we have to provide a lot of
additional information to them so

382
00:18:55,845 --> 00:18:57,715
it knows exactly what to
hand off to the clients.

383
00:18:58,837 --> 00:19:01,365
All right, so let me show you
an example of an SRV record.

384
00:19:01,365 --> 00:19:05,005
Mike, you put one in the show notes which
is an example for finding a SIP server for

385
00:19:05,005 --> 00:19:06,880
voice over IP.

386
00:19:06,880 --> 00:19:13,320
So if I wanna add that,
I'll do the Add-DnsServerResourceRecord,

387
00:19:13,320 --> 00:19:16,250
like we've been doing, but
I'm gonna modify this just a little bit.

388
00:19:16,250 --> 00:19:19,300
I need to tell it we're doing
an SRV record, so I'll say, -Srv.

389
00:19:19,300 --> 00:19:23,250
I need to give it a name, and
we're just gonna call this one sip.

390
00:19:24,560 --> 00:19:27,510
So, this will be sip.lab.itpro.tv.

391
00:19:27,510 --> 00:19:30,970
All right, I need to give it a zone name.

392
00:19:30,970 --> 00:19:32,850
Which will be lab.itpro.tv.

393
00:19:32,850 --> 00:19:36,620
So there I'm defining what the record
is going to be called, and

394
00:19:36,620 --> 00:19:38,640
then I need to tell it
what it's going to be.

395
00:19:38,640 --> 00:19:43,680
Now, SRV records, a lot like mail
exchanges have what they are,

396
00:19:43,680 --> 00:19:48,440
they have their preference, which one's
higher priority, or lower priority, so

397
00:19:48,440 --> 00:19:49,060
I need to give that.

398
00:19:49,060 --> 00:19:50,980
Now, instead of preference
they do call it priority.

399
00:19:52,060 --> 00:19:56,540
So I'll give this one a priority of 0,
lower number is better.

400
00:19:56,540 --> 00:20:00,360
I can give it a weight which
says if there's a tie, if

401
00:20:00,360 --> 00:20:04,820
I have two servers at the same priority,
how do I divide my traffic up amongst it.

402
00:20:04,820 --> 00:20:08,220
Maybe I want half my traffic to go one and
half my traffic to go with another.

403
00:20:08,220 --> 00:20:10,960
I can specify that with a weight value.

404
00:20:10,960 --> 00:20:14,990
And then, because it doesn't know
what kind of software this is,

405
00:20:14,990 --> 00:20:17,280
I need to give it a port number.

406
00:20:17,280 --> 00:20:20,960
When we connect to this,
it needs to know what port to use and

407
00:20:20,960 --> 00:20:25,890
sip usually uses 5060, 5-0-6-0,
so I'll punch that in.

408
00:20:25,890 --> 00:20:29,900
So now, any VoIP phone on my network, if
it's looking for a SIP server, it can just

409
00:20:29,900 --> 00:20:34,530
look for sip.lab.itprotv and it's gonna
return that, oh yeah, yeah, that exists.

410
00:20:34,530 --> 00:20:35,860
We've got a SIP service.

411
00:20:35,860 --> 00:20:37,230
It's on port 5060.

412
00:20:37,230 --> 00:20:40,320
And it's tied to a particular host.

413
00:20:40,320 --> 00:20:42,710
And that's the last time
I need to throw in here.

414
00:20:42,710 --> 00:20:45,360
Which is -DomainName.

415
00:20:47,080 --> 00:20:49,590
>> It's a lot like your C
name records on any of these.

416
00:20:49,590 --> 00:20:50,980
It doesn't point to an IP address.

417
00:20:50,980 --> 00:20:54,719
It points back to a fully qualified domain
name, and then it's gonna turn around and

418
00:20:54,719 --> 00:20:57,315
look at the A record for
that fully qualified domain name.

419
00:20:57,315 --> 00:21:03,238
>> Yep, so then I might have a server on
my network that is server01.lab.itpro.tv.

420
00:21:03,238 --> 00:21:07,860
Maybe that's running some kind of PBX
software, or some kind of VoIP system.

421
00:21:07,860 --> 00:21:09,590
And so,
that's what people are gonna reach out to,

422
00:21:09,590 --> 00:21:11,130
that's the record this
is all gonna point to.

423
00:21:12,220 --> 00:21:15,770
So, when I run that, that gets created,
and now I've got this SRV record.

424
00:21:15,770 --> 00:21:19,244
Now, a lot of companies like Microsoft,
whenever they give it a name for

425
00:21:19,244 --> 00:21:21,990
SRV records,
they'll start it with an underscore.

426
00:21:21,990 --> 00:21:25,960
You don't have to do that, but
most people do because it makes it easy

427
00:21:25,960 --> 00:21:29,290
visually to recognize that hey
this is a service not a host.

428
00:21:29,290 --> 00:21:31,450
No host name would ever
start with an underscore,

429
00:21:31,450 --> 00:21:35,350
in fact with DNS names you're typically
not allowed to use an underscore.

430
00:21:35,350 --> 00:21:39,510
And so that really separates out
SRV records from normal records.

431
00:21:39,510 --> 00:21:43,840
But if I go back to my GUI here, if I go
to lab.itpro.tv, and I'll just refresh

432
00:21:43,840 --> 00:21:49,340
that, I should now have this SRV record
right here, Service Location Record.

433
00:21:49,340 --> 00:21:54,200
It's called sip, and
it points to server01.lab.itpro.tv.

434
00:21:54,200 --> 00:21:58,030
It's on port 5060 and
it's got a priority and weight of 0.

435
00:21:58,030 --> 00:21:59,860
The record is created and it's there.

436
00:22:01,420 --> 00:22:02,410
>> Beautiful thing.

437
00:22:02,410 --> 00:22:06,170
>> And with all of these commands, I've
been using Add-DnsServerResourceRecord.

438
00:22:06,170 --> 00:22:09,320
You've also got
Set-DnsServerResourceRecord,

439
00:22:09,320 --> 00:22:13,670
which lets you modify these if you need
to change values on them after the fact.

440
00:22:13,670 --> 00:22:17,040
But otherwise, creating the records
is pretty straight forward.

441
00:22:17,040 --> 00:22:21,340
There are other records that are out
there, like NS records, and so on.

442
00:22:21,340 --> 00:22:25,280
They're a lot less commonly modified, so
we won't tackle them here in the show.

443
00:22:25,280 --> 00:22:27,235
But if you ever pull up
the help documentation for

444
00:22:27,235 --> 00:22:31,450
Add-DnsServerResourceRecord, you'll see
all the other types that are out there.

445
00:22:31,450 --> 00:22:33,950
But the ones we've shown are the ones
that most people are going to work

446
00:22:33,950 --> 00:22:34,710
with on a regular basis.

447
00:22:36,570 --> 00:22:40,500
All right so in this segment, we got a
chance to see creating those host records.

448
00:22:40,500 --> 00:22:43,502
Putting it in place,
verifying that it actually took effect,

449
00:22:43,502 --> 00:22:45,380
that they're there and
that they're working.

450
00:22:45,380 --> 00:22:48,290
So we saw several of different
resource types that were out there.

451
00:22:48,290 --> 00:22:50,150
Keep in mind that there are others
that you might want to learn about.

452
00:22:51,150 --> 00:22:53,188
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed that segment.

453
00:22:53,188 --> 00:22:58,659
Stay tuned,
we got more PowerShell, coming up.

454
00:22:58,659 --> 00:23:02,700
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Monitoring DNS Status
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,333
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,333 --> 00:00:09,099
In this segment,

3
00:00:09,099 --> 00:00:12,020
we're gonna take a look at monitoring
the status of our DNS server.

4
00:00:12,020 --> 00:00:15,190
You know, once we get DNS fired up and
running, we get our zones created,

5
00:00:15,190 --> 00:00:17,670
our records in there and
it's working, that's great.

6
00:00:17,670 --> 00:00:20,670
But how do we keep an eye
on it performance-wise?

7
00:00:20,670 --> 00:00:23,030
If you're at the machine,
you could use your graphical utilities,

8
00:00:23,030 --> 00:00:24,110
things like a performance monitor.

9
00:00:24,110 --> 00:00:25,070
They're fine.

10
00:00:25,070 --> 00:00:28,540
But in the PowerShell, we've got a couple
of neat commands that we can use.

11
00:00:28,540 --> 00:00:30,100
Some of them, you guys are probably
already familiar with.

12
00:00:30,100 --> 00:00:34,890
Like, if I just want to see if the service
is running, I can do a Get-Service dns.

13
00:00:34,890 --> 00:00:36,850
That's not anything too exciting, here,

14
00:00:36,850 --> 00:00:39,430
let me fire that up,
in a Powershell prompt.

15
00:00:40,430 --> 00:00:42,865
And I'll just do Get-Service dns,
and I can see it's running.

16
00:00:42,865 --> 00:00:43,440
Woo-hoo!

17
00:00:43,440 --> 00:00:43,940
Right?

18
00:00:43,940 --> 00:00:44,632
We're in business.

19
00:00:44,632 --> 00:00:46,340
>> [LAUGH] It's a good start.

20
00:00:46,340 --> 00:00:49,750
>> That's great, but wouldn't it be
great to have better insight into what

21
00:00:49,750 --> 00:00:51,960
the server's actually doing.

22
00:00:51,960 --> 00:00:55,110
And for that,
we've got a couple of other neat commands.

23
00:00:55,110 --> 00:00:57,200
>> Got that good old Get-DnsServer.

24
00:00:57,200 --> 00:01:01,360
And this command is gonna pull back all
the configurations on my DNS server.

25
00:01:01,360 --> 00:01:05,390
You get to see things like what my, I'm
trying to think of some of the good ones

26
00:01:05,390 --> 00:01:08,430
we use, like the socket pool size,
and things like that.

27
00:01:08,430 --> 00:01:10,493
I mean,
it shows a ton of information in here.

28
00:01:10,493 --> 00:01:12,250
>> I'm gonna pipe this
into the more command.

29
00:01:12,250 --> 00:01:14,371
>> Yeah, probably a good idea.

30
00:01:14,371 --> 00:01:16,401
[LAUGH]
>> So Get-DnsServer,

31
00:01:16,401 --> 00:01:19,734
it returns really information
about your server configuration.

32
00:01:19,734 --> 00:01:20,950
Right?

33
00:01:20,950 --> 00:01:22,780
All the various that it's got configured,

34
00:01:22,780 --> 00:01:25,380
a lot of these are gonna be defaults
that you haven't messed with.

35
00:01:25,380 --> 00:01:28,130
Some of them will be the other things
that maybe you have messed with.

36
00:01:28,130 --> 00:01:29,950
Then you can go in there and evaluate.

37
00:01:29,950 --> 00:01:32,208
You guys see all the different
things we can query on.

38
00:01:32,208 --> 00:01:35,592
So if you're trying to verify
a server's configuration,

39
00:01:35,592 --> 00:01:38,361
this is the command for
you, Get-DnsServer.

40
00:01:38,361 --> 00:01:41,520
And when Mike says there's a lot of
stuff in there, he is not lying.

41
00:01:41,520 --> 00:01:44,270
There is a ton of information in here.

42
00:01:44,270 --> 00:01:46,292
As we scroll through,
you'll just see there is quite a bit.

43
00:01:46,292 --> 00:01:48,360
>> I'm trying to think of some of
the things I've used this for.

44
00:01:48,360 --> 00:01:50,320
Primarily, one was the saga pool size,

45
00:01:50,320 --> 00:01:53,090
cuz you can change the amount of
ports that are available for that.

46
00:01:53,090 --> 00:01:57,840
The other one is that caching right there,
I think is, where is it?

47
00:01:57,840 --> 00:01:59,300
No, not the caching.

48
00:01:59,300 --> 00:02:01,910
Anyway, there's a couple
of them in there like the,

49
00:02:01,910 --> 00:02:04,584
oh how long it stays locked
when you get cache, right?

50
00:02:04,584 --> 00:02:06,799
Cuz we can now change that
locking percentage, so

51
00:02:06,799 --> 00:02:09,720
it's a quick easy command
to see what it's set to.

52
00:02:09,720 --> 00:02:12,640
>> Yeah, I know I've manipulated some
of this like this max time to live.

53
00:02:12,640 --> 00:02:15,260
Sometimes you don't want to have
a time to live that's and entire day,

54
00:02:15,260 --> 00:02:16,500
which is the default.

55
00:02:16,500 --> 00:02:17,850
So you can in and manipulate that.

56
00:02:17,850 --> 00:02:20,040
And that way if you try and
cache a record from the Internet, and

57
00:02:20,040 --> 00:02:22,840
they say that it's going to be 72 hours.

58
00:02:22,840 --> 00:02:24,580
Well, if your server has
a maximum of 12 hours,

59
00:02:24,580 --> 00:02:26,770
it will ignore the 72 and make it 12.

60
00:02:26,770 --> 00:02:27,420
Right?

61
00:02:27,420 --> 00:02:28,625
So you can manipulate those things.

62
00:02:28,625 --> 00:02:30,620
You need to be able to verify
those settings right here.

63
00:02:30,620 --> 00:02:32,470
It's all kind of tucked away in it.

64
00:02:32,470 --> 00:02:35,100
There's a route hint servers
that are listed, and so on.

65
00:02:35,100 --> 00:02:36,260
It goes on and on.

66
00:02:36,260 --> 00:02:40,312
So quite a bit of data in there on
the configuration of your server.

67
00:02:40,312 --> 00:02:40,833
>> All right.

68
00:02:40,833 --> 00:02:43,700
And then we can change that to a
Set-DnsServer if we want to modify some of

69
00:02:43,700 --> 00:02:44,500
those parameters.

70
00:02:44,500 --> 00:02:45,550
>> Yeah.

71
00:02:45,550 --> 00:02:51,160
Another one that we've got
is Get-DnsServerStatistics.

72
00:02:51,160 --> 00:02:53,900
>> This is a new one that came out
recently, when they added a bunch of new

73
00:02:53,900 --> 00:02:57,960
commands to the DNS module, and this one
pulls back a lot of information as well.

74
00:02:59,095 --> 00:02:59,915
>> Now when you run it,

75
00:02:59,915 --> 00:03:04,525
the default is going to give you
statistics on the DNS server as a whole.

76
00:03:04,525 --> 00:03:06,645
And that [LAUGH] can be
a ton of information.

77
00:03:06,645 --> 00:03:07,896
Some of it's pretty handy,

78
00:03:07,896 --> 00:03:11,293
you can see how long it's been since
the last time the statistics were reset.

79
00:03:11,293 --> 00:03:15,498
And then you can start to see information
about how many queries it's handled,

80
00:03:15,498 --> 00:03:19,137
you know what it's response times are,
any other information, and

81
00:03:19,137 --> 00:03:21,730
it is screen after screen
after screen of stuff.

82
00:03:21,730 --> 00:03:22,970
It can be quite a bit.

83
00:03:22,970 --> 00:03:25,460
>> And if you have multiple
zones on that DNS server,

84
00:03:25,460 --> 00:03:26,630
this is just gonna summarize it.

85
00:03:26,630 --> 00:03:29,910
So it's going to take all the information
from all the zones and summarize and

86
00:03:29,910 --> 00:03:30,650
give you one report back.

87
00:03:31,660 --> 00:03:34,060
But we can also throw in a name of a zone.

88
00:03:34,060 --> 00:03:37,720
What if we want to see the statistics
on a particular zone that this DNS

89
00:03:37,720 --> 00:03:38,780
server is handling?

90
00:03:38,780 --> 00:03:41,440
All we have to do is do that same
command and then do a dash zone name,

91
00:03:41,440 --> 00:03:44,950
type in the name of the zone, and
now we're seeing zone specific statistics.

92
00:03:46,160 --> 00:03:47,610
>> Yep.
So that kind of filters things out.

93
00:03:47,610 --> 00:03:51,290
That's good, because a lot of those
screens are caching related, and

94
00:03:51,290 --> 00:03:53,070
we don't necessarily need to see
those when we're looking for

95
00:03:53,070 --> 00:03:55,400
information on a particular zone.

96
00:03:55,400 --> 00:03:57,960
So I can see this zone has
handled a whopping five queries,

97
00:03:57,960 --> 00:03:59,420
it's running here on my laptop.

98
00:03:59,420 --> 00:04:00,260
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So we're not gonna see

99
00:04:00,260 --> 00:04:01,240
a ton of stuff there.

100
00:04:01,240 --> 00:04:02,550
Queries that I've responded to.

101
00:04:02,550 --> 00:04:04,550
Query failures, right?

102
00:04:04,550 --> 00:04:07,043
We can see other things like
those are just the A records.

103
00:04:07,043 --> 00:04:09,920
I can see the quad A records,
pointers, CName.

104
00:04:09,920 --> 00:04:12,590
I'm getting statistics for
each of these, so

105
00:04:12,590 --> 00:04:15,550
I can get an idea of how much traffic
this server has been handling, and

106
00:04:15,550 --> 00:04:18,505
it breaks all of those out into
the individual record types.

107
00:04:18,505 --> 00:04:19,400
Right?

108
00:04:19,400 --> 00:04:23,160
And so past that I start to get the zone
transfer information this AXFR and

109
00:04:23,160 --> 00:04:25,600
IXFR, those are my zone transfers.

110
00:04:25,600 --> 00:04:27,270
So, I can see how much have I send out,

111
00:04:27,270 --> 00:04:31,560
how much have I received, how much
data really is this server moving.

112
00:04:31,560 --> 00:04:32,330
>> Absolutely.

113
00:04:32,330 --> 00:04:34,950
>> And so, it all gets laid out there,
and it's pretty handy.

114
00:04:34,950 --> 00:04:37,280
The only problem is, the statistics,

115
00:04:37,280 --> 00:04:40,800
they've really been running since
DNS was installed in this server.

116
00:04:40,800 --> 00:04:44,540
So if you've got a DNS server that's been
up for a year, you're seeing information

117
00:04:44,540 --> 00:04:49,160
about how much that server's done in
that year, you might want to clear out

118
00:04:49,160 --> 00:04:52,580
the statistics to start from scratch and
say, I just want to see the last 24 hours.

119
00:04:52,580 --> 00:04:55,730
So let's clear it out, let it run for
24 hours, and then look.

120
00:04:55,730 --> 00:04:58,910
So you might need to wipe those
statistics from time to time, and

121
00:04:58,910 --> 00:05:04,750
you do that with the, actually
with the Get-DnsServer statistics.

122
00:05:04,750 --> 00:05:08,270
It's one of those weird times where
the get command can actually do something.

123
00:05:08,270 --> 00:05:12,042
>> Yeah, it's gonna return all of
the information at the same time, wipe it.

124
00:05:12,042 --> 00:05:13,930
So it might be something
you wanna pipe out,

125
00:05:13,930 --> 00:05:15,975
like we saw in a couple
of the other segments.

126
00:05:15,975 --> 00:05:20,190
Pipe that result out to a text file or
something to save that information.

127
00:05:20,190 --> 00:05:24,600
So if I add dash clear to the end of it,
right, that's gonna wipe those statistics

128
00:05:24,600 --> 00:05:29,230
and now when I pull it back up, see all
my queries have been reset to zeroes.

129
00:05:29,230 --> 00:05:33,620
Just by adding that dash clear, that reset
it and now as we start to do look ups.

130
00:05:33,620 --> 00:05:38,602
So if I start looking up
like donlaptop.lab.itpro.tv,

131
00:05:38,602 --> 00:05:41,000
against my server, right?

132
00:05:41,000 --> 00:05:42,633
So I'll do a couple other queries,

133
00:05:42,633 --> 00:05:47,060
actually I'm probably gonna start pulling
those off of my own local cache, won't I?

134
00:05:47,060 --> 00:05:48,875
Well no,
I don't think nslookup ever does that.

135
00:05:48,875 --> 00:05:49,914
Well, we can find out.

136
00:05:49,914 --> 00:05:51,458
>> [CROSSTALK] Nslookup
should bypass the cache.

137
00:05:51,458 --> 00:05:52,420
There we go.

138
00:05:52,420 --> 00:05:55,520
And so I can see there are those four
queries that I just ran right there.

139
00:05:55,520 --> 00:05:57,167
I can see it, they did the look ups.

140
00:05:57,167 --> 00:06:00,597
It did the look up for the four A record
also, because I gave it a name and

141
00:06:00,597 --> 00:06:01,833
there are multiple IPs.

142
00:06:01,833 --> 00:06:04,282
So it shows up, but
everything else is still zeroed out,

143
00:06:04,282 --> 00:06:05,667
cuz I haven't looked those up.

144
00:06:05,667 --> 00:06:06,730
All right.

145
00:06:06,730 --> 00:06:09,612
So, couple of good ways to
see the statistics there.

146
00:06:09,612 --> 00:06:12,125
Now you could use your
performance monitor, right?

147
00:06:12,125 --> 00:06:15,084
Your service profile.

148
00:06:15,084 --> 00:06:18,042
There's all those different tools out
there that monitor it with a GUI.

149
00:06:18,042 --> 00:06:21,727
And they give you a lot of power in
logging and so on, but if you just want

150
00:06:21,727 --> 00:06:26,150
quick and easy, look at it, get some
information, Get-DnsServerStatistics.

151
00:06:26,150 --> 00:06:27,062
It's a great utility for you.

152
00:06:27,062 --> 00:06:28,458
All right.

153
00:06:28,458 --> 00:06:31,368
So in this segment we got a chance
to see a few different ways to

154
00:06:31,368 --> 00:06:34,870
monitor performance on our servers,
statistics on our server.

155
00:06:34,870 --> 00:06:38,025
We saw Get-Service,
just to make sure the service was running.

156
00:06:38,025 --> 00:06:41,316
Get-DnsServer to look at
the configuration and

157
00:06:41,316 --> 00:06:46,542
Get-DnsServerStatistics to look at
our actual performance information.

158
00:06:46,542 --> 00:06:51,319
One other thing if you guys want to learn
a little bit more, Mike was showing me

159
00:06:51,319 --> 00:06:55,950
right before the show that with
a Get-DnsServer, you can actually export

160
00:06:55,950 --> 00:07:01,123
that XML to back up that configuration and
restore it on another server if you want.

161
00:07:01,123 --> 00:07:02,410
So there's some neat utilities out there.

162
00:07:02,410 --> 00:07:03,750
Mike, do you remember
what that command was?

163
00:07:03,750 --> 00:07:06,944
>> It was,
you could do that same Get-DnsServer, and

164
00:07:06,944 --> 00:07:09,122
then you do an Export-Clixml, and

165
00:07:09,122 --> 00:07:14,292
that's gonna generate an XML file with all
the configuration from that DNS server.

166
00:07:14,292 --> 00:07:17,339
So as Don was saying, I can use it as
a backup, if I ever have a problem,

167
00:07:17,339 --> 00:07:18,960
I can restore my server.

168
00:07:18,960 --> 00:07:22,650
Or if I wanna set up another DNS server
with those same configurations, I can use

169
00:07:22,650 --> 00:07:26,990
that XML file, that it generated, to
move those settings to a new DNS server.

170
00:07:26,990 --> 00:07:28,160
>> Yeah, so pretty cool stuff there.

171
00:07:28,160 --> 00:07:30,870
You know PowerShell has
a lot of power to it.

172
00:07:30,870 --> 00:07:32,509
Every time we say there's
a command missing,

173
00:07:32,509 --> 00:07:35,083
well there's like 15 other awesome
commands that are already there.

174
00:07:35,083 --> 00:07:38,250
So it's just a matter of figuring
them out and putting them to use.

175
00:07:38,250 --> 00:07:38,876
>> It is.

176
00:07:38,876 --> 00:07:41,195
>> All right.
Well, that's about it for

177
00:07:41,195 --> 00:07:43,510
monitoring DNS statistics.

178
00:07:43,510 --> 00:07:45,070
Hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

179
00:07:45,070 --> 00:07:48,042
Stay tuned, we've got more
PowerShell coming down the line.

180
00:07:48,042 --> 00:07:53,984
{MUSIC]

episodes.title: Installing DHCP Server
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,378
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,378 --> 00:00:11,836
In this segment, we're going to take
a look at installing DHCP server,

3
00:00:11,836 --> 00:00:14,020
using the Microsoft Power Shell.

4
00:00:14,020 --> 00:00:16,440
It's not really any different
than any other role or feature.

5
00:00:16,440 --> 00:00:17,770
It's a pretty straight forward install.

6
00:00:17,770 --> 00:00:19,110
This'll be a short segment.

7
00:00:19,110 --> 00:00:20,220
But we need to see it nonetheless.

8
00:00:20,220 --> 00:00:21,760
If you're going to set up a DHCP server,

9
00:00:21,760 --> 00:00:24,380
this is really going
to be step number one.

10
00:00:24,380 --> 00:00:27,540
Well, step number one I guess
after getting a server, right?

11
00:00:27,540 --> 00:00:29,590
Probably have to have a server
somewhere to do this.

12
00:00:29,590 --> 00:00:34,330
But to add the DHCP server functionality
to a Windows server machine.

13
00:00:34,330 --> 00:00:38,100
We just use the add Windows feature
command line that we've seen for

14
00:00:38,100 --> 00:00:39,370
pretty much every other role.

15
00:00:39,370 --> 00:00:41,930
So I'm going to fire up my PowerShell,
and I'm gonna have at it.

16
00:00:41,930 --> 00:00:44,910
Well, I guess before I do that
maybe I should verify whether or

17
00:00:44,910 --> 00:00:46,450
not I'm actually running DHCP server.

18
00:00:46,450 --> 00:00:48,040
>> That's a good idea.

19
00:00:48,040 --> 00:00:50,160
Instead of an install we
could do a get command.

20
00:00:50,160 --> 00:00:50,660
>> Yeah.

21
00:00:52,220 --> 00:00:54,050
So, we'll just do a get-windowsfeature and

22
00:00:54,050 --> 00:00:56,760
if I just run that by itself,
man do you get some outputs.

23
00:00:56,760 --> 00:00:59,758
So, I'm gonna make sure to qualify
that and just stick dhcp on the end.

24
00:00:59,758 --> 00:01:02,385
I'll say get-windowsfeature dhcp.

25
00:01:02,385 --> 00:01:07,265
That'll run pretty quick, and there I
can see DHCP Server is recognized, but

26
00:01:07,265 --> 00:01:08,045
it's not installed.

27
00:01:08,045 --> 00:01:09,875
It's got an empty little box right there.

28
00:01:09,875 --> 00:01:11,385
Install state is available.

29
00:01:11,385 --> 00:01:14,136
It's available to be installed, but
it's not actually installed yet.

30
00:01:14,136 --> 00:01:15,464
>> Let's do it.

31
00:01:15,464 --> 00:01:20,332
>> So we'll just go ahead and
say add-windowsFeature dhcp.

32
00:01:20,332 --> 00:01:22,372
That's all we need to
do to do the install.

33
00:01:22,372 --> 00:01:25,532
Now, if I'm on a server
that's a core server install.

34
00:01:25,532 --> 00:01:29,296
So no GUI,
that's really all I need to run.

35
00:01:29,296 --> 00:01:31,936
>> Right?
>> But I'm on a full install, and so

36
00:01:31,936 --> 00:01:34,436
I might want to install
the management tools also.

37
00:01:34,436 --> 00:01:38,476
It doesn't do that by default, so I may
need to add a little bit more to this.

38
00:01:38,476 --> 00:01:41,713
To say, include management tools.

39
00:01:42,783 --> 00:01:44,073
So that it knows to put those on there.

40
00:01:44,073 --> 00:01:45,463
And I'll get the graphical tools also.

41
00:01:45,463 --> 00:01:48,643
If we're just working in PowerShell
we don't care about that.

42
00:01:48,643 --> 00:01:51,233
but in my case we'll go ahead and do it.

43
00:01:51,233 --> 00:01:53,240
All right.
So we'll run that and it'll install.

44
00:01:53,240 --> 00:01:55,170
Doesn't take terribly long to do it,
right.

45
00:01:55,170 --> 00:01:57,162
DHCP's not the biggest of services.

46
00:01:57,162 --> 00:01:58,190
>> Right.
That's what I always tell people.

47
00:01:58,190 --> 00:02:00,180
You know,
installing the roles is very easy.

48
00:02:00,180 --> 00:02:02,030
It's configuring the roles after the fact,
and

49
00:02:02,030 --> 00:02:03,920
making it do what you need
it to do on your network.

50
00:02:03,920 --> 00:02:06,150
That's where the skill set
really comes into play.

51
00:02:06,150 --> 00:02:08,950
>> Yeah.
Once this is done, you know what,

52
00:02:08,950 --> 00:02:10,040
if you had to describe it, Mike.

53
00:02:10,040 --> 00:02:13,720
What exactly would the DHCP server
do after this install is done?

54
00:02:13,720 --> 00:02:14,830
>> Absolutely nothing.

55
00:02:14,830 --> 00:02:15,690
>> Absolutely nothing.

56
00:02:15,690 --> 00:02:17,360
Yeah, it's non functional.

57
00:02:17,360 --> 00:02:21,130
There is a lot more to do, but
the install is pretty straight forward.

58
00:02:21,130 --> 00:02:22,620
And you know I say it
doesn't take to long.

59
00:02:22,620 --> 00:02:25,100
In typical Microsoft fashion it
jumps to 92% and then sits there.

60
00:02:25,100 --> 00:02:26,050
>> And it just stops.

61
00:02:26,050 --> 00:02:27,570
>> So there we go.

62
00:02:27,570 --> 00:02:29,190
I can see that it did finish the install.

63
00:02:29,190 --> 00:02:30,530
Success is true.

64
00:02:30,530 --> 00:02:31,730
Restart needed, no.

65
00:02:31,730 --> 00:02:32,940
So I don't need to reboot.

66
00:02:32,940 --> 00:02:33,720
That's kind of nice.

67
00:02:33,720 --> 00:02:34,850
I got a success.

68
00:02:34,850 --> 00:02:38,200
If I just want to do a double
super secret verification.

69
00:02:38,200 --> 00:02:43,090
I can go a get-windowsfeature dhcp,
and this time we should see that

70
00:02:43,090 --> 00:02:46,570
it's got a little check mark letting us
know that it's installed on X, I think.

71
00:02:46,570 --> 00:02:47,270
An X.

72
00:02:47,270 --> 00:02:49,580
And then over here,
install state is installed.

73
00:02:49,580 --> 00:02:50,590
So I've got it.

74
00:02:50,590 --> 00:02:55,630
And I could even go a little bit
further and do a get-service.

75
00:02:55,630 --> 00:02:57,330
Well that really didn't pan out, did it?

76
00:02:57,330 --> 00:02:58,950
There, get-service DHCP.

77
00:02:58,950 --> 00:03:01,090
And I can see, oh,
that's my client though.

78
00:03:01,090 --> 00:03:05,410
Shoot, let me just add a star on that.

79
00:03:05,410 --> 00:03:08,270
There we go.
Get-Service DHCP Server is what

80
00:03:08,270 --> 00:03:09,110
it's actually called.

81
00:03:09,110 --> 00:03:11,420
And I can see the server is there,
and it's running.

82
00:03:11,420 --> 00:03:14,590
So we're installed,
we are now a DHCP server.

83
00:03:14,590 --> 00:03:15,710
Albeit, not a very functional one.

84
00:03:15,710 --> 00:03:17,070
>> Right.

85
00:03:17,070 --> 00:03:19,580
>> All right, so like I said,
pretty short segment on this one.

86
00:03:19,580 --> 00:03:24,550
What we just saw was installing
DHCP server using the PowerShell.

87
00:03:24,550 --> 00:03:27,525
Now if you're asking yourself why did I
just waste my time watching this episode?

88
00:03:27,525 --> 00:03:29,614
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well it is important, but keep in mind,

89
00:03:29,614 --> 00:03:33,089
we're right about to follow that up with
more segments covering how to get it

90
00:03:33,089 --> 00:03:34,686
configured and actually useful.

91
00:03:34,686 --> 00:03:36,392
So definitely stay tuned for that.

92
00:03:36,392 --> 00:03:39,298
There's more PowerShell coming up.

93
00:03:39,298 --> 00:03:45,349
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Authorizing DHCP Server
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:04,900
[SOUND] In this segment, we're gonna

2
00:00:04,900 --> 00:00:10,273
take a look at an often overlooked step,

3
00:00:10,273 --> 00:00:15,184
which is authorizing a DHCP server.

4
00:00:15,184 --> 00:00:19,882
Now, we have to authorize a DHCP server
if we have a Windows DHCP server in

5
00:00:19,882 --> 00:00:22,040
a domain environment.

6
00:00:22,040 --> 00:00:23,630
When you have the active
directory present,

7
00:00:23,630 --> 00:00:27,190
it will purposefully suppress
any DHCP server you bring up.

8
00:00:27,190 --> 00:00:29,670
It will not allow it to
function unless it's

9
00:00:29,670 --> 00:00:31,890
been authorized by
a network administrator.

10
00:00:31,890 --> 00:00:34,375
This is something really easy
to overlook from the PowerShell.

11
00:00:34,375 --> 00:00:38,585
In the GUI when you're setting this up,
you get little red flags, warning messages

12
00:00:38,585 --> 00:00:42,045
that you're not authorized, but
from the PowerShell you don't get those.

13
00:00:42,045 --> 00:00:44,915
So if you just installed your DHCP server,
it's not gonna function.

14
00:00:44,915 --> 00:00:48,260
You might set up your scopes, your
exclusions, and all that, and it won't

15
00:00:48,260 --> 00:00:52,050
function until you authorize it, so
we definitely need to take a look at that.

16
00:00:52,050 --> 00:00:56,100
>> And Active Directory maintains a list
of authorized DHCP servers, so really all

17
00:00:56,100 --> 00:00:59,760
we're doing is we're adding the name of an
IP address for this server to that list.

18
00:00:59,760 --> 00:01:03,870
And then every time that machine starts
up, every time DHCP service starts up,

19
00:01:03,870 --> 00:01:06,130
it queries Active Directory and
says, hey let me look at that list.

20
00:01:06,130 --> 00:01:10,270
Am I in that list and if it's not in
the list, the service will start up, but

21
00:01:10,270 --> 00:01:13,070
it will report an error, and
it just won't service clients.

22
00:01:13,070 --> 00:01:14,313
>> Yeah and
I'm glad you mentioned that, Mike.

23
00:01:14,313 --> 00:01:15,172
Let's take a look at that list.

24
00:01:15,172 --> 00:01:18,100
We can actually pull the list of
DHCP servers that are approved.

25
00:01:18,100 --> 00:01:19,919
I'm gonna see if I'm in that list.

26
00:01:21,080 --> 00:01:23,540
The command for it is,
it’s not very intuitive,

27
00:01:23,540 --> 00:01:26,960
because you’d think it would have
authorize in the name, but it doesn’t.

28
00:01:26,960 --> 00:01:30,997
So I’m gonna say Get-DHCPServerInDC.

29
00:01:30,997 --> 00:01:34,381
All right, in other words,
reach out to a domain controller, and

30
00:01:34,381 --> 00:01:36,670
see what DHCP servers are listed.

31
00:01:36,670 --> 00:01:38,655
Now, if you run it and
you get nothing back,

32
00:01:38,655 --> 00:01:40,864
that means you have no
authorized DHCP servers.

33
00:01:40,864 --> 00:01:44,232
If you do have some DHCP servers out
there, they'll be listed right here, and

34
00:01:44,232 --> 00:01:46,950
you can see which servers
are already authorized, all right.

35
00:01:46,950 --> 00:01:51,800
In my case, I've installed DHCP,
or at least I think I have.

36
00:01:51,800 --> 00:01:56,520
If I do get Windows feature DHCP, let's
see if I've actually got it installed.

37
00:01:56,520 --> 00:01:58,913
So I should have DHCP installed.

38
00:01:58,913 --> 00:02:03,260
Yeah, I do, but I'm not gonna function
unless I authorize the server, so

39
00:02:03,260 --> 00:02:05,930
let's get this thing authorized.

40
00:02:05,930 --> 00:02:09,060
Now authorizing it is not hard, but

41
00:02:09,060 --> 00:02:12,740
it is easy to forget, and
the command is a little bit long.

42
00:02:12,740 --> 00:02:17,586
What we need to do is
say Add-DHCPServerInDC,

43
00:02:17,586 --> 00:02:22,160
all right, and then we need to provide
the information about this system.

44
00:02:22,160 --> 00:02:27,165
So I am gonna do the DNS name for
this server, and mine is server01.,

45
00:02:27,165 --> 00:02:31,650
oh shoot,
I've actually forgotten what my domain is.

46
00:02:33,620 --> 00:02:35,078
[LAUGH] That's always convenient,
isn't it?

47
00:02:35,078 --> 00:02:39,450
Let's see, I think I am lab.itpro.tv.

48
00:02:39,450 --> 00:02:41,250
Let me just pull that up.

49
00:02:41,250 --> 00:02:45,280
I'm sure there's twenty easier ways to
do this than the way that I'm doing it.

50
00:02:45,280 --> 00:02:47,420
But, where's my fully
qualified domain name?

51
00:02:47,420 --> 00:02:47,961
I thought it was in here.

52
00:02:47,961 --> 00:02:48,762
>> I'm looking.

53
00:02:48,762 --> 00:02:51,220
I don't see her yet.

54
00:02:51,220 --> 00:02:53,480
>> Well, shoot.
>> IP config all, just do a little.

55
00:02:53,480 --> 00:02:56,190
>> Oh yeah it is in there, isn't it?

56
00:02:56,190 --> 00:02:58,130
As I go into the wrong window here.

57
00:02:58,130 --> 00:03:00,410
We do need our fully qualified
domain name, though, or

58
00:03:00,410 --> 00:03:02,430
it's not gonna work out too well for us.

59
00:03:02,430 --> 00:03:04,490
Pretty sure it's lab.itpro.tv.

60
00:03:04,490 --> 00:03:06,912
If you get it wrong, it's not going to
work, so we do need to get it right.

61
00:03:06,912 --> 00:03:07,737
Oh, just itprotv.net.

62
00:03:07,737 --> 00:03:08,632
See, I'm glad I checked.

63
00:03:08,632 --> 00:03:09,759
There we go.

64
00:03:09,759 --> 00:03:14,325
So, I'm gonna say -dnsname
server01.itprotv.net, so

65
00:03:14,325 --> 00:03:16,820
that's my DHCP server.

66
00:03:16,820 --> 00:03:20,470
And I'm gonna give it its IP address,
also.

67
00:03:20,470 --> 00:03:24,403
And the IP address for this server,
I guess I need to know that also.

68
00:03:24,403 --> 00:03:30,688
And I should be able to find out right
here in the same screen, 192.168.29.3.

69
00:03:30,688 --> 00:03:32,241
So I'll punch that in, and

70
00:03:32,241 --> 00:03:36,099
I'll probably need an extra little
space in there to make it happy.

71
00:03:36,099 --> 00:03:40,608
All right, now when I specify this,
I'm just gonna be adding this server

72
00:03:40,608 --> 00:03:44,550
to the list, the DNS name and
IP address to the authorized side.

73
00:03:44,550 --> 00:03:48,620
Now I need to be a domain administrator
for this to work, and I am,

74
00:03:48,620 --> 00:03:51,190
and I launch my PowerShell with
administrative privileges.

75
00:03:51,190 --> 00:03:54,060
If I'm not a domain admin,
I can't run that command.

76
00:03:54,060 --> 00:03:56,290
I can't authorize a DHCP server,
so that's important.

77
00:03:58,370 --> 00:04:00,890
>> So now we should be able to go get
that list again, and see if we show up.

78
00:04:00,890 --> 00:04:01,490
>> Yeah, so

79
00:04:01,490 --> 00:04:06,690
if I run that get-windowsFeature dhcp,
oops, sorry, not that one.

80
00:04:06,690 --> 00:04:08,140
We already knew it was installed.

81
00:04:08,140 --> 00:04:14,670
I want to run the get-dhcpServerInDC,
which I thought was in my history.

82
00:04:14,670 --> 00:04:15,742
There it is.
And now it runs, and

83
00:04:15,742 --> 00:04:18,677
instead of getting an empty return,
I actually get an entry.

84
00:04:18,677 --> 00:04:22,670
I see 192.168.29.3 is right there.

85
00:04:22,670 --> 00:04:26,422
It's authorized and
it's mapped to server 01.itprotv.net.

86
00:04:26,422 --> 00:04:29,020
All right, we're authorized.

87
00:04:29,020 --> 00:04:32,090
Now, we're ready to start
using that DHCP server.

88
00:04:32,090 --> 00:04:36,000
If we don't do this,
we will not issue out IP addresses, and

89
00:04:36,000 --> 00:04:38,910
it's super easy to overlook that from
the PowerShell, so real important.

90
00:04:40,090 --> 00:04:40,730
All right.

91
00:04:40,730 --> 00:04:43,860
If we ever want to deauthorize a server,
like we're decommissioning it,

92
00:04:43,860 --> 00:04:46,450
getting it out of there,
the command is really the same.

93
00:04:46,450 --> 00:04:54,790
Except instead of Add-DhcpServerInDC,
you would just say remove.

94
00:04:54,790 --> 00:04:58,628
And if we say remove that same command,
it'll take it out and

95
00:04:58,628 --> 00:05:00,260
deauthorize that server.

96
00:05:00,260 --> 00:05:03,710
And the server doesn't have to be
online to deauthorize it, so if you've

97
00:05:03,710 --> 00:05:06,780
already gotten rid of that DHCP server,
and it's still just kind of sitting around

98
00:05:06,780 --> 00:05:10,360
authorized even though it no longer
exists, you can go to another server or

99
00:05:10,360 --> 00:05:13,042
your work station and run this and
that would deauthorize it.

100
00:05:13,042 --> 00:05:17,310
All right, well,
in this segment we got a chance to see

101
00:05:17,310 --> 00:05:20,340
authorizing that DHCP server
to get it functional.

102
00:05:20,340 --> 00:05:21,710
Now, it's up and running.

103
00:05:21,710 --> 00:05:25,350
So if you've been following all of our
segments in order, we've installed DHCP.

104
00:05:25,350 --> 00:05:26,740
We've authorized it.

105
00:05:26,740 --> 00:05:29,860
The next steps for
us are gonna be creating our scopes and

106
00:05:29,860 --> 00:05:31,805
getting this thing actually
doing something useful.

107
00:05:31,805 --> 00:05:33,710
>> Right.
>> So that's what's coming up next.

108
00:05:33,710 --> 00:05:34,419
Be sure to stay tuned.

109
00:05:34,419 --> 00:05:37,088
We've got more PowerShell coming up next.

110
00:05:37,088 --> 00:05:42,373
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Managing Scopes
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,969
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,232 --> 00:00:09,148
In this segment,

3
00:00:09,148 --> 00:00:13,390
we're gonna take a look at managing
scopes inside of the DHCP server.

4
00:00:13,390 --> 00:00:15,366
Once you get a DHCP server up and running,

5
00:00:15,366 --> 00:00:18,418
it's not particularly useful
until we actually put some scopes

6
00:00:18,418 --> 00:00:21,317
in there to tell it what addresses
it's allowed to hand out.

7
00:00:21,317 --> 00:00:24,250
That's a pretty important step and
you don't just provide a,

8
00:00:24,250 --> 00:00:26,850
well I guess you could just
provide a range of IP's, but

9
00:00:26,850 --> 00:00:30,307
there's normally other things we
provide along with it to customize it.

10
00:00:30,307 --> 00:00:31,540
>> Absolutely.

11
00:00:31,540 --> 00:00:35,440
Once we've authorized it It's allowed to
pass out IP addresses on the network now,

12
00:00:35,440 --> 00:00:37,570
but if it doesn't have a pool
of addresses to pass out,

13
00:00:37,570 --> 00:00:39,050
it's not gonna be able to do it.

14
00:00:39,050 --> 00:00:41,940
And then our scope has a whole bunch
of properties that we can associate

15
00:00:41,940 --> 00:00:43,470
with it that we'll go
through here with PowerShell.

16
00:00:44,470 --> 00:00:47,480
>> All right, so let's just start
out with getting a scope created.

17
00:00:47,480 --> 00:00:52,410
It's pretty easy, we've got a command
which is the Add-DhcpServerScope.

18
00:00:52,410 --> 00:00:56,860
Now there is a little bit more to it
now because we have IPv4 scopes and

19
00:00:56,860 --> 00:00:59,060
IPv6 scopes.

20
00:00:59,060 --> 00:01:03,584
So the command is not actually
Add-DhcpServerScope, or

21
00:01:03,584 --> 00:01:07,646
it's Add-DchpServerv4Scope,
or v6 scope, so

22
00:01:07,646 --> 00:01:13,060
that it knows which address
family we're operating in, right?

23
00:01:13,060 --> 00:01:15,350
In the older versions of Windows,
you didn't really have that problem, but

24
00:01:15,350 --> 00:01:17,740
there are gonna be moments where we
have IPv6 and we've gotta remember that.

25
00:01:17,740 --> 00:01:19,660
>> Exactly.
Almost all of the commands can be

26
00:01:19,660 --> 00:01:20,390
used for either one.

27
00:01:20,390 --> 00:01:24,690
You've just gotta specify, and the noun
part of the command would be v4 or v6.

28
00:01:24,690 --> 00:01:26,270
>> All right.

29
00:01:26,270 --> 00:01:27,480
So let's go ahead and get one created.

30
00:01:27,480 --> 00:01:31,340
Let's say I wanna create a DCHP scope for
the studio here, right.

31
00:01:31,340 --> 00:01:32,305
So for our machines.

32
00:01:32,305 --> 00:01:33,480
We'll see what I can break.

33
00:01:33,480 --> 00:01:36,917
>> All right. [LAUGH] >> So
I'm gonna do Add-DhcpServer,

34
00:01:36,917 --> 00:01:41,570
if I spell it right,
my tab ough to complete a word.

35
00:01:41,570 --> 00:01:45,709
So I'm gonna come in here and
say Add-DhcpServerv4, and

36
00:01:45,709 --> 00:01:49,370
[LAUGH] tab auto complete
sometimes does not pay off.

37
00:01:49,370 --> 00:01:50,420
There it is.

38
00:01:50,420 --> 00:01:51,850
DhcpServerv4Scope.

39
00:01:51,850 --> 00:01:54,700
If I want to IPv6 it
would just be a v6 scope,

40
00:01:54,700 --> 00:01:56,990
otherwise the commands
are basically identical.

41
00:01:56,990 --> 00:01:59,550
And then I need to give it some
information about the scope I'm creating,

42
00:01:59,550 --> 00:02:01,800
and a minimum you'll
want to give it a name.

43
00:02:01,800 --> 00:02:05,040
And I'll call this one the ITProTV Studio.

44
00:02:05,040 --> 00:02:07,670
>> The name doesn't really do
anything functionally, but

45
00:02:07,670 --> 00:02:10,930
when you're working with that DHCP server,
and you've got a bunch of different scope

46
00:02:10,930 --> 00:02:12,950
for your client subnet,
for your server backbone,

47
00:02:12,950 --> 00:02:16,670
things like that, the name helps you
know which one you're working with.

48
00:02:16,670 --> 00:02:22,210
>> And then the three required
options are the beginning IP,

49
00:02:22,210 --> 00:02:25,310
the ending IP, and the sub net mask.

50
00:02:25,310 --> 00:02:27,420
And so those are the three other
things we need to provide.

51
00:02:27,420 --> 00:02:29,890
That's the bare minimum
to get a scope created.

52
00:02:29,890 --> 00:02:31,800
Beginning, end ,and subnet mask.

53
00:02:32,850 --> 00:02:36,663
So I'll just come in here and
I'll say StartRange.

54
00:02:36,663 --> 00:02:42,363
And I'm gonna start this
one at 192.168.29.100.

55
00:02:42,363 --> 00:02:45,604
And then I can say EndRange,

56
00:02:45,604 --> 00:02:51,555
which is gonna be 192.168.29.150.

57
00:02:51,555 --> 00:02:54,527
Or maybe I'll do 149 so
it's a nice even 50 addresses.

58
00:02:54,527 --> 00:02:55,756
>> I like it.

59
00:02:55,756 --> 00:02:59,597
>> So I'll go and
specify as a start and the end, and

60
00:02:59,597 --> 00:03:05,877
then I need my subnet mask at the very
end, so I'll just add that -SubnetMask,

61
00:03:05,877 --> 00:03:09,853
and this one we'll just
do as a slash 24 class C.

62
00:03:09,853 --> 00:03:12,504
255.255.255.0.

63
00:03:12,504 --> 00:03:17,058
So once I've got that punched in, it's
the name of the scope, the beginning IP,

64
00:03:17,058 --> 00:03:19,785
the ending IP, and the subnet mask.

65
00:03:19,785 --> 00:03:25,525
Now, a lot of this can be changed after
the fact using Set-DhcpServerScope.

66
00:03:25,525 --> 00:03:28,447
You can change things like
the beginning and ending IP address.

67
00:03:28,447 --> 00:03:32,707
But that subnet mask is one of those few
things in here that you can't change.

68
00:03:32,707 --> 00:03:36,117
So make sure you get that set right,
otherwise you gotta remove the scope and

69
00:03:36,117 --> 00:03:37,467
recreate it, and that can be a pain.

70
00:03:39,407 --> 00:03:43,050
All right so, now I've got a scope,
or at least I think I do.

71
00:03:43,050 --> 00:03:47,229
Right?
I guess we could verify that with

72
00:03:47,229 --> 00:03:51,783
a quick get-DhcpServerv4Scope.

73
00:03:53,090 --> 00:03:56,340
I don't even know why I bother
with that one completely [LAUGH]

74
00:03:56,340 --> 00:03:57,460
>> Some of them it works really well,

75
00:03:57,460 --> 00:03:58,400
some of them you gotta type so

76
00:03:58,400 --> 00:04:00,375
many letters that you might as
well just finish typing it out.

77
00:04:00,375 --> 00:04:02,250
[LAUGH]
>> I could have typed five characters, or

78
00:04:02,250 --> 00:04:03,865
I could hit Tab 12 times.

79
00:04:03,865 --> 00:04:05,520
>> [LAUGH]
>> So anyhow,

80
00:04:05,520 --> 00:04:08,110
you can see right here that Scope
that we made, ITProTV Studio.

81
00:04:08,110 --> 00:04:10,550
It is active by default,
so be aware of that.

82
00:04:10,550 --> 00:04:12,940
I'm serving up addresses right now.

83
00:04:12,940 --> 00:04:16,980
It's got a StartRange of 192.168.29.100,
all the way to 149.

84
00:04:16,980 --> 00:04:18,861
The LeaseDuration is at the default.

85
00:04:18,861 --> 00:04:23,031
There were a lot of other options I
could have provided on that line, but

86
00:04:23,031 --> 00:04:26,450
the minimum was the start,
the end, and the subnet mask.

87
00:04:26,450 --> 00:04:28,530
And so, it's got all of that,
and it's ready to rock.

88
00:04:28,530 --> 00:04:30,428
I've got my scope.
>> And that's something to keep in mind,

89
00:04:30,428 --> 00:04:32,050
is that is different
from the GUI interface.

90
00:04:32,050 --> 00:04:35,160
When you create that scope through
the GUI, there's a check mark that you can

91
00:04:35,160 --> 00:04:38,900
choose, but by default, it's not gonna
be the scope, it's not gonna be active.

92
00:04:38,900 --> 00:04:41,830
So, you set that scope up, and then it
gives you a chance to go back in and

93
00:04:41,830 --> 00:04:43,730
set some of the additional parameters, and

94
00:04:43,730 --> 00:04:44,860
then you can activate
it when you're ready.

95
00:04:44,860 --> 00:04:48,600
With PowerShell, it's gonna be active
as soon as you run that command.

96
00:04:48,600 --> 00:04:50,970
>> Yeah, so
let's say I created a second one here.

97
00:04:50,970 --> 00:04:54,582
So I'll just go in, and
I'm gonna create a ITProTV Studio 2.

98
00:04:54,582 --> 00:04:57,130
That's in a different network, right.

99
00:04:57,130 --> 00:04:59,000
So now I've got two of these scopes.

100
00:04:59,000 --> 00:05:01,630
And I can see them both created here,
and their ranges.

101
00:05:01,630 --> 00:05:09,190
If I wanna get rid of a scope, it's
just gonna be Remove-dhcpServerv4Scope,

102
00:05:09,190 --> 00:05:12,920
and then all you have
to provide is the name.

103
00:05:12,920 --> 00:05:17,080
You don't have to provide all the other
information that we did before.

104
00:05:17,080 --> 00:05:19,440
You can just say, I'm sorry,
not the name, the scope ID.

105
00:05:20,510 --> 00:05:21,400
There we go, ScopeID.

106
00:05:21,400 --> 00:05:24,970
And the scope ID, notice how the scope
ID is not actually the name,

107
00:05:24,970 --> 00:05:29,500
it's the subnet or
the network that this is attached to.

108
00:05:29,500 --> 00:05:31,100
So if I wanna get rid
of this 192.168.28.0,

109
00:05:31,100 --> 00:05:37,050
that's what I have to punch in, and
we can punch that in right there.

110
00:05:37,050 --> 00:05:40,190
We don't have to provide all the other
details, start range, end range,

111
00:05:40,190 --> 00:05:40,960
subnet mask.

112
00:05:40,960 --> 00:05:45,500
We just specify that scope ID And
that’ll remove it, and now it’s gone.

113
00:05:45,500 --> 00:05:49,570
All right, so
pretty straightforward there, but

114
00:05:49,570 --> 00:05:52,470
we don’t normally stop right here,
this scope is gonna be pretty boring.

115
00:05:52,470 --> 00:05:56,430
If machines boot up on our network,
they’ll get an IP address and that’s it.

116
00:05:56,430 --> 00:05:57,450
>> And that’s about it, right?

117
00:05:57,450 --> 00:06:00,090
And that’s where the power
of DHCP comes into play.

118
00:06:00,090 --> 00:06:03,440
We can pass out all the other TCP IP
configurations and more stuff.

119
00:06:03,440 --> 00:06:07,870
And then more, your DNS server address,
your default gateway.

120
00:06:07,870 --> 00:06:10,130
All this stuff we're going to need
to really function on a network.

121
00:06:10,130 --> 00:06:10,870
>> Yep.

122
00:06:10,870 --> 00:06:12,840
In the show notes for this episode,

123
00:06:12,840 --> 00:06:17,470
I'm gonna include a link to
this Microsoft TechNet article.

124
00:06:17,470 --> 00:06:20,910
And in this TechNet article, they
highlight all the different options that

125
00:06:20,910 --> 00:06:25,580
we can provide to a scope, so that we can
give our clients a configuration to use

126
00:06:25,580 --> 00:06:29,470
when they boot up and get a DHCP address,
but there's a lot of them.

127
00:06:29,470 --> 00:06:33,670
And there's a lot that a lot of
people aren't really going to use.

128
00:06:33,670 --> 00:06:34,990
So I'll include the link to that article,
but

129
00:06:34,990 --> 00:06:38,230
what I want to show you here in
the video are the most common ones.

130
00:06:38,230 --> 00:06:40,910
Things like who your DNS
servers are going to be, and

131
00:06:40,910 --> 00:06:43,370
who your default gateway is going to be.

132
00:06:43,370 --> 00:06:45,760
Those are the two things that
we really need to get good,

133
00:06:45,760 --> 00:06:47,800
clean functionality on our DHCP server.

134
00:06:49,198 --> 00:06:51,940
Well, since I've already created my scope,
I just need to go in and

135
00:06:51,940 --> 00:06:53,770
modify the options on it.

136
00:06:53,770 --> 00:06:57,920
And to that, we’re gonna say Set,
and actually let me move this,

137
00:06:57,920 --> 00:07:01,230
cuz this is gonna be a long command, and
I don't want my head to cover it up.

138
00:07:01,230 --> 00:07:02,708
>> Just the command looks long enough.

139
00:07:02,708 --> 00:07:05,268
[LAUGH]
>> So all right, here,

140
00:07:05,268 --> 00:07:07,260
we'll start from the top.

141
00:07:07,260 --> 00:07:10,490
So, we're gonna come in here and we're
basically gonna set this option, right?

142
00:07:10,490 --> 00:07:15,935
So I'll just say
Set-DHCPServerv4OptionValue.

143
00:07:20,990 --> 00:07:22,880
That's the main commandlet right there.

144
00:07:22,880 --> 00:07:26,630
Set-DHCPServerv4OptionValue, we
can go in here, and

145
00:07:26,630 --> 00:07:28,120
we can set all of our various options.

146
00:07:28,120 --> 00:07:31,202
And you can even start to
create some new options with

147
00:07:31,202 --> 00:07:34,000
the Add-DhcpServerv4OptionValue.

148
00:07:34,000 --> 00:07:36,513
Cuz you might have custom
options that you need to make.

149
00:07:36,513 --> 00:07:42,070
But for the most part, we can use
the built-in ones and they're just fine.

150
00:07:42,070 --> 00:07:46,200
All right, so I'm gonna be modifying my
scope ID that we just made a moment ago,

151
00:07:46,200 --> 00:07:47,450
which for me is 192.168.29.0.

152
00:07:47,450 --> 00:07:51,710
And now I provide the various
options that I want it to have.

153
00:07:51,710 --> 00:07:53,538
I mention DNS server, right.

154
00:07:53,538 --> 00:08:03,010
So I'll say -DnsServer and maybe my DNS
server here is going to be 192.168.29.3.

155
00:08:03,010 --> 00:08:05,150
So that's the DNS server that
I'm gonna give to people.

156
00:08:05,150 --> 00:08:07,392
If I had more than one I
would just do a comma and

157
00:08:07,392 --> 00:08:09,463
list the other ones that were available.

158
00:08:09,463 --> 00:08:11,647
You can do more than one DNS server.

159
00:08:11,647 --> 00:08:13,200
All right.

160
00:08:13,200 --> 00:08:15,610
I might choose to do a DNS suffix also,
and

161
00:08:15,610 --> 00:08:19,730
that's -DnsDomain, and
then we specify what domain they're in.

162
00:08:19,730 --> 00:08:22,700
I'm in ITProTV.net,
I believe is what I'm in.

163
00:08:22,700 --> 00:08:25,290
All right.

164
00:08:25,290 --> 00:08:29,895
And then,
that default gateway which is -Router and

165
00:08:29,895 --> 00:08:37,279
then the ip address of your router
which on my network is 192.168.29.2.

166
00:08:37,279 --> 00:08:40,720
So, right here I see the main
options that we're gonna set.

167
00:08:40,720 --> 00:08:45,500
The default gateway, the DNS server, and
I went ahead and did the DNS suffix also.

168
00:08:45,500 --> 00:08:48,300
But there's plenty more options that
are out there that you can set,

169
00:08:48,300 --> 00:08:55,050
maybe win servers and other things,
hopefully not, but I'll run that.

170
00:08:55,050 --> 00:08:57,750
There was a little message that popped
up there, just a little status setting.

171
00:08:57,750 --> 00:09:02,900
It goes by real fast, and then we get
our prompt, my options are set, right?

172
00:09:02,900 --> 00:09:05,920
So now when my clients go to connect, they
don't just get an IP address and a subnet

173
00:09:05,920 --> 00:09:10,700
mask, they also get the other supporting
information that they need, right?

174
00:09:10,700 --> 00:09:13,110
If I want to verify that,
I can jump back to my GUI,

175
00:09:13,110 --> 00:09:15,090
it's probably the easiest way to see it.

176
00:09:15,090 --> 00:09:18,775
And I don't see any scopes here, but
if I refresh this screen, I should.

177
00:09:18,775 --> 00:09:21,850
There's my scope, 192.169 29.0.

178
00:09:21,850 --> 00:09:23,240
It's called ItProTV studio.

179
00:09:23,240 --> 00:09:28,320
And if I go down to Scope Options,
there's the router, DNS servers,

180
00:09:28,320 --> 00:09:32,650
and domain name, all set just
like we did from the PowerShell.

181
00:09:32,650 --> 00:09:38,750
Now, because I created this scope from
the PowerShell, It was active by default.

182
00:09:39,980 --> 00:09:41,850
But there may be times when
we're troubleshooting or

183
00:09:41,850 --> 00:09:46,050
dealing with other issues that we might
want to disable a scope temporarily, or

184
00:09:46,050 --> 00:09:48,780
maybe we created it disabled,
and now we're ready to enable it.

185
00:09:48,780 --> 00:09:51,170
Well, that's another thing that
we can do from the PowerShell,

186
00:09:51,170 --> 00:09:54,170
is you can turn these scopes on and
off as you need it.

187
00:09:54,170 --> 00:09:55,713
And it's really not a hard command.

188
00:09:55,713 --> 00:10:01,290
It's Set-DHCPServerv4Scope -ScopeID,

189
00:10:01,290 --> 00:10:07,440
we have to tell it which
scope we're working with.

190
00:10:09,210 --> 00:10:12,640
And then, we can say -State, and for

191
00:10:12,640 --> 00:10:17,850
the state there's really just two
values which is active and inactive.

192
00:10:19,170 --> 00:10:23,320
So if I say inactive,
that's gonna disable the scope.

193
00:10:23,320 --> 00:10:27,650
The scope still exists, but we're no
longer handing out addresses for it.

194
00:10:27,650 --> 00:10:29,280
And back here in DHTP,

195
00:10:29,280 --> 00:10:34,870
if I refresh this screen,
what I should see is that scope there.

196
00:10:34,870 --> 00:10:36,260
It's got a little red circle on it.

197
00:10:36,260 --> 00:10:37,720
It's been deactivated.

198
00:10:37,720 --> 00:10:38,410
It's inactive.

199
00:10:39,470 --> 00:10:40,330
All right.

200
00:10:40,330 --> 00:10:43,970
And if I go back to my PowerShell and
run that same command but change this

201
00:10:43,970 --> 00:10:48,900
to Active, now when I run that it's active
and it's handing out addresses again.

202
00:10:48,900 --> 00:10:51,560
I can come back here and
refresh this screen.

203
00:10:52,715 --> 00:10:54,895
And I can see that it is now active.

204
00:10:54,895 --> 00:10:58,075
So, pretty easy to turn those on and
off as needed.

205
00:10:58,075 --> 00:11:01,505
And we can use Get-DhcpServerv4Scope
to find out whether or

206
00:11:01,505 --> 00:11:03,335
not they're active or inactive.

207
00:11:03,335 --> 00:11:10,320
So, if I inactivate it again,
and run the scope command.

208
00:11:10,320 --> 00:11:12,860
And I'm just going to leave off the ID so
it'll display everything.

209
00:11:12,860 --> 00:11:15,620
You can see in here,
I've got that state of Inactive.

210
00:11:15,620 --> 00:11:19,611
So pretty easy to verify that
from the PowerShell too.

211
00:11:19,611 --> 00:11:20,885
I like the GUI.

212
00:11:20,885 --> 00:11:22,371
Something like this, inactivating and

213
00:11:22,371 --> 00:11:24,780
activating a scope is not something
I'm going to do all the time.

214
00:11:24,780 --> 00:11:26,560
So I'll usually use the GUI for it.

215
00:11:26,560 --> 00:11:29,337
>> [CROSSTALK] [INAUDIBLE],
or something like that?

216
00:11:29,337 --> 00:11:32,769
>> Yeah, maybe you've got some kind of
scripted response, like a threat response

217
00:11:32,769 --> 00:11:35,595
or something that you want to
inactivate that scope really quick so

218
00:11:35,595 --> 00:11:38,030
you're not hitting on addresses.

219
00:11:38,030 --> 00:11:41,240
Or maybe you only want to hand out DHCP
addresses during certain times of the day.

220
00:11:41,240 --> 00:11:43,070
You could automate it
with something like this.

221
00:11:44,570 --> 00:11:48,820
All right well, All in all, working
with the scopes, not that big of a deal.

222
00:11:48,820 --> 00:11:50,270
Right.
The trick is just remembering what

223
00:11:50,270 --> 00:11:51,620
options you want to set.

224
00:11:51,620 --> 00:11:54,050
We really just saw three different
commands in there, right.

225
00:11:54,050 --> 00:11:57,530
If I do a get-history,
we'll kind of see the ones that I did.

226
00:11:57,530 --> 00:12:01,270
There was the Add-DHCPServerv4Scope,

227
00:12:01,270 --> 00:12:05,990
there was the set DHCP
server option value.

228
00:12:05,990 --> 00:12:08,750
I guess really just that and the GET.

229
00:12:08,750 --> 00:12:11,180
Get-DhcpServerv4Scope.

230
00:12:11,180 --> 00:12:13,230
So really just a handful
of commands there and

231
00:12:13,230 --> 00:12:15,770
just different options that we're
using with it to achieve our goals.

232
00:12:17,752 --> 00:12:21,280
All right, well in this segment we got
a chance to see how to create those DHCP

233
00:12:21,280 --> 00:12:26,040
scopes, how to modify the scopes,
and how to set options on them and

234
00:12:26,040 --> 00:12:29,920
at the very end there we took a look at
activating and inactivating those scopes.

235
00:12:29,920 --> 00:12:31,650
So, pretty good stuff.

236
00:12:31,650 --> 00:12:36,080
At this point, we typically consider our
DHCP server functional and ready to run.

237
00:12:37,972 --> 00:12:40,060
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

238
00:12:40,060 --> 00:12:43,660
Stay tuned because we do have a little
bit more of Dhcop coming up, but

239
00:12:43,660 --> 00:12:46,210
otherwise we have other PowerShell
episodes coming up too.

240
00:12:46,210 --> 00:12:47,420
So stay tuned.

241
00:12:47,420 --> 00:12:48,903
There'll be more after this.

242
00:12:48,903 --> 00:12:55,129
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: DHCP Exclusions
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,025 --> 00:00:05,397
[SOUND] In this segment we're gonna take

2
00:00:05,397 --> 00:00:13,711
a look at creating exclusions
inside of a DHCP server scope.

3
00:00:13,711 --> 00:00:17,547
When we create a scope, they let us
pick the beginning IP of a range and

4
00:00:17,547 --> 00:00:18,950
the ending IP of a range.

5
00:00:18,950 --> 00:00:22,800
And sometimes that works out great for us,
we have a whole block of IPs we wanna use.

6
00:00:22,800 --> 00:00:26,110
There are times where there's particular
IPs that we need to leave out right.

7
00:00:26,110 --> 00:00:27,600
And I'm not talking about a reservation,

8
00:00:27,600 --> 00:00:29,770
where I wanna map it to
one host all the time.

9
00:00:29,770 --> 00:00:31,430
I mean I wanna leave it out all together.

10
00:00:31,430 --> 00:00:33,710
I don't want DHCP to touch it.

11
00:00:33,710 --> 00:00:37,730
>> Somebody statically mapped a print
server a long time ago before you set that

12
00:00:37,730 --> 00:00:41,470
scope up, and now that address you can't
change or you don't wanna change it.

13
00:00:41,470 --> 00:00:42,018
But again, so

14
00:00:42,018 --> 00:00:44,780
I gotta make sure that my DHCP server
doesn't pass out that IP address.

15
00:00:45,830 --> 00:00:48,910
>> So let's take a look at that process,
it is pretty straightforward.

16
00:00:48,910 --> 00:00:52,950
I've got a scope that I've created
in a previous segment, and so

17
00:00:52,950 --> 00:00:59,160
I'm gonna just pull that scope up real
quick, it's the 192.168.29.0 scope.

18
00:00:59,160 --> 00:01:02,899
And it runs from .100 all the way to .49.

19
00:01:02,899 --> 00:01:03,414
I've got 50 IPs.

20
00:01:03,414 --> 00:01:08,202
Well let's say that .107

21
00:01:08,202 --> 00:01:11,780
was already in use by a machine on
the network that's statically assigned.

22
00:01:11,780 --> 00:01:14,170
So not using DHCP,
it's just statically assigned.

23
00:01:14,170 --> 00:01:16,680
I wanna tell DHCP to leave that alone.

24
00:01:16,680 --> 00:01:22,230
Not to mess with .7, and to do that,
I can create an exclusion to map it out.

25
00:01:22,230 --> 00:01:25,930
Now, when you create an exclusion,
you can exclude a single IP, or

26
00:01:25,930 --> 00:01:27,800
you can exclude a range of IPs.

27
00:01:27,800 --> 00:01:29,790
It's up to you how you want to do it.

28
00:01:29,790 --> 00:01:31,770
But, I'm gonna exclude just
a single one to start one.

29
00:01:31,770 --> 00:01:32,620
I'll do a range afterwards.

30
00:01:32,620 --> 00:01:35,340
I'm gonna knock out .7.

31
00:01:35,340 --> 00:01:36,205
>> 107.

32
00:01:36,205 --> 00:01:37,682
>> 107, sorry.

33
00:01:37,682 --> 00:01:42,093
So, I'm gonna come in here and just say,

34
00:01:42,093 --> 00:01:46,393
Add-DhcpServerv4ExclusionRange.

35
00:01:46,393 --> 00:01:50,180
And, even though I'm excluding just one
IP, you still say it's an exclusion range.

36
00:01:50,180 --> 00:01:53,810
It's just gonna start and
stop at the exact same IP.

37
00:01:53,810 --> 00:01:56,030
Then I tell it what
scope I'm working with.

38
00:01:56,030 --> 00:02:01,473
So I'll say -ScopeID 192.168.29.0,
is my ScopeID.

39
00:02:01,473 --> 00:02:03,920
And now, I need to tell it the exclusion.

40
00:02:03,920 --> 00:02:07,390
And very similar to creating
an actual scope, we say start range,

41
00:02:07,390 --> 00:02:08,680
and an end range.

42
00:02:09,730 --> 00:02:14,830
So if we say -StartRange, in my case it's

43
00:02:14,830 --> 00:02:20,970
going to be 192.168.29.107, and
my EndRange is gonna be the same IP.

44
00:02:20,970 --> 00:02:25,500
If I just wanna include one IP,
I just list it as the start and the end.

45
00:02:25,500 --> 00:02:27,930
It's both for that particular exclusion.

46
00:02:29,470 --> 00:02:32,540
And so when I run that,
it should be happy.

47
00:02:32,540 --> 00:02:33,080
How do I know it worked?

48
00:02:33,080 --> 00:02:34,490
Well I can query these.

49
00:02:34,490 --> 00:02:40,149
I can do a Get-DhcpServerv4ExclusionRange.

50
00:02:40,149 --> 00:02:42,130
And now, I can see I've got
a range from 107 to 107, right?

51
00:02:42,130 --> 00:02:44,540
That one's excluded out.

52
00:02:45,690 --> 00:02:48,170
If I wanted to do a block of IPs well,

53
00:02:48,170 --> 00:02:51,150
you just put different IPs in
the beginning and in the end.

54
00:02:51,150 --> 00:02:54,520
Be careful though, it does get unhappy
if you do things like overlapping.

55
00:02:54,520 --> 00:02:58,324
So, if I wanted to exclude 105 to 110.

56
00:02:59,330 --> 00:03:03,408
Right, if I go in here and modify that
previous command like that, they overlap.

57
00:03:03,408 --> 00:03:06,751
So I'd actually need to remove
the exclusion for 107, and

58
00:03:06,751 --> 00:03:08,950
then add the block for 105 to 110.

59
00:03:10,950 --> 00:03:12,550
If they don't overlap,
it's no big deal though.

60
00:03:12,550 --> 00:03:16,764
So like if I wanted to
exclude 110 through 115.

61
00:03:18,150 --> 00:03:22,935
I can just come in here and
modify this, and now when I do my

62
00:03:22,935 --> 00:03:27,380
Get-DhcpServerv4ExclusionRange, I'll
see the two ranges.

63
00:03:27,380 --> 00:03:33,104
The first one is just a single IP,
the second one is that range, 110 to 115.

64
00:03:33,104 --> 00:03:36,989
Now, this is different than a reservation,
because what this does is,

65
00:03:36,989 --> 00:03:40,620
it tells DHCP to pretend like
these IPs don't even exist.

66
00:03:40,620 --> 00:03:41,664
Don't hand them out.

67
00:03:41,664 --> 00:03:44,000
If somebody asked for
an IP, don't issue this.

68
00:03:44,000 --> 00:03:45,770
Don't even pretend these are around.

69
00:03:45,770 --> 00:03:47,320
Just ignore it.

70
00:03:47,320 --> 00:03:48,670
Reservations are a lot different.

71
00:03:48,670 --> 00:03:51,010
We put specialized requirements on those.

72
00:03:51,010 --> 00:03:52,870
But here, you just ignore it.

73
00:03:52,870 --> 00:03:55,340
All right, once they're in place,

74
00:03:55,340 --> 00:03:59,830
you can get rid of them by doing
the Remove-DhcpServerv4ExclusionRange.

75
00:03:59,830 --> 00:04:02,960
Syntax is the same for the rest of it, you
can remove them and get them out of there.

76
00:04:02,960 --> 00:04:04,890
Or put them right back again.

77
