00:04:04,890 --> 00:04:07,640
Notice how each of these do have
their own kind of scope ID.

78
00:04:07,640 --> 00:04:10,740
It's just mapping it to the scope
ID of the actual scope,

79
00:04:10,740 --> 00:04:14,540
this isn't tied to each individual
range like each on its own.

80
00:04:14,540 --> 00:04:17,700
But you might have exclusion ranges for
several different scopes.

81
00:04:17,700 --> 00:04:19,570
I could have filtered this down and

82
00:04:19,570 --> 00:04:22,910
specified the scope ID that I
wanted to see exclusion ranges for.

83
00:04:22,910 --> 00:04:25,930
That's useful if you
have more than one scope.

84
00:04:25,930 --> 00:04:28,090
I don't, I've only got the one scope,
so I don't need the filter.

85
00:04:29,752 --> 00:04:30,680
All right, but that's basically it,

86
00:04:30,680 --> 00:04:33,160
this is one of the simpler
topics that we've got.

87
00:04:33,160 --> 00:04:35,974
Adding an exclusion range,
viewing the exclusion ranges,

88
00:04:35,974 --> 00:04:37,528
it's all done with one command.

89
00:04:37,528 --> 00:04:46,119
Well, the set, get, and remove variations
of the DhcpServerv4ExclusionRange command.

90
00:04:46,119 --> 00:04:46,886
That's a long one.
[LAUGH]

91
00:04:46,886 --> 00:04:47,482
>> All right,

92
00:04:47,482 --> 00:04:50,226
well in this segment,
we got a chance to see creating,

93
00:04:50,226 --> 00:04:54,356
modifying and removing those exclusions,
pretty straightforward on this one.

94
00:04:54,356 --> 00:04:55,517
Hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

95
00:04:55,517 --> 00:05:00,450
Stay tuned, we've got more DHCP and
more power shell coming up.

96
00:05:00,450 --> 00:05:06,590
[SOUND]

episodes.title: DHCP Reservations
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,974
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,974 --> 00:00:08,845
In this segment,

3
00:00:08,845 --> 00:00:13,720
we're gonna take a look at creating DHCP
reservations from the Windows PowerShell.

4
00:00:13,720 --> 00:00:15,940
Creating reservation in DHCP
is really handy, right?

5
00:00:15,940 --> 00:00:19,730
We wanna a machine to boot up and always
get the same IP address from our pool.

6
00:00:19,730 --> 00:00:22,210
Or maybe we want it to
get custom options or

7
00:00:22,210 --> 00:00:25,095
settings from the other machines that
are getting IP's from our server.

8
00:00:25,095 --> 00:00:27,610
>> Mm-hm
>> Reservations let us do that, right?

9
00:00:27,610 --> 00:00:29,301
But we gotta get them
created before they function.

10
00:00:29,301 --> 00:00:30,580
>> Right
>> And that's what we're gonna

11
00:00:30,580 --> 00:00:31,129
see right here.

12
00:00:32,130 --> 00:00:35,730
Now creating reservation, it's almost
identical to creating an exclusion.

13
00:00:35,730 --> 00:00:38,380
The difference is, instead of
providing a start and an end IP,

14
00:00:38,380 --> 00:00:44,540
we're providing a specific IP and
a Mac address that's gonna be tied to it.

15
00:00:44,540 --> 00:00:47,630
So a little bit of a variation,
but the syntax is pretty familiar.

16
00:00:47,630 --> 00:00:51,110
So let's take a look at that
right here on my machine.

17
00:00:51,110 --> 00:00:55,870
Let's say that I wanna make sure my laptop
always gets the same IP address from our

18
00:00:55,870 --> 00:00:56,716
DHCP server.

19
00:00:56,716 --> 00:00:57,610
All right.

20
00:00:57,610 --> 00:01:01,350
I always wanna get an IP that ends in 123.

21
00:01:01,350 --> 00:01:04,625
So I want to create
a reservation that will do that.

22
00:01:04,625 --> 00:01:05,570
>> Mm-hm
>> All right?

23
00:01:05,570 --> 00:01:11,265
So I'm gonna come in and
say Add-DhcpServerv4Reservation.

24
00:01:11,265 --> 00:01:17,560
All right, so
I'm gonna be adding that reservation in.

25
00:01:17,560 --> 00:01:20,620
I need to tell it what scope this
reservation is a part of, and

26
00:01:20,620 --> 00:01:24,255
my scope that I'm working
with is 192.168.29.0.

27
00:01:24,255 --> 00:01:28,950
Then I need to tell it the IP address
that I want this machine to have.

28
00:01:28,950 --> 00:01:31,961
And so I'll come in and
just say -IPAddress.

29
00:01:31,961 --> 00:01:35,124
And I'm gonna give myself 192.168.29.123.

30
00:01:35,124 --> 00:01:37,590
Right.
That's the IP address I always want

31
00:01:37,590 --> 00:01:38,129
to have.

32
00:01:38,129 --> 00:01:39,966
Now here's the important part.

33
00:01:39,966 --> 00:01:42,647
Well, I guess let me add
a little bit more to that.

34
00:01:42,647 --> 00:01:45,741
The IP address you pick has
to be inside of the scope, so

35
00:01:45,741 --> 00:01:48,788
you know your scope does have a start and
an end range.

36
00:01:48,788 --> 00:01:50,771
It's gotta be inside of there.

37
00:01:50,771 --> 00:01:53,150
And it cannot be an exclusion range.

38
00:01:53,150 --> 00:01:57,320
I know some people will try and exclude an
IP and then create a reservation for it.

39
00:01:57,320 --> 00:01:59,010
That doesn't work, right?

40
00:01:59,010 --> 00:01:59,960
>> When you exclude it,

41
00:01:59,960 --> 00:02:03,600
you're telling the DHCP server you
cannot pass out this IP address.

42
00:02:03,600 --> 00:02:05,570
You can't use that in a reservation.

43
00:02:05,570 --> 00:02:06,160
>> Or if you try and

44
00:02:06,160 --> 00:02:09,850
create a reservation for
a scope that's outside of the scope IP.

45
00:02:09,850 --> 00:02:13,310
So like my scope goes from
.100 all the way to .49.

46
00:02:13,310 --> 00:02:17,470
If I tried to create a reservation for
150, it's outside the scope and

47
00:02:17,470 --> 00:02:18,040
won't let you do it.

48
00:02:18,040 --> 00:02:21,922
So it's gotta be a valid IP
inside of the current scope.

49
00:02:21,922 --> 00:02:23,290
All right.

50
00:02:23,290 --> 00:02:26,510
So, the next part is the most
important part, which is.

51
00:02:26,510 --> 00:02:29,110
The MAC address of the machine, all right?

52
00:02:29,110 --> 00:02:32,830
So I need to come in and
just tell it -ClientID, and

53
00:02:32,830 --> 00:02:35,830
then the MAC address, all right?

54
00:02:35,830 --> 00:02:40,540
The MAC address is a 48-bit hexadecimal
number, and when I write, or letters and

55
00:02:40,540 --> 00:02:41,820
numbers, I guess, whatever.

56
00:02:41,820 --> 00:02:44,440
When we write it,
it does need to be in a particular format.

57
00:02:44,440 --> 00:02:48,890
It needs to be two characters and a dash,
two characters and a dash, and so on.

58
00:02:48,890 --> 00:02:53,190
So, if I'm gonna create one for my Laptop,
I'll just punch in my MAC address here, so

59
00:02:53,190 --> 00:02:54,360
I'm just gonna get that punched in.

60
00:02:54,360 --> 00:02:59,460
And I've got it written down on a piece of
paper here, so I don't have to look it up.

61
00:02:59,460 --> 00:03:01,410
>> That is kind of a negative in the GUI,

62
00:03:01,410 --> 00:03:03,000
you don't have to put those dashes in,
right?

63
00:03:03,000 --> 00:03:05,730
When you go through wizard,
you can just type in your 12 digits there,

64
00:03:05,730 --> 00:03:07,442
and it'll assume the dashes.

65
00:03:07,442 --> 00:03:09,130
In PowerShell, you do have to
put those in, unfortunately.

66
00:03:10,180 --> 00:03:12,110
>> And then we need to give it a name.

67
00:03:12,110 --> 00:03:16,310
And I'll just call this one donlaptop so
I can remember what it is, all right.

68
00:03:16,310 --> 00:03:20,070
And that's gonna create that reservation
so that now whenever my laptop gets an IP

69
00:03:20,070 --> 00:03:26,390
address from the server, it will
always get 192.168.29.123, all right.

70
00:03:26,390 --> 00:03:33,707
And if I run a get-dhcpserverv4reservation
which apparently I spelled wrong, again.

71
00:03:33,707 --> 00:03:40,570
Apparently I'm going to set record for the
amount of times that I can spell it wrong.

72
00:03:40,570 --> 00:03:44,810
Then you'll see it's prompting me for
my scope ID, I didn't provide that.

73
00:03:44,810 --> 00:03:52,330
So if I, oops, there we go,
if I provide my scope ID of 192.168.29.0.

74
00:03:52,330 --> 00:03:58,540
So I'm running get-Dhcpserverv4reservation
-scope ID and providing the scope.

75
00:03:58,540 --> 00:04:01,230
Now, I can see each of
the reservations that are out there.

76
00:04:01,230 --> 00:04:05,495
So I can see that .123 is mapped to this
MAC address, and it's named donlaptop.

77
00:04:07,310 --> 00:04:08,810
Now, at this point,

78
00:04:08,810 --> 00:04:13,830
I can go even further if I wanted
using the set.Dhcpv4reservation.

79
00:04:13,830 --> 00:04:15,660
And specify other values.

80
00:04:15,660 --> 00:04:17,370
You can even do custom options and

81
00:04:17,370 --> 00:04:22,070
really advanced things that are tailored
just to this particular reservation.

82
00:04:22,070 --> 00:04:25,820
But that's not as common as like, if we
wanna override something on a particular

83
00:04:25,820 --> 00:04:28,820
basis, we normally go to that
particular system and modify it there.

84
00:04:28,820 --> 00:04:32,440
So right here is pretty much the extent
of what most people are gonna

85
00:04:32,440 --> 00:04:33,075
do for reservations.

86
00:04:33,075 --> 00:04:35,190
>> Mm-hm
>> You might need to remove one,

87
00:04:35,190 --> 00:04:36,912
I guess, [INAUDIBLE].

88
00:04:36,912 --> 00:04:39,180
But otherwise, that's really about it.

89
00:04:39,180 --> 00:04:41,870
I'm trying to think of anything
else to throw in on this one Mike.

90
00:04:41,870 --> 00:04:44,770
>> All right, I can’t think of anything,
I mean, you can do the reservation or

91
00:04:44,770 --> 00:04:46,790
you can see the type
column there says both,

92
00:04:46,790 --> 00:04:52,250
they’re referring to the DHCP and
BootP, that’s one thing.

93
00:04:52,250 --> 00:04:53,200
>> Yeah, defaults to both.

94
00:04:53,200 --> 00:04:54,300
Most people just leave it at that.

95
00:04:54,300 --> 00:04:55,540
>> Yeah, absolutely.

96
00:04:55,540 --> 00:04:57,660
And they are very handy,
and a lot of people wonder,

97
00:04:57,660 --> 00:05:01,470
why not just go statically map the IP
address if you’re gonna set a reservation?

98
00:05:01,470 --> 00:05:03,320
It's really because DHCP is so
powerful, right.

99
00:05:03,320 --> 00:05:04,890
It has all those other options.

100
00:05:04,890 --> 00:05:08,970
Here, we're making sure it gets
the same IP address every time.

101
00:05:08,970 --> 00:05:10,850
But what if the DNS server changes?

102
00:05:10,850 --> 00:05:12,770
Or their default gateway changes?

103
00:05:12,770 --> 00:05:14,630
If I statically map that information,

104
00:05:14,630 --> 00:05:17,080
now I've gotta go manually
update that information.

105
00:05:17,080 --> 00:05:19,430
Here, if I change that,
if that information changes,

106
00:05:19,430 --> 00:05:21,300
I update my scope properties.

107
00:05:21,300 --> 00:05:24,590
And that client will get that new
information still getting the same IP

108
00:05:24,590 --> 00:05:25,740
address every time.

109
00:05:25,740 --> 00:05:29,443
And it can be handy like making sure I
know what the IP address of that kiosk

110
00:05:29,443 --> 00:05:30,360
machine is.

111
00:05:30,360 --> 00:05:33,550
So if I ever have troubles I can
always get in to it by IP address.

112
00:05:35,070 --> 00:05:35,800
>> It's all cool stuff.

113
00:05:36,932 --> 00:05:38,620
All right,
well that pretty much wraps this one up.

114
00:05:38,620 --> 00:05:42,260
So in this segment we got a chance to see
how to create that reservation map and

115
00:05:42,260 --> 00:05:45,180
get it in place,
take a look to hold them back up,

116
00:05:45,180 --> 00:05:47,920
return what reservations we made,
and how to remove them.

117
00:05:47,920 --> 00:05:50,587
All pretty straightforward
using the get set or

118
00:05:50,587 --> 00:05:53,794
remove -Dhcpserverv4reservation command.

119
00:05:53,794 --> 00:05:54,757
>> Mm-hm
>> All right,

120
00:05:54,757 --> 00:05:57,150
well I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

121
00:05:57,150 --> 00:05:59,041
Stay tuned,
we've got more power show coming up.

122
00:05:59,041 --> 00:06:05,549
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Monitoring Status
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,695
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,695 --> 00:00:08,535
In this segment,

3
00:00:08,535 --> 00:00:12,470
we're gonna take a look at monitoring
the status of our DHCP server.

4
00:00:12,470 --> 00:00:16,590
For the most part, when you set up a DHCP
server, you get it configured, you turn it

5
00:00:16,590 --> 00:00:20,200
on, you walk away, and you never mess
with it again, that's it, right?

6
00:00:20,200 --> 00:00:22,488
>> Until people come crying to you,
I can't get on the network,

7
00:00:22,488 --> 00:00:25,449
I can't get an IP address, and you go oh,
wow, yeah, I should check that out.

8
00:00:25,449 --> 00:00:27,736
>> So there are times when we
need to take a look at it,

9
00:00:27,736 --> 00:00:31,067
make sure things are working properly,
that we've got IPs available.

10
00:00:31,067 --> 00:00:33,308
And that's the main thing
that we need to track,

11
00:00:33,308 --> 00:00:36,730
is making sure that we don't run
out of IP addresses in our pool.

12
00:00:36,730 --> 00:00:38,320
That used to never be a problem.

13
00:00:38,320 --> 00:00:41,100
You'd create a network or
a pool size that was large enough, and

14
00:00:41,100 --> 00:00:42,400
you never worry about it.

15
00:00:42,400 --> 00:00:46,210
But recently, it's become more of
a problem where people have phones and

16
00:00:46,210 --> 00:00:47,970
tablets that are adding, doubling,

17
00:00:47,970 --> 00:00:50,335
or tripling the amount of
IPs a single person takes.

18
00:00:50,335 --> 00:00:50,930
>> Mm-hm.
>> As

19
00:00:50,930 --> 00:00:53,991
we're starting to see more smartwatches
come out now, these wearables,

20
00:00:53,991 --> 00:00:56,480
that IP utilization is really
gone through the roof.

21
00:00:56,480 --> 00:01:00,485
So keeping tabs on how much of your pool
has been leased out is pretty important.

22
00:01:00,485 --> 00:01:01,093
>> Mm-hm.

23
00:01:01,093 --> 00:01:04,067
Definitely, it is one of the big
things that we always run into is,

24
00:01:04,067 --> 00:01:06,141
I mean DHCP was a very
dynamic environment, so

25
00:01:06,141 --> 00:01:09,830
we've gotta make sure we're monitoring it,
keeping track of what's going on.

26
00:01:10,960 --> 00:01:12,127
>> All right.
So let's take a look at

27
00:01:12,127 --> 00:01:15,188
some of the commands that are available
for us for helping to monitor, right?

28
00:01:15,188 --> 00:01:19,381
There's some that we've already seen,
things like,

29
00:01:19,381 --> 00:01:22,153
Get-Service DHCPServer, right?

30
00:01:22,153 --> 00:01:25,150
If we wanna make sure that DHCP
service is actually running,

31
00:01:25,150 --> 00:01:28,500
we can quick query it and
see if that status is running or not.

32
00:01:28,500 --> 00:01:30,950
I know my server is up.

33
00:01:30,950 --> 00:01:34,500
If I'm issuing out IPs,
I should have leases, and

34
00:01:34,500 --> 00:01:38,080
I'll probably want to be able to query and
look at the leases that are out there.

35
00:01:38,080 --> 00:01:41,480
Now, you may have a ton of leases or
you may have a very small amount.

36
00:01:41,480 --> 00:01:44,780
It just depends on the size of
the client base on your system.

37
00:01:44,780 --> 00:01:47,940
But either way,
the commands are all pretty much the same.

38
00:01:47,940 --> 00:01:53,420
We can run get-DHCPServerv4Leases,
or lease.

39
00:01:53,420 --> 00:01:55,375
Sorry, it's singular.

40
00:01:55,375 --> 00:02:00,028
Get-DHCPServerv4Lease, and
you do have to specify a scope ID.

41
00:02:00,028 --> 00:02:03,709
So I'll do -ScopeID and
specify the scope that I'm looking at.

42
00:02:03,709 --> 00:02:08,210
I'm gonna look at the 192.168.29.0 scope.

43
00:02:08,210 --> 00:02:12,130
When I run that, it's gonna show
all of the leases that I have.

44
00:02:12,130 --> 00:02:12,850
Now, I've only got one,

45
00:02:12,850 --> 00:02:15,650
this is a reservation that we
created in another segment.

46
00:02:15,650 --> 00:02:20,150
I can see the IP address that's assigned,
the MAC address tied to that machine and

47
00:02:20,150 --> 00:02:22,810
it's HostName, and I can see it's state.

48
00:02:22,810 --> 00:02:28,020
Now normally you'll see Active or
InactiveReservation, like this.

49
00:02:28,020 --> 00:02:31,670
Active means that somebody's
actively using that address.

50
00:02:31,670 --> 00:02:33,710
Inactive would mean it's not in use.

51
00:02:33,710 --> 00:02:37,165
Now normally inactive means the IP
becomes available for use again.

52
00:02:37,165 --> 00:02:38,960
It'll be issued out for
use to other people.

53
00:02:38,960 --> 00:02:42,570
But InactiveReservation
means it's being held.

54
00:02:42,570 --> 00:02:45,470
This client is not up and
using the address yet, but

55
00:02:45,470 --> 00:02:48,845
if they want it, it's being reserved and
it would go active when they ask for it.

56
00:02:48,845 --> 00:02:50,150
>> Mm-hm.

57
00:02:50,150 --> 00:02:53,780
Another good one to use with
that one is that BadLeases.

58
00:02:53,780 --> 00:02:55,410
>> Oh yeah.
>> Because that's one that you'll run

59
00:02:55,410 --> 00:03:00,035
into like you've got an issue if a client,
if there's a conflict of addresses like if

60
00:03:00,035 --> 00:03:03,280
a DHCP tries to pass out an address
to a node, but then the IP

61
00:03:03,280 --> 00:03:07,340
addresses may be statically mapped to
something else and we get a conflict.

62
00:03:07,340 --> 00:03:10,480
It'll report it with that
bad lease as a parameter.

63
00:03:10,480 --> 00:03:13,880
>> Yeah, there's actually another type of
lease that might not show up by default,

64
00:03:13,880 --> 00:03:16,410
which is when you have a routing and
remote access server.

65
00:03:16,410 --> 00:03:19,800
It will grab pools of IPs to use for
VPN clients.

66
00:03:19,800 --> 00:03:22,590
>> And,
those might not show up by default too.

67
00:03:22,590 --> 00:03:23,550
So, there is another one.

68
00:03:23,550 --> 00:03:27,530
Instead of BadLeases,
we can say AllLeases.

69
00:03:27,530 --> 00:03:31,799
And now it'll show you everything,
good, bad, inactive, active,

70
00:03:31,799 --> 00:03:33,806
ones that are for remote access.

71
00:03:33,806 --> 00:03:35,456
It'll show you all leases.

72
00:03:35,456 --> 00:03:40,230
Now, in my database here I've only
got one lease, so it's no big deal.

73
00:03:40,230 --> 00:03:43,080
But, what if you've got thousands of them?

74
00:03:43,080 --> 00:03:44,740
This can get really out of hand.

75
00:03:44,740 --> 00:03:47,210
If you're looking for
something in particular,

76
00:03:47,210 --> 00:03:51,690
don't forget about the Where-Object
filter that's available, right?

77
00:03:51,690 --> 00:03:56,110
We can take our command output, and
we can pipe that into Where-Object, and

78
00:03:56,110 --> 00:03:57,660
you can filter based on anything.

79
00:03:57,660 --> 00:04:01,750
So I could say if a particular property,
like if I'm looking for a HostName,

80
00:04:03,580 --> 00:04:08,850
I could say I'm trying to find that
where it equals donlaptop, right.

81
00:04:08,850 --> 00:04:11,010
And now it's gonna return just that lease.

82
00:04:11,010 --> 00:04:14,530
Or I could say I'm looking for
a particular IP.

83
00:04:14,530 --> 00:04:21,132
So I could say the Property is
IPAddress and say it equals 10.

84
00:04:21,132 --> 00:04:27,275
192.168.29.123, and
it's gonna return that one.

85
00:04:27,275 --> 00:04:30,830
Now, the get-dhcp server v4 release,

86
00:04:30,830 --> 00:04:35,630
it does actually have a dash IP
address and dash computer name option.

87
00:04:35,630 --> 00:04:36,970
I've never been able to
get to those to work.

88
00:04:36,970 --> 00:04:39,530
We were trying during the break
before this segment started,

89
00:04:39,530 --> 00:04:41,410
because we had some
questions in the chat room.

90
00:04:41,410 --> 00:04:42,680
I've never been able to get it to work.

91
00:04:42,680 --> 00:04:46,460
So, Where-Object, you know that works,
you just parse your output together.

92
00:04:46,460 --> 00:04:52,422
So, quick, easy and
there's your information on that lease.

93
00:04:52,422 --> 00:04:55,150
There is another neat command
that I do want to show,

94
00:04:55,150 --> 00:04:58,030
which is to pull up our
DHCP server statistics.

95
00:04:58,030 --> 00:05:00,880
Sometimes you just want to know
how many IPs we have left,

96
00:05:00,880 --> 00:05:02,810
how much of our pool is in use?

97
00:05:02,810 --> 00:05:04,610
What are the statistics for our server?

98
00:05:04,610 --> 00:05:07,020
And so, there's a cool command for that.

99
00:05:07,020 --> 00:05:08,170
>> Yeah.
This is the kind of thing you want to

100
00:05:08,170 --> 00:05:12,270
monitor proactively, cuz I want to know
before I run out of IP addresses, right.

101
00:05:12,270 --> 00:05:15,800
I don't want to wait until I've got nodes
on the network that can't connect, or

102
00:05:15,800 --> 00:05:18,200
people are saying they
can't get any access.

103
00:05:18,200 --> 00:05:19,980
So you monitor those
on a regular basis and

104
00:05:19,980 --> 00:05:21,970
you can see that trend, things like that.

105
00:05:21,970 --> 00:05:23,210
If we keep going at this rate,

106
00:05:23,210 --> 00:05:25,680
in a few more weeks we're
gonna be out of IP addresses.

107
00:05:25,680 --> 00:05:28,500
So if you're not monitoring it, you're
not gonna know until there's a problem.

108
00:05:28,500 --> 00:05:31,802
>> Yeah, and
this one's a record setter for long names.

109
00:05:31,802 --> 00:05:36,520
It's Get-DhcpServerv4ScopeStatistics, and

110
00:05:36,520 --> 00:05:39,420
unfortunately tab autocomplete
really doesn't help you on this one.

111
00:05:39,420 --> 00:05:42,304
Because it's not unique until you
get to that [INAUDIBLE] key word.

112
00:05:42,304 --> 00:05:45,624
But, it's a long one and then you just
tell it the scope that you want to see.

113
00:05:45,624 --> 00:05:50,283
I'm gonna say scope id 192.168.29.0,
and when you run that,

114
00:05:50,283 --> 00:05:53,270
you'll get some information back on it.

115
00:05:53,270 --> 00:05:58,540
The scope id, how many free or
in use leases that it has,

116
00:05:58,540 --> 00:06:02,070
the percentage in use, the reserved IP's.

117
00:06:02,070 --> 00:06:04,790
Any pending leases,
where we've offered to somebody, but

118
00:06:04,790 --> 00:06:06,500

it benefited us here

But either way pulling up basic statistics

00:08:43,940 --> 00:08:46,770
>> Like I said, it really should be

it kind of gets outside of

00:09:19,137 --> 00:09:21,681
It's what's packaged

episodes.title: Installing Active Directory
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:01,040 --> 00:00:03,790
In this

2
00:00:08,530 --> 00:00:11,740
segment, we're gonna take a look at
installing the active directory domain

3
00:00:11,740 --> 00:00:13,620
services using PowerShell.

4
00:00:14,930 --> 00:00:18,590
So, one of the first things you're gonna
do if you're setting up a new forest, or

5
00:00:18,590 --> 00:00:21,660
if you're adding another
domain to your forest, or

6
00:00:21,660 --> 00:00:24,180
if you're adding an additional
domain controller.

7
00:00:24,180 --> 00:00:27,530
To an existing domain, part of
installing the active directory and

8
00:00:27,530 --> 00:00:30,210
getting that configured
is installing the role.

9
00:00:30,210 --> 00:00:32,920
So let's take a look at how we
can do that through PowerShell.

10
00:00:32,920 --> 00:00:35,710
If we pull up my screen here, the command
is pretty straightforward it's just going

11
00:00:35,710 --> 00:00:40,900
to be install dash windows feature, And

12
00:00:40,900 --> 00:00:46,840
then the name of the role that I want
to install, dash name parameter and

13
00:00:46,840 --> 00:00:52,030
the name is going to be AD
dash domain dash services.

14
00:00:52,030 --> 00:00:55,980
So that's the name of the role
that I want to install.

15
00:00:55,980 --> 00:00:59,730
I also have to decide whether or not I
want to include the management tools.

16
00:00:59,730 --> 00:01:01,610
In this case, I am going to, so

17
00:01:01,610 --> 00:01:06,480
I'll do the include Management tools,
and I'll hit Enter, and

18
00:01:06,480 --> 00:01:10,600
that's gonna go ahead and install the role
active directory domain services.

19
00:01:10,600 --> 00:01:14,760
Now, remember while this is installing,
when you install a role like this,

20
00:01:14,760 --> 00:01:17,170
once it's finished,
I don't have a domain controller, right?

21
00:01:17,170 --> 00:01:20,860
But I've installed all the pieces,
I've unpacked all the pieces necessary

22
00:01:20,860 --> 00:01:24,460
To make this a domain controller,
but I still have to go back and

23
00:01:24,460 --> 00:01:28,060
actually configure the Active
Directory Domain Services role, so

24
00:01:28,060 --> 00:01:29,600
that I can make this a domain controller.

25
00:01:29,600 --> 00:01:32,460
So this command is just
installing the role.

26
00:01:32,460 --> 00:01:35,320
So probably what we should do here
is take a little TV time out,

27
00:01:35,320 --> 00:01:38,470
Let this finish installing the role,
we'll come back and

28
00:01:38,470 --> 00:01:43,130
we'll verify that, that role got installed
successfully, and we'll go from there.

29
00:01:43,130 --> 00:01:45,068
So, we'll see you guys back
here in just a couple minutes.

30
00:01:45,068 --> 00:01:52,837
[MUSIC]

31
00:01:52,837 --> 00:01:54,875
So, that command has completed, and

32
00:01:54,875 --> 00:01:59,610
let's see if we can verify that that
role got installed successfully.

33
00:01:59,610 --> 00:02:01,390
So, we take a look at my screen here.

34
00:02:01,390 --> 00:02:05,290
I can see the exit code was success,
so everything looks good.

35
00:02:05,290 --> 00:02:09,340
So, how do I verify that it
actually installed that role?

36
00:02:09,340 --> 00:02:11,620
My favorite way is just to
get a list of the commands.

37
00:02:11,620 --> 00:02:14,350
Make sure that they module for
active directory got installed.

38
00:02:14,350 --> 00:02:18,520
By installing that role that's gonna
include the active directory module for

39
00:02:18,520 --> 00:02:19,700
Windows powershell.

40
00:02:19,700 --> 00:02:23,900
So that it'll have all the commands
necessary to work with active directory

41
00:02:23,900 --> 00:02:26,920
as well as the active
directory deployment module.

42
00:02:26,920 --> 00:02:31,780
All the commands I need to create
a forest, create a new child domain,

43
00:02:31,780 --> 00:02:34,000
add additional domain controllers and
things like that.

44
00:02:34,000 --> 00:02:37,840
So let's just do a real
quick Get command and

45
00:02:37,840 --> 00:02:43,040
then I'm going to pull up the module,
let's verify that ADDS deployment module,

46
00:02:43,040 --> 00:02:49,580
so ADDS deployment is the name of
the module I hit enter and sure enough

47
00:02:49,580 --> 00:02:54,000
there's a list of commands I now have
available which is a good indication that

48
00:02:54,000 --> 00:02:57,810
that active directory role was installed,
again I don't have a domain controller,

49
00:02:57,810 --> 00:03:02,295
I don't have a domain, I didn't create
anything, All I did was install the roll.

50
00:03:02,295 --> 00:03:05,735
And in future segment's we'll go back and
we'll take a look at these commands.

51
00:03:05,735 --> 00:03:10,485
Like the first one we'll be using
is gonna install that ADDSForest.

52
00:03:10,485 --> 00:03:13,415
Create that first domain
in our organization.

53
00:03:13,415 --> 00:03:17,595
Then in future segments we'll take a look
at adding, creating a child domain,

54
00:03:17,595 --> 00:03:21,480
adding additional domain
controllers to an existing domain.

55
00:03:21,480 --> 00:03:23,190
And so on.

56
00:03:23,190 --> 00:03:27,610
So in this episode all we really did
was we saw how to install the role.

57
00:03:27,610 --> 00:03:31,500
In future segments we'll take a look
at adding our domain controllers and

58
00:03:31,500 --> 00:03:32,480
we'll go from there.

59
00:03:32,480 --> 00:03:34,110
So I hope you guys enjoyed it.

60
00:03:34,110 --> 00:03:34,970
Stay tuned.

61
00:03:34,970 --> 00:03:37,091
More PowerShell coming your way.

62
00:03:37,091 --> 00:03:42,239
[MUSIC]

1

In this segment, we're gonna take a look

3
00:00:12,680 --> 00:00:14,250

00:00:14,250 --> 00:00:18,000
If you're just getting started with

5
00:00:18,000 --> 00:00:21,215
Right, we need to get that forest

00:00:21,215 --> 00:00:22,851
the Active Directory feature and

7
00:00:22,851 --> 00:00:25,940
bringing up our first
Active Directory domain controllers.

8
00:00:25,940 --> 00:00:27,950
So that's what we're gonna kick off,
right here.

9
00:00:27,950 --> 00:00:29,450

All right, so

00:00:29,450 --> 00:00:32,250
just like when you were installing Active
Directory through the GUI there's really

00:00:32,250 --> 00:00:33,590
a two step process right?

12
00:00:33,590 --> 00:00:36,650
First you have to install
the role which unpacks all

00:00:36,650 --> 00:00:38,680

00:00:38,680 --> 00:00:41,870

00:00:41,870 --> 00:00:44,280
You still have to go
through the configuration.

16
00:00:44,280 --> 00:00:46,800
So we pull up my screen here, the first

00:00:46,800 --> 00:00:48,780
and we've seen this on our
other PowerShell segments,

00:00:48,780 --> 00:00:51,860
it's just gonna be our

00:00:54,570 --> 00:00:58,500
And there we go, Install-windowsFeature,
and then the name of that feature that we

20
00:00:58,500 --> 00:01:03,320

be the AD-domain-services.

21
00:01:03,320 --> 00:01:06,569
So AD-domain-services, and

22
00:01:06,569 --> 00:01:11,861
as we've said before in
a couple of other segments,

23
00:01:11,861 --> 00:01:18,734
I've got a choice here,
if I want to install the management tools.

24
00:01:18,734 --> 00:01:21,054
This is going to be a full blown server,
so

25
00:01:21,054 --> 00:01:23,651
we are going to include
the management tools.

26
00:01:25,300 --> 00:01:27,940
I'll hit Enter, and
that shouldn't take very long.

27
00:01:27,940 --> 00:01:30,690
It'll unpack all those files,
and get this ready for

28
00:01:30,690 --> 00:01:32,160
me to make our domain controller.

29
00:01:32,160 --> 00:01:34,830
And as Don was saying,
the first one we bring up,

30
00:01:34,830 --> 00:01:36,680
the first I have nothing on this network.

31
00:01:36,680 --> 00:01:39,700
So the first server I take, and
I install an Active Directory on,

32
00:01:39,700 --> 00:01:41,760
that's going to be my forced
root domain controller...

33
00:01:41,760 --> 00:01:44,980
Right, that's the one that's gonna
have a couple of things that no other

34
00:01:44,980 --> 00:01:47,110
domain controllers gonna
have in my environment.

35
00:01:47,110 --> 00:01:52,830
It's gonna have the scheme admins group,
my enterprise admins group, what else.

36
00:01:52,830 --> 00:01:57,350
That's where the only writable copy
of the schema's gonna be located so

37
00:01:57,350 --> 00:02:00,170
it our special domain controller.

38
00:02:00,170 --> 00:02:03,370
It's got those two forest-wide FSMOs,
right.

39
00:02:03,370 --> 00:02:06,570
The schema master and the domain
naming master are gonna be on there.

40
00:02:08,000 --> 00:02:10,390
>> Yeah, it's a pretty important one.

41
00:02:10,390 --> 00:02:13,540
All these tools, at least at this stage,
are identical no matter what we're doing.

42
00:02:13,540 --> 00:02:16,470
But once we do that setup,
this will be a pretty big step.

43
00:02:16,470 --> 00:02:19,970
Now there is other infrastructure
we probably need to have in

44
00:02:19,970 --> 00:02:22,270
place before we jump
through a lot of this and

45
00:02:22,270 --> 00:02:24,790
we've covered it in some of out other
segments so we don't want to do it here.

46
00:02:24,790 --> 00:02:27,980
But you'll typically need things like
a DNS server to be able to store your

47
00:02:27,980 --> 00:02:28,930
records.

48
00:02:28,930 --> 00:02:32,330
You may need a DHCP server
to support your clients and

49
00:02:32,330 --> 00:02:34,930
so on, So right here step one,
you might not be

50
00:02:34,930 --> 00:02:38,580
ready to just jump right into deploying
that active directory but once

51
00:02:38,580 --> 00:02:41,510
you've got your infrastructure in place
the steps are pretty straight forward.

52
00:02:41,510 --> 00:02:43,530
>> They really are.

53
00:02:43,530 --> 00:02:46,870
>> In typical Microsoft fashion
we're gonna sit here at 91%.

54
00:02:46,870 --> 00:02:47,825
>> [LAUGH]
>> Waiting, that's.

55
00:02:47,825 --> 00:02:48,815
>> Right.

56
00:02:48,815 --> 00:02:50,215
All the way to the end and stop.

57
00:02:50,215 --> 00:02:52,835
So once we get this rolling here,
we'll do a quick

58
00:02:52,835 --> 00:02:56,815
command that we wanna make sure that
the role got installed properly.

59
00:02:56,815 --> 00:02:59,150
And an easy way to do that through
PowerShell is just to get a list of

60
00:02:59,150 --> 00:03:00,160
all the commands, right?

61
00:03:00,160 --> 00:03:04,140
Cuz when we installed it that should
include the active directory module for

62
00:03:04,140 --> 00:03:09,700
Windows PowerShell as well as
the ADDS deployment module.

63
00:03:09,700 --> 00:03:13,370
This is a module they've added recently
that gives me the ability to run

64
00:03:13,370 --> 00:03:17,800
all these commands like add ADDS porous,
and add ADDS domain,

65
00:03:17,800 --> 00:03:19,910
a domain controller and things like that.

66
00:03:19,910 --> 00:03:24,080
So there we go the command is finished,
looks I've got an Exit Code of Success.

67
00:03:24,080 --> 00:03:26,530
So hopefully everything went well.

68
00:03:26,530 --> 00:03:32,560
As I said, the next thing I'm gonna
do is just gonna be a Get-Command and

69
00:03:32,560 --> 00:03:38,670
then, -module, and
the name of that module is addsdeployment.

70
00:03:40,190 --> 00:03:41,810
And as the tab auto-fill work,

71
00:03:41,810 --> 00:03:45,096
which pretty good indication
that it's gonna be there, right.

72
00:03:45,096 --> 00:03:46,890
>> [LAUGH]
>> So hit enter.

73
00:03:46,890 --> 00:03:51,200
And here you can see the commands,
and now I can use to deploy my domain

74
00:03:51,200 --> 00:03:55,630
controllers and set up my active

00:01:27,205 --> 00:01:30,675
And the command for that, and this guy
I've already installed the role, right?

31
00:01:30,675 --> 00:01:33,748
The role active directory domain
service has been installed.

32
00:01:33,748 --> 00:01:39,344
The next thing we're gonna do
is configure it as a domain

00:01:39,344 --> 00:01:44,583
controller, and from PowerShell,
the command for

00:01:44,583 --> 00:01:50,908
that is gonna be install,
-ADDomain, sorry, ADDSDomain.

35
00:01:50,908 --> 00:01:51,610
I always forget that DS in there.

36
00:01:51,610 --> 00:01:53,110
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

37
00:01:53,110 --> 00:01:54,720
active directory domain service domain.

38
00:01:54,720 --> 00:01:58,060
And then the parameters I'm gonna use with
this, first thing I've gotta do is I gotta

00:01:58,060 --> 00:02:01,480
specify what the name of this
new child domain is going to be.

40
00:02:01,480 --> 00:02:04,530
And the parameter for
that is new domain name.

41
00:02:04,530 --> 00:02:07,395
So newdomainname.

42
00:02:07,395 --> 00:02:09,320
And then we're gonna call this one lab.

00:02:09,320 --> 00:02:14,090
Now you could type out
the fqtnlab.itprotv.net but

00:02:14,090 --> 00:02:15,970
it knows that if it's
gonna be a child domain,

00:02:15,970 --> 00:02:18,978

46
00:02:18,978 --> 00:02:24,010
You have specified who that
parent domain name is, or

00:02:24,010 --> 00:02:25,840
what that parent domain name is.

00:02:25,840 --> 00:02:29,200
So it knows what tree, you might have

00:02:29,200 --> 00:02:31,940

00:02:31,940 --> 00:02:38,008
In our case, that's gonna be ITProTV.net.

51
00:02:38,008 --> 00:02:39,300
And then I've got to have credentials,
right?

52
00:02:39,300 --> 00:02:41,460
What we did in the previous segment,

00:02:41,460 --> 00:02:44,500
when we added that forest root there

00:02:44,500 --> 00:02:48,520
I was logged on as the administrator

00:02:48,520 --> 00:02:52,250
I ran through the configuration

00:02:52,250 --> 00:02:53,090
Now when you come and

add a child domain, you're adding

00:02:57,180 --> 00:02:59,770
To an existing forest, so you're gonna

60
00:03:02,590 --> 00:03:07,680
And for security purposes I'm gonna type

00:03:07,680 --> 00:03:11,670
And you could specify the user account

00:03:11,670 --> 00:03:15,760

account in that forest root.

00:03:15,760 --> 00:03:20,740
For security, though,

00:03:27,260 --> 00:03:29,950

00:03:29,950 --> 00:03:34,710
This way it's going to prompt me as I run

68
00:03:34,710 --> 00:03:37,330
And that's really all

00:03:37,330 --> 00:03:39,770
That'd be the required parameters.

00:03:39,770 --> 00:03:40,680
I'm gonna add a couple more.

I wanna do an install-DNS so we can have

00:03:46,815 --> 00:03:50,585
And I'm also gonna go ahead and

00:03:50,585 --> 00:03:55,277
That way it'll go ahead and it'll go up
to that forest root, it'll go to that DNS

00:03:55,277 --> 00:03:59,279
server, and delegate authority for
that portion of the name space,

75
00:03:59,279 --> 00:04:02,946
lab.itprotv.net to the DNS
server that I'm creating here.

00:04:02,946 --> 00:04:05,858
And that's just going to save me
time from having to go back and

00:04:05,858 --> 00:04:07,660
do that as an extra step in the future.

00:04:07,660 --> 00:04:10,771
So we'll create that DNS delegation.

79
00:04:10,771 --> 00:04:14,440
As we saw in some previous segments,

00:04:14,440 --> 00:04:18,425
a change where the database in being

00:04:18,425 --> 00:04:20,640
I'm just going to skip that here.

I'm also gonna skip the prechecks.

In the real world you would obviously want

00:04:26,360 --> 00:04:30,035

85
00:04:30,035 --> 00:04:34,955
To speed things up here I'm just gonna

00:04:34,955 --> 00:04:36,015
double check.

One other parameter I'm not gonna use,

Now, DomainType, cuz if I'm adding

00:04:45,880 --> 00:04:50,760
be adding, as Don says, as an additional

00:04:50,760 --> 00:04:53,400
I could also be making a new tree,

00:04:54,480 --> 00:04:58,740
In which case, I would just specify

00:04:58,740 --> 00:05:01,670
I could do tree domain,
I could also do child domain.

93
00:05:03,810 --> 00:05:08,640
And if I don't specify anything, it's
gonna assume or default to child domain.

94
00:05:08,640 --> 00:05:09,679
We'll go ahead and run that.

95
00:05:10,880 --> 00:05:15,654
And it's gonna ask me what

00:05:15,654 --> 00:05:20,246
this domain to the forest and

00:05:20,246 --> 00:05:24,870
Use my administrator account and

I could specify that parameter in

00:05:37,410 --> 00:05:39,400
And you'll see it puts

00:05:43,002 --> 00:05:46,270
All right, then I'll say yes to

00:05:47,710 --> 00:05:49,970
And now it's gonna go through the process.

I'm gonna to get the same warnings I

And that should be the only one I

create that delegation up

00:06:07,480 --> 00:06:09,870
>> And now it's going to take a moment to

this is actually a little more involved

When we created a forest, an empty copy

But here, it's actually gotta reach

Give server manager a chance to fire

00:07:22,630 --> 00:07:24,718
And in fact,

00:07:24,718 --> 00:07:27,260

00:07:27,260 --> 00:07:32,298
While I'm waiting for server manager

So that's pointing over

00:07:51,553 --> 00:07:55,610
who is that new domain controller

00:07:55,610 --> 00:07:56,800
So that worked great.

That create DNS delegation.

00:07:59,770 --> 00:08:03,820
Flip back over to server two,

00:08:03,820 --> 00:08:08,390
Server manager still gathering

00:08:08,390 --> 00:08:09,970
There it goes.

And that is the active directory

I flip over to my DNS console,

The server managers,

you've gotta wait until it's done

If you try to go before that,

And here we go, open up DNS.

And I should see that serve two

00:08:35,134 --> 00:08:38,306
I can see my records in there,

It detected,

We use that install dash

>> Yep,

1

2
00:00:08,000 --> 00:00:12,070
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at creating additional domain controllers

3
00:00:12,070 --> 00:00:13,208
in an existing domain.

4
00:00:13,208 --> 00:00:16,568
And this is probably, of the various
examples that we've done so far,

5
00:00:16,568 --> 00:00:18,390
this is probably the most common.

6
00:00:18,390 --> 00:00:19,040
Right?

7
00:00:19,040 --> 00:00:22,400
People don't create new forest and
new domains everyday.

8
00:00:22,400 --> 00:00:25,370
But people do create new domain
controllers all of the time for

9
00:00:25,370 --> 00:00:27,980
existing domains and forests.

10
00:00:27,980 --> 00:00:31,170

pretty straight forward, right Mike?

11
00:00:31,170 --> 00:00:31,925
>> It really is.

12
00:00:31,925 --> 00:00:33,750
A pretty straight forward command.

13
00:00:33,750 --> 00:00:39,380
I've got a server here, we've already got
our domain set up we've got ITProTV.net.

14
00:00:39,380 --> 00:00:41,272
And what I've done is I've
brought up another server,

15
00:00:41,272 --> 00:00:43,580
and I want to add a second
domain controller.

16
00:00:43,580 --> 00:00:46,980
As Don said, this is something you do
much more regularly for fault tolerance,

17
00:00:46,980 --> 00:00:50,310
for deploying out to a new office,
or something like that.

18
00:00:50,310 --> 00:00:54,290
So the command, once I've got that roll
installed, if you've watched the previous

19
00:00:54,290 --> 00:01:00,200
segments, to create the domain,
it was install-adds domain.

20
00:01:00,200 --> 00:01:03,200
Once you've got the domain created,
now when you're adding another domain

00:01:03,200 --> 00:01:05,240
controller, you're not creating
another domain, right?

22
00:01:05,240 --> 00:01:08,265
You're adding a domain controller to
an existing domain if you think back

23
00:01:08,265 --> 00:01:09,230
to your GUI.

24
00:01:09,230 --> 00:01:11,458
So the command, the noun,
is slightly different.

25
00:01:11,458 --> 00:01:18,667
It's gonna be
install-ADDSDomainController, right?

26
00:01:18,667 --> 00:01:20,750
Instead of just ADDSDomain.

27
00:01:20,750 --> 00:01:22,780
And then the parameters
are pretty straightforward.

28
00:01:22,780 --> 00:01:25,400
As always, there's a whole bunch
of parameters that you can use.

29
00:01:25,400 --> 00:01:27,880
I'm gonna give you guys a link
to Technet so you can go out and

30
00:01:27,880 --> 00:01:29,560
see some of those additional parameters.

31
00:01:29,560 --> 00:01:32,740
But if you just need a second or
third or fourth domain controller,

32
00:01:32,740 --> 00:01:37,130
all you need to do is use the command
install-ADDSDomainController.

33
00:01:37,130 --> 00:01:38,310
I am going to put DNS on here.

34
00:01:38,310 --> 00:01:43,720
So I'll do a little install,
or -installdns.

35
00:01:43,720 --> 00:01:48,520
And then the name of the domain that
I'm adding this domain controller to.

36
00:01:48,520 --> 00:01:49,990
The parameter is going to be domain name.

37
00:01:49,990 --> 00:01:56,635
And the name of the domain I'm adding
this to is going to be ITProTV.net.

38
00:02:01,540 --> 00:02:07,460
Let's see if I am going to,
I'm logged onto this guy as local.

39
00:02:07,460 --> 00:02:10,440
I probably am going to
need credentials for that.

40
00:02:10,440 --> 00:02:11,855
Let's see what it says.

00:02:11,855 --> 00:02:13,290
>> [LAUGH] Wait a minute.

00:02:13,290 --> 00:02:15,470
You need credentials to be able

00:02:15,470 --> 00:02:16,390
What's that all about?

00:02:16,390 --> 00:02:20,470
>> I was trying to think if I
set this guy as a, I guess.

45
00:02:20,470 --> 00:02:24,470
So let me add, all I'm gonna do is
add a credentials switch to this.

46
00:02:24,470 --> 00:02:27,520
So just like we did in our previous
segment, I'm gonna do a -credential.

47
00:02:27,520 --> 00:02:29,570
>> Mike, your head's covering that up so
we can't see it all.

48
00:02:29,570 --> 00:02:30,945
>> Sorry,
let's bring that up a little bit.

49
00:02:30,945 --> 00:02:32,885
Or let's just clear that
screen a little bit.

50
00:02:32,885 --> 00:02:35,800
[LAUGH] All right, so
we'll do that one more time.

51
00:02:35,800 --> 00:02:38,760
So what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna take
that same command that I ran, and

52
00:02:38,760 --> 00:02:41,600
I'm gonna add a -credential.

53
00:02:41,600 --> 00:02:43,520
Because this guy's not a member server,
right?

54
00:02:43,520 --> 00:02:44,920
He's in a work group right now.

55
00:02:44,920 --> 00:02:48,120
So I'm logged on as a local admin
who's not gonna have any rights within

56
00:02:48,120 --> 00:02:50,470
the domain that I'm trying to add this to.

57
00:02:50,470 --> 00:02:56,180
So -credential and
then I'll do a get -credential

58
00:02:56,180 --> 00:03:00,770
to have it prompt me for
those credentials, all right?

59
00:03:00,770 --> 00:03:09,050
So there we go, I'm going to
give it ITProTV\administrator.

60
00:03:09,050 --> 00:03:12,208
Make sure I spell that right.

61
00:03:12,208 --> 00:03:16,917
And then my DSRM password, my
Directory Service Restore Mode password.

62
00:03:21,375 --> 00:03:25,312
And there it goes, it's gonna run through
the process of creating that additional

63
00:03:25,312 --> 00:03:26,333
domain controller.

64
00:03:26,333 --> 00:03:28,805
Another switch, as I said,
I'll give you guys a link to TechNet so

65
00:03:28,805 --> 00:03:30,495
you can go out and
look at all the parameters.

66
00:03:30,495 --> 00:03:35,370
Another one you might find useful
in some situations, is there is a,

67
00:03:35,370 --> 00:03:37,810
oh gosh, if I can remember the actual
wording of this parameter.

68
00:03:37,810 --> 00:03:39,840
You can actually skip
a lot of the initial,

00:03:39,840 --> 00:03:42,700
it's called dash critical replication.

70
00:03:42,700 --> 00:03:46,370
And what it'll do is, instead of
replicating the entire active directory

71
00:03:46,370 --> 00:03:51,030
database and getting it all set up before
the reboot, it'll just do the critical

72
00:03:51,030 --> 00:03:53,820
replication and go ahead and reboot and
get that guy up and running.

73
00:03:53,820 --> 00:03:57,830
And then it will replicate
the other noncritical information

74
00:03:57,830 --> 00:03:59,340
as it has time in the background.

75
00:03:59,340 --> 00:04:01,120
So, it can kind of speed up the process,
or

76
00:04:01,120 --> 00:04:03,679
the deployment, of new domain controllers.

77
00:04:05,060 --> 00:04:06,750
While that guy's running,

78
00:04:06,750 --> 00:04:10,870
what I was gonna show you next is
a read-only domain controller.

79
00:04:10,870 --> 00:04:12,360
So, that's the command for

80
00:04:12,360 --> 00:04:16,090
installing an additional domain
controller in an existing domain.

81
00:04:16,090 --> 00:04:20,563
Another thing that we can do from
PowerShell is to create a read-only domain

82
00:04:20,563 --> 00:04:21,340
controller.

83
00:04:21,340 --> 00:04:24,975
The command is actually the same
commandlet, so it's going to be

84
00:04:24,975 --> 00:04:30,980
install-ADSDomainController, just
like we did just now.

85
00:04:30,980 --> 00:04:36,730
The difference is, we're gonna add
this -ReadOnlyReplica, all right?

86
00:04:36,730 --> 00:04:41,125
That's going to indicate that it is
a Read Only Domain Controller, or an RODC.

87
00:04:41,125 --> 00:04:43,645
You could stop there.

88
00:04:43,645 --> 00:04:46,295
There's some other parameters
you can use if you're doing

89
00:04:46,295 --> 00:04:47,435
a Read Only Domain Controller.

90
00:04:47,435 --> 00:04:50,979
Like, you might want to go ahead and set
who the delegated administrator account is

91
00:04:50,979 --> 00:04:54,080
going to be, or what group is going
to have administrator permissions.

92
00:04:54,080 --> 00:04:57,560
Remember we've learned that with
an RODC you actually have a local

93
00:04:57,560 --> 00:05:00,060
admins group that you can give
somebody permissions over.

94
00:05:00,060 --> 00:05:01,670
Another useful parameter you'll find for

95
00:05:01,670 --> 00:05:06,640
RODCs is this
-AllowPasswordReplicationAccountName.

96
00:05:06,640 --> 00:05:11,270
Remember RODCs do not cache passwords or
any passwords by default.

97
00:05:11,270 --> 00:05:14,620
We get to pick and choose whose passwords
are cached out there on that RODC.

98
00:05:14,620 --> 00:05:16,070
This is how I can go ahead and

99
00:05:16,070 --> 00:05:20,580
specify what user's passwords will
be allowed to be cached on that.

100
00:05:20,580 --> 00:05:23,130
What I've done here is I've
actually got an empty string.

101
00:05:23,130 --> 00:05:25,850
I've got quote,
quote with nothing in-between there.

102
00:05:25,850 --> 00:05:30,220
That's gonna ensure that that allow
password replication group list is blank.

103
00:05:30,220 --> 00:05:31,700
That there's nobody in there.

104
00:05:31,700 --> 00:05:36,670
You could also do
a -DenyPasswordReplecationAccountName,

105
00:05:36,670 --> 00:05:41,000
which would let you set up the ones you
wanted to insure were not replicated over

106
00:05:41,000 --> 00:05:46,400
to that RODC, but the allow password
replication group is blank by default.

107
00:05:46,400 --> 00:05:49,440
So, I blanked it out anyway,
but it is blank by default.

108
00:05:49,440 --> 00:05:52,590
The denied RODC password
replication group is not blank.

109
00:05:52,590 --> 00:05:56,520
There is some key accounts in there that
it already knows it's not supposed to

110
00:05:56,520 --> 00:05:57,510
allow to be cached.

111
00:05:57,510 --> 00:06:00,560
Like the domain admins,
the enterprise admins, scheme admins,

112
00:06:00,560 --> 00:06:01,460
and things like that.

113
00:06:01,460 --> 00:06:03,640
So if I start that list in this parameter,

114
00:06:03,640 --> 00:06:05,250
then I would have to make
sure I included all those.

115
00:06:05,250 --> 00:06:07,740
Because it would wipe it
add only what I added here.

116
00:06:07,740 --> 00:06:11,140
So typically you're not going to use
that parameter when you're running

117
00:06:11,140 --> 00:06:12,730
this command.

118
00:06:12,730 --> 00:06:15,000
Also if you had pre-created.

119
00:06:15,000 --> 00:06:18,682
Typically we're going to pre-create
the read only domain controller account in

120
00:06:18,682 --> 00:06:20,000
active directory.

121
00:06:20,000 --> 00:06:25,780
And if I have, then there's a command
dash or a parameter -UseExistingAccount.

122
00:06:25,780 --> 00:06:28,340
And that's gonna tell it to go look for
the account in active directory,

123
00:06:28,340 --> 00:06:29,610
it's already there.

124
00:06:29,610 --> 00:06:33,430
And to match up that physical server
with that account active directory.

125
00:06:33,430 --> 00:06:37,159
So just a few of those parameters we can
use if I'm trying to set up a read-only

126
00:06:37,159 --> 00:06:38,300
domain controller.

127
00:06:38,300 --> 00:06:39,960
Again, I've got links
in the show notes here,

128
00:06:39,960 --> 00:06:42,560
I'll make sure you have access to those.

So that should have given
serve two enough time.

Let's go back over there and

It's in the process of

I'm in that domain controller as OU.

So I do now have a second domain

We'll flip back over.

Server one is still in

>> And like we said earlier,

segments how to create new forests and

But those aren't things

Adding domain controllers like this is if

Logging in, setting up my profile for

>> The real power with this is that idea

Maybe you work for a school system and you

Well you don't wanna have to manually

episodes.title: Managing OUs
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,113
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,113 --> 00:00:09,005
In this segment,

3
00:00:09,005 --> 00:00:13,760
we're gonna be taking a look at managing
organizational units with the PowerShell.

4
00:00:13,760 --> 00:00:16,940
Organizational units are a pretty key
piece inside of the active directory.

5
00:00:16,940 --> 00:00:20,020
Because they're how we sort our various
user accounts, computer accounts,

6
00:00:20,020 --> 00:00:20,890
and other items.

7
00:00:20,890 --> 00:00:24,490
And if you're applying group policy
objects organizational units are kind of

8
00:00:24,490 --> 00:00:27,340
that key thing that defines
where they're going to apply.

9
00:00:27,340 --> 00:00:28,680
So they're real important.

10
00:00:28,680 --> 00:00:31,130
Well, most of us don't create
these on a daily basis but

11
00:00:31,130 --> 00:00:35,270
if you're ever in a situation where you
need to create a large quantity of OU's.

12
00:00:35,270 --> 00:00:38,510
It is far easier to script it and
automate it from the PowerShell

13
00:00:38,510 --> 00:00:41,640
than it is to go to the GUI and
manually create OU after OU.

14
00:00:41,640 --> 00:00:43,910
So, that's what we're going
to be taking a look at and

15
00:00:43,910 --> 00:00:46,370
Mike you've got some great
examples lined up for us, right?

16
00:00:46,370 --> 00:00:48,020
>> I do, so
lets take a look at my screen here.

17
00:00:48,020 --> 00:00:51,880
The first thing we're going to do is
simply create an organizational unit.

18
00:00:51,880 --> 00:00:57,030
And the command is pretty straight forward
its just new-ad organizational unit.

19
00:00:57,030 --> 00:01:01,240
As with most of our PowerShell commands,
there's several parameters we can use,

20
00:01:01,240 --> 00:01:02,840
most of them optional.

21
00:01:02,840 --> 00:01:05,360
In fact, the only required parameter

22
00:01:05,360 --> 00:01:08,480
is going to be the name that you want
to give that organizational unit.

23
00:01:08,480 --> 00:01:13,100
So if I just do new-AD organizational unit
and then the name test and hit enter.

24
00:01:13,100 --> 00:01:15,680
You see I don't get any red text back and

25
00:01:15,680 --> 00:01:19,320
if I flip back over to active
directory and refresh that console.

26
00:01:19,320 --> 00:01:23,050
There is my new organizational
unit called test.

27
00:01:23,050 --> 00:01:24,245
All right, so very simple.

28
00:01:24,245 --> 00:01:27,840
New-AD organizational unit and
then the name of the OU.

29
00:01:27,840 --> 00:01:29,230
Let's take it a step further, though.

30
00:01:29,230 --> 00:01:32,370
Let's do a new-AD organizational unit.

31
00:01:32,370 --> 00:01:34,150
And for the first one I'm
going to kind of copy that.

32
00:01:34,150 --> 00:01:36,290
I want to make one called user accounts.

33
00:01:36,290 --> 00:01:37,700
The parameter,

34
00:01:37,700 --> 00:01:41,450
you'll notice on the previous example
I didn't specify any parameters.

35
00:01:41,450 --> 00:01:42,910
I just put the word test.

36
00:01:42,910 --> 00:01:44,960
It assumes it's the only
required parameter.

37
00:01:44,960 --> 00:01:47,780
It's a positional parameter,
I don't need anything else.

38
00:01:47,780 --> 00:01:52,590
But I could do a -name, and then the name
I wanted to give the organizational unit.

39
00:01:52,590 --> 00:01:55,090
Like user accounts for example.

40
00:01:57,140 --> 00:01:59,360
Again, I go back in and
look at active directory and

41
00:01:59,360 --> 00:02:04,080
I'll see that at the root, I should
have a new OU called user accounts.

42
00:02:05,570 --> 00:02:07,890
That works well because I
didn't provide the path,

43
00:02:07,890 --> 00:02:11,380
I didn't tell it where in active directory
I wanted to make the organizational unit.

44
00:02:11,380 --> 00:02:15,230
So it just had to assume
that the root of my domain.

45
00:02:15,230 --> 00:02:17,050
But, if we want to start nesting OUs,

46
00:02:17,050 --> 00:02:21,390
get a little fancy, we're going to
change this up just a little bit.

47
00:02:21,390 --> 00:02:23,570
I'm going to create one called employees.

48
00:02:25,170 --> 00:02:28,720
And I want to make it inside
that user accounts OU.

49
00:02:28,720 --> 00:02:32,840
So, all I'm going to do is I'm going
to add a -path parameter and then

50
00:02:32,840 --> 00:02:36,390
the distinguished name, or the location,
of where I want to create the OU.

51
00:02:36,390 --> 00:02:40,463
So in this case, I want to make it inside
that other OU called user accounts.

52
00:02:42,320 --> 00:02:45,938
And then as with most of our
distinguished names, OU=useraccounts,

53
00:02:45,938 --> 00:02:47,879
and then all of my domain components.

54
00:02:47,879 --> 00:02:52,343
So dc=itprotv, dc=net,

55
00:02:52,343 --> 00:02:58,682
if I make sure I type that in there right.

56
00:02:58,682 --> 00:03:00,390
>> [LAUGH]
>> DC=net, and

57
00:03:00,390 --> 00:03:04,450
my quote,
I should be able to enter no red text.

58
00:03:04,450 --> 00:03:07,665
We flip back over to active directory and
do a little refresh.

59
00:03:07,665 --> 00:03:12,335
And now inside user accounts I
have a nested OU called employees.

60
00:03:12,335 --> 00:03:14,365
And that's typically what we're doing,
right?

61
00:03:14,365 --> 00:03:19,115
We're organizing my objects so that I
can delegate administrative control and

62
00:03:19,115 --> 00:03:21,100
scope my group policies.

63
00:03:21,100 --> 00:03:25,170
So we're nesting our OU's according
to whatever our business model is.

64
00:03:26,550 --> 00:03:29,290
But once you get them created,
again there's a lot of other parameters.

65
00:03:29,290 --> 00:03:32,560
I've got a link in the show notes that I
give you to Tech Net that will give you

66
00:03:32,560 --> 00:03:35,670
a bunch of additional parameters
that you can set on there.

67
00:03:37,450 --> 00:03:38,730
Other things we might wanna do.

68
00:03:38,730 --> 00:03:41,780
Once we've got those OUs created,
we might want go back and

69
00:03:41,780 --> 00:03:44,340
modify an organizational unit.

70
00:03:44,340 --> 00:03:47,260
So one example of that might
be adding a description.

71
00:03:47,260 --> 00:03:50,630
And the command, remember,
are new creates.

72
00:03:50,630 --> 00:03:51,810
We switch that verb and

73
00:03:51,810 --> 00:03:56,230
we change it to a set instead of new,
now we're modifying an existing object.

74
00:03:56,230 --> 00:04:00,440
So it's just gonna be
set-ad organizational unit.

75
00:04:00,440 --> 00:04:02,860
And then the parameter
that you want to modify.

76
00:04:04,030 --> 00:04:08,130
I might do a -description or
something like that.

77
00:04:08,130 --> 00:04:11,820
And maybe we put default.

78
00:04:14,110 --> 00:04:16,470
Oh, let me take that back.

79
00:04:16,470 --> 00:04:17,020
One second,

80
00:04:17,020 --> 00:04:21,240
I do have to tell it that I'm not creating
one, I'm modifying an existing one.

81
00:04:21,240 --> 00:04:24,770
So I really need to tell it which
object I'm going to be modifying.

82
00:04:24,770 --> 00:04:29,770
Instead of a -name,
it's actually a dash identity parameter.

83
00:04:29,770 --> 00:04:36,280
So a little bit different, if I modify
that, let's do the ou=useraccounts

84
00:04:37,952 --> 00:04:42,813
dc=itprotv, dc=, what are we doing,
.net in this one, so

85
00:04:42,813 --> 00:04:48,710
there's the distinguished name for
the object that I'm trying to modify.

86
00:04:50,010 --> 00:04:53,930
And then the parameter I want
to modify is description, and

87
00:04:53,930 --> 00:04:57,419
I'm just going to put the default OU for

88
00:04:57,419 --> 00:05:03,560
user accounts and my quote.

89
00:05:03,560 --> 00:05:04,730
Hit enter.

90
00:05:04,730 --> 00:05:06,770
And if we want to go back and
take a look at that,

91
00:05:06,770 --> 00:05:08,530
I should be able to pull
up the properties for that.

92
00:05:08,530 --> 00:05:11,047
Let's just do a little refresh here.

93
00:05:14,018 --> 00:05:16,760
And it didn't seem to set my description,
interesting.

94
00:05:18,490 --> 00:05:20,410
All right so
that's how I modify those guys.

95
00:05:20,410 --> 00:05:23,380
I might have to find out why it
didn't set that description properly.

96
00:05:23,380 --> 00:05:24,730
There's my description.

97
00:05:24,730 --> 00:05:27,765
It's just not showing on my screen
out here, normally it would,

98
00:05:27,765 --> 00:05:29,380
we'll figure that out later.

99
00:05:29,380 --> 00:05:30,670
So that's how you go back and modify.

100
00:05:30,670 --> 00:05:33,190
All you're doing is
a set-adorganizationunit.

101
00:05:33,190 --> 00:05:36,980
The identity of the OU that
you're trying to modify,

102
00:05:36,980 --> 00:05:40,510
and then the particular parameter
that you're trying change.

103
00:05:41,630 --> 00:05:44,450
So there's create an OU,
modify an existing OU.

104
00:05:44,450 --> 00:05:49,249
The only thing that really leaves us
is removing an organizational unit.

105
00:05:50,400 --> 00:05:51,620
So let's take a look.

106
00:05:51,620 --> 00:05:54,150
Let me flip back over to
active directory real quick.

107
00:05:55,600 --> 00:05:58,970
And I've got an OU called test that
we created in the very beginning.

108
00:05:59,980 --> 00:06:01,930
Now if I want to delete that.

109
00:06:01,930 --> 00:06:02,710
All right, if we want to remove it,

110
00:06:02,710 --> 00:06:06,660
the command is just gonna be
remove -ad organizational unit.

111
00:06:06,660 --> 00:06:08,790
Some of you might know
where I'm going with this.

112
00:06:08,790 --> 00:06:12,442
Let's see if you catch on, remove-ad

113
00:06:12,442 --> 00:06:17,990
organizational unit, and then the name
of the OU that I want to remove.

114
00:06:17,990 --> 00:06:21,010
Really need the distinguish name
just cuz it's at the root so

115
00:06:21,010 --> 00:06:23,150
it should be okay if we're
just using the name.

116
00:06:23,150 --> 00:06:25,110
So you're going to work on,
what do you think?

117
00:06:25,110 --> 00:06:26,410
>> Well, you know,
it's like you always say.

118
00:06:26,410 --> 00:06:29,085
Remember what happens in
the graphical user interface, right?

119
00:06:29,085 --> 00:06:30,430
>> Mm-hm.
>> If you try and

120
00:06:30,430 --> 00:06:34,450
delete an OU,
ever since Windows Server 2003,

121
00:06:34,450 --> 00:06:37,570
there's a little feature in there
that's going to stop that from working.

122
00:06:37,570 --> 00:06:38,560
>> Exactly.

123
00:06:38,560 --> 00:06:40,670
And just to show you guys, I'm going
to use the distinguished name and

124
00:06:40,670 --> 00:06:43,110
make sure that's not why
we're getting the error.

125
00:06:43,110 --> 00:06:51,109
Let's do a remove-ad
organizational unit OU = test,

126
00:06:51,109 --> 00:06:56,563
dc equals IT Pro TV, dc= equals net.

127
00:06:58,768 --> 00:07:01,255
It says yes I want to remove it,
I hit a Y.

128
00:07:02,635 --> 00:07:05,135
And you'll notice I get access is denied.

129
00:07:05,135 --> 00:07:08,055
So what Don is referring to remember

130
00:07:08,055 --> 00:07:11,750
now from when we created a new
organizational unit by default.

131
00:07:11,750 --> 00:07:15,000
The protect from accidental
deletion check mark is checked.

132
00:07:15,000 --> 00:07:17,160
If we go back over to active directory and

133
00:07:17,160 --> 00:07:20,820
I pull up the properties of test and
I've already turned on my advanced view.

134
00:07:20,820 --> 00:07:23,250
Remember you don't get to
see that object tab if

135
00:07:23,250 --> 00:07:26,340
you don't have your advanced view
turned on in active directory.

136
00:07:26,340 --> 00:07:29,410
And there I can see,
protect object from accidental deletion.

137
00:07:30,790 --> 00:07:33,890
>> It's a funny feature because it's not
really protecting you from deletion so

138
00:07:33,890 --> 00:07:38,100
much as it is accidentally dragging and
dropping this to another location.

139
00:07:38,100 --> 00:07:40,060
So that was a real problem in the GUI.

140
00:07:40,060 --> 00:07:43,840
From the PowerShell, it's not a problem
but the feature still applies.

141
00:07:43,840 --> 00:07:46,550
We've gotta remember to disable
that before we move forward.

142
00:07:46,550 --> 00:07:47,610
>> Exactly.

143
00:07:47,610 --> 00:07:48,560
So all we're gonna do,

144
00:07:48,560 --> 00:07:51,360
now I could have unchecked that
right there in the GUI, right, but.

145
00:07:51,360 --> 00:07:51,960
>> That's cheating.

146
00:07:51,960 --> 00:07:54,770
>> This is a PowerShell show,
so let's not do that.

147
00:07:54,770 --> 00:07:56,880
So what I'm gonna do is I'm
gonna use my set command.

148
00:07:58,210 --> 00:08:03,130
So, just like I did before,
we're doing a set-adorganizationalunit.

149
00:08:03,130 --> 00:08:06,220
And then the name of the OU
that I'm trying to modify.

150
00:08:07,890 --> 00:08:10,690
And then the parameter's
just going to be a dash, and

151
00:08:10,690 --> 00:08:15,320
this is a long one,
ProtectFromAccidentalDeletion.

152
00:08:15,320 --> 00:08:18,915
ProtectFromAccidentalDeletion, thank
God for tab autofill.

153
00:08:18,915 --> 00:08:19,900
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

154
00:08:19,900 --> 00:08:24,740
I'm just gonna set that to a $false and
hit enter.

155
00:08:24,740 --> 00:08:27,770
And so what that should do is that's
basically clearing that check mark in

156
00:08:27,770 --> 00:08:29,840
the GUI, same thing if I went in there.

157
00:08:29,840 --> 00:08:32,830
Now, if I go and
do another remove organizational unit.

158
00:08:34,560 --> 00:08:38,770
And I hit a Y for yes, we get no red text.

159
00:08:38,770 --> 00:08:40,570
If I flip back to overactive directory and

160
00:08:40,570 --> 00:08:45,458
refresh my screen we should
see that that test OU is gone.

161
00:08:45,458 --> 00:08:50,040
And that's it, so it's out of there.

162
00:08:50,040 --> 00:08:55,520
You get that one chance you can hit Y for
yes, and that's all you get.

163
00:08:55,520 --> 00:08:58,040
>> And a great of where I've
used this in the past was.

164
00:08:58,040 --> 00:09:02,920
I worked for an organization where you had
branch offices, over 110 branch offices.

165
00:09:02,920 --> 00:09:04,190
And every branch office had a number.

166
00:09:04,190 --> 00:09:05,780
So it was branch number 1,

167
00:09:05,780 --> 00:09:10,890
all the way through branch number 110, and
we needed to create OUs for each branch.

168
00:09:10,890 --> 00:09:13,640
And so, I just whipped up a quick
little PowerShell script and

169
00:09:13,640 --> 00:09:17,810
said, create an OU that
was named branch 001.

170
00:09:17,810 --> 00:09:22,580
And then, add one to that, and
create branch 002, and add one to that and

171
00:09:22,580 --> 00:09:26,600
create branch 003; it was just
a little loop that went 110 times.

172
00:09:26,600 --> 00:09:30,190
Quickly and easily created 110 OUs,
all named for the various branches.

173
00:09:30,190 --> 00:09:32,220
I didn't have to do it by hand.

174
00:09:32,220 --> 00:09:33,970
That's the kind of thing that you can do,

175
00:09:33,970 --> 00:09:35,920
when you're creating this
stuff from the PowerShell.

176
00:09:35,920 --> 00:09:38,060
So, managing OUs, pretty straightforward.

177
00:09:39,170 --> 00:09:43,200
So in this segment, we got a chance
to see how to create, modify and

178
00:09:43,200 --> 00:09:47,630
ultimately remove,
OUs from the PowerShell prompt, right?

179
00:09:47,630 --> 00:09:50,780
So excellent stuff there,
definitely something to take advantage of.

180
00:09:50,780 --> 00:09:52,210
Hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

181
00:09:52,210 --> 00:09:57,363
Stay tuned,
we’ve got more PowerShell coming up.

182
