episodes.title: Managing User Accounts
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,191 --> 00:00:08,500
[MUSIC].

2
00:00:08,500 --> 00:00:11,922
In this segment, we're gonna
look at managing user account in

3
00:00:11,922 --> 00:00:16,391
the direct directory via Power Shell cuz
we already have our local user accounts.

4
00:00:16,391 --> 00:00:20,060
We're not gonna mess with those but
on the active directory side, we have use

5
00:00:20,060 --> 00:00:23,672
accounts, which are put inside of OUs and
they have to have group statute and

6
00:00:23,672 --> 00:00:27,810
all this other stuff but before we even
get that far, we've got to get created.

7
00:00:27,810 --> 00:00:30,890
So we're gonna take a look at that
process of creating user accounts and

8
00:00:30,890 --> 00:00:33,470
manipulating their data,
all via the Power Shell.

9
00:00:33,470 --> 00:00:34,961
All right, Mike.

10
00:00:34,961 --> 00:00:35,941
What have you got for us today?

11
00:00:35,941 --> 00:00:37,061
>> Well, let's take a look.

12
00:00:37,061 --> 00:00:40,610
With these commands,
the command is going to be new-aduser.

13
00:00:40,610 --> 00:00:45,550
So pretty straightforward, your new verb,
your noun is going to be aduser.

14
00:00:45,550 --> 00:00:49,641
And at it's simplest form,
it's new-aduser.

15
00:00:49,641 --> 00:00:52,380
It helps to put a dash in there.

16
00:00:52,380 --> 00:00:56,380
New-aduser, and then you could just
give it a name like I did here.

17
00:00:56,380 --> 00:01:00,620
And at this point, I have a new user
account, hopefully, called Nate.

18
00:01:00,620 --> 00:01:02,440
We'll go in here and
refresh Active Directory.

19
00:01:02,440 --> 00:01:06,201
And we'll take a look
inside my Users container.

20
00:01:06,201 --> 00:01:09,241
And sure enough,
there is a user named Nate.

21
00:01:09,241 --> 00:01:12,486
Now if you can see I know this is
very small on the screen there, but

22
00:01:12,486 --> 00:01:16,321
if you look really closely at that icon;
you'll notice that that account for

23
00:01:16,321 --> 00:01:17,690
Nate is disabled, right?

24
00:01:17,690 --> 00:01:20,390
I didn't set any parameters
when I ran that command,

25
00:01:20,390 --> 00:01:24,360
I gave it the one required command
to create that new user account.

26
00:01:24,360 --> 00:01:28,192
And that was the name of the account.

27
00:01:28,192 --> 00:01:31,610
So [INAUDIBLE] there are several different
parameters I can throw in there, in fact

28
00:01:31,610 --> 00:01:35,460
I'll give you guys the link to the notes
out there and some technical commands.

29
00:01:36,730 --> 00:01:39,160
Many, many different parameters
I can throw in there.

30
00:01:39,160 --> 00:01:42,605
Let's take a look at a couple of those,
because normally we're going to want

31
00:01:42,605 --> 00:01:45,640
to set a few more than that at least,
you know, we want to enable it.

32
00:01:45,640 --> 00:01:49,713
And you guys remember with server
2012 R2 if you create an account and

33
00:01:49,713 --> 00:01:53,710
you do not set the password,
the account is going to be disabled.

34
00:01:53,710 --> 00:01:57,330
So we might wanna try to set that
password in our command, and

35
00:01:57,330 --> 00:01:58,430
we might want to also enable it.

36
00:01:58,430 --> 00:02:01,160
Just because you set the password doesn't
mean it's automatically be enabled.

37
00:02:01,160 --> 00:02:04,600
You'd have to set the password and
enable the account, but if you don't set

38
00:02:04,600 --> 00:02:09,070
the password Active Directory will
not let you enable that account.

39
00:02:09,070 --> 00:02:11,520
So, let's try another one, I'm gonna do
a little bit longer command this time.

40
00:02:11,520 --> 00:02:14,140
We're gonna do New-ADUser.

41
00:02:14,140 --> 00:02:19,075
And I'm gonna do a- Name and
then I'll give it a name.

42
00:02:19,075 --> 00:02:22,575
We'll call this one Ronnie Wong.

43
00:02:24,485 --> 00:02:25,955
And then I'll throw in a few more.

44
00:02:25,955 --> 00:02:30,095
And like I said, there are several like
given name would be like his first name.

45
00:02:31,895 --> 00:02:35,271
We can do his last name which is
gonna be a- Surname parameter.

46
00:02:39,111 --> 00:02:42,433
And then some more important ones that
we typically want to set would be like

47
00:02:42,433 --> 00:02:44,131
the user principal name, all right?

48
00:02:44,131 --> 00:02:48,659
So we'll do a user principal name and

49
00:02:48,659 --> 00:02:54,071
we'll call that rwong.@itprotv.net.

50
00:02:54,071 --> 00:02:58,611
And let's also do that SAMACCOUNTNAME,
that pre-Windows 2000 logon name.

51
00:02:58,611 --> 00:03:01,491
And we'll do rwong.

52
00:03:01,491 --> 00:03:05,720
And then I'm gonna go ahead and
do an enable, so a -enabled.

53
00:03:05,720 --> 00:03:07,440
I'm gonna set that to a true or 1.

54
00:03:07,440 --> 00:03:11,420
You can actually do either one,
$true or a 1.

55
00:03:11,420 --> 00:03:14,440
And then the key here is to make sure I
set the password otherwise I won't be

56
00:03:14,440 --> 00:03:15,610
able to enable it.

57
00:03:15,610 --> 00:03:21,280
And we're gonna use the AccountPassword
parameter, -AccountPassword.

58
00:03:21,280 --> 00:03:23,202
And then there's a couple
different ways you can do this.

59
00:03:23,202 --> 00:03:26,840
You can provide the password in line,
or you can prompt, and

60
00:03:26,840 --> 00:03:30,220
it really depends on what you're trying
to do, if I was automating this,

61
00:03:30,220 --> 00:03:32,490
running through a script,
I might want to go ahead and

62
00:03:32,490 --> 00:03:36,470
set the parameter in the command,
or the password in the command, and

63
00:03:36,470 --> 00:03:39,575
then I can go but have them change
their password their next log on.

64
00:03:39,575 --> 00:03:42,230
And I'm creating a single account,
I might want to just go ahead and

65
00:03:42,230 --> 00:03:44,490
have it prompt me right here
which is what I'm going to do for

66
00:03:44,490 --> 00:03:47,840
this particular example,
just so you can see that option.

67
00:03:47,840 --> 00:03:54,220
It's just a Read-Host, and
then as secure string and

68
00:03:54,220 --> 00:03:57,040
that's going to cause it to put those
little asterisks out there to hide what

69
00:03:57,040 --> 00:04:00,900
I'm typing in case somebody is shoulder
surfing, looking over my shoulder.

70
00:04:00,900 --> 00:04:03,880
And then I'm gonna set
the prompt to just say Password.

71
00:04:06,670 --> 00:04:10,820
And I will end that guy with a little
close parentheses and hit enter.

72
00:04:10,820 --> 00:04:14,695
>> Your spelling doesn't really matter
on Password, it's just a prompt there.

73
00:04:14,695 --> 00:04:19,440
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
you can see my prompt now says Passoword.

74
00:04:19,440 --> 00:04:22,270
So you know, and then I'll go ahead and
set his password.

75
00:04:22,270 --> 00:04:25,760
Notice it's not showing you what
I'm typing for that password.

76
00:04:25,760 --> 00:04:28,460
>> And this one's extra secure, because if
anybody's shoulder surfing, they just see

77
00:04:28,460 --> 00:04:31,750
the stars, and they don't think it's
a password because it's spelled wrong.

78
00:04:31,750 --> 00:04:33,320
So it's an extra level.

79
00:04:33,320 --> 00:04:35,630
>> You know,
I like many layers of security.

80
00:04:35,630 --> 00:04:38,840
It's an important part of security
in our network environment.

81
00:04:38,840 --> 00:04:41,830
So if I flip back over here to
active directory I did specify

82
00:04:41,830 --> 00:04:45,160
the path of where I wanted to
create that user account so

83
00:04:45,160 --> 00:04:48,140
it should have just gone
into my User's container.

84
00:04:48,140 --> 00:04:50,510
And sure enough there is Ronnie Wong.

85
00:04:50,510 --> 00:04:53,300
And you'll notice from that
little icon that it is enabled.

86
00:04:53,300 --> 00:04:54,500
So the account is ready to go.

87
00:04:54,500 --> 00:04:56,600
He could sign on with it at this point.

88
00:04:56,600 --> 00:05:02,170
Got a first name and last name,
we also set that SAMACCOUNTNAME.

89
00:05:02,170 --> 00:05:04,950
And what else; and
we set the password for that guy.

90
00:05:04,950 --> 00:05:07,661
So, there is creating,
excuse me close that.

91
00:05:07,661 --> 00:05:12,210
There's our creating a user
account from active directory.

92
00:05:12,210 --> 00:05:15,650
Now once you've got these guys created,
typically, you don't wanna stop there.

93
00:05:15,650 --> 00:05:17,350
We're gonna have to go back occasionally,
and

94
00:05:17,350 --> 00:05:19,990
make changes to some of
these user accounts.

95
00:05:19,990 --> 00:05:22,070
And all we do is swap out the verb, right?

96
00:05:22,070 --> 00:05:24,640
Just like everything else
we've done with PowerShell.

97
00:05:24,640 --> 00:05:27,600
New is, typically, my create verb.

98
00:05:27,600 --> 00:05:31,890
Set is going to be my modifier,
my right verb.

99
00:05:31,890 --> 00:05:35,870
So we're just gonna change that verb,
Set-ADUser.

100
00:05:35,870 --> 00:05:39,640
And then depending on what I want to
change and who I want to modify, for

101
00:05:39,640 --> 00:05:43,270
this one, instead of a -name,
it's a -name you create but,

102
00:05:43,270 --> 00:05:47,596
when you're trying to modify something
they want you to do a -Identity, so

103
00:05:47,596 --> 00:05:52,710
-Identity, and there's several ways
you can refer to a user account.

104
00:05:52,710 --> 00:05:55,500
Some parameter, some of these
commandlets are very specific,

105
00:05:55,500 --> 00:05:59,120
you can only use the distinguished name or
the GUID.

106
00:05:59,120 --> 00:06:00,750
Others are a little more flexible and

107
00:06:00,750 --> 00:06:05,190
they'll let you use like
the SAMACCOUNTNAME and things like that.

108
00:06:05,190 --> 00:06:08,340
And this is one of those, so
I can just do an rwong and

109
00:06:08,340 --> 00:06:12,620
it's gonna know what I'm referring to,
and then what parameter do I wanna set.

110
00:06:12,620 --> 00:06:17,334
Maybe I wanna set his manager

111
00:06:17,334 --> 00:06:21,876
to Don Pezet and hit Enter.

112
00:06:21,876 --> 00:06:27,750
And -manager could not be resolved,
that's nice.

113
00:06:27,750 --> 00:06:28,741
Well let's just set his description.

114
00:06:28,741 --> 00:06:33,523
Some of these parameters, what you're
gonna find is, you can't set them,

115
00:06:33,523 --> 00:06:36,110
depending on the command you're using.

116
00:06:36,110 --> 00:06:38,409
We'll just call this guy, host.

117
00:06:40,850 --> 00:06:43,130
I'll explain what I mean here in a second.

118
00:06:43,130 --> 00:06:44,670
So that should set that description.

119
00:06:44,670 --> 00:06:46,650
I've got a link in the show notes for you.

120
00:06:46,650 --> 00:06:49,190
What you'll find is some of these
parameters you can set during

121
00:06:49,190 --> 00:06:53,810
the creation command but you can't set
them the same way during the set user.

122
00:06:53,810 --> 00:06:56,340
You have to actually do
a dash other attributes, and

123
00:06:56,340 --> 00:06:59,450
then make like a little block and
fill those attributes in.

124
00:06:59,450 --> 00:07:03,130
So some of them you can set inline, some
of them you're going to have to go and

125
00:07:03,130 --> 00:07:04,920
do a dash other parameters.

126
00:07:04,920 --> 00:07:07,260
It's on that link that I'll
give you in the show notes but

127
00:07:07,260 --> 00:07:09,320
there you see I've
modified Ronnie's account.

128
00:07:09,320 --> 00:07:11,870
I set his description as a host.

129
00:07:14,050 --> 00:07:17,670
And then the last thing we might need to
be able to do with power shell to manage

130
00:07:17,670 --> 00:07:19,810
our user accounts is gonna be remove one.

131
00:07:19,810 --> 00:07:20,540
All right.

132
00:07:20,540 --> 00:07:22,010
At the end of it's lifetime,

133
00:07:22,010 --> 00:07:25,480
if you no longer need that account, I need
to remove it from from active directory,

134
00:07:25,480 --> 00:07:28,190
it might have been some test accounts,
might have been an account.

135
00:07:28,190 --> 00:07:32,520
I don't know about you, Don, I don't
like deleting user accounts that often.

136
00:07:32,520 --> 00:07:33,725
>> I usually disable.

137
00:07:33,725 --> 00:07:38,310
>> Disable them or move them into an OU,
and maybe a year from now, delete it if I

138
00:07:38,310 --> 00:07:44,700
need to but it's a straightforward
command, just Remove-ADUser.

139
00:07:44,700 --> 00:07:48,960
And then the identity, and I'll go and

140
00:07:48,960 --> 00:07:53,930
find that Nate account that I created and
yes to remove it.

141
00:07:55,720 --> 00:07:56,660
And it should be gone.

142
00:07:56,660 --> 00:08:00,570
If we flip back over to active directory
and I refresh, we can see there it is.

143
00:08:00,570 --> 00:08:05,570
I do a little refresh, and
Nate's account is now gone.

144
00:08:05,570 --> 00:08:08,370
So there's working with my user accounts,
we saw that we could

145
00:08:08,370 --> 00:08:11,290
create the user account, modify that,
and then delete that guy.

146
00:08:12,640 --> 00:08:16,203
>> So Mike, I was looking at where you
went to set the manager a moment ago and

147
00:08:16,203 --> 00:08:19,884
I just was trying to debug it real quick
and find out where it went wrong, and

148
00:08:19,884 --> 00:08:23,291
then I noticed it says cannot find
an object with identity Don Pezet.

149
00:08:23,291 --> 00:08:25,151
Do I have an account?

150
00:08:25,151 --> 00:08:26,591
>> No, oh.

151
00:08:26,591 --> 00:08:30,865
>> With manager, it's not, manager is just
one of those fields you can type whatever

152
00:08:30,865 --> 00:08:33,870
the heck you want in,
it actually ties to another AD user.

153
00:08:33,870 --> 00:08:36,478
So it’s it's looking for me and
I don't have an account, and so

154
00:08:36,478 --> 00:08:39,730
that's why it's doing that, but
otherwise you're syntactically correct.

155
00:08:39,730 --> 00:08:41,550
That's my big word of the day right there,
syntactically.

156
00:08:41,550 --> 00:08:44,679
>> Syntactically, I like that,
>> So yeah,

157
00:08:44,679 --> 00:08:46,885
just set ADUser dash
manager on that one but

158
00:08:46,885 --> 00:08:51,065
you're exactly right, there are other
ones [INAUDIBLE] do the other object tag.

159
00:08:51,065 --> 00:08:52,025
Super annoying.

160
00:08:52,025 --> 00:08:54,856
>> Yeah, like title I think is one
of them that pops up in there.

161
00:08:54,856 --> 00:08:57,456
I don't why they won't let you set
that straight from the command there.

162
00:08:57,456 --> 00:09:01,285
>> Yeah, those are things we'll see
evolve over time as power shell moves on.

163
00:09:01,285 --> 00:09:04,575
By the time we got power shell 10 it
will be a usable product [LAUGH] but

164
00:09:04,575 --> 00:09:08,000
until then we have a little
bit of grey area there.

165
00:09:08,000 --> 00:09:12,490
All right guys, well in this segment we
got a chance to see creating modifying and

166
00:09:12,490 --> 00:09:15,720
removing a user account
all via the Power Shell.

167
00:09:15,720 --> 00:09:18,790
Now stay tuned, because we've got
an episode coming up on groups.

168
00:09:18,790 --> 00:09:22,580
Typically when we create a user account,
our very next step is to

169
00:09:22,580 --> 00:09:25,890
put them in the necessary groups for
them to perform their job.

170
00:09:25,890 --> 00:09:27,871
So really that segment's going to
go hand in hand with this one.

171
00:09:27,871 --> 00:09:29,391
You definitely want to check that one out.

172
00:09:29,391 --> 00:09:32,760
So stay tuned, more Power Shell coming up.

173
00:09:32,760 --> 00:09:39,170

episodes.title: Managing Groups
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,058
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,058 --> 00:00:08,855
In this segment,

3
00:00:08,855 --> 00:00:12,450
we're gonna take a look at managing
groups inside of the PowerShell.

4
00:00:12,450 --> 00:00:15,910
When you create user accounts inside of
the AD, one of the next steps that you

5
00:00:15,910 --> 00:00:19,960
take is to assign permissions to them, and
assigning permissions requires groups.

6
00:00:19,960 --> 00:00:23,650
So, definitely a key piece
inside of our IT infrastructure.

7
00:00:23,650 --> 00:00:26,050
And if we're trying to automate
the creation of user accounts,

8
00:00:26,050 --> 00:00:28,260
this is something that you'll
wanna work into your script.

9
00:00:28,260 --> 00:00:29,860
So, let's take a look at it, Mike.

10
00:00:29,860 --> 00:00:31,850
>> All right, let's take a peak here.

11
00:00:31,850 --> 00:00:34,650
So, as we continue on with these
different commands, same idea,

12
00:00:34,650 --> 00:00:36,860
we're just going to use a different noun,
right.

13
00:00:36,860 --> 00:00:39,930
We've seen how to create users,
we've seen how to create OU's.

14
00:00:39,930 --> 00:00:44,710
Now, we wanna create groups, we swap
out the noun, we change it to ADGroup.

15
00:00:44,710 --> 00:00:49,085
So, let's start with a simple one,
we're just gonna do new-adGroup.

16
00:00:49,085 --> 00:00:50,435
And then the parameters,

17
00:00:50,435 --> 00:00:54,745
as always there's several parameters that
we can use with that ADGroup command.

18
00:00:54,745 --> 00:00:58,775
I'll give you guys the notes, or the link
to the notes in our show notes to show

19
00:00:58,775 --> 00:01:00,885
you some of the additional parameters.

20
00:01:00,885 --> 00:01:03,787
I'm gonna give it a name,
so I'm gonna specify name.

21
00:01:03,787 --> 00:01:09,670
I'm just gonna call it HOSTS, if I can
spell that, that's a tricky word to spell.

22
00:01:09,670 --> 00:01:17,420
And then I'll do the SAMACCOUTNAME,
and I'm gonna call that HOSTS as well.

23
00:01:17,420 --> 00:01:21,138
And then, just like when you go through
the GUI, think about right-click,

24
00:01:21,138 --> 00:01:21,890
new group.

25
00:01:21,890 --> 00:01:25,130
There's really only a couple parameters
you have to specify, right, the name of

26
00:01:25,130 --> 00:01:29,530
the group, and then you've got your group
category and your group scope or your

27
00:01:29,530 --> 00:01:33,230
group type and your group scope depending
on which book you're reading there.

28
00:01:33,230 --> 00:01:37,010
The group category is gonna be,
remember there's two options here.

29
00:01:37,010 --> 00:01:38,370
I've got distribution.

30
00:01:38,370 --> 00:01:39,970
And I've got security.

31
00:01:39,970 --> 00:01:43,960
We're gonna do a security group cuz I
want to use this to assign permissions.

32
00:01:43,960 --> 00:01:47,360
So I want to make sure it gets an SID,
and make it a security principle.

33
00:01:47,360 --> 00:01:51,080
If I did distribution,
that would be email applications only.

34
00:01:51,080 --> 00:01:55,650
No SID, it's not a security principle,
you cannot use it to assign permissions.

35
00:01:55,650 --> 00:01:59,990
And then the next parameter I wanna
add is going to be my GroupScope.

36
00:01:59,990 --> 00:02:03,934
And I've got three choices there,
I've got my domain local,

37
00:02:03,934 --> 00:02:07,840
I've got my global, and
I've got my universal.

38
00:02:07,840 --> 00:02:10,080
And we'll go with global for this one.

39
00:02:10,080 --> 00:02:14,990
And then if I hit Enter there,
it would just create it at the root.

40
00:02:14,990 --> 00:02:19,860
If I want I can specify a path, and
then it’s just the distinguished

41
00:02:19,860 --> 00:02:23,560
name of where I wanna create
that group in active directory.

42
00:02:23,560 --> 00:02:28,260
And I’ve gonna go ahead and put it,
I’ve got an OU called groups, I think.

43
00:02:28,260 --> 00:02:32,372
So I’m gonna tell you ou=groups,

44
00:02:32,372 --> 00:02:37,784
dc=itprotv, dc=net,

45
00:02:37,784 --> 00:02:43,720
and should be able to hit Enter and
no red text is usually a good sign.

46
00:02:43,720 --> 00:02:49,653
So, well come back in here and refresh my
console and I take a look at my group.

47
00:02:49,653 --> 00:02:53,298
So, sure enough,
there is my host group and

48
00:02:53,298 --> 00:02:57,247
you'll see that it is
a global security group.

49
00:02:57,247 --> 00:02:59,408
So that is creating
a group from PowerShell.

50
00:02:59,408 --> 00:03:05,290
It's just new-adgroup, give it a SAM
account name, give it a group scope,

51
00:03:05,290 --> 00:03:09,000
global universal domain local,
and give it a group category,

52
00:03:09,000 --> 00:03:13,710
either security or distribution group,
depending on what you're trying to do.

53
00:03:13,710 --> 00:03:17,550
Once I've got that group created, next
thing we might want to be able to do with

54
00:03:17,550 --> 00:03:19,870
a group is to go back and modify a group.

55
00:03:19,870 --> 00:03:24,220
For example, one of the things we
typically do is change the group scope.

56
00:03:24,220 --> 00:03:25,340
If we create a group and

57
00:03:25,340 --> 00:03:29,105
active directory through the GUI,
the default is global security group.

58
00:03:29,105 --> 00:03:32,575
I don't know about you, Don, several
I've gone in and created a group and

59
00:03:32,575 --> 00:03:34,365
kind of forgot to change those.

60
00:03:34,365 --> 00:03:37,055
You go to type the name,
you hit the Enter, and you go, oh smack,

61
00:03:37,055 --> 00:03:39,495
I wanted to change that into a universal
group or something like that.

62
00:03:39,495 --> 00:03:42,317
>> It's funny cuz that's exactly
what I say, I'm like, oh smack.

63
00:03:42,317 --> 00:03:44,771
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't think I've ever said that but

64
00:03:44,771 --> 00:03:46,594
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I thought that was where I got

65
00:03:46,594 --> 00:03:48,410
that from was you.

66
00:03:48,410 --> 00:03:51,552
So, we can change the verb
to a set command, so

67
00:03:51,552 --> 00:03:54,870
set is gonna modify an existing object.

68
00:03:54,870 --> 00:03:57,330
So, Set-ADGroup.

69
00:03:57,330 --> 00:04:00,632
The name of the group
that I want to modify.

70
00:04:00,632 --> 00:04:03,470
Actually hat's gonna be an identity
parameter in this case.

71
00:04:03,470 --> 00:04:06,630
Remember when you change when you're
doing the new commands, it's -name.

72
00:04:06,630 --> 00:04:10,380
When you're doing the commands,
it's typically -identity.

73
00:04:10,380 --> 00:04:14,000
Or you could leave identity off and
just provide that name.

74
00:04:14,000 --> 00:04:16,380
And what did I call that one, Hosts.

75
00:04:18,030 --> 00:04:21,360
And let’s modify the group scope, so

76
00:04:21,360 --> 00:04:26,410
I can just put in a little -groupscope.

77
00:04:26,410 --> 00:04:28,479
And I’m gonna change that
one over to universal.

78
00:04:30,030 --> 00:04:33,740
And if I go back into my
GUI at this point, and

79
00:04:33,740 --> 00:04:38,390
I pull up the properties,
we'll see that is now a universal group.

80
00:04:38,390 --> 00:04:41,330
Keep in mind all my rules still apply,
right.

81
00:04:41,330 --> 00:04:45,490
So if I was trying to convert
a universal group into a global group,

82
00:04:45,490 --> 00:04:50,350
I can do that unless there's members
of that universal group that are going

83
00:04:50,350 --> 00:04:53,530
to violate the rules of what
a global group can contain.

84
00:04:53,530 --> 00:04:57,360
That a global group can only
contain users from the same domain.

85
00:04:57,360 --> 00:04:59,840
So I'd have to make sure I
wasn't violating any of that,

86
00:04:59,840 --> 00:05:04,390
I'd have to remove users
first if necessary.

87
00:05:04,390 --> 00:05:06,970
And then the last thing that
I want to be able to do

88
00:05:06,970 --> 00:05:11,070
with PowerShell is to remove a group
when I no longer need that group.

89
00:05:11,070 --> 00:05:15,145
And as you can imagine the command
is going to be remove-adgroup.

90
00:05:16,960 --> 00:05:18,625
And we'll just do a -identity.

91
00:05:20,640 --> 00:05:23,760
I really don't even need that one but
I'll go ahead and put it in there.

92
00:05:23,760 --> 00:05:26,570
I could just do remove-adgroup hosts and

93
00:05:26,570 --> 00:05:28,380
that would go find that group and
remove it.

94
00:05:28,380 --> 00:05:33,120
Or I can do a -identity hosts,
Yes to confirm.

95
00:05:34,135 --> 00:05:34,822
No red text.

96
00:05:34,822 --> 00:05:39,073
Remember, unlike organizational units,
OUs by default when you create them,

97
00:05:39,073 --> 00:05:41,648
they're protected from
accidental deletion.

98
00:05:41,648 --> 00:05:44,816
So if I were to try to run this
command on an OU without unchecking or

99
00:05:44,816 --> 00:05:47,468
running the command to remove
that protection first,

100
00:05:47,468 --> 00:05:51,080
I would have gotten an error,
as we saw in a previous segment.

101
00:05:51,080 --> 00:05:52,610
Groups, however, when you create those,

102
00:05:52,610 --> 00:05:55,010
they're not protected from
accidental deletion by default.

103
00:05:55,010 --> 00:05:57,880
I can go back in there and turn that on,
but they're not by default.

104
00:05:57,880 --> 00:06:00,590
So in this case the remove
command worked just fine.

105
00:06:00,590 --> 00:06:03,610
The group is no longer there,
and we would lose that group.

106
00:06:03,610 --> 00:06:08,270
Just remember, think back to our
lessons or our previous segments,

107
00:06:08,270 --> 00:06:11,970
when you remove that group you lose
the SID associated with that group,

108
00:06:11,970 --> 00:06:13,550
you lose all the membership of that group.

109
00:06:13,550 --> 00:06:16,260
So, be careful when you
go into deleting groups.

110
00:06:16,260 --> 00:06:17,090
>> Yeah.

111
00:06:17,090 --> 00:06:19,510
Another thing to remember, and this is
the one that's always hard for me is,

112
00:06:19,510 --> 00:06:22,230
in the GUI there's two different
ways to do groups, right,

113
00:06:22,230 --> 00:06:24,480
you can put a user into a group.

114
00:06:24,480 --> 00:06:28,050
Or you can go to a group and modify
it's membership and add users into it.

115
00:06:28,050 --> 00:06:30,600
But in the PowerShell,
it's really all the same,

116
00:06:30,600 --> 00:06:32,180
regardless of which way
that you look at it.

117
00:06:32,180 --> 00:06:35,727
So there's only one set of commands from
the PowerShell versus the two different

118
00:06:35,727 --> 00:06:36,677
pathways in the GUI.

119
00:06:36,677 --> 00:06:37,373
A little bit of a difference there.

120
00:06:37,373 --> 00:06:38,905
>> Exactly.

121
00:06:38,905 --> 00:06:40,430
In fact, that's one thing we didn't do.

122
00:06:40,430 --> 00:06:42,320
Did we?
We didn't ad anybody to our group.

123
00:06:42,320 --> 00:06:44,190
So let's go back and do that.

124
00:06:44,190 --> 00:06:46,820
I went ahead and recreated that group,
that host group.

125
00:06:46,820 --> 00:06:49,320
And to add a user to
a group from PowerShell,

126
00:06:49,320 --> 00:06:53,685
it's gonna be add-adgroupmember.

127
00:06:53,685 --> 00:06:55,680
That's gonna be the command.

128
00:06:55,680 --> 00:06:58,210
And then the main the name of the group
that I wanna add somebody to,

129
00:06:58,210 --> 00:07:01,450
in this case hosts, and
then the user account.

130
00:07:01,450 --> 00:07:04,880
And you can do a comma separated list
at this point, so if you’re adding

131
00:07:04,880 --> 00:07:09,140
multiple users into this group, I don’t
have to run this command for each one.

132
00:07:09,140 --> 00:07:12,710
I can just find that, so let’s do a little
rwong, she would still be out there.

133
00:07:14,280 --> 00:07:15,590
All right.
And now, if I go back, so

134
00:07:15,590 --> 00:07:18,180
it's just, add-adgroupmember.

135
00:07:18,180 --> 00:07:22,360
You can do a -identity, and then the name
of the group, and in this case, hosts.

136
00:07:22,360 --> 00:07:25,760
And then the members that I wanna add,
rwong.

137
00:07:25,760 --> 00:07:28,540
I could have done a comma separated list.

138
00:07:28,540 --> 00:07:31,790
Go back into active directory,
and refresh my council.

139
00:07:33,650 --> 00:07:35,240
And where did I create that group?

140
00:07:35,240 --> 00:07:38,350
I did that inside my groups OU.

141
00:07:39,620 --> 00:07:44,000
I pull up the properties for hosts and I
look at that Members tab, and sure enough,

142
00:07:44,000 --> 00:07:47,130
Ronnie Wong is now a member
of our host group.

143
00:07:47,130 --> 00:07:49,350
So there we can see we can add.

144
00:07:49,350 --> 00:07:51,210
There is a remove command a swell.

145
00:07:52,420 --> 00:07:54,560
I don't think I want to get
into that one right now.

146
00:07:54,560 --> 00:07:58,950
But this is just gonna be
changing up the verb on that one.

147
00:07:58,950 --> 00:08:02,740
>> And you also have get-adgroupmember, so
if Mike wanted to verify that membership,

148
00:08:02,740 --> 00:08:05,790
he had to hunt and figure out,
where did I put that host group.

149
00:08:05,790 --> 00:08:10,130
If you don't want to do that you can do
get-adgroupmember hosts and just run that,

150
00:08:10,130 --> 00:08:13,150
it'll return who's in it and
you can see Ronnie's right there.

151
00:08:13,150 --> 00:08:15,690
So very easy to work with
these from the PowerShell.

152
00:08:15,690 --> 00:08:17,940
Put people into a group,
take them out of a group.

153
00:08:17,940 --> 00:08:20,020
Add, remove, really straight forward.

154
00:08:20,020 --> 00:08:21,400
And a pretty cool thing to have.

155
00:08:21,400 --> 00:08:24,170
The nice thing about this is
that you can script it and

156
00:08:24,170 --> 00:08:25,970
you can set it to run at certain times.

157
00:08:25,970 --> 00:08:31,210
Because I might want Mike to be in
a group, but not until midnight tonight.

158
00:08:31,210 --> 00:08:33,400
Maybe he doesn't actually start
work until tomorrow morning.

159
00:08:33,400 --> 00:08:36,610
So I don't want to put him in
the group now until it's closer to

160
00:08:36,610 --> 00:08:37,820
the time that he starts.

161
00:08:37,820 --> 00:08:42,080
Or maybe I know that Mike is changing
job roles six months from now.

162
00:08:42,080 --> 00:08:43,980
I don't want to disable
his account in six months.

163
00:08:43,980 --> 00:08:45,500
Windows makes that easy.

164
00:08:45,500 --> 00:08:48,020
Instead, I just want to take him
out of some groups in six months.

165
00:08:48,020 --> 00:08:50,715
So I can write a quick PowerShell
script that says just remove Mike

166
00:08:50,715 --> 00:08:51,305
from this group,

167
00:08:51,305 --> 00:08:55,145
and I then I can schedule it to run six
months from now at midnight or whenever.

168
00:08:55,145 --> 00:08:57,826
That's the power of being able to
do this stuff from the PowerShell,

169
00:08:57,826 --> 00:08:59,408
as well as doing things in bulk, right?

170
00:08:59,408 --> 00:09:02,659
Adding into a bunch of groups
all at once or whatever.

171
00:09:02,659 --> 00:09:04,485
That's something that
becomes a lot more simple.

172
00:09:04,485 --> 00:09:05,155
>> All right, exactly.

173
00:09:06,155 --> 00:09:09,545
>> All right, so in this segment we got a
chance to see how to create groups, how to

174
00:09:09,545 --> 00:09:12,675
modify the groups that we've created,
and then how to add people into them,

175
00:09:12,675 --> 00:09:16,540
which is kind of an important piece
if we anticipate using them, right?

176
00:09:16,540 --> 00:09:19,390
Gotta have people in the group
to get any work done.

177
00:09:19,390 --> 00:09:20,657
All right, I hope you guys enjoyed that.

178
00:09:20,657 --> 00:09:23,954
Stay tuned,
we've got more power shell coming up.

179
00:09:23,954 --> 00:09:29,029
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Import Export Data
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,305
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,305 --> 00:00:10,986
In this segment,
we gonna take a look at importing and

3
00:00:10,986 --> 00:00:14,490
exporting data to the active
directory,data PowerShell.

4
00:00:14,490 --> 00:00:16,110
And most commonly this
is gonna be done for

5
00:00:16,110 --> 00:00:21,840
doing things like creating user accounts
or other activities, as far as importing.

6
00:00:21,840 --> 00:00:24,730
On the exporting side,
it's just generating reports.

7
00:00:24,730 --> 00:00:28,450
Finding information out about the users
that are inside of our active directory.

8
00:00:28,450 --> 00:00:32,360
PowerShell gives us quite a few utilities
to do that so let's take a look.

9
00:00:32,360 --> 00:00:33,740
>> Let's take a peek here.

10
00:00:33,740 --> 00:00:36,300
So one of the things, you're probably
familiar if you've worked with active

11
00:00:36,300 --> 00:00:40,860
directory any amount of time, you might
be familiar with some tools like CSVDE Or

12
00:00:40,860 --> 00:00:45,030
L div DE, these were command line
tools that we could use to import and

13
00:00:45,030 --> 00:00:47,570
export data out of Active Directory.

14
00:00:47,570 --> 00:00:51,330
PowerShell let's us do that,
let's us work with our CSV files.

15
00:00:51,330 --> 00:00:56,340
We can actually use PowerShell to go get
that CSV file, load it up into variable,

16
00:00:56,340 --> 00:00:59,390
and then just do a Foreach loop and
work our way through that CSV file.

17
00:00:59,390 --> 00:01:02,260
Your first question might be, why?

18
00:01:02,260 --> 00:01:03,290
Why the heck would I do that?

19
00:01:03,290 --> 00:01:07,590
I already have CSVDE, I can use
CSVDE to pull in that text file and

20
00:01:07,590 --> 00:01:08,490
dump it in Active Directory,

21
00:01:08,490 --> 00:01:11,890
because you can create new objects
in Active Directory with CSVDE.

22
00:01:12,930 --> 00:01:17,450
What you cannot do With CSVED,
is set the password.

23
00:01:17,450 --> 00:01:19,480
Right?
Which mean all those accounts that you

24
00:01:19,480 --> 00:01:23,170
create, you're gonna have to go back,
and set the password,

25
00:01:23,170 --> 00:01:26,470
then you're gonna have to go back again,
and enable those accounts.

26
00:01:26,470 --> 00:01:28,980
Which I could do with
the PowerShell script as well.

27
00:01:28,980 --> 00:01:33,100
But if I use PowerShell to bring
the CSV file in the first place,

28
00:01:33,100 --> 00:01:37,160
I can go ahead and set the password
then as well as enable the account.

29
00:01:37,160 --> 00:01:37,860
I can do it all in one step.

30
00:01:37,860 --> 00:01:41,570
What's really cool is typically we're
going to be doing this with a script, so

31
00:01:41,570 --> 00:01:44,180
I can,
in fact let me pull it up the script.

32
00:01:44,180 --> 00:01:45,550
First I'll pull up the CSV file.

33
00:01:45,550 --> 00:01:47,530
You guys have seen.

34
00:01:47,530 --> 00:01:49,900
Let me modify my extension
on this guy real quick.

35
00:01:51,915 --> 00:01:54,550
You guys have seen a CSV file, I'm sure.

36
00:01:54,550 --> 00:01:56,640
I want to pull it up and
show you what I've got in there.

37
00:01:58,080 --> 00:02:02,006
All right, and let's bump that font
up a wee bit so we can see it on TV.

38
00:02:03,586 --> 00:02:06,010
All right.

39
00:02:06,010 --> 00:02:11,460
So, like any other CSV file I've got
separate lines on each line is one object.

40
00:02:11,460 --> 00:02:15,890
The values on one line represent one
object, they're separated by commas.

41
00:02:15,890 --> 00:02:18,750
On that very first line,
I've got what we call our header row.

42
00:02:18,750 --> 00:02:21,480
Where I'm defining the order
of those attributes, right?

43
00:02:21,480 --> 00:02:23,730
What order those attributes
are gonna appear in.

44
00:02:23,730 --> 00:02:24,600
So, I've got first name,

45
00:02:24,600 --> 00:02:27,740
comma, last name, comma, department,
and comma default password.

46
00:02:27,740 --> 00:02:32,400
Now, notice I'm not using the actual name
we would see in Active Directory, and

47
00:02:32,400 --> 00:02:36,320
that's okay because we're gonna be
swapping them up when we run our script.

48
00:02:36,320 --> 00:02:39,780
If I was doing this with CSVDE,
that would fail, right?

49
00:02:39,780 --> 00:02:41,940
There is no first name attribute,
it's a given name.

50
00:02:41,940 --> 00:02:45,240
There is no last name attribute,
it's dash surname.

51
00:02:45,240 --> 00:02:49,940
So because I'm using a script, I can put a
little more user friendly information here

52
00:02:49,940 --> 00:02:55,110
and you use this, you might have a brand
new network that you're setting up and

53
00:02:55,110 --> 00:02:59,460
you want to create all of your users in
bulk or maybe hrs hiring a whole slew,

54
00:02:59,460 --> 00:03:01,460
maybe they're bringing in
20 new employees next week.

55
00:03:01,460 --> 00:03:04,700
They've already I've already got
a spreadsheet, with first name, last name,

56
00:03:04,700 --> 00:03:08,190
some address information, and
things like that in the spreadsheet.

57
00:03:08,190 --> 00:03:12,460
I can save it as a CSV file, and
turn around and import it with PowerShell.

58
00:03:12,460 --> 00:03:15,930
Now let me show you the script
that I've written here

59
00:03:15,930 --> 00:03:18,605
you're gonna edit this newusers.ps1.

60
00:03:18,605 --> 00:03:22,095
PowerShell will open up, there we go.

61
00:03:22,095 --> 00:03:26,920
[LAUGH] And I simply have a couple of
variables at the beginning, a csvfile and

62
00:03:26,920 --> 00:03:30,210
then the path to that csvfile.

63
00:03:31,670 --> 00:03:36,040
And on the following line,
where do I wanna create these new users.

64
00:03:36,040 --> 00:03:40,420
I'm gonna put them in UserAccounts,

65
00:03:40,420 --> 00:03:43,670
I'm pretty sure I have an OU
called user accounts in there.

66
00:03:43,670 --> 00:03:46,660
So I'm just storing that information and
variables.

67
00:03:46,660 --> 00:03:49,400
And then I've got a $users= and

68
00:03:49,400 --> 00:03:54,660
there's my PowerShell command,
import-CSV, this is what's gonna go out,

69
00:03:54,660 --> 00:03:59,650
find that CSV file, and
store that in this variable $users.

70
00:03:59,650 --> 00:04:01,980
So with this script I've given
myself a little flexibility.

71
00:04:01,980 --> 00:04:07,670
I could have just done Import-CSV and
then the path to that CSV file.

72
00:04:07,670 --> 00:04:11,910
But instead I put in a variable up here,
so if I want to reuse this next week,

73
00:04:11,910 --> 00:04:13,190
I can just come in here.

74
00:04:13,190 --> 00:04:17,510
And modify the name or
the location of that CSV file or

75
00:04:17,510 --> 00:04:21,420
modify the OU that I wanna
dump those user accounts in.

76
00:04:21,420 --> 00:04:23,700
I don't have to rewrite
the entire script every time, so

77
00:04:23,700 --> 00:04:26,079
there's a little bit
of re-usability there.

78
00:04:26,079 --> 00:04:32,040
So there's $users Import-CSV and then the
variable, it's gonna go pull that file and

79
00:04:32,040 --> 00:04:36,157
then the actual PowerShell
script four each $I and

80
00:04:36,157 --> 00:04:40,730
$user so it's going to loop through
each line in that CSV file and

81
00:04:40,730 --> 00:04:44,320
it's going to set their display
name we're gonna right.

82
00:04:44,320 --> 00:04:48,490
We're going to plug two strings
together with a space in between them,

83
00:04:48,490 --> 00:04:50,710
that firstName and that LastName.

84
00:04:50,710 --> 00:04:55,130
Now these are the names from the CSV file,
so

85
00:04:55,130 --> 00:04:58,455
if I'd called them something else,
given name, surname Name.

86
00:04:58,455 --> 00:05:00,435
Just name, whatever.

87
00:05:00,435 --> 00:05:02,325
I would change those there.

88
00:05:02,325 --> 00:05:04,865
The dollar sign display name is
the attribute that we're gonna

89
00:05:04,865 --> 00:05:07,625
change in active directory
on that user account.

90
00:05:07,625 --> 00:05:10,625
I've also got a $SecurePass,

91
00:05:10,625 --> 00:05:14,695
and I'm setting that equal
to ConvertTo-Securestring.

92
00:05:14,695 --> 00:05:19,295
And then I'm just gonna pull from
the CSVfile whatever I've got in that

93
00:05:19,295 --> 00:05:22,650
last column if you will
that DefaultPassword.

94
00:05:22,650 --> 00:05:24,680
I'm doing it as plain text.

95
00:05:24,680 --> 00:05:27,860
And then the final part of the script
is the actual new user command.

96
00:05:27,860 --> 00:05:30,730
So until here we've just been
getting everything set up so

97
00:05:30,730 --> 00:05:33,720
that I can now run the new-ad user.

98
00:05:33,720 --> 00:05:38,410
So it's new-Aduser-Name and
it's gonna grab the first name.

99
00:05:38,410 --> 00:05:42,430
-Given, and
it's gonna go grab the FirstName again.

100
00:05:43,500 --> 00:05:46,710
Surname is gonna be their
LastName from the CSV file.

101
00:05:46,710 --> 00:05:49,500
DisplayName, it's gonna
do the $DisplayName.

102
00:05:49,500 --> 00:05:53,330
And remember,
I set that equal to FirstName concatenated

103
00:05:53,330 --> 00:05:54,255
with their LastName.

104
00:05:55,390 --> 00:05:57,820
And then I've got their department pulling
from the CSV file, and then the path,

105
00:05:57,820 --> 00:06:03,810
pulling from the variable we set
at the beginning of this script,

106
00:06:03,810 --> 00:06:05,560
and then the account password.

107
00:06:05,560 --> 00:06:08,640
It's going to grab the password
out of that file and

108
00:06:08,640 --> 00:06:11,190
it's going to Enable that account.

109
00:06:11,190 --> 00:06:14,070
>> Because the default is that
the accounts we create will be disabled,

110
00:06:14,070 --> 00:06:17,230
which you may want, but in our case we're
going to go ahead and bring them live.

111
00:06:17,230 --> 00:06:18,070
>> So let's find out.

112
00:06:18,070 --> 00:06:20,750
We've got that script set up, we're going
to go ahead and execute this script.

113
00:06:20,750 --> 00:06:26,529
Just going to save the script before I
run it, the changes that I made there.

114
00:06:29,290 --> 00:06:31,900
And barring any red text,
we should be successful,

115
00:06:31,900 --> 00:06:35,800
so if I go take a look in
Active Directory, and I think I did that,

116
00:06:35,800 --> 00:06:40,127
what, in User Accounts,
where did I make that?

117
00:06:40,127 --> 00:06:41,660
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now I forgot where I

118
00:06:41,660 --> 00:06:42,445
actually made it there.

119
00:06:42,445 --> 00:06:45,050
ou=UserAccounts, so
let's refresh this screen.

120
00:06:46,540 --> 00:06:50,620
And sure enough there are my three new
employees that have pulled from that

121
00:06:50,620 --> 00:06:51,590
CSV file.

122
00:06:51,590 --> 00:06:54,840
And if I pull one of them up,
I'll see it's got the first name,

123
00:06:54,840 --> 00:06:59,560
the last name the display name and I'll
also notice that the accounts are enabled.

124
00:06:59,560 --> 00:07:01,370
So they're ready to go at this point.

125
00:07:01,370 --> 00:07:03,580
They've got that default password set.

126
00:07:03,580 --> 00:07:07,020
that have pulled from that so at this
point if the user could log on with

127
00:07:07,020 --> 00:07:09,920
those accounts,
we could have them change their password.

128
00:07:09,920 --> 00:07:12,780
And there's other parameters as you saw
in the previous segments, when you go to

129
00:07:12,780 --> 00:07:17,150
create a new user I could have used any
of those parameters If that CVS had more

130
00:07:17,150 --> 00:07:21,250
information, like somebody had gone in,
filled in department, things like that.

131
00:07:21,250 --> 00:07:26,750
Address, city, state, zip, phone numbers,
faxes, all that can be in that text file,

132
00:07:26,750 --> 00:07:30,080
and I could populate all that with
just running that one script.

133
00:07:30,080 --> 00:07:31,350
>> Yeah, basically yeah.

134
00:07:31,350 --> 00:07:32,190
>> And that is it.

135
00:07:32,190 --> 00:07:34,200
That is importing users with CSV.

136
00:07:35,390 --> 00:07:40,340
>> Now, as far as exporting users,
well, do we have an example for

137
00:07:40,340 --> 00:07:40,880
them in this segment?

138
00:07:40,880 --> 00:07:42,026
>> You know, I did not set one up.

139
00:07:42,026 --> 00:07:46,625
>> Okay, we actually did cover that in
another segment if you go back into our

140
00:07:46,625 --> 00:07:51,075
earlier part of the series, which was
actually in the very beginning of

141
00:07:51,075 --> 00:07:53,993
the series,
back in the one point whatevers.

142
00:07:53,993 --> 00:07:57,090
I did one on formating output.

143
00:07:57,090 --> 00:08:00,200
And what you could do is you
can use get dash AD user and

144
00:08:00,200 --> 00:08:02,230
that's what's gonna let you
pull up your user list.

145
00:08:02,230 --> 00:08:03,510
Or get dash anything right?

146
00:08:03,510 --> 00:08:08,090
You can get whatever the heck you want out
of the Active Directory or anywhere else.

147
00:08:08,090 --> 00:08:13,303
And you can pipe that into
the export CSV command lit and

148
00:08:13,303 --> 00:08:16,530
then [INAUDIBLE] dump it out as
a CSV is that's what you want.

149
00:08:16,530 --> 00:08:21,250
There's the convert dash two HTML command
let also that will dump that out.

150
00:08:21,250 --> 00:08:24,627
So, there's a few different
ones that are out there.

151
00:08:24,627 --> 00:08:26,813
Pulls out really quick here, 1.8 so

152
00:08:26,813 --> 00:08:30,600
in 1.8 we did a segment called
Formatting Command Output.

153
00:08:30,600 --> 00:08:34,070
Jump over and check that one out, cuz it
handles all the export stuff right there.

154
00:08:34,070 --> 00:08:35,670
And if not just tied to Active Directory,

155
00:08:35,670 --> 00:08:38,370
it's really tied to everything
inside of the PowerShell.

156
00:08:38,370 --> 00:08:41,780
But if you want to create that CSV,
maybe have a test domain.

157
00:08:41,780 --> 00:08:44,680
And you want to export the users
from this test domain and

158
00:08:44,680 --> 00:08:47,250
then go import them in
your production domain.

159
00:08:47,250 --> 00:08:51,400
You would use the export-CSV
command let to get that data out.

160
00:08:51,400 --> 00:08:52,080
And then you go and

161
00:08:52,080 --> 00:08:56,810
you use a script like Mike's to bring that
data in from that CSV, and move it along.

162
00:08:56,810 --> 00:08:58,180
So that's kind of the other side of it.

163
00:08:58,180 --> 00:08:59,810
Definitely check out that other segment.

164
00:08:59,810 --> 00:09:03,170
It is titled formatting command output,
and it's all right in there.

165
00:09:04,402 --> 00:09:07,660
All right, so in this segment we got
a chance to see how to import data from

166
00:09:07,660 --> 00:09:08,260
a CSV.

167
00:09:08,260 --> 00:09:11,440
Most particularly to create user
accounts inside of the Active Directory.

168
00:09:11,440 --> 00:09:14,470
Iterate through that and
create all those accounts, all at once.

169
00:09:14,470 --> 00:09:15,920
Very nice and easy to do.

170
00:09:15,920 --> 00:09:18,790
Beats the heck out of using the GUI for
something like this.

171
00:09:18,790 --> 00:09:19,690
>> Absolutely.

172
00:09:19,690 --> 00:09:21,340
>> Alright,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the segment.

173
00:09:21,340 --> 00:09:22,420
Stay tuned.

174
00:09:22,420 --> 00:09:24,512
We've got more PowerShell coming up.

175
00:09:24,512 --> 00:09:30,369

episodes.title: Performing Bulk Operations
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,972
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,972 --> 00:00:11,674
In this segment we're gonna take a look
at performing bulk operations inside of

3
00:00:11,674 --> 00:00:13,310
the Active Directory.

4
00:00:13,310 --> 00:00:18,140
The whole glory of PowerShell, if it has
any glory, is the fact that it makes it

5
00:00:18,140 --> 00:00:22,770
really easy to make large quantities
of changes really rapidly.

6
00:00:22,770 --> 00:00:25,570
If I just have to change a value for
one user, I'll just go into

7
00:00:25,570 --> 00:00:29,450
Active Directory the computers do it in
the GUI, why mess around with a script?

8
00:00:29,450 --> 00:00:33,330
But, if I have to change 1000 users,
forget that, you don't want to go and

9
00:00:33,330 --> 00:00:35,910
do that in a GUI,
that PowerShell is where it's at.

10
00:00:35,910 --> 00:00:39,250
So, Mike you've got a couple example for
us of ways to do that, right?

11
00:00:39,250 --> 00:00:42,620
>> I do, hopefully,
[LAUGH] yeah, it really is,

12
00:00:42,620 --> 00:00:46,450
it's advantageous because in the GUI
you can do some bulk operations, right?

13
00:00:46,450 --> 00:00:49,220
If you can select all the users
you want to work with,

14
00:00:49,220 --> 00:00:52,460
you can pull up the properties and
you'll see the things that you can change

15
00:00:52,460 --> 00:00:54,390
when you have more than
one object selected.

16
00:00:54,390 --> 00:00:55,920
The problem is the selection, right?

17
00:00:55,920 --> 00:00:58,220
If they're all in the same OU and
they're all on the same screen,

18
00:00:58,220 --> 00:01:01,490
I can use my different techniques like
click on the first one, hold down Shift,

19
00:01:01,490 --> 00:01:02,660
click on the last one.

20
00:01:02,660 --> 00:01:03,800
What if they're in different OUs,

21
00:01:03,800 --> 00:01:05,780
different locations
within Active Directory?

22
00:01:05,780 --> 00:01:08,560
No way to select those
multiple objects and

23
00:01:08,560 --> 00:01:10,570
you can’t change all the parameters
when you’re in the GUI.

24
00:01:10,570 --> 00:01:12,490
So that’s really where
PowerShell comes into play,

25
00:01:12,490 --> 00:01:16,615
the ability to find what I’m looking for
and then make changes en masse.

26
00:01:16,615 --> 00:01:17,275
So let's take a look.

27
00:01:17,275 --> 00:01:19,945
The first thing you're gonna need
to be able to do is find what

28
00:01:19,945 --> 00:01:20,495
you're looking for.

29
00:01:20,495 --> 00:01:24,185
We somehow need to select
the objects that I wanna change.

30
00:01:24,185 --> 00:01:27,425
And we're gonna use a Get-ADUser command.

31
00:01:27,425 --> 00:01:32,745
And if I just do a Get-ADUser,
it does require a filter parameter.

32
00:01:32,745 --> 00:01:35,535
You can do an asterisk for the filter and

33
00:01:35,535 --> 00:01:39,120
it should return all the users
I have in Active Directory.

34
00:01:39,120 --> 00:01:43,065
Including things like my built-in
administrator account, my guest account,

35
00:01:43,065 --> 00:01:46,836
my Kerberos Ticket-Granting Ticket Service
account and things like that,

36
00:01:46,836 --> 00:01:49,250
typically not what we're trying to do.

37
00:01:49,250 --> 00:01:51,290
So, we can do a couple
of different things,

38
00:01:51,290 --> 00:01:54,390
we can change up the filter to
change what we're looking for.

39
00:01:54,390 --> 00:01:56,948
We can also adjust the search base.

40
00:01:56,948 --> 00:02:00,310
So for example; I'm gonna come back
in here and add, I'm gonna reuse this

41
00:02:00,310 --> 00:02:03,380
command a few times, so I'm gonna add
it to the beginning of this command.

42
00:02:03,380 --> 00:02:05,210
I'm gonna do a search base.

43
00:02:05,210 --> 00:02:09,850
And this is telling it where
I want to start the search.

44
00:02:09,850 --> 00:02:13,030
For example, if I put in here for

00:15:09,360 --> 00:15:13,410
If you want it to prompt you for
each one, that yes, no all prompt,

270
00:15:13,410 --> 00:15:16,610
and that way you can go one by one and
verify.

271
00:15:16,610 --> 00:15:19,040
So, if you want to make sure, yeah,
go ahead and search the AD for

272
00:15:19,040 --> 00:15:21,090
people who haven't
logged in in 90 days but

273
00:15:21,090 --> 00:15:23,600
one by one give me a chance to accept or
deny, right?

274
00:15:23,600 --> 00:15:27,870
You can throw a -confirm on the end and
it'll confirm each step along the way.

275
00:15:27,870 --> 00:15:31,300
So -whatif, -confirm, good ones to use
when you're doing bulk operations.

276
00:15:33,230 --> 00:15:36,470
All right, well, in this segment
we got a chance to see how to

277
00:15:36,470 --> 00:15:38,760
handle bulk operations in the PowerShell.

278
00:15:38,760 --> 00:15:42,410
We come up with some kind of get command
that gathers all the objects you want

279
00:15:42,410 --> 00:15:43,260
to modify.

280
00:15:43,260 --> 00:15:46,850
And we pipe that into a set or
a modified command to actually go in and

281
00:15:46,850 --> 00:15:49,510
change those values and
get them put in place.

282
00:15:49,510 --> 00:15:51,910
Pretty easy to do, very powerful.

283
00:15:51,910 --> 00:15:54,890
We also talk about some ways to test and
make sure we don't screw it up!

284
00:15:54,890 --> 00:15:55,820
Right?
>> [LAUGH]

285
00:15:55,820 --> 00:15:57,220
>> Running our get command

286
00:15:57,220 --> 00:15:59,640
with the filter first to verify
we get the results we want.

287
00:15:59,640 --> 00:16:01,850
Using what if, using confirm, right?

288
00:16:01,850 --> 00:16:04,300
All different modifiers that
are pretty handy there.

289
00:16:04,300 --> 00:16:08,480
Really good stuff and this is truly
what the PowerShell is designed for.

290
00:16:08,480 --> 00:16:09,260
Bulk changes.

291
00:16:10,330 --> 00:16:11,790
All right, well,
I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

292
00:16:11,790 --> 00:16:14,450
Stay tuned we've got more
PowerShell coming up.

293
00:16:14,450 --> 00:16:20,109
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Installing Hyper-V
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,457
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,161 --> 00:00:13,200
All right, in this segment, we're going to
be using PowerShell to install Hyper-V.

3
00:00:13,200 --> 00:00:14,589
So let's take a look at
what we've got here.

4
00:00:15,810 --> 00:00:18,224
I've got a server and I've got
server manager opened up currently.

5
00:00:18,224 --> 00:00:21,278
As we can see, there are no roles
installed on it currently and

6
00:00:21,278 --> 00:00:24,392
we're going to take this server and
make it a Hyper-V server so

7
00:00:24,392 --> 00:00:26,551
we can use it to host
our virtual machines.

8
00:00:26,551 --> 00:00:30,987
So I'm going to pull up PowerShell, and
as we've seen in previous segments,

9
00:00:30,987 --> 00:00:34,838
the installing of the role,
is a pretty straight forward command.

10
00:00:34,838 --> 00:00:40,144
It's gonna be, install-windowsfeature and

11
00:00:40,144 --> 00:00:45,581
the name of the role that
we're trying to install

12
00:00:45,581 --> 00:00:50,636
is going to be a Hyper-V, so name Hyper-V.

13
00:00:50,636 --> 00:00:56,580
And then I have to decide whether or not
I want to include the management tools,

14
00:00:56,580 --> 00:01:00,377
which I'm going to try to
spell a little bit better

15
00:01:06,665 --> 00:01:10,794
They include those management tools, and
Hyper-V is one of the roles that's going

16
00:01:10,794 --> 00:01:13,250
to require a restart to
finish the installation.

17
00:01:13,250 --> 00:01:16,570
So, I am going to include
a restart perimeter

18
00:01:16,570 --> 00:01:19,700
which will force that machine to restart
on the completion of this command.

19
00:01:19,700 --> 00:01:21,580
So, I'll go ahead and run that command.

20
00:01:21,580 --> 00:01:25,790
It's gonna collect the data and
it's gonna begin installing that role.

21
00:01:25,790 --> 00:01:27,836
So that you guys don't
have to sit here and

22
00:01:27,836 --> 00:01:31,656
watch the progress bar go across the
screen, we'll take a quick TV time out.

23
00:01:31,656 --> 00:01:33,823
We come back the server
will have rebooted and

24
00:01:33,823 --> 00:01:37,313
we'll verify that Hyper-V has been
installed so we'll be right back.

25
00:01:37,313 --> 00:01:43,241
[SOUND] [SOUND] All right,
and through the magic of TV,

26
00:01:43,241 --> 00:01:47,160
that was the fastest reboot ever.

27
00:01:47,160 --> 00:01:50,608
So if we take a look at my screen now,
we’ve installed that role, the server is

28
00:01:50,608 --> 00:01:54,404
rebooted, and I’m gonna open up PowerShell
just to make sure everything went well.

29
00:01:54,404 --> 00:01:57,970
Couple ways we could verify
that that role was installed.

30
00:01:57,970 --> 00:02:03,592
One of them is gonna check on the service,
see we’ll do a get-service.

31
00:02:03,592 --> 00:02:05,375
I'm really having a hard
time typing today.

32
00:02:05,375 --> 00:02:09,565
get-service, the name of that service
is VMMS and there I already can see

33
00:02:09,565 --> 00:02:15,130
the Hyper-V Virtual Machine Management
service is running, so that's a good sign.

34
00:02:15,130 --> 00:02:18,302
The other thing I can do is a get-vmhost.

35
00:02:20,296 --> 00:02:24,750
And that should tell me about the physical
machine that I've installed this role on.

36
00:02:24,750 --> 00:02:27,700
There I can see the name of
the machine is actually VMHOST,

37
00:02:27,700 --> 00:02:28,940
we did that intentionally.

38
00:02:28,940 --> 00:02:33,080
It's got a couple logical processors
there, I can see its memory capabilities.

39
00:02:33,080 --> 00:02:37,631
Another command I could run that's not
gonna be so exciting just yet is get-vm.

40
00:02:37,631 --> 00:02:39,908
We'll run this one in a segment coming up,

41
00:02:39,908 --> 00:02:42,330
because right now I have
no virtual machine.

42
00:02:42,330 --> 00:02:46,710
We just installed Hyper-V, so I don't
really have anything to look at there.

43
00:02:46,710 --> 00:02:51,760
Another command I could do would be a
get-command, especially useful when we're

44
00:02:51,760 --> 00:02:56,675
getting familiar with Hyper-V and what
I can do with Hyper-V from PowerShell.

45
00:02:56,675 --> 00:03:04,234
So I do a get-command -module, and the
name of that module is gonna be hyper-v.

46
00:03:04,234 --> 00:03:07,990
And you can see there's quite a few
commands that I can use to manipulate

47
00:03:07,990 --> 00:03:12,435
the physical server you know the virtual
machine host itself the virtual machines,

48
00:03:12,435 --> 00:03:13,910
the virtual switches.

49
00:03:13,910 --> 00:03:17,929
Everything associated with managing and
maintaining these virtual machines.

50
00:03:17,929 --> 00:03:21,694
Now the one thing I want to point out
is these commands became available with

51
00:03:21,694 --> 00:03:22,785
PowerShell 3.0.

52
00:03:22,785 --> 00:03:27,678
That's when they added the module for
Hyper-V to give us the ability to work

53
00:03:27,678 --> 00:03:31,130
with the Hyper-V server
from my PowerShell prompt.

54
00:03:32,980 --> 00:03:36,300
So, in this segment,
we installed the role Hyper-V.

55
00:03:36,300 --> 00:03:39,140
Got that installed,
verified that was installed.

56
00:03:39,140 --> 00:03:42,875
In future segments coming up, we're gonna
take a look at all of the things we can do

57
00:03:42,875 --> 00:03:45,710
with our Hyper-V server,
now that we've got it installed.

58
00:03:45,710 --> 00:03:49,670
We'll take a look at creating some virtual
switches, creating some virtual machines

59
00:03:49,670 --> 00:03:52,450
and then managing and
maintaining those virtual machines.

60
00:03:52,450 --> 00:03:55,651
So you guys stay tuned,
more PowerShell coming up.

61
00:03:55,651 --> 00:03:57,460
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Configuring VMs
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,441
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,441 --> 00:00:11,882
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at how we can use PowerShell to create

3
00:00:11,882 --> 00:00:16,560
virtual machines and manage those
virtual machines on a Hyper-V server.

4
00:00:16,560 --> 00:00:18,750
So let's dive in and see what we've got.

5
00:00:18,750 --> 00:00:21,150
First thing I'm gonna do is we're gonna
go ahead and create a virtual machine.

6
00:00:21,150 --> 00:00:24,800
In a previous segment I've
installed Hyper-V on this server.

7
00:00:24,800 --> 00:00:28,050
So I’ve got a brand new Hyper-V server,
nothing created yet.

8
00:00:28,050 --> 00:00:30,190
Now I did do a little
bit behind the scenes.

9
00:00:30,190 --> 00:00:35,310
We’re gonna take a look at another segment
at how I can create my virtual switches

10
00:00:35,310 --> 00:00:38,495
that we use to network these
virtual machines together, and

11
00:00:38,495 --> 00:00:41,165
with our physical network in
our corporate environment.

12
00:00:41,165 --> 00:00:42,835
I'm gonna save that for
another segment, so

13
00:00:42,835 --> 00:00:47,785
I precreated a switch that I can use
when I create these virtual machines.

14
00:00:47,785 --> 00:00:51,090
So let's take a look at the command and
how we can create some virtual machines.

15
00:00:51,090 --> 00:00:54,132
The syntax is relatively straight forward.

16
00:00:54,132 --> 00:00:58,762
It's going to be new-vm is
the command that we're gonna use.

17
00:00:58,762 --> 00:01:02,785
And I can do it a couple of different
ways, we can do new-vm and then just

18
00:01:02,785 --> 00:01:07,430
give it a name and hit enter and you'll
see it actually created a virtual machine.

19
00:01:07,430 --> 00:01:09,196
Now I've used all of my defaults.

20
00:01:09,196 --> 00:01:12,136
If I was to go into my Hyper-V settings,
I've got my defaults for

21
00:01:12,136 --> 00:01:15,342
where it's going to create the virtual
machine configuration files,

22
00:01:15,342 --> 00:01:18,725
where it's gonna create, in fact,
this one didn't create a hard drive.

23
00:01:18,725 --> 00:01:21,691
I didn't specify to create
a hard drive in the command,

24
00:01:21,691 --> 00:01:24,670
I didn't attach an existing
hard drive in the command.

25
00:01:24,670 --> 00:01:28,300
And if you think to the GUI, right, if you
go back to the wizard cuz most of us have

26
00:01:28,300 --> 00:01:29,980
gone through the wizard at this point.

27
00:01:29,980 --> 00:01:32,720
We're now moving on to using PowerShell,
we can start automating this,

28
00:01:32,720 --> 00:01:33,870
get a little more powerful.

29
00:01:33,870 --> 00:01:36,879
Think about the options that you had
to choose when you're creating a new VM

30
00:01:36,879 --> 00:01:39,666
through the wizard, right,
inside the graphical user interface.

31
00:01:39,666 --> 00:01:41,882
You gotta specify the name and
the location.

32
00:01:41,882 --> 00:01:46,940
Well, since I didn't specify, I gave it
a name, it used all my default locations.

33
00:01:46,940 --> 00:01:48,640
I didn't attach a virtual hard drive.

34
00:01:48,640 --> 00:01:49,330
So it just left it.

35
00:01:49,330 --> 00:01:51,539
It does not have a virtual
hard drive at this point.

36
00:01:51,539 --> 00:01:53,931
So not the most useful command, right?

37
00:01:53,931 --> 00:01:57,149
Just wanted to show you that you
could do that and then go back and

38
00:01:57,149 --> 00:01:59,050
add the rest of it later.

39
00:01:59,050 --> 00:02:02,530
Next I wanna show you a command where I
actually specify a few more parameters,

40
00:02:02,530 --> 00:02:05,590
make it a more useful virtual machine.

41
00:02:05,590 --> 00:02:08,400
I'm gonna start out the same, new-vm.

42
00:02:08,400 --> 00:02:10,320
I'm gonna give this
virtual machine a name.

43
00:02:10,320 --> 00:02:15,421
I'm gonna call it something like web01,
keep it nice and short.

44
00:02:15,421 --> 00:02:17,169
Next parameter I'm gonna use,

45
00:02:17,169 --> 00:02:20,413
I'm gonna specify how much
memory it has when it starts up.

46
00:02:20,413 --> 00:02:24,443
And the parameter for that is gonna be

47
00:02:24,443 --> 00:02:30,167
-MemoryStartupBytes, -MemoryStartupBytes.

48
00:02:30,167 --> 00:02:34,252
I'll go ahead and
give this guy 2048, a couple gigs.

49
00:02:34,252 --> 00:02:37,663
All right, and
that's gonna be in megabytes, and

50
00:02:37,663 --> 00:02:40,380
then I'm gonna attach it to a network.

51
00:02:40,380 --> 00:02:41,970
Now again,
I've already created this network,

52
00:02:41,970 --> 00:02:45,530
I'll show you how to create those
networks in a later segment.

53
00:02:45,530 --> 00:02:51,280
So the parameter's gonna be -SwitchName,
-SwitchName,

54
00:02:51,280 --> 00:02:54,870
and the one I created was called lan,
or I just called it lan for short.

55
00:02:56,450 --> 00:03:02,652
And then I can do a -NewVHDPath,
-NewVHDPath,

56
00:03:02,652 --> 00:03:08,271
and I'll specify where
I wanna create that.

57
00:03:08,271 --> 00:03:12,556
Remember when you configure your Hyper-V
server you can specify what your default

58
00:03:12,556 --> 00:03:14,402
locations are for creating these.

59
00:03:14,402 --> 00:03:17,909
And then you don't have to provide these,
but if you want to create it in

60
00:03:17,909 --> 00:03:21,534
an alternate location, you can provide
this parameter in the command and

61
00:03:21,534 --> 00:03:23,920
you can use that alternate location.

62
00:03:23,920 --> 00:03:29,106
For me, I'm gonna do c:\,
I think I made a folder called virtuals.

63
00:03:29,106 --> 00:03:30,198
Yeah, I did.

64
00:03:30,198 --> 00:03:34,610
I'll just dump it in there, and
then I'm gonna give that disc a name.

65
00:03:34,610 --> 00:03:40,260
I'm going to call it webo1-disc1 and
we'll go ahead and

66
00:03:40,260 --> 00:03:44,441
make that a vhdx, that new generation, and

67
00:03:44,441 --> 00:03:48,063
then the size is -NewVHDSizeBytes.

68
00:03:48,063 --> 00:03:51,709
So, -NewVHDSizeBytes.

69
00:03:51,709 --> 00:03:57,701
And I'm going to make
this one 64GB in size.

70
00:03:57,701 --> 00:03:59,363
Go ahead and hit Enter.

71
00:03:59,363 --> 00:04:03,990
Now if I didn't make any crazy typos
it should create that machine.

72
00:04:03,990 --> 00:04:08,106
Now, in this case, it created what we'd
call a dynamically expanding drive, right?

73
00:04:08,106 --> 00:04:10,644
You guys have gone through the episodes
hopefully where we've talked

74
00:04:10,644 --> 00:04:12,332
about Hyper-V and virtual machines before.

75
00:04:12,332 --> 00:04:17,395
It creates a dynamically expanding drive,
meaning it's not actually 64 gigabytes.

76
00:04:17,395 --> 00:04:22,175
It completed almost immediately, so
right now it's about 4 megs in size and

77
00:04:22,175 --> 00:04:24,244
it'll grow as I add data to them.

78
00:04:24,244 --> 00:04:28,127
When I install my operating system, when
I configure it, when I add files to it,

79
00:04:28,127 --> 00:04:29,051
things like that.

80
00:04:29,051 --> 00:04:32,812
That drive will expand to
a maximum of 64 gigabytes.

81
00:04:32,812 --> 00:04:36,379
So, that's really what I'm specifying
there, is the max size for

82
00:04:36,379 --> 00:04:38,954
that dynamically expanding drive,
all right.

83
00:04:38,954 --> 00:04:41,738
So, now I've got a virtual
machine that we can work with and

84
00:04:41,738 --> 00:04:44,816
let's take a look at a couple of
the commands I might use for that.

85
00:04:44,816 --> 00:04:48,635
The first one,
one I find very useful is just Get-VM.

86
00:04:48,635 --> 00:04:51,497
Now if I do a get-vm,
we saw that a previous segment, and

87
00:04:51,497 --> 00:04:54,460
I didn't have any virtual
machines at that point.

88
00:04:54,460 --> 00:04:57,330
Now that I've got a virtual machine,
or a couple of virtual machines,

89
00:04:57,330 --> 00:05:00,450
I can see a little bit of information
about those virtual machines.

90
00:05:00,450 --> 00:05:04,360
I've got one called test, I've got one
called web01, both of them are currently

91
00:05:04,360 --> 00:05:08,470
turned off so they're not using any
CPU and they're not using any memory.

92
00:05:08,470 --> 00:05:09,730
Real quick easy command,

93
00:05:09,730 --> 00:05:13,210
though, if I need to take a look at any
of my Hyper-V servers, and see which

94
00:05:13,210 --> 00:05:17,690
one of my machines is soaking up a lot
of my resources, easy command to use.

95
00:05:17,690 --> 00:05:19,750
Now, I can get a little more
specific with that command.

96
00:05:19,750 --> 00:05:21,771
We can take that get-vm command,

97
00:05:21,771 --> 00:05:26,315
add the name of a particular virtual
machine that I wanna get information on.

98
00:05:26,315 --> 00:05:29,197
And if I just do it like that
I get the same information,

99
00:05:29,197 --> 00:05:33,395
it's just filtered to that one machine,
which could be handy if you have dozens

100
00:05:33,395 --> 00:05:35,986
of machines and
you want to see a particular one.

101
00:05:35,986 --> 00:05:39,980
You can also use wildcards in here,
which is another very handy thing to do.

102
00:05:39,980 --> 00:05:44,984
Like if I had several web servers and
also additional servers as well.

103
00:05:44,984 --> 00:05:49,714
If I wanted to see just some information
about the web servers, I had web01,

104
00:05:49,714 --> 00:05:52,866
web01, web03,
I could do a get-vm web *, and

105
00:05:52,866 --> 00:05:56,660
I would see just the virtual
machines I started with web.

106
00:05:56,660 --> 00:05:58,090
So very handy there.

107
00:05:58,090 --> 00:05:59,686
And another command,
what I like to do, though,

108
00:05:59,686 --> 00:06:01,740
is I want a little more information
about that virtual machine.

109
00:06:01,740 --> 00:06:03,782
I want to see what some
of the configuration is.

110
00:06:03,782 --> 00:06:07,530
Like in the GUI if we were to go in and
right-click on our virtual machine and

111
00:06:07,530 --> 00:06:10,460
choose settings and
pull up that settings page.

112
00:06:10,460 --> 00:06:14,530
I could do that here by
piping out the get-vm,

113
00:06:14,530 --> 00:06:19,020
name of the virtual machine,
pipe that into a select all.

114
00:06:19,020 --> 00:06:21,786
I'll just do a select and
then an asterisk, and

115
00:06:21,786 --> 00:06:25,867
I should get all that information or
the majority of the information,

116
00:06:25,867 --> 00:06:28,789
a lot of the information I'm looking for
anyway.

117
00:06:28,789 --> 00:06:32,212
Like I can see the current
state is that it's off.

118
00:06:32,212 --> 00:06:35,630
I can see memory assign,
it's not turned on right now so

119
00:06:35,630 --> 00:06:38,740
it's not really using any resources.

120
00:06:38,740 --> 00:06:43,166
Where the snapshots are going,
what my automatic start and

121
00:06:43,166 --> 00:06:45,130
stop action is, things like that.

122
00:06:45,130 --> 00:06:50,550
And all of these parameters can be set
through PowerShell using a set-vm command,

123
00:06:50,550 --> 00:06:51,130
right.

124
00:06:51,130 --> 00:06:53,910
And then we can use
the name of the parameter.

125
00:06:53,910 --> 00:06:56,939
For example, let's say I want to
change the number of processors.

126
00:06:56,939 --> 00:07:00,625
I can see right here, this virtual
machine has a processor count of one.

127
00:07:00,625 --> 00:07:01,144
All right.

128
00:07:01,144 --> 00:07:06,926
So if I wanna give it another processor,
I can do a Set-VMProcessor.

129
00:07:06,926 --> 00:07:11,492
All right, so I'm specifying that
attribute that I'm trying to change on

130
00:07:11,492 --> 00:07:14,251
that virtual machine, Set-VMProcessor.

131
00:07:14,251 --> 00:07:16,169
And the name of that is web01,

132
00:07:16,169 --> 00:07:19,872
the machine I'm trying to make
the configuration change to.

133
00:07:19,872 --> 00:07:22,579
And we'll set that to a -Count of 2,

134
00:07:22,579 --> 00:07:26,396
I'm assuming I have a couple
processors available.

135
00:07:26,396 --> 00:07:28,637
It should take care of that.

136
00:07:28,637 --> 00:07:34,016
It doesn't give me a lot of information
back, so I could run another get-vm web01,

137
00:07:34,016 --> 00:07:37,570
we'll just pipe that out into
a select all or a select *.

138
00:07:39,370 --> 00:07:42,630
And now I can see the number
of processors is up to 2.

139
00:07:42,630 --> 00:07:47,370
So I was able to modify a configuration
setting on that virtual machine

140
00:07:47,370 --> 00:07:50,640
via PowerShell.

141
00:07:50,640 --> 00:07:55,981
Another one that you might find
useful in the production environment,

142
00:07:55,981 --> 00:07:59,015
don't usually use the dynamic memory.

143
00:07:59,015 --> 00:08:00,424
But in a test environment,

144
00:08:00,424 --> 00:08:03,925
I really like the dynamic memory
because it's a test environment.

145
00:08:03,925 --> 00:08:05,958
I'm not looking for extreme performance.

146
00:08:05,958 --> 00:08:09,635
I want to be able to fire up as many
machines as I can at the same time so

147
00:08:09,635 --> 00:08:13,565
I'll typically use this dynamic memory but
just so you guys know how.

148
00:08:13,565 --> 00:08:19,432
Set-VMMemory and then the name of
the server I'm setting that memory on,

149
00:08:19,432 --> 00:08:24,726
web01, the parameter of that one is
going to be -DynamicMemoryEnabled,

150
00:08:24,726 --> 00:08:27,300
-DynamicMemoryEnabled.

151
00:08:27,300 --> 00:08:34,610
And I'm just going to set that to a $true,
hit Enter, and we are good to go.

152
00:08:34,610 --> 00:08:38,660
So more commands that we might use with
a virtual machine once we've got them

153
00:08:38,660 --> 00:08:41,205
created, the ability to start and
stop the VM.

154
00:08:41,205 --> 00:08:44,550
Like this, now, I don't have an operating
system installed on this machine yet.

155
00:08:44,550 --> 00:08:45,990
We just created it.

156
00:08:45,990 --> 00:08:50,409
But I can go ahead and start the VM or
attempt to start the VM anyway.

157
00:08:50,409 --> 00:08:56,308
We're going to a start-vm, and then the
name of the VM I'm trying to start, web01.

158
00:08:56,308 --> 00:09:00,310
And it'll fire the machine up, I mean,
the virtual machine will start, right,

159
00:09:00,310 --> 00:09:02,113
it's just not going to go anywhere.

160
00:09:02,113 --> 00:09:05,247
It's going to come to that screen and
say no boot device detected, right,

161
00:09:05,247 --> 00:09:08,830
because I don't have anything
installed on that particular machine.

162
00:09:08,830 --> 00:09:11,978
If I go back and
get some status on that machine,

163
00:09:11,978 --> 00:09:16,780
I can see that it is currently running and
it is using the two gigs of memory

164
00:09:16,780 --> 00:09:20,126
that I assigned to it when
I created that machine.

165
00:09:20,126 --> 00:09:22,100
Uptime 14 seconds.

166
00:09:22,100 --> 00:09:22,623
Woo hoo!

167
00:09:22,623 --> 00:09:24,747
It’s like a record for
a Microsoft machine.

168
00:09:24,747 --> 00:09:31,640
All right, so then if I wanna stop that,
the command is simply stop-vm.

169
00:09:31,640 --> 00:09:34,030
And then the name of the VM
that I'm trying to stop.

170
00:09:35,620 --> 00:09:37,320
Yes to actually stop that guy.

171
00:09:37,320 --> 00:09:38,650
Oh, you know what?

172
00:09:38,650 --> 00:09:41,440
I haven't installed
the integration services.

173
00:09:41,440 --> 00:09:45,720
It'll stop it anyway, it's just warning me
there that it's not gonna be a graceful

174
00:09:45,720 --> 00:09:48,630
shutdown because I haven't
installed the integration services.

175
00:09:48,630 --> 00:09:51,310
There's no operating system on
the virtual machine yet, so

176
00:09:51,310 --> 00:09:54,120
I can't really install
those integration services.

177
00:09:54,120 --> 00:09:56,820
So there we get to see how to stop and
start that guy.

178
00:09:56,820 --> 00:09:59,620
The other nice thing about that,
remember I said we could use wildcards.

179
00:09:59,620 --> 00:10:01,730
We can use wildcards in
this command as well.

180
00:10:01,730 --> 00:10:06,491
So if I have five webservers,
web01, 2, 3, 4,

181
00:10:06,491 --> 00:10:10,200
and 5, I could do a start-vm web*.

182
00:10:10,200 --> 00:10:14,600
And that would fire up all five of those
machines, or you could do the same thing

183
00:10:14,600 --> 00:10:17,720
if you wanted to shut them all down, or
you can shut every virtual machine down.

184
00:10:17,720 --> 00:10:20,590
You can do a start-vm, or a stop-vm,

185
00:10:20,590 --> 00:10:24,720
and an asterisk with no name at all,
and that will start or

186
00:10:24,720 --> 00:10:29,470
stop all of the virtual machines that
are residing on that Hyper-V host.

187
00:10:31,120 --> 00:10:34,070
All right so in this segment, oh, and
I didn't, let me delete a vm for you guys.

188
00:10:34,070 --> 00:10:36,530
Another thing you might
have to do is remove one.

189
00:10:36,530 --> 00:10:39,820
So the command is just simply
gonna be delete-vm and

190
00:10:39,820 --> 00:10:40,940
then the name of that machine.

191
00:10:40,940 --> 00:10:44,700
I'll go ahead and delete that test virtual
machine we created earlier in the segment.

192
00:10:44,700 --> 00:10:46,920
So delete-vm.

193
00:10:46,920 --> 00:10:48,398
I say delete, I meant remove.

194
00:10:48,398 --> 00:10:52,989
How about remove-vm, and then test.

195
00:10:52,989 --> 00:10:57,751
And it's gonna ask are you sure you
want to remove that virtual machine?

196
00:10:57,751 --> 00:11:00,723
I'll say yes and it will be gone.

197
00:11:00,723 --> 00:11:03,682
Remember when you're running
Hyper-V without a system center

198
00:11:03,682 --> 00:11:07,189
configuration manager when you delete
a machine like that you're deleting

199
00:11:07,189 --> 00:11:08,460
the configuration files.

200
00:11:08,460 --> 00:11:10,682
The hard drive itself is
still going to be there so

201
00:11:10,682 --> 00:11:12,536
something that you have to keep in mind.

202
00:11:12,536 --> 00:11:15,756
You have to go back and delete that
file if I truly wanted to get rid of all

203
00:11:15,756 --> 00:11:17,679
the components of that virtual machine.

204
00:11:17,679 --> 00:11:18,589
All right so

205
00:11:18,589 --> 00:11:24,517
in this segment we've learned how we
can use PowerShell to manage Hyper-V.

206
00:11:24,517 --> 00:11:27,455
We took a look at creating
a virtual machine.

207
00:11:27,455 --> 00:11:31,080
Once we created a virtual machine
we looked at how we start and

208
00:11:31,080 --> 00:11:35,274
stop the machine, make changes to
the configuration of the machine,

209
00:11:35,274 --> 00:11:38,772
as well as remove the machine
at the end of its usefulness.

210
00:11:38,772 --> 00:11:42,643
So I hope you guys enjoyed
today's segment, stay tuned,

211
00:11:42,643 --> 00:11:44,936
more PowerShell coming your way.

212
00:11:44,936 --> 00:11:51,849
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Configuring VHDs
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,370 --> 00:00:08,726
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,726 --> 00:00:11,989
In this segment, we're gonna use
PowerShell to configure some virtual hard

3
00:00:11,989 --> 00:00:15,000
drives, for our virtual
machines on our Hyper-V server.

4
00:00:15,000 --> 00:00:17,018
So let's dive right in and
see what we've got.

5
00:00:17,018 --> 00:00:22,410
Got our Hyper-V, in a previous segment
we installed a Hyper-V on this server.

6
00:00:22,410 --> 00:00:24,220
We also created a couple
of virtual machines.

7
00:00:24,220 --> 00:00:28,020
Now I'm going to take a look at
creating some additional hard drives.

8
00:00:28,020 --> 00:00:29,210
So the first thing I want to do for

9
00:00:29,210 --> 00:00:32,855
you guys is create a dynamic
virtual hard drive.

10
00:00:32,855 --> 00:00:36,765
Production environment, typically we don't
use these dynamic virtual hard drives.

11
00:00:36,765 --> 00:00:40,295
Because we lose a little bit of
performance when that drive has to grow.

12
00:00:40,295 --> 00:00:44,410
We can also run into some issues if
we over allocate that drive space.

13
00:00:44,410 --> 00:00:45,970
As they grow they might run out of space.

14
00:00:45,970 --> 00:00:48,470
They can also become
fragmented as they grow.

15
00:00:48,470 --> 00:00:52,130
But in a test environment before I
move them to a production environment,

16
00:00:52,130 --> 00:00:53,540
we're just testing new technologies.

17
00:00:53,540 --> 00:00:55,780
Dynamic drives are very useful.

18
00:00:55,780 --> 00:00:59,810
When we used that command earlier in
a previous segment to create a VM.

19
00:00:59,810 --> 00:01:04,010
It creates a dynamically
expanding drive by default.

20
00:01:04,010 --> 00:01:08,200
If I want to create a virtual
machine with a fix size drive.

21
00:01:08,200 --> 00:01:11,420
I'd actually have to create
that drive ahead of time, and

22
00:01:11,420 --> 00:01:14,160
then attach it to the virtual machine.

23
00:01:14,160 --> 00:01:17,860
