I can attach it to that virtual machine
after I create the virtual machine.

24
00:01:17,860 --> 00:01:22,710
Or I can attach it during the creation
using the command I used to create.

25
00:01:22,710 --> 00:01:24,510
In the VM or the virtual machine.

26
00:01:24,510 --> 00:01:25,190
So let's see how you do it.

27
00:01:25,190 --> 00:01:27,340
The command is just simply New-VHD.

28
00:01:27,340 --> 00:01:32,710
And then where do I wanna
create this virtual hard drive?

29
00:01:32,710 --> 00:01:34,800
The parameter for that is gonna be -Path.

30
00:01:34,800 --> 00:01:39,401
And I have a folder, I believe,
we'll find out here.

31
00:01:39,401 --> 00:01:44,990
Now, C:\Virtuals\VHD.

32
00:01:44,990 --> 00:01:46,560
So I'm going to drop it in there.

33
00:01:46,560 --> 00:01:49,660
That's where we keep all our virtual
hard drives on our Hyper-V server.

34
00:01:49,660 --> 00:01:52,080
And then the name of the drive
that I want to create.

35
00:01:52,080 --> 00:01:57,304
So I'm going to call this web01 -Disk2.

36
00:01:57,304 --> 00:02:01,690
And I'll make it a VHDX,a
second generation there.

37
00:02:01,690 --> 00:02:05,430
And then the size of that drive I'll
specify with a size bytes command.

38
00:02:08,551 --> 00:02:10,080
And I'll go ahead and create this one.

39
00:02:10,080 --> 00:02:11,720
Since it's a dynamically expanding,

40
00:02:11,720 --> 00:02:14,710
I'm gonna go ahead and
create a 36 gigabyte drive.

41
00:02:14,710 --> 00:02:16,850
So I don't have to wait for
it to be created.

42
00:02:16,850 --> 00:02:17,670
I'll go ahead and hit enter.

43
00:02:19,390 --> 00:02:23,000
And there we see I have a new drive,
web01 -Disc2.

44
00:02:23,000 --> 00:02:27,260
It's 36 gigabytes, but
it's a dynamically expanding drive.

45
00:02:27,260 --> 00:02:30,360
So right now it's taking up
about four megs in space.

46
00:02:30,360 --> 00:02:40,000
In fact, we flip over there,
we're up with that C:\Virtuals\VHD.

47
00:02:40,000 --> 00:02:41,220
And we take a look,

48
00:02:41,220 --> 00:02:44,440
there's the disc I created in
a previous segment Web01 -Disc1.

49
00:02:44,440 --> 00:02:48,450
And there's the one I just created,
Web01 -Disc 2,

50
00:02:48,450 --> 00:02:52,500
both of which are about four megs in size,
because they're dynamically expanding.

51
00:02:52,500 --> 00:02:54,260
There's no data in there yet.

52
00:02:54,260 --> 00:02:56,840
We haven't installed an operating system,
or anything like that.

53
00:02:59,200 --> 00:03:01,100
All right, so
that's our dynamically expanding disk.

54
00:03:01,100 --> 00:03:03,910
The other disk that we can create
would be a fixed size disk.

55
00:03:03,910 --> 00:03:08,810
When we create a fixed size VHD, it's
gonna go ahead and grab all of the space.

56
00:03:08,810 --> 00:03:11,150
So I created a 36 gigabyte drive.

57
00:03:11,150 --> 00:03:16,210
It's gonna go ahead and allocate 36
gigabytes of hard drive space to that VHD.

58
00:03:16,210 --> 00:03:19,260
The command is very similar.

59
00:03:19,260 --> 00:03:20,374
It's new-VHD.

60
00:03:23,200 --> 00:03:28,716
And we're gonna give it a path and
I'll use that same path there.

61
00:03:28,716 --> 00:03:32,590
C:/Virtual/VHD, and
then the name of this disk.

62
00:03:32,590 --> 00:03:35,472
I'm gonna call it,

63
00:03:35,472 --> 00:03:40,391
stick with my naming convention,

64
00:03:40,391 --> 00:03:46,336
we'll call it web01 -Disk3.VHDX.

65
00:03:46,336 --> 00:03:49,316
And then I'm gonna add a parameter,
-fixed.

66
00:03:49,316 --> 00:03:53,287
That's what's gonna change it from
a dynamically expanding drive,

67
00:03:53,287 --> 00:03:54,575
to a fixed size drive.

68
00:03:54,575 --> 00:03:57,215
And then same parameter for the size.

69
00:03:57,215 --> 00:03:58,015
-sizebytes.

70
00:03:59,905 --> 00:04:04,245
And I am going to just create
a three gigabyte drive.

71
00:04:04,245 --> 00:04:06,275
Just so that I don't want to wait for
it to create.

72
00:04:07,425 --> 00:04:08,727
So three gigabytes.

73
00:04:08,727 --> 00:04:09,227
I'll hit enter.

74
00:04:14,624 --> 00:04:18,360
Creates that virtual Hard Drive, notice
it's taking a little longer to create.

75
00:04:18,360 --> 00:04:21,684
It's actually taking longer to
create this 3 gigabyte drive,

76
00:04:21,684 --> 00:04:25,560
than it did to create that 36
gigabyte in the previous command.

77
00:04:25,560 --> 00:04:28,850
Again, because that 36 gigabyte
drive was dynamically expanding.

78
00:04:28,850 --> 00:04:30,560
It starts out at 4 megs,

79
00:04:30,560 --> 00:04:35,540
this one is actually claiming the 3
gigs of space on my physical disc.

80
00:04:35,540 --> 00:04:38,120
So we'll let this finish up, and
then I'll show you guys that drive.

81
00:04:40,900 --> 00:04:44,980
We'll do a little, we'll clear that
screen out and do a directory.

82
00:04:46,190 --> 00:04:50,400
And I can see Disk3 is
indeed 3 gigabytes in size.

83
00:04:50,400 --> 00:04:52,290
Even though there's no data in there.

84
00:04:52,290 --> 00:04:54,460
So that's a fixed drive.

85
00:04:54,460 --> 00:04:56,910
Better performance because I don't
have to worry about it expanding in

86
00:04:56,910 --> 00:04:57,660
the middle of usage.

87
00:04:57,660 --> 00:05:01,030
I don't have to worry about it becoming
fragmented or anything like that.

88
00:05:01,030 --> 00:05:04,325
But I do have to have the space
available when I create the drive.

89
00:05:04,325 --> 00:05:08,430
And it takes a little bit longer
to initially create that drive.

90
00:05:08,430 --> 00:05:12,280
Third type of drive I can create in
Hyper-V with my virtual machines,

91
00:05:12,280 --> 00:05:14,070
is going to be a differencing disk.

92
00:05:14,070 --> 00:05:18,510
Differencing disks are when we want to,
we have a base drive, and

93
00:05:18,510 --> 00:05:20,850
we wanna keep that base
drive the way it is.

94
00:05:20,850 --> 00:05:25,650
And we're gonna make a second drive
that stores all of the changes.

95
00:05:25,650 --> 00:05:26,380
These are, again,

96
00:05:26,380 --> 00:05:29,610
something you're never probably gonna
use in a production environment.

97
00:05:29,610 --> 00:05:32,510
But, in the test environment,
they can be very handy.

98
00:05:32,510 --> 00:05:37,120
I have a base drive for 2012 R2.

99
00:05:37,120 --> 00:05:39,660
And I take that base drive,
I set it aside.

100
00:05:39,660 --> 00:05:42,580
And then when I create
my new virtual machines,

101
00:05:42,580 --> 00:05:47,680
I create differencing drives based off or
linked back to that base drive.

102
00:05:47,680 --> 00:05:50,810
So, I can have several virtual
machines with their own hard drives.

103
00:05:50,810 --> 00:05:52,410
Their own distancing drives.

104
00:05:52,410 --> 00:05:54,950
Pointing back to that one base drive.

105
00:05:54,950 --> 00:05:56,670
So all the files that are in common,

106
00:05:56,670 --> 00:06:00,000
the operating system installation
is on that base drive.

107
00:06:00,000 --> 00:06:01,680
But when I create the differencing drive,

108
00:06:01,680 --> 00:06:04,590
that's the drive that I assign
to the virtual machine itself.

109
00:06:04,590 --> 00:06:08,460
And so when I give that server a name,
add roles to it, and things like that.

110
00:06:08,460 --> 00:06:10,850
Those are stored in that
differencing drive.

111
00:06:10,850 --> 00:06:14,640
So I could have more than one server,
different names, different roles.

112
00:06:14,640 --> 00:06:17,180
All pointed back to that one base drive.

113
00:06:17,180 --> 00:06:19,340
But as you can imagine, if I have four or

114
00:06:19,340 --> 00:06:22,130
five servers,
each with their own differencing drive.

115
00:06:22,130 --> 00:06:25,070
All pointed back to that one base drive.

116
00:06:25,070 --> 00:06:26,850
My performance is gonna degrade, right?

117
00:06:26,850 --> 00:06:30,390
I'm gonna have a lot of contention
trying to read that base drive.

118
00:06:30,390 --> 00:06:33,490
So again, nothing I'm gonna use
in a production environment.

119
00:06:33,490 --> 00:06:36,470
But in a test environment, when I'm
whipping out a little test network and

120
00:06:36,470 --> 00:06:38,590
I need to throw out three or
four servers real quick.

121
00:06:38,590 --> 00:06:41,310
And I don't want to take up
a lot of space or a lot of time.

122
00:06:41,310 --> 00:06:43,210
They work fantastic for that.

123
00:06:43,210 --> 00:06:47,082
The command is gonna be new-VHD again.

124
00:06:47,082 --> 00:06:51,590
So new-VHD, and for this one,
a little bit different.

125
00:06:51,590 --> 00:06:53,820
Because I'm making a differencing drive.

126
00:06:53,820 --> 00:06:55,660
I've got to tell it where
that base drive is.

127
00:06:55,660 --> 00:06:59,770
And in Microsoft lingo, or at least in the
Hyper-V commands, the PowerShell commands

128
00:06:59,770 --> 00:07:02,910
that work with Hyper-V, they're
going to call that the parent drive.

129
00:07:02,910 --> 00:07:05,580
We're going to do a dash parent path and

130
00:07:05,580 --> 00:07:09,610
I'm going to tell it where
that parent drive is.

131
00:07:09,610 --> 00:07:13,190
And just for giggles,
I'm going to use the one we already have.

132
00:07:13,190 --> 00:07:16,320
So I go Virtuals, VHD.

133
00:07:17,850 --> 00:07:19,460
And we'll just use that web01 -Disk1.

134
00:07:19,460 --> 00:07:21,300
Again there's nothing
installed on that drive.

135
00:07:21,300 --> 00:07:24,590
But just to show you this command,
and then the rest of the command.

136
00:07:24,590 --> 00:07:26,970
So that's where the parent
drive is going to be.

137
00:07:26,970 --> 00:07:30,560
And then the actual differencing drive,
my path.

138
00:07:30,560 --> 00:07:31,820
Back to the original command.

139
00:07:31,820 --> 00:07:34,130
Just like when we created a fixed drive,
or

140
00:07:34,130 --> 00:07:36,080
when I created a dynamically
expanding drive.

141
00:07:36,080 --> 00:07:38,820
I have to tell it where I
want to create this drive.

142
00:07:38,820 --> 00:07:41,360
And I'll put it in the same place here.

143
00:07:41,360 --> 00:07:49,400
We'll just go C:\Virtuals\VHDs,
and we'll give it a name.

144
00:07:49,400 --> 00:07:53,232
And I'll call this one maybe web02

145
00:07:53,232 --> 00:07:58,920
-Disk1.vhdx.

146
00:07:58,920 --> 00:08:02,690
And the last thing I've got add
is the perimeter differencing.

147
00:08:04,000 --> 00:08:06,810
Let it know I'm making
a differencing disk.

148
00:08:06,810 --> 00:08:07,310
Hit enter.

149
00:08:08,930 --> 00:08:11,069
Let that thing whirl and
grind for a second.

150
00:08:12,290 --> 00:08:16,730
And then if I do another directory,
I can see I now have this.

151
00:08:16,730 --> 00:08:17,348
Where'd she go?

152
00:08:17,348 --> 00:08:20,310
web02 -Disk1, alright.

153
00:08:20,310 --> 00:08:22,010
It's pointed back to that base drive.

154
00:08:22,010 --> 00:08:24,620
So if I was to create a virtual machine,
and

155
00:08:24,620 --> 00:08:27,980
assign a web02 -Disk 1
to that virtual Machine.

156
00:08:27,980 --> 00:08:30,730
Anything I did to that machine
would be stored in there.

157
00:08:30,730 --> 00:08:35,540
The operating system itself would
still be in that web01 -Disk1.

158
00:08:35,540 --> 00:08:38,070
Not a good example here,
wouldn't work out too well.

159
00:08:38,070 --> 00:08:42,190
But that's the idea behind
these difference in drives.

160
00:08:42,190 --> 00:08:44,240
Not really gonna see those
in a production environment.

161
00:08:44,240 --> 00:08:46,710
Great for test environments though.

162
00:08:46,710 --> 00:08:48,510
All right.

163
00:08:48,510 --> 00:08:50,400
So now I've got a bunch of drives.

164
00:08:50,400 --> 00:08:51,770
I've got a couple of virtual machines.

165
00:08:51,770 --> 00:08:54,680
How do I attach these drives
to those virtual machines?

166
00:08:54,680 --> 00:08:56,480
That's the next thing we're
gonna take a look at.

167
00:08:56,480 --> 00:09:02,380
And the command for
that is just gonna be Add-VMHardDiskDrive.

168
00:09:02,380 --> 00:09:06,324
Let's do an Add- VMHardDiskDrive.

169
00:09:06,324 --> 00:09:10,700
I've got to tell it the name of the
vertical that I'm trying to attach this

170
00:09:10,700 --> 00:09:12,170
hard drive to.

171
00:09:12,170 --> 00:09:16,390
As we'd use the VM name parameter.

172
00:09:16,390 --> 00:09:18,603
And we'll say maybe web01.

173
00:09:18,603 --> 00:09:21,980
And let's attach that second disk.

174
00:09:21,980 --> 00:09:27,080
So, I've got Web 01 for the name of
the virtual machine, and then -path.

175
00:09:27,080 --> 00:09:29,210
And the path to the drive
that I'm trying to add.

176
00:09:29,210 --> 00:09:32,657
So Virtuals\VHD and

177
00:09:32,657 --> 00:09:38,360
then web01 -Disk2.vhdx.

178
00:09:38,360 --> 00:09:43,230
And then if I want to
hit that one more time.

179
00:09:43,230 --> 00:09:49,710
And change that to web01 -Disk3.vhdx.

180
00:09:49,710 --> 00:09:55,420
So, at this point I've added two
more drives to that virtual machine.

181
00:09:55,420 --> 00:09:57,100
Let's see if we can see.

182
00:09:57,100 --> 00:10:00,700
If we do a get -VM web01.

183
00:10:00,700 --> 00:10:05,580
And we pipe that out into a select all.

184
00:10:09,767 --> 00:10:11,870
It's gonna show me here.

185
00:10:11,870 --> 00:10:15,310
Let's see if I can see the actual
drives that are installed.

186
00:10:16,610 --> 00:10:19,220
And it does not show me the actual drives.

187
00:10:19,220 --> 00:10:24,830
I see hard drive on IDE controller 0,
hard drive on a controller 1, and at 1,1.

188
00:10:24,830 --> 00:10:27,611
So it shows me that there
are three drives attached.

189
00:10:27,611 --> 00:10:30,676
I can see 2 of them are attached
to IDE controller 0.

190
00:10:30,676 --> 00:10:33,180
One of them attached to IDE controller 1.

191
00:10:33,180 --> 00:10:37,539
It doesn't really show me the names of
the locations of those hard drives there.

192
00:10:39,050 --> 00:10:42,560
Alright so that is how we're going to
work with our virtual hard drives.

193
00:10:42,560 --> 00:10:46,090
We saw how we could create
a dynamically expanding drive.

194
00:10:46,090 --> 00:10:49,230
We saw how we could create
a fixed data drive.

195
00:10:49,230 --> 00:10:51,665
We also saw how we can
create a differencing drive.

196
00:10:51,665 --> 00:10:55,580
Then once we had those created,
we saw how we could go back and

197
00:10:55,580 --> 00:10:59,000
attach a VHD to an existing
virtual machine.

198
00:11:00,770 --> 00:11:02,190
So I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

199
00:11:02,190 --> 00:11:05,253
Stay tuned more PowerShell
coming up in just a few.

200
00:11:05,253 --> 00:11:07,630
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Configuring Virtual Switches
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,730 --> 00:00:07,963
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,963 --> 00:00:12,603
In this segment we're going to take a look
at how we can use PowerShell to work

3
00:00:12,603 --> 00:00:16,070
with our virtual switches
on a Hyper-V Server.

4
00:00:16,070 --> 00:00:17,830
Let's take a look at what we got here and

5
00:00:17,830 --> 00:00:21,320
when we talk about our virtual switches in
Hyper-V we've really got three different

6
00:00:21,320 --> 00:00:24,160
types of virtual switches
that we can create.

7
00:00:24,160 --> 00:00:27,030
Before, they recently switched
over to virtual switches,

8
00:00:27,030 --> 00:00:29,620
they used to be called virtual networks.

9
00:00:29,620 --> 00:00:32,340
I think by 2008 they started
calling them virtual switches.

10
00:00:32,340 --> 00:00:34,160
But there's really three
different types I can create.

11
00:00:34,160 --> 00:00:37,430
I can create a,
if I can remember their names.

12
00:00:37,430 --> 00:00:40,020
You can create a private virtual switch.

13
00:00:40,020 --> 00:00:42,660
Which is only gonna be used
by the virtual machines,

14
00:00:42,660 --> 00:00:44,850
that are running on that Hyper-V host.

15
00:00:44,850 --> 00:00:47,790
I can create an internal, virtual switch.

16
00:00:47,790 --> 00:00:51,780
Which will be used again by the virtual
machines running on that particular host,

17
00:00:51,780 --> 00:00:53,760
as well as the host itself.

18
00:00:53,760 --> 00:00:56,620
And then you can create an external,
which would give those

19
00:00:56,620 --> 00:01:01,430
virtual machines that are connected to the
external network access to the external

20
00:01:01,430 --> 00:01:05,260
media into our local area network,
the rest of the corporate network,

21
00:01:05,260 --> 00:01:09,290
possibly the Internet depending on how
we then have our network routed out.

22
00:01:09,290 --> 00:01:13,510
So lets take a look at the commands we can
use to configure those virtual switches.

23
00:01:14,820 --> 00:01:18,570
I'm gonna pull up PowerShell,
clear my screen a little bit.

24
00:01:20,370 --> 00:01:23,570
And the first one I'm gonna do, the first
command I wanna run is just to get a list

25
00:01:23,570 --> 00:01:25,990
of what switches I already
have if I have any.

26
00:01:25,990 --> 00:01:31,458
And the command is just
gonna be Get-VMswitch.

27
00:01:31,458 --> 00:01:35,110
And I can see I have one switch currently.

28
00:01:35,110 --> 00:01:39,400
I've got one and it's an internal type,
so that means it's going to be accessible

29
00:01:39,400 --> 00:01:43,370
to the virtual machines as well
as the host operating system, and

30
00:01:43,370 --> 00:01:47,190
I've given it a name of LAN,
pretty straightforward there.

31
00:01:47,190 --> 00:01:51,392
So if we wanna create
a new virtual switch,

32
00:01:51,392 --> 00:01:55,372
the command is gonna be New-VMswitch.

33
00:01:55,372 --> 00:02:00,038
I'm gonna give it a name, if I've got
spaces in the name I am going to need to

34
00:02:00,038 --> 00:02:04,277
limit that if I can say that,
I'll have to puts quotes around that.

35
00:02:04,277 --> 00:02:07,702
For this one I'm just going to call it,
let's see which one I wanna do first,

36
00:02:07,702 --> 00:02:08,978
can we create this private?

37
00:02:08,978 --> 00:02:16,760
I'll call it Private LAN, just so we can
see the difference in our list here.

38
00:02:16,760 --> 00:02:19,280
So I'm gonna give it
a name of Private LAN, and

39
00:02:19,280 --> 00:02:24,240
then the switch type is
really where I'm deciding

40
00:02:24,240 --> 00:02:28,210
whether it's gonna be private,
internal, or external for this one.

41
00:02:28,210 --> 00:02:29,410
I'll do private.

42
00:02:29,410 --> 00:02:34,260
And then I can add notes if I want,
I usually don't, but

43
00:02:34,260 --> 00:02:40,710
just to show you that you can, we can do a
notes parameter maybe something like this

44
00:02:40,710 --> 00:02:45,650
is an isolated network.

45
00:02:47,450 --> 00:02:50,750
Could help other admins that
are working on this Hyper-V Server.

46
00:02:52,160 --> 00:02:52,930
So go ahead and hit Enter.

47
00:02:54,080 --> 00:02:58,620
And that will create a new,
private switch-type named Private LAN.

48
00:02:59,770 --> 00:03:04,840
So if I go back and do another
Get-VMSwitch, I can see I now have two.

49
00:03:04,840 --> 00:03:06,680
One called LAN that's internal.

50
00:03:06,680 --> 00:03:11,730
A second one called Private LAN,
that is of the private switch type.

51
00:03:11,730 --> 00:03:15,550
Now if we want to create
an external virtual switch.

52
00:03:15,550 --> 00:03:19,410
If I want to give these virtual machines
the ability to connect with the rest of my

53
00:03:19,410 --> 00:03:23,550
network beyond the host that they
are running on, so other computers

54
00:03:23,550 --> 00:03:28,770
on the network, or possibly the Internet,
if we've got things routed out properly.

55
00:03:28,770 --> 00:03:32,120
The command for that is gonna be the same,
we're just gonna switch,

56
00:03:32,120 --> 00:03:35,630
for this one though, a little bit
different, because I've got to bind

57
00:03:35,630 --> 00:03:39,990
the virtual switch to a physical
network adapter in that machine, right.

58
00:03:39,990 --> 00:03:43,940
So it can have access to
the actual corporate network.

59
00:03:43,940 --> 00:03:47,440
So for that I need to know what physical

60
00:03:49,200 --> 00:03:54,010
networks adapters I have
in this Hyper-V host.

61
00:03:54,010 --> 00:04:00,995
So the command for
that is going to be Get-NetAdapter.

62
00:04:00,995 --> 00:04:05,330
Get-NetAdapter, and I want to see
what the name of these guys are, so

63
00:04:05,330 --> 00:04:10,300
I'm going to do a -Name and then *, that
should return all of my network adapters

64
00:04:10,300 --> 00:04:13,530
that I have available on this
Hyper-V host, and I'll go ahead and

65
00:04:13,530 --> 00:04:21,325
pipe that out into a format list command
and I can see that I have several.

66
00:04:21,325 --> 00:04:23,480
I've got my vEthernet (LAN).

67
00:04:23,480 --> 00:04:28,190
I've got my physical adapter there,
Ethernet.

68
00:04:28,190 --> 00:04:31,720
Got a couple others in this particular
host that we're not worried about for

69
00:04:31,720 --> 00:04:32,260
this segment.

70
00:04:32,260 --> 00:04:35,060
Student Side, Test 1 and Test 2.

71
00:04:35,060 --> 00:04:38,580
The one I created earlier, though, or

72
00:04:38,580 --> 00:04:43,770
that private network is not in this list.

73
00:04:43,770 --> 00:04:45,950
So, again those are my
physical network adapters.

74
00:04:45,950 --> 00:04:48,560
If I was to go in my network connections

75
00:04:48,560 --> 00:04:51,870
on this particular host that's
what I would see there.

76
00:04:51,870 --> 00:04:55,300
So now that I know I want to create one,
I want to attach to that Ethernet.

77
00:04:55,300 --> 00:04:59,910
All right, so this network adapter
here is really the one I want

78
00:04:59,910 --> 00:05:05,250
to bind this external network adapter to,
or this external virtual switch to.

79
00:05:05,250 --> 00:05:07,712
The command to create
one starts out the same.

80
00:05:07,712 --> 00:05:13,260
New -VMSwitch and

81
00:05:13,260 --> 00:05:19,750
I'm going to give it a name,
let's do a -Name.

82
00:05:19,750 --> 00:05:24,490
And we're gonna call this one External.

83
00:05:25,790 --> 00:05:27,620
Because I'm very creative like that.

84
00:05:27,620 --> 00:05:31,220
We'll call it External and then
the adapter that I want to bind it to.

85
00:05:31,220 --> 00:05:35,360
This is where the command differs a little
bit from creating that private or

86
00:05:35,360 --> 00:05:37,470
that internal virtual switch.

87
00:05:37,470 --> 00:05:40,120
Cuz I'm binding it to
a physical network adapter.

88
00:05:41,790 --> 00:05:44,850
So NetAdapterName is that parameter.

89
00:05:44,850 --> 00:05:52,820
And then in my case it's named ethernet,
and then if we think back to the GUI,

90
00:05:52,820 --> 00:05:57,710
when you're creating a virtual switch
like this I can choose whether or

91
00:05:57,710 --> 00:06:01,360
not I want to allow the management
operating system to have access to that.

92
00:06:01,360 --> 00:06:06,950
So I can throw in a parameter
called AllowManagementOS and

93
00:06:06,950 --> 00:06:09,658
I can set that to $true,

94
00:06:09,658 --> 00:06:13,940
which will be the same as checking that
check mark when I go through the graphical

95
00:06:13,940 --> 00:06:18,730
user interface now this is going to cause
when you create a new external adapter.

96
00:06:18,730 --> 00:06:23,320
When you bind something to a physical
network adapter, in that Hyper-V host,

97
00:06:23,320 --> 00:06:28,630
there is going to be a momentary break in
connectivity with that network adapter.

98
00:06:28,630 --> 00:06:32,170
So typically,
when I'm remoted into a Hyper-V host and

99
00:06:32,170 --> 00:06:35,080
I make one of these,
usually remote desktop doesn't crap out,

100
00:06:35,080 --> 00:06:39,100
it does not break it long enough for
me to loose my remote desktop connection.

101
00:06:39,100 --> 00:06:41,740
We'll keep our fingers crossed here and
see what happens, so I'll hit Enter.

102
00:06:44,837 --> 00:06:48,437
And we should see a little bit
of a glitch there, maybe or

103
00:06:48,437 --> 00:06:51,900
I might drop the connection altogether.

104
00:06:51,900 --> 00:06:52,690
There we go.

105
00:06:52,690 --> 00:06:55,420
So you saw that it did temporarily
drop my connection and

106
00:06:55,420 --> 00:06:58,890
then of course Remote Desktop attempts
to reconnect there in the background.

107
00:06:58,890 --> 00:07:00,470
It reconnected just fine.

108
00:07:00,470 --> 00:07:02,510
And I can see the results of my command.

109
00:07:02,510 --> 00:07:06,090
There's a new network, or
virtual switch, named External.

110
00:07:06,090 --> 00:07:08,610
It is of the external switch type, and

111
00:07:08,610 --> 00:07:13,900
it is bound to my Gigabit Network adapter
that I have in that Hyper-V host.

112
00:07:13,900 --> 00:07:17,322
So if we go back and take a look now
at that initial command that we run,

113
00:07:17,322 --> 00:07:24,350
Get-VMSwitch, we'll see now I have
three different virtual switches.

114
00:07:24,350 --> 00:07:28,510
I got an Internal virtual switch name LAN,
a private virtual switch named

115
00:07:28,510 --> 00:07:34,480
Private LAN, and
an external virtual switch named External.

116
00:07:34,480 --> 00:07:37,490
So in this segment we worked
with our virtual switches.

117
00:07:37,490 --> 00:07:41,660
We saw how we could create the different
types of virtual switches that I'm allowed

118
00:07:41,660 --> 00:07:44,020
to make within my Hyper-V Server.

119
00:07:44,020 --> 00:07:47,030
We created a private virtual switch,

120
00:07:47,030 --> 00:07:51,440
we created an internal virtual switch,
as well as an external virtual switch.

121
00:07:51,440 --> 00:07:55,380
That was bound to a physical network
adapter, in that Hyper-V host and

122
00:07:55,380 --> 00:07:59,570
now I can give my virtual machines access
to the rest of the corporate network.

123
00:08:00,660 --> 00:08:05,369
So, say tuned,
more PowerShell coming your way.

124
00:08:05,369 --> 00:08:10,309
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Configuring VM Snapshots
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,012 --> 00:00:04,593
[SOUND] In this segment, we're gonna

2
00:00:04,593 --> 00:00:09,320
take a look at using PowerShell to work

3
00:00:09,320 --> 00:00:14,207
with our snapshots on a Hyper V server.

4
00:00:14,207 --> 00:00:19,035
So our snapshots, or checkpoints,
depending on which book you're reading and

5
00:00:19,035 --> 00:00:20,885
which version you're using.

6
00:00:20,885 --> 00:00:24,495
We started out calling them checkpoints,
they're now called snapshots.

7
00:00:24,495 --> 00:00:28,240
You'll actually see in our commands,
they still use both terms, but

8
00:00:28,240 --> 00:00:33,210
these snapshots or checkpoints are just
points in time that I can roll back to.

9
00:00:33,210 --> 00:00:37,560
They're really handy if I'm getting ready
to make some major configuration change,

10
00:00:37,560 --> 00:00:41,160
install some application on
the server that I'm testing, and

11
00:00:41,160 --> 00:00:43,980
I want to have a roll back point.

12
00:00:43,980 --> 00:00:48,190
If something goes wrong, I want to
be able to roll that server back in

13
00:00:48,190 --> 00:00:50,380
time to before I started that operation.

14
00:00:50,380 --> 00:00:54,300
Now again, this is another one of those
things that really are not recommended in

15
00:00:54,300 --> 00:00:59,320
a production environment,
except for temporary use.

16
00:00:59,320 --> 00:01:03,570
Once you've created a snapshot or
a checkpoint, you can merge them back in.

17
00:01:03,570 --> 00:01:06,472
They are gonna cause some
performance degradation,

18
00:01:06,472 --> 00:01:09,480
because they're basically
differencing disks.

19
00:01:09,480 --> 00:01:12,900
In a previous segment,
we talked about differencing disks and

20
00:01:12,900 --> 00:01:17,790
how you have a base drive and then a drive
that stores all the changes that are being

21
00:01:17,790 --> 00:01:21,080
made so when don't effect
that underlying base drive.

22
00:01:21,080 --> 00:01:24,720
So when you read from that, when a virtual
machine reading from its hard drive,

23
00:01:24,720 --> 00:01:27,710
it's really reading from
two different VHDs, right?

24
00:01:27,710 --> 00:01:32,890
And the more checkpoints I create,
those are gonna be the ADHD drives, and

25
00:01:32,890 --> 00:01:33,850
it's just gonna cause,

26
00:01:35,110 --> 00:01:37,620
a degradation performance is
just the best way to say it.

27
00:01:37,620 --> 00:01:41,020
So you really want to avoid using
them in a production environment.

28
00:01:41,020 --> 00:01:42,330
If you do have to create one,

29
00:01:42,330 --> 00:01:45,750
they're really good in test environments,
cuz I'll take a server and

30
00:01:45,750 --> 00:01:49,175
I wanna do something to it,
I'll make a quick checkpoint, or snapshot.

31
00:01:49,175 --> 00:01:51,435
I'll do whatever it is
I'm trying to test out.

32
00:01:51,435 --> 00:01:55,095
When I'm done, I just roll it back and
I'm back to a fresh installer server,

33
00:01:55,095 --> 00:01:59,015
if that's I took the checkpoint,
and I can try something else.

34
00:01:59,015 --> 00:02:01,795
In a production environment,
because of the performance degradation,

35
00:02:01,795 --> 00:02:05,705
not really recommended, but if you
are getting ready to do some, like a major

36
00:02:05,705 --> 00:02:09,450
Windows update that you're not sure,
you know, you haven't tested it out.

37
00:02:09,450 --> 00:02:12,670
Shouldn't be testing it in a production
environment in the first place, but

38
00:02:12,670 --> 00:02:16,920
assuming there was some reason you needed
to do something to a production machine,

39
00:02:16,920 --> 00:02:18,900
you could create a checkpoint and

40
00:02:18,900 --> 00:02:23,160
then have the ability to roll back
to that checkpoint if you needed to.

41
00:02:23,160 --> 00:02:26,890
So let's take a look at the commands
that we can use to perform that.

42
00:02:26,890 --> 00:02:33,789
The first thing we're gonna do is,
we're gonna need to create a checkpoint,

43
00:02:33,789 --> 00:02:38,713
and the command for
that is gonna be checkpoint dash VM.

44
00:02:38,713 --> 00:02:42,900
The name of the virtual machine that I
am trying to make this checkpoint on,

45
00:02:42,900 --> 00:02:47,417
we'll do web oh one, and then you can see
right in the middle of the command we're

46
00:02:47,417 --> 00:02:51,624
gonna change our naming convention,
now we're gonna call it a snapshot.

47
00:02:51,624 --> 00:02:52,820
Thank you Microsoft.

48
00:02:52,820 --> 00:02:57,612
So snapshot name, and I'm just gonna

49
00:02:57,612 --> 00:03:02,717
name it something like prior to update.

50
00:03:02,717 --> 00:03:04,200
Hit Enter.

51
00:03:04,200 --> 00:03:08,692
And I don't have a web oh one, really?

52
00:03:08,692 --> 00:03:10,560
Oh, silly me.

53
00:03:10,560 --> 00:03:13,070
That is not the parameter; that
is the name of the computer.

54
00:03:13,070 --> 00:03:15,450
So let's swap that up just a little bit.

55
00:03:15,450 --> 00:03:21,015
Let's do a dash name, and

56
00:03:21,015 --> 00:03:27,740
then the name of the virtual machine, I
wanna make that snapshot on is web oh one.

57
00:03:27,740 --> 00:03:29,110
So, there it creates that checkpoint.

58
00:03:30,580 --> 00:03:32,740
If I wanna see what
checkpoints are available,

59
00:03:32,740 --> 00:03:35,970
I might have made several checkpoints,
hopefully not, but,

60
00:03:35,970 --> 00:03:39,796
we can do a get VM, and now we're gonna
change over and use the word, snapshot.

61
00:03:39,796 --> 00:03:46,630
So, get dash VM snapshot, dash VM name,
and we'll do web oh one again.

62
00:03:49,918 --> 00:03:53,300
And, it will list all of the different
snapshots that I have available.

63
00:03:54,680 --> 00:03:59,330
So, I've made one snapshot for
this guy prior to update, and the date and

64
00:03:59,330 --> 00:04:01,330
time that that snapshot was created.

65
00:04:02,380 --> 00:04:04,700
Let's make another one just for
giggles real quick.

66
00:04:04,700 --> 00:04:10,650
We'll call this one, I don't know,
how about something like after update.

67
00:04:10,650 --> 00:04:13,513
Wouldn't make a whole lot of sense,
but just for example for our lab here,

68
00:04:13,513 --> 00:04:14,797
I'll create a second snapshot.

69
00:04:14,797 --> 00:04:19,707
And now we'll have something
a little more exciting to

70
00:04:19,707 --> 00:04:24,840
look at when I do that get snapshot,
our get VM snapshot.

71
00:04:24,840 --> 00:04:28,710
Now you can see I have two
separate snapshots created,

72
00:04:28,710 --> 00:04:31,620
one prior to update, one after update.

73
00:04:34,620 --> 00:04:37,820
So that's how I can create
a snapshot in the first place,

74
00:04:37,820 --> 00:04:40,670
and get a list of available snapshots.

75
00:04:40,670 --> 00:04:44,030
The last thing I want to show you for
the snapshots is how do I use them?

76
00:04:44,030 --> 00:04:46,840
What if that update did cause a problem,
and

77
00:04:46,840 --> 00:04:51,650
I want to roll back to that point in
time before I applied that update?

78
00:04:51,650 --> 00:04:58,660
Well, the command is simply
restore dash VM snapshot,

79
00:04:58,660 --> 00:05:03,500
and then the name of the snapshot
that I want to really, and

80
00:05:03,500 --> 00:05:07,090
these parameters can go in either order,
I prefer to name this VM first.

81
00:05:07,090 --> 00:05:11,000
So let's do VM name, and
that's gonna be web oh one.

82
00:05:12,670 --> 00:05:19,078
And then the name of the snapshot,
and that's gonna be prior to update.

83
00:05:26,636 --> 00:05:28,930
And it will ask me if I wanna do this.

84
00:05:28,930 --> 00:05:35,050
I'll say yes, Y for yes, and
it's gonna apply the checkpoint.

85
00:05:35,050 --> 00:05:38,800
Notice that I needed the name of that
snapshot in order to apply it, which is

86
00:05:38,800 --> 00:05:44,410
why that get dash VM snapshot command is
very handy, cuz it lists those snapshots.

87
00:05:44,410 --> 00:05:48,411
You can also see this
Parent Snapshot Name in that command,

88
00:05:48,411 --> 00:05:52,652
the after update is like a chain,
or a hierarchy, if you will,

89
00:05:52,652 --> 00:05:57,853
I've got that base drive, and then I've
got that prior to update snapshot,

90
00:05:57,853 --> 00:06:01,076
and then I've got that
after update snapshot.

91
00:06:01,076 --> 00:06:05,570
So all three of those are really
required to run that virtual machine.

92
00:06:05,570 --> 00:06:11,600
Now I've rolled back to that
prior to update snapshot.

93
00:06:11,600 --> 00:06:15,552
All right, so there we saw how we can
work with snapshots through PowerShell.

94
00:06:15,552 --> 00:06:20,898
All right, we were able to create
a snapshot, get a list of the available

95
00:06:20,898 --> 00:06:25,510
snapshots, and roll back to
a previously created snapshot.

96
00:06:25,510 --> 00:06:28,150
So I hope you guys enjoyed this segment.

97
00:06:28,150 --> 00:06:29,070
Stay tuned.

98
00:06:29,070 --> 00:06:33,050
More PowerShell coming your way.

99
00:06:33,050 --> 00:06:37,569
[SOUND]

episodes.title: Import Export VMs
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:05,022
[SOUND] All right,
in this segment we're gonna

2
00:00:05,022 --> 00:00:09,786
take a look at using
PowerShell to import and

3
00:00:09,786 --> 00:00:15,214
export virtual machines
from a Hyper-V server.

4
00:00:15,214 --> 00:00:19,327
During the management of our Hyper-V
servers we're gonna occasionally need to

5
00:00:19,327 --> 00:00:21,420
export those virtual machines.

6
00:00:21,420 --> 00:00:26,170
Could be to create a backup of a virtual
machine or it could be to move a virtual

7
00:00:26,170 --> 00:00:29,740
machine from one Hyper-V server that
maybe we're decommissioning and

8
00:00:29,740 --> 00:00:32,140
move it from that server to a new server.

9
00:00:32,140 --> 00:00:35,242
So we need to be able to export these
virtual machines and then turn around and

10
00:00:35,242 --> 00:00:36,420
import them.

11
00:00:36,420 --> 00:00:40,970
If we had a problem with one we can
import that machine that we had exported.

12
00:00:40,970 --> 00:00:43,710
Or, if we are, again,
bringing up a new Hyper-V host,

13
00:00:43,710 --> 00:00:46,860
we could import those new virtual
machines onto that new Hyper-V host.

14
00:00:46,860 --> 00:00:49,550
So let's dive into PowerShell and
see how we can accomplish this.

15
00:00:50,660 --> 00:00:54,160
First thing we'll need to do, is we need
to export an existing virtual machine.

16
00:00:54,160 --> 00:00:56,657
And the command is simply export-vm.

17
00:00:56,657 --> 00:00:57,350
All right?

18
00:00:57,350 --> 00:01:02,057
Now we could do it where I
don't use any parameters.

19
00:01:02,057 --> 00:01:02,680
Right?

20
00:01:02,680 --> 00:01:07,090
Most of our PowerShell commands, we've
got a lot of parameters that we can use,

21
00:01:07,090 --> 00:01:09,700
most of them are optional,
some of them required.

22
00:01:09,700 --> 00:01:13,690
This particular command, the only thing
I have to give it is a destination.

23
00:01:13,690 --> 00:01:16,510
If I don't specify a name of
an individual virtual machine,

24
00:01:16,510 --> 00:01:19,830
what it's gonna do is it's gonna
export all of the virtual machines.

25
00:01:19,830 --> 00:01:25,680
So in this case export-vm and
then D:\ would end up dumping out all

26
00:01:25,680 --> 00:01:29,670
the virtual machines that existed on this
Hyper-V host to the root of the D drive.

27
00:01:29,670 --> 00:01:31,840
And I would create a subfolder for

28
00:01:31,840 --> 00:01:34,940
each one of those virtual
machines that it was exporting.

29
00:01:34,940 --> 00:01:37,810
In this case I just want to export
a particular virtual machine.

30
00:01:37,810 --> 00:01:42,100
So I am going to specify the name of
the machine that I'm trying to export.

31
00:01:42,100 --> 00:01:43,090
That's gonna be web01.

32
00:01:43,090 --> 00:01:47,470
And then the path is
a little -path parameter.

33
00:01:47,470 --> 00:01:51,033
And where I want to export
this virtual machine to.

34
00:01:51,033 --> 00:01:55,973
So export-vm, -name, web01, -path, and

35
00:01:55,973 --> 00:02:01,030
then the path or c:\Exported, in my case.

36
00:02:01,030 --> 00:02:02,920
I'm gonna hit Enter, and

37
00:02:02,920 --> 00:02:05,980
it should begin the process of
exporting that virtual machine.

38
00:02:05,980 --> 00:02:08,320
Now while it's going through here,
one of the things I could have done,

39
00:02:08,320 --> 00:02:10,360
this process could take a little while.

40
00:02:10,360 --> 00:02:14,070
This particular machine,
we just built it in a previous segment, so

41
00:02:14,070 --> 00:02:16,500
there's really no data on the hard drives.

42
00:02:16,500 --> 00:02:17,890
Shouldn't take it very long.

43
00:02:17,890 --> 00:02:20,580
But in the real world,
if you had a lot of drives attached, or

44
00:02:20,580 --> 00:02:24,340
if those drives were larger,
this process could take a little while, so

45
00:02:24,340 --> 00:02:28,075
there is a parameter we can use -asjob.

46
00:02:28,075 --> 00:02:33,230
If I add a -asjob to this,
it would run as a background process, and

47
00:02:33,230 --> 00:02:37,850
I would be able to continue to work
while this job was in progress.

48
00:02:37,850 --> 00:02:38,850
So we'll let this run for a minute.

49
00:02:38,850 --> 00:02:42,980
We'll let this machine get exported, and
then once it that has finished exporting,

50
00:02:42,980 --> 00:02:45,442
we'll go take a look at
the folder that it created.

51
00:02:45,442 --> 00:02:48,510
It's gonna export everything needed
to run that virtual machine.

52
00:02:48,510 --> 00:02:52,350
That means the virtual machine
configuration files themselves, the VHDs,

53
00:02:52,350 --> 00:02:56,740
the hard drives associated with it,
if there's more then one hard drive,

54
00:02:56,740 --> 00:02:58,990
it'll include all of those hard drives.

55
00:02:58,990 --> 00:03:02,620
It would also include any
checkpoints that we created.

56
00:03:02,620 --> 00:03:04,350
Those would be exported along as well.

57
00:03:06,270 --> 00:03:10,360
So it exports everything I need
to use that virtual machine.

58
00:03:10,360 --> 00:03:13,870
Now one of the things that's new with
2012 with this import and export process,

59
00:03:14,960 --> 00:03:19,640
prior to 2012,
if you could not import a virtual machine,

60
00:03:19,640 --> 00:03:24,580
if it had not been exported through
Hyper-V in the first place,

61
00:03:24,580 --> 00:03:28,610
now it allows you to take any machine
whether it's been exported first, or

62
00:03:28,610 --> 00:03:30,795
not and import that virtual machine.

63
00:03:30,795 --> 00:03:32,015
And there we go.

64
00:03:32,015 --> 00:03:33,730
It looks like my job is finished.

65
00:03:33,730 --> 00:03:40,050
So if I take a look in file explorer,
I can see now in my C:\Exported directory,

66
00:03:40,050 --> 00:03:44,270
I have a folder called web01, and
in there I've got my virtual machines.

67
00:03:44,270 --> 00:03:47,860
There's the actual virtual
machine configuration file.

68
00:03:47,860 --> 00:03:50,290
I've got my virtual hard drives
that are associated with that.

69
00:03:50,290 --> 00:03:53,710
Notice I've got three different
drives attached to that VM.

70
00:03:53,710 --> 00:03:58,010
It exported all three of those drives as
well as a couple of differencing disks

71
00:03:58,010 --> 00:03:58,680
that had been made.

72
00:03:58,680 --> 00:04:01,920
So a couple of snapshots that
I made on a previous segment,

73
00:04:01,920 --> 00:04:03,870
it exported those as well.

74
00:04:03,870 --> 00:04:07,370
And then, the actual snapshot files.

75
00:04:07,370 --> 00:04:11,680
We had the configuration files for those
snapshots, the time stamp information,

76
00:04:11,680 --> 00:04:13,300
information about the snapshot itself.

77
00:04:13,300 --> 00:04:16,340
So you've got the config file for
the snapshot and

78
00:04:16,340 --> 00:04:19,690
then you have the actual differencing
disks over here, the AVHDX files.

79
00:04:19,690 --> 00:04:20,230
Right?

80
00:04:20,230 --> 00:04:27,020
So that's exporting a virtual machine
using PowerShell, pretty straightforward.

81
00:04:27,020 --> 00:04:29,590
Once I've got those exported,
at some point,

82
00:04:29,590 --> 00:04:33,800
I'm gonna wanna be able to import those
virtual machines back into Hyper-V,

83
00:04:33,800 --> 00:04:38,630
whether that's the same Hyper-V server or
a different HyperV server.

84
00:04:38,630 --> 00:04:43,270
So the command is simply
going to be import-vm.

85
00:04:43,270 --> 00:04:48,290
As always, there are several
parameters that we can use,

86
00:04:48,290 --> 00:04:54,330
especially with this import command, and
I'll talk about a couple of them here.

87
00:04:54,330 --> 00:04:57,201
Primarily the one command that
I really need is the -path.

88
00:04:57,201 --> 00:04:58,830
Right?
I have to tell it

89
00:04:58,830 --> 00:05:01,770
where the virtual machine is
that I'm trying to import.

90
00:05:01,770 --> 00:05:05,360
There are some other parameters
that I could throw in there.

91
00:05:05,360 --> 00:05:06,710
You can throw in a computer name,

92
00:05:06,710 --> 00:05:12,073
maybe you're importing this
into a different Hyper-V host.

93
00:05:12,073 --> 00:05:14,435
The exported files are on this server, but

94
00:05:14,435 --> 00:05:17,320
I wanna import them into
a different server on my network.

95
00:05:17,320 --> 00:05:20,400
I can actually do a dash computer
name to have that happen.

96
00:05:20,400 --> 00:05:23,920
You can choose whether or
not you want to move the files.

97
00:05:23,920 --> 00:05:27,090
Right now, once I exported it,
the files, the hard drives,

98
00:05:27,090 --> 00:05:31,670
the configuration files, all those
are located in that C:\Exported folder.

99
00:05:31,670 --> 00:05:35,960
I can allow it to register
that virtual machine in place.

100
00:05:35,960 --> 00:05:38,691
In other words,
not move the files themselves.

101
00:05:38,691 --> 00:05:41,144
Typically, that's not what I want to do.

102
00:05:41,144 --> 00:05:42,690
Right?
Because I exported it to that exported

103
00:05:42,690 --> 00:05:46,590
folder, I want to get it out of there and
put it back in the default location.

104
00:05:46,590 --> 00:05:51,560
If I don't provide any information,
the default is to move those files, or

105
00:05:51,560 --> 00:05:56,520
copy I should say, those files back to
the default location for your Hyper-V.

106
00:05:56,520 --> 00:05:59,740
So if you took a look at your Hyper-V
settings, you can specify the default

107
00:05:59,740 --> 00:06:03,902
location for the virtual machine
config files as well as the VHDs, and

108
00:06:03,902 --> 00:06:08,630
it's gonna use that information when
it imports that virtual machine.

109
00:06:08,630 --> 00:06:11,340
Or I could specify a different location.

110
00:06:11,340 --> 00:06:14,062
I can actually tell it, hey, I wanna
import it, but I wanna store it here.

111
00:06:14,062 --> 00:06:15,260
All right?

112
00:06:15,260 --> 00:06:19,560
So I can leave it where it is, I can
copy it back to the default location, or

113
00:06:19,560 --> 00:06:23,000
I can choose a different
location when I import it.

114
00:06:23,000 --> 00:06:27,980
I also have to worry about the ID that's
associated with that virtual machine.

115
00:06:27,980 --> 00:06:31,600
By default if I don't specify it's
going to leave the machine ID.

116
00:06:31,600 --> 00:06:35,590
So it's going to be the same machine
that it was when I exported it.

117
00:06:35,590 --> 00:06:40,195
I can actually generate a new
ID during the import process so

118
00:06:40,195 --> 00:06:42,900
Hyper-V will see it as
a different virtual machine.

119
00:06:42,900 --> 00:06:45,032
In other words I could import
it more than once, and

120
00:06:45,032 --> 00:06:48,030
I could give it a different ID each time.

121
00:06:48,030 --> 00:06:50,100
Now, that doesn't handle
the Windows side of things.

122
00:06:50,100 --> 00:06:53,650
Windows is not gonna be happy that you've
got two machines with the same name and

123
00:06:53,650 --> 00:06:54,930
the same configuration and all that.

124
00:06:54,930 --> 00:06:58,040
You still have to deal with that,
but as far as Hyper-V's concerned,

125
00:06:58,040 --> 00:07:00,777
I could import that a second
time with a different ID.

126
00:07:00,777 --> 00:07:02,240
All right?

127
00:07:02,240 --> 00:07:03,530
So let's see how that process works.

128
00:07:03,530 --> 00:07:09,570
So I'm gonna do an import-vm, and
then I've got my path parameter.

129
00:07:09,570 --> 00:07:15,560
I've gotta tell it where that machine is
located, so I'm gonna do a C:\ Exported.

130
00:07:15,560 --> 00:07:18,070
And then in there,
I've got a couple of machines.

131
00:07:18,070 --> 00:07:20,790
I'm gonna try to bring
in this ITProTV-DC2.

132
00:07:20,790 --> 00:07:24,250
This is one that I exported previously.

133
00:07:24,250 --> 00:07:27,230
So I found the folder for
that in the exported.

134
00:07:27,230 --> 00:07:28,650
Inside there, there's a code.

135
00:07:28,650 --> 00:07:31,085
You've got to tell it
where the config file is.

136
00:07:31,085 --> 00:07:31,930
Right?

137
00:07:31,930 --> 00:07:32,940
We saw just a minute ago,

138
00:07:32,940 --> 00:07:35,920
when I exported that virtual machine
it created several subfolders,

139
00:07:35,920 --> 00:07:40,920
one of the VM config files, one for
the VHD files, one for the snapshots.

140
00:07:40,920 --> 00:07:44,080
When you import this, you actually
have to point it to the XML file,

141
00:07:44,080 --> 00:07:46,530
or the VM config file.

142
00:07:46,530 --> 00:07:50,710
So that is gonna be inside that
virtual machines folder, and

143
00:07:50,710 --> 00:07:51,990
there's the name of that file.

144
00:07:51,990 --> 00:07:55,510
It's a big long GUID that's
assigned to that virtual machine.

145
00:07:55,510 --> 00:08:02,620
So I've done my import virtual machine or
Import-VM-Path, and I'm gonna say -copy.

146
00:08:02,620 --> 00:08:07,360
So that's gonna leave the exported machine
where it is, but it's gonna copy these

147
00:08:07,360 --> 00:08:11,962
files back into the default location for
my particular Hyper-V server.

148
00:08:11,962 --> 00:08:13,310
All right?

149
00:08:13,310 --> 00:08:14,510
So I should be able to hit Enter.

150
00:08:16,170 --> 00:08:18,160
And, we will see what happens.

151
00:08:19,480 --> 00:08:23,580
So right now, it's examining the files,
making sure that all the files necessary

152
00:08:23,580 --> 00:08:28,270
to bring that virtual machine
are in place, or that are readable.

153
00:08:28,270 --> 00:08:31,540
Making sure that here's one
that can really throw you for

154
00:08:31,540 --> 00:08:33,850
a loop, the network adaptors.

155
00:08:33,850 --> 00:08:35,180
A couple of things you can do.

156
00:08:35,180 --> 00:08:37,850
If I try to import a virtual machine and

157
00:08:37,850 --> 00:08:42,525
the network adaptor that it was attached
to when I exported it is not available.

158
00:08:42,525 --> 00:08:47,835
Let's say I'm moving this from
VM host 01 to VM host 02, and

159
00:08:47,835 --> 00:08:55,550
on VM host 01 I had a virtual switch
named private LAN or something like that.

160
00:08:55,550 --> 00:08:59,060
Well if I go to import that
machine on VM host O2 and

161
00:08:59,060 --> 00:09:03,310
there is no virtual switch called
private LAN, it's gonna throw an error.

162
00:09:03,310 --> 00:09:06,650
It's not gonna let me continue cuz it's
not gonna be able to import the machine

163
00:09:06,650 --> 00:09:07,950
and configure it properly.

164
00:09:09,280 --> 00:09:13,380
Something that is very easy to run
into especially if you had to rebuild

165
00:09:13,380 --> 00:09:16,550
the server and maybe you didn't recreate
all the virtual switches first.

166
00:09:16,550 --> 00:09:19,970
So a couple of things you can do,
first is recreate the switches.

167
00:09:19,970 --> 00:09:22,060
Right?
If you've documented what virtual switches

168
00:09:22,060 --> 00:09:24,650
you had before you did
the export process and

169
00:09:24,650 --> 00:09:27,660
you know which ones it was attached to,
then recreate them.

170
00:09:27,660 --> 00:09:28,616
Give them the same name.

171
00:09:28,616 --> 00:09:33,750
They don't even really have to be the same
type, internal, external or private.

172
00:09:33,750 --> 00:09:34,670
It's not looking at that.

173
00:09:34,670 --> 00:09:35,890
It's actually looking at the name, and

174
00:09:35,890 --> 00:09:39,210
as long as it sees that name,
it's gonna be fine.

175
00:09:39,210 --> 00:09:43,532
So recreate your virtual switches
before you do your import process, or,

176
00:09:43,532 --> 00:09:47,585
disconnect the machine from
the networks before you export.

177
00:09:47,585 --> 00:09:49,760
Right?
Go into the settings or

178
00:09:49,760 --> 00:09:54,120
use PowerShell to detach that
network adapter, and then export it.

179
00:09:54,120 --> 00:09:56,020
And then when you import it,
it's not looking for
